HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

RESEARCHERS DISCOUNT A WELFARE EXODUS
When Mayor Giuliani predicted that many poor New Yorkers would move out of state as a "natural consequence" of the welfare cuts he is championing, there were cries of outrage from advocates for the poor. But perhaps more telling, demographers, economists and poverty experts who have researched the migratory patterns of welfare recipients say the Mayor is simply mistaken. National studies by independent researchers have consistently found that differing levels of welfare benefits are seldom the primary motivation behind a move. A1.
Finally it is out in the open, the assumption behind New York's new, get-tough welfare policies: they might tempt the poor to leave town. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick, B4.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
A NEW SHIELD FOR A NEW ERA
Just before midnight yesterday, housing police officers in the Melrose section of the Bronx fastened a plastic plate high on the wall behind the station desk bearing the shield of the New York City Police Department. For the officers there, the act symbolized a merger that would forever change the structure of law enforcement in New York City. B3.
 
MOURNING A BUSINESSMAN AND FRIEND
Yesterday, five days after Thomas Cuevas, 55, was killed in what was apparently a robbery, old friends and people who had never met exchanged similar stories about him at Park Abbey Funeral Chapel in the Bronx. Hundreds of people, from gang members to legislators, filed past the body of Mr. Cuevas and paid their respects to his daughter and son. B3.
 
REBUILDING, AGAIN, AFTER AN ARSON FIRE
When an arson fire tore through the 90-year-old synagogue of Congregation Derech Emunoh in the Rockaways last July 12, Stuart Nadel responded with tools and paint brushes and an ardor for saving it from the ravages of urban decay. After a suspected arson fire early yesterday ripped a gaping new hole in the synagogue's roof, Mr. Nadel, now head of the congregation's restoration effort, said he had no choice but to keep rebuilding. B3.
 
ACTOR HAS A HEART ATTACK ON STAGE
Audience members at the final preview performance of "On the Waterfront" at the Brooks Atkinson Theater said they thought at first that it was part of the plot: an actor fell forward onto the stage during a tense scene several seconds before the curtain closing the first act. But as the dialogue stopped and the performers on stage crouched around the fallen actor, Jerry Grayson, it became apparent that something was wrong. B3.
 
REGION
 
WELFARE LIMITS SET IN HARTFORD
Averting a contentious battle over changes in the state's welfare system, Democratic and Republican lawmakers in Hartford have agreed on a plan that would establish the nation's strictest time limit on how long people can remain on the welfare rolls. The plan would also make Connecticut the second state in the nation with a two-tiered welfare system. B4.
 
SEX OFFENDERS BARRED FROM PROGRAM
Signaling his support for harsher measures against sex crimes, Governor Pataki has signed an executive order prohibiting sex offenders from participating in a new program for nonviolent felons. The order means that people convicted of nonviolent sexual offenses cannot be assigned by judges to a highly intensive probation program. B4.
 
HOSPITAL FACES RETURN OF DEFICITS
Long Island's only public hospital, the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, could lose $25 million a year in state aid under Governor Pataki's proposed budget, putting new pressure on the county to sell or lease the hospital, county officials say. The loss in aid would result from the Governor's plan to cut Medicaid costs by $1.2 billion. B5.
 
A.C.L.U. DISCIPLINES A RENEGADE MEMBER
In a rare move to discipline one of its own adherents, the American Civil Liberties Union voted to suspend a renegade member of its New Jersey chapter for five years for stuffing the ballot box in a 1994 election. The member, Dr. Alan Bell, has contended that the A.C.L.U., which dedicates itself to protecting individual rights, is trying to silence him because of his dissidence. B2.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Movies Finally Look on the Dark Side of War

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, April 30

 BODY:
In a new film released in Vietnam last week, the hero, a veteran named Hung, is a crazed tramp who lives on the streets and has hallucinations that the people around him are enemy soldiers. He "fires" a bamboo pipe he mistakes for a machine gun and frightens villagers, who want him locked away in an insane asylum.
A John Wayne war epic this is not. 
 It is an odd, and remarkable, story for a film released as this country celebrates the 20th anniversary of the Communist victory in the Vietnam War.
"Of course, we could not make a film like this before," said the film's producer, Nguyen Dat Hai. He fought with the Vietcong, even though his three brothers were officers in the South Vietnamese Army and fled to the United States after 1975.
"But now we have more freedom," Mr. Hai said. "We wanted to tell the true story of the war. Even now, the veterans still suffer from a sickness of the mind. To treat this sickness there is no medicine. Only the hearts of the people can help them."
The Vietnam War inspired a number of popular films in the United States, some of which helped to focus attention on neglected war veterans.
In Vietnam, the war has been fodder for dozens of films since 1975, all dealing with the heroic aspects. Film makers dared not explore the darker side: the impact on the soldiers and their families.
With the release of Mr. Hai's "You'll Come Back" and three other recent films, that threshold has been crossed.
In "People Looking for the Past," a Communist soldier is despondent and incapable of getting on with his life after the war. He takes a journey back to a Mekong Delta battleground and along the way encounters an old girlfriend, a nemesis and ghosts of fallen soldiers.
Two other films also explore the troubled lives of war veterans.
"The films do not criticize Vietnam or the U.S.," said Nguyen The Dung, the director of "People Looking at the Past." Criticizing the Government is still not allowed, film makers say, and criticizing the United States is seen as pointless.
"We want to talk about the life of the soldier who suffers," Mr. Dung said.
The shift in direction of the war genre here reflects two changes in society: a relative openness that allows some debate over Vietnam's recent history, and the introduction of market economics.
Even though film companies are Government-owned, they are having to become self-sufficient. But all films must still be approved by censors; the title of "People Looking at the Past," for instance, was changed from "Beggars Searching for the Past" because the word "beggars" was seen as condescending.
"People are bored with the war," said Nguyen Quang Song, a novelist and screenwriter whose war film "The Wild Fields" was screened in the United States in 1988.
Indeed, an informal survey of moviegoers and customers at video shops found little interest in war movies. "We like love stories and action movies," a young Vietnamese man said. The only war movies some customers at a video shop seemed to like were American.
"We love 'Rambo,' " one man said, "even though we are not supposed to see it."
Mr. Song said: "Films about the battlefield are not popular. They do not make any money. Since the Government does not fund films anymore, we have to make films that people will see."
A film critic, Le Thu An, said people wanted to see war movies only if they dealt with the influences of the war on their lives today. "They do not want to see any more films about the battlefield," she said. "That is irrelevant. They want detail about how people go on with their lives."
Although she thinks the new direction of Vietnamese war films is a positive development, she is nonetheless critical. In "You'll Come Back," she said, "they make it so people watching the movie are afraid of the veteran, not sympathetic toward him."
Indeed, the veteran, Hung, is a pathetic character. But perhaps even more revealing are the heartless attitudes of some of the villagers and authorities.
When he is finally reunited with his family, who thought him long dead, stubborn local authorities refuse to grant him veteran's benefits. A local official snaps: "You are not the only family with a war invalid. How can we solve everything right away?"
And after the old soldier suffers a flashback and goes on a rampage, a neighbor tells the family it is unfair for them to keep this "lunatic" in the village.
The film is a true story, said Mr. Hai, the producer.
"There are many veterans like this," he said. "Many of them are badly treated. The Government cannot take care of all of them. But we make this film so people will understand their situation."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Radical of '69 Donates Prize For Racial Accord at Cornell

 BODY:
In April 1969, a Cornell student, Thomas W. Jones, led more than 100 other black students in an armed takeover of the university's main student union. The explosive incident eventually forced the university president, James A. Perkins, to step down.
Now, 26 years later, Mr. Jones has surprised the campus of Cornell, in Ithaca, N.Y., by endowing an annual prize: the James A. Perkins Prize for Interracial Understanding and Harmony. 
 The first award of $5,000 is to be given on Thursday. The prize honors the Cornell student, faculty or staff member or program that contributed the most in the previous year to fostering racial understanding at the institution, which is still grappling with issues of race. Last month, the state began an investigation into allegations that some student housing at Cornell is illegally segregated along ethnic lines.
Mr. Jones himself has long reconciled with Cornell itself. By 1993, he had risen to become president of TIAA-CREF, the world's largest private pension fund, and that year, Cornell named him to its board of trustees. In announcing the prize earlier this year, Mr. Jones said it was a final reconciliation.
"President Perkins has contributed greatly to racial progress at Cornell," he said, "and is most worthy of recognition in praise. And, I want to atone, to the extent that I can, for the hurt and anguish he suffered personally as a result of the racial tensions which boiled over in April 1969."
Mr. Jones cited Mr. Perkins's "historic decision to increase very significantly the enrollment of African-American and other minority students at Cornell," saying the former university president "made a courageous and wise decision and deserves recognition and appreciation for his courage and wisdom."
Mr. Perkins, now an environmental policy consultant in Princeton, N.J., declined to be interviewed, saying, "This is going to be closing a chapter for me."
The students' armed occupation of Cornell's Willard Straight Hall lasted 34 hours, ending when the administration agreed to ask the faculty to rescind sanctions imposed against three students involved in an earlier demonstration over race relations.
But the faculty defied the administration's request, prompting 6,000 students to rally in the campus gymnasium. As 100 sheriff's deputies gathered downtown, the talk in the gymnasium mirrored the tension.
"In the past it has been the black people who have done all the dying," declared Mr. Jones, then a 19-year-old senior. "Now the time has come when the pigs are going to die, too. We are moving tonight. Cornell has until 9 to live. It is now three minutes past 8."
The faculty eventually rescinded the reprimands, but Mr. Perkins was replaced as president. Dale R. Corson, who succeeded Mr. Perkins as president in the summer of 1969, said: "Tom Jones left a legacy that wasn't the happiest in the world. I'm pleased to see this honor and the effort on Tom Jones's part to do something important for the community."
But Edward Whitfield, who helped Mr. Jones lead the demonstrations, said it was a mistake to name an award for Mr. Perkins. Reached in Greensboro, N.C., where he is now the chairman of a nonprofit economic development organization aimed at assisting minorities, he said: "I don't understand anything about his activity in the field or racial harmony that would make us want to name a serious award for him."

HEADLINE: Fire Ruins Synagogue Again, But Not Faith of Its Members

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC 

 BODY:
When an arson fire tore through the 90-year-old synagogue of Congregation Derech Emunoh in the Rockaways last July 12, Stuart Nadel responded with tools and paintbrushes and an ardor for saving it from the ravages of urban decay.
After a suspected arson fire early yesterday ripped a gaping new hole in the synagogue's roof, Mr. Nadel, now head of the congregation's restoration effort, said he has no choice but to keep rebuilding. 
 More than 100 firefighters battled the flames in the synagogue for about an hour before bringing the blaze under control at about 2:30 A.M., a fire department spokesman, Firefighter Elbert Washington, said. At one point, firefighters were ordered out of the building because their commander thought the two-story structure might crash.
"The preliminary report is that the fire was set," Firefighter Washington said, although investigators had not yet determined exactly what flammable material was used. The blaze started on a low ledge overlooking a lonely, litter-strewn lot stretching a quarter-mile to the ocean.
The police department labeled the fire a possible bias crime.
"You can listen to people and they'll tell you that," said the synagogue's President, Howard Finkelstein. "But it is not the case. If it were a bias case, they would have destroyed it. They would have ripped up the books. They would have turned over the pews."
Mr. Nadel agreed, saying that the fire was probably set by drug addicts who burglarized the temple in February, stealing electric appliances, radiators and other readily salable items, and who have repeatedly tried to break into the building since.
"Somebody has been trying to break into the back of the building since February," Mr. Finkelstein said. "They are trying to plunder the stuff from inside -- the decorations and the copper."
Mr. Nadel gazed at the twisted and blackened pieces of decorative copper cornice and a copper spire that had tumbled from the building into a yard. "There are thousands of dollars worth of copper here," he said.
The synagogue, at Beach 67th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard in the Arverne section of Queens, was once the spiritual home of 2,000 worshipers. It was purchased by the city in 1978 as part of an urban-renewal project that left the neo-Georgian-style building stranded in a large grassy field that was once a warren of beach bungalows, Mr. Finkelstein said.
The congregation has leased the building from the city since and carries no insurance. He said the congregation normally uses the 600-seat structure only for Friday and Saturday prayers and for Hebrew classes and Sunday services. City workers finished repairing the fire-damaged tin ceiling of the sanctuary only three weeks ago, Mr. Nadel said.
No one was ever charged in connection with last summer's fire, and the police said they had no witnesses to yesterday's blaze. But the fire had a renewing effect on the synagogue's membership.
"After the first fire, the congregation expanded from 35 to over 200 dues-paying members," Mr. Nadel said. "The temple was dying. Now it has a growing congregation."
Indeed, Mr. Nadel said it was the synagogue's plight that prompted him to join the congregation. "I was driving by with my wife and saw the damage from the first fire," he said. "I painted and did a lot of restoration."
"Now we must simply go on."

HEADLINE: How to Succeed in the Odd Hours;
A Business Market Grows Among the Time-Deprived

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The fiercer pace of work in the 1990's, especially the longer hours for many, has been bemoaned as a grim dividend of the late-20th-century economy. It is Matthew Ryffel's bread and butter.
Mr. Ryffel, 30, an engineer who started his own one-man company this year, is an on-call computer repairman, available 24 hours a day to serve time-stressed work-at-home telecommuters, after-hours executives and anyone else who has transcended the boundaries of 9-to-5. He has fixed authors' hard-drives in the middle of the night, and reprieved lawyers caught on Saturday with their word processors down. 
 "Nobody works stranger hours than me," Mr. Ryffel, of Wyckoff, N.J., said. "I sleep with a beeper under my pillow."
His company is one of a new crop of businesses in the New York area founded to serve a growing market: the time deprived. Although round-the-clock food service and entertainment are nothing new in the region, newer companies specialize in providing the utterly mundane at times and places of convenience.
From corporate office parks where workers can get their shoes repaired or their car's oil changed or buy a new suit or a set of pots and pans without leaving work, to vendors at railroad stations who sell hot gourmet meals, to doctors who will see patients before sunrise and chiropractors who make office calls, the margins of ordinary commerce are stretching into some extraordinary territory.
"You have a bunch of entrepreneurs who see an opportunity," said William Dunkelberg, the chief economist at the National Federation of Independent Business. He said he believes that the increasing number of two-income households is the driving force.
"Two people come home and they're tired, and that's it," he said. "That's what's creating all the opportunities for these new little niche firms."
There are no statistics about this market, because most of the providers are small. But economists and sociologists agree that society's changes are creating greater opportunities for any company with selling points of accessibility and speed.
The impetus, these experts say, is partly from a longer workday, but also from an odder workday, as more self-employed people and computer-connected people who work at home find their own rhythms. In addition, increases in car-pooling, encouraged by clean-air laws, have made it harder for people to run errands on their lunch hours or on the way home.
On the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, for example, the number of people arriving at Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan between 6:30 A.M. and 7 A.M., before the traditional morning rush has even begun, increased 56 percent between 1989 and 1994 -- one of the railroad's fastest-growing travel times. Many commuters are also going home later. Eastbound departures on the Long Island Rail Road between 7 and 8 P.M., after the formal end of the evening rush, rose 38 percent between 1992 and 1994.
"The concept that you can't get something done at any given time of the day just doesn't exist anymore," said John Saunders, the publisher of "The New York City Business Source Book," an annual guide. "In the last five years, it seems you can get anything."
Mel Barlin's niche is the after-hours crisis.
"There's an animal in your cellar, your computer crashes, your TV or your fax machine isn't working -- any emergency of any kind, any time, that's our motto," said Mr. Barlin, who runs 1-800-All-Night, a telephone referral service in Rockland County that opened in January and serves New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The company now has 700 businesses on its list, all but a few of which are available on the fly, including Mr. Ryffel's computer repair.
But wooing and winning the exhausted consumer means being more flexible in how and where services are offered as well as when. In Maplewood, N.J., for example, the town is developing plans for a train station concierge who, for fees paid by merchants, will return a commuter's library books and video rentals, do shopping, fill a prescription at the drug store and have it all ready by the evening train.
In Parsippany, N.J., local merchants descend on the cafeteria at the Nabisco Inc. headquarters every Wednesday for vendor day -- a concept introduced last year to keep employees from running off to the mall at lunch. On a rotating schedule, businesses offering anything from picture framing to clothing, pots and pans to children's toys set up their folding shops. AT&T's company headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., has five vendors in the building every workday in rotating schedule.
"Businesses are trying to adhere to new life styles," said Brian Colburn, the president of All-in-One Cleaners, a Somerdale, N.J., company that branched out last year into corporate service, opening stores at two AT&T offices in New Jersey. "That's what's really important to succeeding in the future -- working with consumers rather than getting them to work with you."
Another factor that encourages companies to allow more commerce during the workday is that it does not cost the employer any money and looks like a new benefit.
"Give them anything but money -- that's the byword these days," said Tom Deschere, the owner of Hamilton Art, a vendor of prints, posters and frames who rides the corporate circuit, mostly in Connecticut and New Jersey.
Workers say that while there are still deep frustrations -- most government offices and banks, in particular, have yet to adapt -- the menu of options has unquestionably expanded.
Edward L. Hansen, an associate at William M. Mercer Inc., a human resources consulting firm in Manhattan, said that for years he often had the train to himself as he took the 6:09 A.M. from Hartsdale, N.Y. "Now, I'm surrounded by purposeful people running along, carrying two briefcases," he said.
Arriving at Grand Central, people too harried to enter a deli can get their rolls and coffees at one of the early morning food vendors, which Mr. Hansen likened to "drive throughs" for pedestrians.
Kathleen Luke, a lawyer for Pepsico in Purchase, N.Y., referring to the number of business services she can use on her busy schedule, said: "It's growing. It's not there yet, but it's growing."
Mrs. Luke, who said she was typically at her desk from 9 A.M. to 6:30 or 7 P.M., was interviewed just after 7 A.M. at Allergy and Asthma Associates of Norwalk, Conn., as she and her 6-year-old daughter, Lindsay, waited for Lindsay's appointment. "When the economy is not good, service people are more willing to do what you need them to do," she said.
Her husband, John A. Luke Jr., the president and chief executive officer of the Westvaco Corporation, a paper and packaging company, works even longer hours than his wife, typically leaving home in New Canaan, Conn., at 6 A.M. for Manhattan and getting home 14 hours later, at 8 P.M. Mr. Luke said the expansion of hours in businesses he needs is welcome. He also called it an inevitable result of capitalism.
"I see what's happening as a very logical, constructive response to changing demographics," he said. "Whether it's doctor's hours, the local oil company and you have to schedule a service, or lawn care, people are more responsive in the hours they will meet you."
At Allergy and Asthma Associates, which began offering 7 A.M. appointments four years ago, demand is such that early appointments are now available three mornings a week. Night hours until 8 are even busier.
"Our waiting room looks like corporate America at 7 A.M.," said Dr. Maryanne Scott, one of three physicians who run the office.
Older personal time-saving services have seen new markets develop.
"Home-based business people, downsized into their homes, need help getting started, then the mail comes in, and it piles up and they're inundated," said Linda Rothschild, owner of Cross It Off Your List, a five-year-old company that helps people get organized.
Yet, there are apparently limits to where odd-hours commerce can go.
Mr. Barlin, who runs the 24-hour referral service, said that for reasons he is still not sure of, most housepainters will not paint at night or submit to the whims of beepers.
Other services have tried and failed. Metro-North solicited a vendor in 1991 to sell dinners at suburban train stations but closed the effort as a failure after only a few months. Pepsico eliminated its corporate concierge office last year in a cost-cutting move.
Tom Yermack, the general manager at En Route, a gourmet store inside the Princeton Junction train station in New Jersey, said the limit of extracurricular commerce is that many people are too rushed or too tired or too obsessed to be bothered, even for things that will save them time.
"Once people get off that train, you can see it in their eyes," Mr. Yermack said. "They want to get to their cars and they want to get home, and that's it."

HEADLINE: Exodus Over Welfare Cuts? Researchers Say It Isn't So

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted last week that many poor New Yorkers would move out of state as a "natural consequence" of the welfare cuts he is championing, there were cries of outrage from advocates for the poor. But perhaps more telling, demographers, economists and poverty experts who have researched the migratory patterns of welfare recipients say the Mayor is simply mistaken.
National studies by independent researchers have consistently found that differing levels of welfare benefits have little impact on a poor family's decision to pull up stakes and are seldom the primary motivation behind a move. Like other Americans, a single mother and her children are much more likely to be drawn to a new place by job opportunities, family ties, warm weather, better schools and safer streets than by a few extra dollars in their welfare check. 
 Rather, experts say, the Mayor may discover some unpleasant and expensive consequences of lower benefits and of a more complicated, arduous process of qualifying for Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the main welfare program. While the changes may weed out some cheaters, they will also deprive some of the neediest, least competent families of benefits, they said.
"The cream of the crop can figure out a new system," said Gordon Berlin, a senior vice president of the nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, which evaluates welfare experiments. "But the people who are barely coping now probably won't negotiate the new barriers, and they're also the people more likely to slip into homelessness or whose poverty ends up causing them to neglect their children."
In recent weeks, the Mayor has said that the welfare system in the city has become much too "user-friendly," effectively inviting people to defraud the taxpayers or discouraging them from finding a job. He has said that the new policies he favors will encourage people to get off welfare and move to states where they can find work.
But experts say Mr. Giuliani overestimates the importance of welfare benefits in choices about where to live. If Mr. Giuliani were correct, they note, poor people would have flocked to New York, with its relatively high welfare benefits.
New York actually lost more poor people to other states from 1985 to 1990 than did any other state in the nation -- and many of them moved to the South, where welfare benefits are among the lowest in the nation, said William Frey, a demographer at the University of Michigan's Population Studies Center.
"The bottom line is that the welfare magnet effect is almost nil," Mr. Frey said.
Even with Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed welfare cuts, the monthly combined food stamp and cash welfare benefits to a typical family of three in New York would fall by $26, to $551 a month -- enough to hurt, certainly, but not enough to prompt a move, experts say. More than 300,000 families in the city now receive A.F.D.C., a near record high.
Virginia Johnson, 35, a welfare recipient and mother of three who lives in Long Island City, Queens, said on Saturday that $26 was enough to keep her 2-year-old son, Kevin, in diapers for a couple of weeks. But she said a cut in benefits would not make her move. "Where would I go?" she said. "How can I afford the money to move anywhere? Where would the money come from?"
Nyoma Pitts, 33, another mother of three who lives in Long Island City, said she left New York City briefly, but she was looking for a job, not better welfare benefits. Now back, she said unemployment paid her more than welfare would. She added that she hoped to start a child-care business with a friend before those benefits expired.
"I don't know how they say you sit back and relax," she said of A.F.D.C. "They don't even give you enough money to sit back and relax."
Researchers echo the views of Ms. Johnson and Ms. Pitts. A fairly modest cut in benefits is rarely enough to motivate a family to hit the road, especially since the value of welfare benefits nationwide has been in a precipitous decline for more than two decades and many states -- including neighboring Connecticut -- are considering even more severe cutbacks than New York.
Both welfare recipients and researchers note that it is expensive for the poor to relocate, what with the cost of paying a mover, plus a security deposit and month's rent on a new apartment. And there are other deterrents.
Many families on welfare do not live solely on their benefits and can ill afford to lose off-the-books income by moving to a new place. Some get money on the side from friends or family members, while others find odd jobs, looking after other people's children or cleaning their homes.
"I don't think people come for higher welfare benefits unless the change in benefits in their home state is so drastic they couldn't live on them," said William Grinker, who advised Mr. Giuliani on welfare issues during his campaign and headed the city's Human Resources Administration during the mayoralty of Edward I. Koch. "Where are they going to go? Mississippi? Where is it so wonderful?"
In addition to supporting lower benefits, Mr. Giuliani last week presented a city budget that included a promise of stringent, though yet undefined, new eligibility requirements for families applying for A.F.D.C.
City budget officials said on Thursday that the new rules, based on regulations recently carried out in the Home Relief program, which provides welfare payments mainly to single, childless adults, would cause the percentage of A.F.D.C. applicants found eligible to plummet by 30 percent.
By Friday, the Mayor had begun backing away from his budget staff's position that the new A.F.D.C. rules would be based on those developed for Home Relief, and hedged on the 30 percent figure.
Westchester County is the model for the city's new policies. Like Westchester, the city began in January to conduct unannounced home visits on all Home Relief applicants to insure they live where they say they do. It also set up elaborate steps that applicants must follow -- including visits to several offices in Brooklyn and Manhattan and long waits in many lines -- that advocates said were aimed at knocking people off the rolls.
The percentage of Home Relief applicants in the city found ineligible rose to 57 percent in the first three months of this year, compared with 20 percent the previous year.
Westchester, too, found that a hard look at all Home Relief applicants more than doubled the percentage found ineligible. But when the county tested tough eligibility processes on A.F.D.C. applicants in its Yonkers office in 1993, the percentage found ineligible did not rise, said Mary E. Glass, the county's Social Services Commissioner.
"We found no measurable difference in Yonkers," she said. Her explanation for the difference in the results was that, unlike the single adults who receive Home Relief, the A.F.D.C. recipients, mostly mothers with children, are much less transient and have much more difficulty finding steady work.
Nonetheless, she said the city's welfare procedures may have become so lax that the city should test a wider-ranging eligibility process of A.F.D.C. applicants.
Miss Glass wryly recalled when the city's last Human Resources Administration Commissioner, Barbara J. Sabol, applied for welfare incognito, in wigs and sweat shirts, and then described the indignities and humiliations of the process.
Indeed, the attitude of the Giuliani administration toward welfare recipients is much less sympathetic than that of Mrs. Sabol and her patron, Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mr. Berlin, who was a social services official in the Koch years, said: "She was determined to make it a user-friendly system, and when you do that you do get more people on the rolls. Now, Giuliani is swinging in the opposite direction, trying to make it more difficult to get on."

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO ORDER A TRADE EMBARGO AGAINST TEHERAN

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
President Clinton said yesterday that he would cut off all United States trade and investment with Iran, including purchases by American companies that account for more than 20 percent of that country's oil exports, in a further effort to isolate it as an "inspiration and paymaster to terrorists".
"This is not a step I take lightly," 
 Mr. Clinton said last night at a dinner of the World Jewish Congress in New York. "But I am convinced that instituting a trade embargo with Iran is the most effective way our nation can help to curb that nation's drive to acquire devastating weapons and its continued support for terrorism."
The White House said Mr. Clinton would sign an executive order outlining the ban later this week, to take effect in 30 days. It would apply to all American companies and foreign branches deemed to be under their control but not to separate foreign subsidiaries. Moreover, it would eliminate virtually all remaining United States exports to Iran, which totaled $326 million last year -- mostly in farm, industrial and oilfield equipment -- while affecting at least "a few thousand" jobs, White House said.
But the biggest practical effect would be to end American companies' purchases of Iranian oil for resale on the world market. Already, American oil companies are barred from importing Iranian oil, but they and their foreign subsidiaries are the biggest single buyers of it, and last year bought crude oil worth about $4 billion on the open market. While that amounts to a quarter of Iran's oil exports, it is equivalent to only about 2 percent of the world's total oil exports.
The Administration has tried without success to persuade its European and Japanese allies to join in a ban, and White House officials said the President would still urge other nations not to buy the oil. But oil industry experts have said a United States ban is likely to cause only short-term and small-scale disruptions in the world market.
"American companies will find other sources of oil to meet their contracts and Iran will have no trouble finding other buyers," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. But he added that the ban would put the American companies at a slight competetive disadvantage against foreign rivals, since they will now be prohibited from buying both Iranian and Libyan crude.
Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy advisers have been urging for weeks that he adopt the embargo, over the objections of trade and economic aides. The President portrayed it yesterday as a necessary weapon in the fight against terrorism, an issue given new immediacy after the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. But the announcement was also suffused with domestic politics.
Anti-Iranian sentiment has been building in Congress, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, has proposed legislation that would not only ban trade between the United States and Iran but would also impose a secondary boycott on American trade with foreign companies that continue to do business with Iran.
By acting on its own, the White House hoped to seize the initiative, and officials said yesterday that they wanted to consult with Mr. D'Amato and Representative Peter J. King of Long Island, the measure's sponsor in the House, in hopes of persuading them that it was no longer needed. The Administration decided against extending the embargo to foreign companies that continue to trade with Iran on the ground that it would alienate allies and do more harm than good, one senior official said.
Mr. Clinton's move was also heavy with political symbolism and appeal because he made the announcement at a dinner of the World Jewish Congress honoring Edgar M. Bronfman, the patriarch of the Seagram's distilling family and a leading critic of Iran as a threat to the drive for Middle East peace, with the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, sitting across the table.
As major shareholders and board members of Du Pont, the parent company of Conoco, the Bronfman family used its influence last month to press Conoco to abandon a deal under which it would have developed two large offshore oilfields for Iran. Conoco dropped the plan after the White House announced that Mr. Clinton would issue a directive blocking all such transactions on grounds of national security.
In his remarks last night, the President said the Conoco case and the new embargo showed that there are times when support for free trade and open markets must take second place to concerns about international threats.
"Many people have argued passionately that the best route to changing Iranian behavior is by engaging the country," Mr. Clinton told the dinner audience at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. "Unfortunately, there is no evidence to support that argument. Indeed, the evidence of the last two years suggests exactly the reverse.
"Iran's appetite for acquiring and developing nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them has only grown larger. Even as prospects for the peace in the Middle East have grown, Iran has broadened its role as an inspiration and paymaster to terrorists. There is nothing to suggest that further engagement will alter that course."
Before attending the dinner, Mr. Clinton shared a platform with Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Peres, at a ceremony commemorating the Holocaust and the 52d annivesary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising at the Paramount at Madison Square Garden. Mr. Clinton's new announcement brings the United States policy on Iran more into line with Israel's.
In his remarks there, Mr. Peres did not mention Iran. But he recalled the evils of Nazism and Communism to warn against the current threat of Islamic fundamentalism, which, he said, "like Communism adopted the Machiavellian slogan that ends justify means, which is a license to lie, to subvert, to kill."
The United States already limits not only most imports from Iran but also the export of sensitive goods that could be used in military technology. The White House said Mr. Clinton's decision was the culmination of a interagency review of policy toward Iran that began last November. Secretary of State Warren Christopher concluded more than a month ago that existing efforts to isolate Iran were not working, and urged an embargo.
But Mr. Christopher's recommendation met with fierce opposition from senior officials at the Defense, Commerce, Treasury and Energy Departments, who argued that curbing American trade would have little effect on Iran and could hurt American companies instead.
White House aides said Mr. Clinton made the decision to impose the additional sanctions on Friday. Once the order takes effect, officials said, the Government will make some exceptions to allow companies to keep operating while they shut down dealings with Iran. A White House aide said American corporate operations in Iran had dwindled to almost nothing in the 15 years since Washington severed ties with Teheran during the hostage crisis.

HEADLINE: Unity Is Missing as Vietnam Remembers War's End

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, April 30

 BODY:
The Vietnamese Government celebrated the 20th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War today with bursts of fireworks and a grand parade through the streets of the city once known as Saigon, but without the spirit of unity that the Communist leadership has struggled to portray.
That Vietnam still has far to go in reuniting north and south was obvious in the barricades set up throughout the city, preventing all but Communist Party members and invited guests from watching a parade that brought together the aging soldiers who defeated a superpower. 
 There was heavy security along the parade route, apparently out of fear that opponents of the Government might use the anniversary as an opportunity for a protest in front of television cameras from around the world. There was no protest.
"I feel very happy about this anniversary and the reunification of our country, but I feel bad because I cannot get to the parade," said Nguyen Hung, 42, an English teacher, who stood across the street from the former United States Embassy here, straining to catch even a glimpse of the parade, a camera around his neck.
"The camera is useless today," he said with a smile of resignation.
Still, if the Vietnamese of the north and south have not yet made peace with each other, the country's leaders made clear today that they were interested in peace with their former enemy, the United States.
Their speeches to mark the anniversary were remarkably free of the venomous rancor about the United States that marked earlier anniversaries of the capture of Saigon -- renamed Ho Chi Minh City after the Communist victory -- and the end of a war that took more than three million lives, including those of 58,000 Americans.
Speaking from a grandstand within sight of the former Presidential Palace, where the Saigon Government surrendered on April 30, 1975, Mayor Truong Tan Sang spoke of the anniversary as "a resplendent milestone" for Vietnam but did not even once mention the United States, the archenemy of the Communist forces in fighting that lasted a decade.
On Saturday in Hanoi, the Vietnamese capital, Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet recalled raids by American B-52 bombers, the massacre at My Lai and other "genocidal crimes" committed by the Americans during the war.
But at the same time, he urged the Vietnamese to "shut the door to the past and look to the future to raise our national spirit, expand international relations and work together with other countries for peace, cooperation and development."
Vietnam is eager for full diplomatic and trade relations with the United States, which last year lifted a 19-year-old trade embargo that had crippled the Vietnamese economy.
In January the United States opened a diplomatic liaison office in Hanoi but said it would not agree to full diplomatic relations until there was additional progress in determining the fate of more than 2,000 troops still listed as missing in action from the war.
Mr. Kiet was in Ho Chi Minh City today and watched the parade from the grandstand, seated alongside the legendary general of the Communist army, Vo Nguyen Giap, the "Red Napoleon" who defeated the French Army at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 and was among the architects of the war against the United States and the American-backed Government of South Vietnam.
Before the parade, General Giap joined in laying wreaths before a statue of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam's revolutionary leader. The general was dressed in a gray uniform adorned only with the Hero of the People's Army of Vietnam medal, the nation's highest military award.
"The Vietnamese people have put this war behind them," said Michael Liscio, 52, a Navy veteran from Sherman Oaks, Calif., who was with the first American combat forces to land in Vietnam in 1965 and who today was invited to watch the anniversary parade as a guest of the Vietnamese Government.
Mr. Liscio, who last week completed a 1,300-mile, two-month run from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City, said that after meeting with Vietnamese from all parts of the country, "I think there is still a difference between the people in the north and the people in the south, just as there was a difference in the United States a hundred years ago after the Civil War."
"But now these people want peace," he added. "Basically these people are not warriors -- they are warm, friendly people who want to move on."

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: DAMAGES;
For the Dispossessed, Aid With No Red Tape

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 30

 BODY:
Jesse Carretero was putting the finishing touches on a cabinet in his downtown store on April 19 when the explosion at the Federal Building a block away blew off the garage door. The blast also knocked Mr. Carretero off his feet and into the ranks of the thousands who suddenly found themselves without homes or businesses.
Mr. Carretero, who said the bombing destroyed his fledgling cabinet business, was among the first group of applicants to walk in the door of a temporary emergency relief center set up on Saturday by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
 Within hours, he had made the rounds, receiving $900 in vouchers from the Red Cross and a $30 medication allowance from the Oklahoma County Disaster Relief Team. He left with a stack of application forms for loans from the Small Business Administration and unemployment benefits from the state.
"Before today, I thought I was finished," Mr. Carretero said. "I had nothing to go on with."
About 500 people visited the center, in the Sheppard Mall on the edge of the city, on Saturday, and a similar crowd was there today. The center will operate as long as applications for help are coming in.
Buddy Young, regional director of FEMA, estimated that more than 300 buildings near the explosion site were affected. The damage, he said, could exceed $500 million.
Mr. Carretero said that he was not injured but that the explosion was devastating nonetheless. The ceiling of his store caved in. The windows were shattered. The half-finished cabinets were smashed to bits and buried beneath the rubble along with $12,000 worth of equipment. He said he also lost two contracts, totaling $6,000, because he could not meet their deadlines. Within half an hour of the explosion, inspectors condemned his building and shut off the electricity.
Without insurance or the income from the contracts, which he would have received last Wednesday, Mr. Carretero, 44, fell behind on his $250 rent and was evicted from his apartment today, he said. He also said he had been unable to pay $400 in child support for his two boys, Daniel, 8, and Ryan, 6, or buy medicine he needs for a heart condition.
He contemplated suicide, he said, but the thought of his two boys kept him from going through with it.
During the last two days, the people who came to the emergency relief center for help ranged from those like Mr. Carretero who had lost entire businesses to those who had no idea what the damage was yet.
Bobby G. Rumfelt, an employee with the state of Oklahoma, was hesitating when filling out a damage-assessment form at the Small Business Administration table. He told Vic Moerbe, a loan officer from the agency, that he had no idea what had been damaged in his apartment in the Regency Towers, one block east of the Federal building, because he had only been allowed back in for five minutes to collect a few belongings.
"Don't worry about it," Mr. Moerbe said. "Just list whatever you have in the apartment. We just want to get your application in early so we can take care of you as fast as we can. Our inspectors will go up on Monday morning to verify your claims."
At the center, employees from Government and private relief agencies worked to help applicants fill out forms for business and personal loans and cash vouchers, patiently explaining what programs were available and from time to time giving counseling to those who broke down when recalling what they had lost.
In one room, volunteers from the Red Cross filled out forms for those needing emergency shelter and expenses for food, transportation and medication. In another, employees from the Small Business Administration, the Oklahoma County Disaster Relief Team, FEMA's emergency housing program and the Internal Revenue Service sat ready to help. Those who lost properties can apply for a credit through the I.R.S. against last year's taxes.
For the most part, those who came in were grateful for the swift and courteous help they received.
"I can't believe how quickly the Government is taking care of our needs," said Jane Vowell, whose 1975 Buick was destroyed in the blast.
But some were frustrated with the pace.
Sitting in the Red Cross office, Esmaiel Eijadey and his wife, Sedegheh, sighed and shook their heads impatiently during their 20-minute wait. Mr. Eijadey said that although he had made all the obligatory stops and filled out the forms, help just was not coming soon enough.
"You just sit here and wait and wait and wait," said Mr. Eijadey, whose Italian restaurant half a block from the blast site was demolished. "They tell me I am going to get the money in a week or two. But I need the money now, lots of it."
Mr. Eijadey said he owed $25,000 for supplies and was pressed to pay it as soon as possible.
"The Red Cross will help you find housing and buy you food," he said. "But I don't need that. I need cars to get around and money to pay my bills. I'm not going to get it tomorrow."
Rita Kepner, a spokeswoman for FEMA, said her agency had already sent out nearly $200,000 in checks for emergency housing, averaging $1,500 per application. The Small Business Administration also was processing loan applications on the site, offering loans for businesses of up to $1.5 million, for personal property loss of up to $40,000, and for housing damage of up to $100,000.
"We are doing the best we can," Ms. Kepner said. "People have to understand that it still takes time. This is the weekend. We have to wait for the banks to open to check their credit history.
"It will take a long time for the businesses and people who lost their homes to rebuild their lives," Ms. Kepner said. "But this is a start."

HEADLINE: Pentagon Seeks to End Preference Program

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Pentagon's affirmative action program in long-distance telephone services seemed such a triumph -- it had raised the portion of contracts with small, minority-owned businesses to 57 percent from just 3 percent within two years -- that Congress last year adopted the basic concept Government-wide.
The program was particularly admired for the way it avoided the political weaknesses of affirmative action programs for minority-owned businesses in which a certain amount of work is "set aside" for them. Instead, market forces were given a small nudge, as minority companies were given a 10 percent pricing advantage on their bids. 
 But now the Pentagon is considering shutting the program down in the face of protests by white-owned small businesses and after a report by the Defense Department's Inspector General found that none of the chosen companies were able to meet requirements set by Congress that were meant to prevent fraud.
Neither the apparent initial success nor later criticisms are that clear-cut, however, in the views of the Pentagon, the minority businesses that got the contracts or the white-owned companies that had vociferously fought to end the program.
In some ways, the fight over a small, obscure preference program mirrors the larger debate around affirmative action that is swirling in Congress and elsewhere. At a time when special efforts to aid women and members of minorities are under increasing attack, the program indicates that when the overarching goal of affirmative action meets the complex brew of conflicting Congressional mandates, arcane bureaucratic regulations and contemporary economic trends, the results are often unsatisfactory for everyone.
"I think this was pushed without a lot of thought about the implications," said David R. Smith, a lawyer in Fairfax, Va., who represents minority-owned telecommunications companies.
The short history of the program also belies two other often-voiced notions about preference programs: that without their continuation minorities would falter and that minority preferences have caused whites to suffer economically. In this case, neither notion appears to be true.
The Pentagon's proposal to eliminate the mandatory preference program in long-distance service is not final. Officials say it will be published in the next several weeks in the Federal Register. After that, the public will have 60 days to comment on it. It is sure to provoke criticism from minority-owned companies that argue that without some kind of preferential treatment, they will be shut out of a burgeoning market.
"There are not that many in this industry because of the costs of getting started," Mr. Smith said. "So if you don't have some kind of program, you're going to have zero."
The program in question involves contracts to supply dedicated telephone lines used mainly to transmit data between military bases. With the deregulation of the telecommunications industry the field has increasingly attracted small "resellers," companies that lease lines from communications giants like AT&T and MCI and then sell services to customers like the Defense Department.
According to the Inspector General's report, at least 278 contracts valued at $30.3 million were awarded to resellers between 1992 and the end of 1993.
Under the program, minority-owned companies have been given a pricing preference -- meaning that bids by their white-owned competitors are automatically increased by 10 percent.
Pricing preferences have two advantages over "set aside" programs, Administration officials said. One is that in theory there is less opportunity to create sham companies that do nothing but hand off guaranteed business, since a company would have to have the ability to make a bid that was close to competitive. The other advantage is that the discounts are less politically vulnerable than set asides, which are much more open to attack as quotas.
But while the 10 percent margin might seem relatively small, in the communications reselling market a difference of even 2 or 3 percent can be insurmountable.
"It's a very competitive industry," said Allen Smith, director of business development and product marketing for Communications Transmission Inc., a white-owned reseller with headquarters in Austin, Tex. "Fifty cents makes a difference."
"We're losing business left and right," said Craig Brooks, president of Electra, a small, white-owned telecommunications reseller based in Bethesda, Md. "We're going under. What about us? We're a small business, too."
Complicating the program, however, were rules imposed by Congress -- rules that both sides in the debate agree no small business in this field, whether owned by whites or minority members, can meet.
In order to insure that minority-owned companies are not merely acting as fronts for larger, white-owned businesses, Congress requires that for a minority-owned company to qualify for a program, the company must perform at least 50 percent of the actual work as measured by cost. In the case of telecommunications, the rule has been interpreted as meaning these companies have to have borne 50 percent of the cost of installing and maintaining the telephone lines.
In reality, most resellers do little more than act as a middleman. The telephone companies installed the lines, own them, do the billing and maintain them as part of the lease arrangement with resellers.
Spokesmen for minority-owned telecommunications businesses say the interpretation of the 50 percent rule is unfair.
"To require a small disadvantaged business to perform 50 percent of the work, when you include the cost of developing the infrastructure, is ridiculous," said David Smith. "They can't do that and still qualify for being a small business. So it's an unrealistic requirement from the get-go."
Realizing this, Government agencies -- in this case the Pentagon -- have been reluctant to enforce the 50 percent labor rule. Doing so would make it difficult to meet another Congressional mandate: that 5 percent of Defense Department procurement contracts be awarded to small minority-owned companies.
In an interview, Eleanor Spector, director of procurement for the Defense Department, said the Pentagon would not follow an Inspector General's recommendation that the Defense Department drop all such pricing preference programs -- unless it can be verified that they will be able to perform at least half of the required work. "The I.G. recommends that we eliminate it everywhere," Ms. Spector said. "His position is that we would save money and streamline the process. But if we do so we could not make our 5 percent small disadvantaged business goal."
In the end the Pentagon program, and its possible elimination, have left a bitter taste in the mouths both of officials of white companies that have been protesting the preference, and of officials affiliated with firms that have received it. Both sides say they favor policies to spur the development of minority companies. But both express disappointment over the way this particular program was handled.
"It was a great idea," David Smith said. But he said the Pentagon decided to "push it not thinking that somebody might have a problem with it."
"And that somebody happens to be other small business who have the same problems with raising capital and developing a market, but don't get the preference."
"Had more thought been put into the program before it got going," Mr. Smith said, "they could have minimized a lot of these problems."

HEADLINE: Respect for Justice System Slides, Poll Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The murder trial of O. J. Simpson has weakened Americans' respect for the criminal justice system, according to an opinion poll released today by the American Bar Association.
In a survey of 1,011 people conducted April 10-14, 45 percent said the continuing trial had caused them to lose respect for the justice system. In a poll the association took in July, when the Simpson case was still in its pretrial stages, 28 percent of the 1,011 respondents gave that reply. 
 Both polls were conducted for the A.B.A. Journal by the Gallup Organization. In each, the margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
"We take these concerns seriously," Robert Cooper Ramo, the president-elect of the association, said of the latest poll's findings. "It is critical to our democracy that the American people have faith in the integrity of the justice system."
The percentage of those who said the Simpson case had caused them to lose respect for prosecutors remained about the same from one poll to the next -- 21 percent in July and 24 percent in April. But the surveys showed the defense did not fare as well: in July, 26 percent said they had lost respect for defense lawyers, but in the latest survey the figure was 41 percent.
In both polls, 56 percent of those asked said they had lost respect for the news media.

HEADLINE: An Eclipse for the Group of Seven

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Financial fire fighting and economic coordination are supposed to be specialties of the Group of Seven, as the consortium of the world's biggest industrial nations calls itself. But on both counts the recent record of these nations -- the United States, France, Britain, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan -- is looking less than impressive.
Indeed, some economists believe that its impact is in the process of being eclipsed by a lesser-known body of industrialized and developing nations which scored an economic success last week as the Group of Seven produced another disappointment. 
 At their annual spring session in Washington last week, finance ministers of the Group of Seven's member nations fell out over the Clinton Administration's indifference toward a weak dollar, with many complaining that turbulent currency markets are endangering world recovery.
Helmut Kohl, the Chancellor of Germany, had set the tone before the talks even started by saying American policy was "not acceptable." Lawrence H. Summers, an Under Secretary of the Treasury, hit back in an interview published with the Handlesblatt newspaper just after the talks by accusing the Germans of "always saying no." Lamberto Dini, Italy's Prime Minister and Finance Minister, termed the meeting "tense."
So much for Group of Seven effectiveness. But it has been that way for a while, with the 20-year-old organization looking increasingly ineffective because it no longer reflects the financial realities of a world where the successful emerging economies of Asia and Latin America are growing almost twice as fast as those of the older industrialized nations.
When the Group of Seven tried to cope with Mexico's peso crisis earlier this year, its members immediately quarreled over the rescue package designed by the United States, with the Europeans accusing Washington of railroading them into a bailout for American investors.
At their previous meeting in Madrid in October, the group managed to provoke the most bitter North-South clash in a decade by vetoing a plan for developing nations to create more monetary reserves only to find that the third world refused to take no for an answer. Deadlock continues.
"This G-7 is not the class of '85," Lisa S. Kaes of the New York investment advisory firm of Geoffrey Bell & Company said, referring to the group's successful 1985 exchange rate accord that capped the soaring dollar during the Reagan Administration.
And it is definitely not the class of '87 -- the year the group successfully put a floor under a tumbling dollar.
Yet if last week's meeting disappointed, the gathering that immediately followed of the Interim Committee, the oddly named body which oversees the International Monetary Fund, was much more successful.
This 24-nation committee, where Group of Seven finance ministers sit with colleagues from all other regions of the world, quickly reached preliminary agreement on a plan to prevent more Mexican-style crises through stricter economic monitoring and a new safety net by the International Monetary Fund.
"The G-7 is a relic of a world divided into a rich North and a poor South that is disappearing," argued Robert Solomon, a former chief international economist at the Federal Reserve now with the Brookings Institution in Washington. "The Interim Committee better represents today's world."
Efforts to bring the Group of Seven into line with that reality are under way. Last year the Commission on Global Governance, led by Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson of Sweden and Shridath Ramphal, former secretary general of the Commonwealth, proposed an Economic Security Council for the United Nations.
But the United States would never allow such a body real authority without a veto, and the emerging economies of Asia and Latin America are unlikely to accept that.
Another plan has come from Peter Sutherland, the former director of the new World Trade Organization. He favors expanding the group to include Russia, China and the fast-growing emerging economies with reduced representation for European Union nations to keep numbers manageable.
Meanwhile, as the economic gap between the group's member nations and the rest of the world narrows, its self-appointed position as guardian of the international economic system causes growing resentment and becomes harder to justify.
According to World Bank projections, by 2020 the world's seven biggest economies will be China, the United States, Japan, India, Indonesia, Germany and Korea in that order, followed by France, Taiwan, Brazil, Italy, Russia, Britain and Mexico. Today's Group of Seven is a sunset institution enjoying the late afternoon.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Moderate Outlook For Media Prices

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
In another sign that inflation is fading as a concern for advertisers, an annual survey indicated that media prices this year are expected to rise by 5 percent or less. 
 The poll, released on Friday by DeWitt Media Inc., a media services company in New York, said that 56 percent of the advertisers surveyed estimated that media prices they have paid or expect to pay this year have increased by 5 percent or less, while 18 percent anticipated the increase to hold at the 5 percent level and 22 percent pegged the rise between 3 percent and 4 percent.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Atlanta Sounds Gun For Tickets

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
While the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta are still 15 months away, fierce competition has already begun in the unofficial Olympic sports of ticket roulette, hotel price gouging and the long-distance commuter relay.
Getting tickets to at least 1 of the 542 sessions in 26 Olympic sports will be a piece of cake. Tickets go on sale today, and 11 million are available, more than the combined totals of the 1984 Los Angeles Games and the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. 
 And now for the fine print.
Getting tickets to preferred events, such as opening and closing ceremonies, swimming, men's basketball and women's gymnastics, will be a challenge. An even bigger challenge will be finding a hotel room in downtown Atlanta.
Olympic and consumer affairs officials are committed to keeping price gouging to a minimum. But spectators who do find a hotel or apartment or home outside the Olympic housing network will have to navigate an obstacle course of profiteers, some seeking $350 a night for a hotel room that normally goes for $79, $10,000 a month for a one-bedroom condominium and $150,000 for two weeks in a rented house.
At these Centennial Games, a road atlas may be as valuable as a ticket. Many spectators will have to commute from outlying cities, even outlying states. To alleviate the housing crunch, there are also plans to fly spectators in for the day from Chicago and New York.
Officially, the Atlanta Olympics open on July 19, 1996, and close 16 days later on Aug. 4. But the scramble for tickets begins with a mail-order phase today, when 35 million ticket brochures will be available at Coca-Cola displays at 15,000 grocery stores nationwide. Ticket brochures are also available at 335 Home Depot stores.
Ticket prices for sporting events range from $6 to $250, with tickets to the opening and closing ceremonies costing $200, $400 and $600. All tickets include transportation on local bus and rail systems. The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games is relying on ticket sales to provide $261 million of its $1.6 billion budget. To match that forecast, organizers will have to sell roughly 6.3 million of the 11 million tickets.
But what may seem like an ocean of tickets for the average fan is actually something like an Olympic-sized pool. Four million of the 11 million tickets have already been set aside for purchase by corporate sponsors, holders of broadcast rights and Olympic committees from 200 nations.
The sport with the most seats available is soccer, which will have 2.4 million tickets to sell. But there's one catch: Preliminary matches will be played in Birmingham, Ala., Orlando, Fla., Washington and Miami, but not in Atlanta. Only the semifinals and finals of the men's and women's competition will be held in Georgia -- at Sanford Stadium in Athens, 60 miles northeast of Atlanta. Another 2.4 million tickets are available for sports not traditionally popular with Americans in the Olympics -- baseball, field hockey and equestrian events.
But Atlanta officials say it is not true that most seats to the highly prized events have been grabbed by corporate sponsors. Scott Anderson, who oversees the Olympic ticket operation, said more seats have been reserved for the general public than for corporate sponsors at each session for each sport. Tickets are available for every session, he said, from the opening ceremonies to the men's basketball final.
"We have more seats available to the general public than Los Angeles had total seats available," Anderson said, referring to the 1984 Summer Games, which had 6.9 million tickets for sale.
Several people familiar with ticketing plans said that of the approximately 60,000 seats available for the opening ceremonies at Olympic Stadium, about 20,000 would be reserved for the general public. Officials also said that given the 30,000-plus seating capacity for men's basketball and women's gymnastics in the Georgia Dome, the public will have a greater opportunity to see these sports than at previous Olympics.
"There is a good possibility of getting a high-profile ticket," said Harvey Schiller, president of Turner Sports in Atlanta and formerly the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee. "If you want to go to the opening and closing ceremonies, gymnastics and swimming, I don't think you'll get all that. At the same time, if you want to see handball and also gymnastics, I think you have a chance."
He added: "It's like the Final Four. It's tough to get tickets, but after two teams lose, there are plenty available."
Atlanta officials are encouraging fans to make a wide variety of requests for tickets. They emphasize such sports as women's softball and women's soccer, at which the United States is expected to win gold medals.
For those determined to see the glamour events, $50,000 will buy a patron package that includes a pair of tickets to the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as 30 other highly coveted sessions.
Tickets will be easier to come by in Atlanta than hotel rooms. As of February, 80 percent of the 55,000 hotel rooms in the Atlanta metropolitan area had been reserved for international Olympic officials, sponsors and members of the news media.
Thousands of eventual ticket-holders are faced with the prospect of daily commutes from satellite cities such as Birmingham, Ala., (161 miles) and Chattanooga, Tenn. (120 miles).
Atlanta organizers predict that half of the expected two million visitors during the Games will be residents of the Southeast. And many of them will be able to commute from their homes. As many as a third of the expected visitors are expected to stay with friends and relatives in Atlanta. Atlanta organizers are creating an Olympic housing network for the distant traveler. Ten thousand private homes and 3,000 apartments and condominiums are now in the network, with prices ranging from $150 to $425 a bedroom a night.
As evidence of price gouging by tour operators has surfaced, Atlanta officials have reminded hoteliers of a 1994 Georgia law that allows hotels to charge no more than their 1994 rate plus 5.7 percent for inflation during the Games. Spectators cannot be forced to reserve rooms before and after the Olympics, and the price of the room must be separated from other services in any tour package, according to the law. The fine for excessive rates is $1,000 a room, officials said.
"Despite anything you may have heard or read to the contrary, this Olympic effort in Atlanta is not about how much money can be made," Billy Payne, the chief Olympic organizer, said in a speech last week.

How to order olympic tickets by mail.
* Grab a 44-page ticket brochure from a grocery store or from a Home Depot store.
* Choose up to 16 of 542 available sports sessions. Pick two alternate choices for each session.
* Don't expect tickets to all highly coveted events such as the finals of men's basketball, swimming and women's gymnastics. Make a smorgasbord of choices, say an early round of basketball, a session of track and field and women's softball.
* Apply for some tickets in the higher price categories. If a price category is sold out, lower-priced tickets will be automatically considered.
* Apply by June 30. Your order will be included in a lottery for sessions in which there are more requests than tickets. For an additional six months, mail-order tickets will be sold on a first-come, first-served basis.
* Order tickets by check or with a Visa credit card. Include a $16 service fee with each order. Ticket orders requested by June 30 will be filled in September. Tickets will be mailed next spring.

HEADLINE: Mr. Dole's Assault on Regulations

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, made points last week with government-bashers by pushing a bill through committee that would create regulatory gridlock. Under the guise of making regulators conscious of costs, the bill would gut the ability of Federal agencies to promulgate new health, safety or environmental rules, good or bad. Any hope that the Senate would act as a restraint on House efforts to destroy the regulatory apparatus are diminishing as Mr. Dole presses his Presidential campaign.
Had Mr. Dole sought to bring common sense to Federal rule making, he would instead have started with a bill sponsored by William Roth, Republican of Delaware, which would require regulators to pay attention to costs without scuttling their ability to protect the public. The best hope now is that the Democrats will filibuster the Dole bill or the White House will veto it. 
 True, Mr. Dole can point to some needlessly costly regulations. Owners of toxic waste dumps are required to scrub their sites to the same level of cleanliness whether or not people would ever visit the area. And Federal rules pay more attention to outdoor air pollution than to indoor pollution, which can pose graver, more easily remediable, risks. Studies show that rules on formaldehyde exposure cost industry $80 million for each life saved, yet far more lives could be saved at a fraction of the cost by tightening drinking-water standards.
These examples do not prove, as Republicans claim, that the country spends too much in total on health, safety and environmental regulations. But Government does spend money in the wrong places. Smarter rules could save more lives at less cost.
The reform proposed by Mr. Dole would require regulators to perform elaborately detailed studies to show that proposed rules would likely generate more benefits -- such as lives saved or wetlands preserved -- than costs. Cost-benefit tests, where possible, would push regulators toward rules that do more good than harm. But these tests are difficult to complete. What is the value of clean air over the Grand Canyon? The Dole bill cynically builds in more than 60 steps that the cost-benefit analysis must surmount.
The show-stopper comes in the fact that every one of those needlessly detailed steps is subject to judicial review upon challenge by the regulated industry. Industry could also challenge existing regulations according to the same 60 or more steps -- an indiscriminate assault on environmental and safety rules.
Mr. Roth's bill also missteps by, for example, eliminating rules that agencies fail to review according to deadline. Yet the bill's overall direction is balanced. It would require that regulators identify and, where possible, measure the likely benefits and costs of regulation. That way the public would have an accounting of what will be gained, and at whose expense, if the rule goes forward.
Mr. Roth would rely on peer review to double check that cost-benefit analysis. There is no need for judicial oversight of regulatory minutiae. The Senate has already passed an even better backstop: a 45-day grace period during which Congress could block new regulations that it feared would be excessively costly or ineffective.
Yes, some regulations squander money that could be put to better use improving health and safety somewhere else in the economy. But there is no regulatory crisis. Congress has time to make constructive changes. Mr. Roth points in the right direction. Mr. Dole does not.
