HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Forgo Opportunity to Expand on Recent Commerce-Clause Ruling in Gun Case

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today made a strategic, although perhaps only temporary, retreat from the constitutional battle lines it drew last week in a 5-to-4 decision over the power of Congress to regulate commerce.
Rather than use a new case to elaborate on last week's ruling that Congress lacked authority to ban possession of guns near schools, the Justices re-examined the facts in the new case and ruled unanimously that the Court did not have to address the question it took the case last October to decide: whether the Federal racketeering law applies to a local business that does not serve an interstate market and that has only an incidental effect on interstate commerce. 
 Instead, in a three-page unsigned opinion announced from the bench this morning by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the Court concluded that the business, an Alaskan gold mine, was directly and not incidentally engaged in interstate commerce because it brought equipment and employees to Alaska from other states.
This factual conclusion, treating the small, defunct mine as if it were the General Motors Corporation or any other interstate business, enabled the Court to put off deciding an issue on which the Justices are undoubtedly deeply divided: whether an economic activity that takes place in one state nonetheless "affects" interstate commerce enough to support the exercise of Federal jurisdiction.
The outcome was intriguing because the Court had labored for more than two months on this case only to produce such a minimal opinion. The case was argued on Feb. 27. It is possible that, with tempers still raw from the battle over United States v. Lopez, the gun case, a ruling to which the decision today did not refer, the Justices simply decided to disengage and step back from the issue rather than divert energy needed for other hard cases before the term ends in about two months.
Last week, in Lopez, the Court held that the possession of guns near schools did not affect interstate commerce. In fact, such possession was "in no sense an economic activity" at all, Chief Justice Rehnquist said in the majority opinion that invalidated a 1990 Federal law, the Gun-Free School Zones Act.
The case the Court decided today, United States v. Robertson, No. 94-251, posed the same question in the related but even more provocative context of the widely used Federal racketeering law. To establish a violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, usually known as RICO, the Government must show as an initial matter that the business or "enterprise" accused of being racketeering affects or is engaged in interstate commerce.
Since the Alaskan gold mine in this case was by any definition an economic activity, the Court's expected focus was on how to evaluate its ties, admittedly slight, to the national economy. The case raised, more directly than in the Lopez case, the question of what standard the Court should use to determine an "effect" on interstate commerce.
The mine was opened by a former Federal prosecutor with money he had received from dealing in narcotics. Last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, overturned his racketeering conviction on the ground that "there was no evidence to show that the activities of the mine, or the proceeds therefrom, affected interstate commerce."
Today, the Supreme Court said that "we do not have to consider that point" because the hiring of seven out-of-state employees and the purchase of supplies from Los Angeles showed that the mine was "engaged in commerce." For that reason, the Government was not required to demonstrate that the mine's operations had any particular effect on the interstate economy, the unsigned opinion said.
But it is not unusual for the Court, after struggling over an issue, to then pull back to await further developments in the lower courts.
Three years ago, for example, the Court decided in Lee v. Weisman, a bitterly contested 5-to-4 ruling, that a public-school district violated the Constitution by inviting a clergyman to offer an invocation at a graduation ceremony. The Court then declined to take up a case raising the obvious follow-up question of whether students themselves could offer prayers at graduations. Another case on that issue reached the Court several months ago, and the Justices have yet to decide whether to hear it.
Today, the Court denied review in two criminal appeals that raised Commerce Clause questions related to the decisions last week and today. Both were appeals from convictions under the Federal arson law, which makes it a crime to engage in arson of "any building used in an activity that affects interstate or foreign commerce."
In one case, Ramey v. United States, No. 94-5755, a West Virginia man appealed his conviction for burning a trailer to express his disapproval of the interracial couple who lived there. The Government argued successfully in the lower courts that the trailer's receipt of electricity through an interstate power grid was sufficient to establish its connection to interstate commerce.
The second case, Moore v. United States, No. 94-642, was an arson-for-hire appeal from South Carolina. The lower courts upheld the Federal prosecution on the ground that the house that was burned was connected to interstate gas and telephone lines.
The lower Federal courts are in agreement on this use of the Federal arson law, a fact that was undoubtedly important to the Justices' decision not to take these cases. In addition, the South Carolina house was being marketed for sale in other states and had its mortgage and insurance with out-of-state companies. The Government argued that the case was an unsuitable candidate for review because these factors would have sustained Federal jurisdiction even if the gas lines and telephone connections were found insufficient.
There were also these developments at the Court today.
 
Liquor Advertisements
 The Court agreed to use a Rhode Island case to decide whether the First Amendment permits states to ban the advertising of liquor prices. The case, 44 Liquormart v. Rhode Island, No. 94-1140, will continue the Justices' active examination of commercial speech in the context of alcohol regulations; two weeks ago, the Court declared unconstitutional a Federal law that prohibited brewers from listing the alcohol content of their beer on the label.
Rhode Island, like a dozen other states, prohibits the advertising of liquor prices on the theory that price competition would increase consumption. The state enforces its law strictly, imposing fines for advertisements that use words like "Wow" or "Sale" even when no price is listed.
The law was challenged in a Federal court suit by two liquor stores, one in Johnston, R.I., and another that advertised to Rhode Island customers from over the state line in Massachusetts. The in-state liquor store, 44 Liquormart Inc., had earlier paid a $400 fine for an advertisement in The Providence Journal-Bulletin that did not list prices, but showed pictures of liquor bottles with the words "Thanksgiving Harvest" as well as peanut-shaped forms that contained the word "Wow."
The Federal District Court in Rhode Island declared the law unconstitutional in a 1993 ruling that the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, overturned last year. The appeals court held that because the 21st Amendment, which repealed prohibition, gave the states broad authority to regulate liquor sales, courts should uphold any "reasonable" state regulation.
 
Jesus Portrait
 Without comment, the Court let stand a ruling by a Federal appeals court that a Michigan high school could not constitutionally display a portrait of Jesus in a central corridor outside the principal's office.
The portrait, a copy of a well-known painting by Warner Sallman called "Head of Christ," had hung in the Bloomingdale, Mich., school for 30 years until the school district removed it this spring on the order of Judge Benjamin F. Gibson of Federal District Court in Grand Rapids, Mich.
A high school student, Eric Pensinger, had sued to have the portrait removed before he graduated in 1993. One question for the Justices, had they accepted the school district's appeal, Bloomingdale Public Schools v. Washegesic, No. 94-1383, was whether the plaintiff's graduation made the case moot.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, upheld Judge Gibson's decision last November. In his ruling, Chief Judge Gilbert S. Merritt said that while the portrait would probably not offend most people, "a few see it as a government statement favoring one religious group and downplaying others" and "it is the rights of these few that the Establishment Clause protects." The school district argued in its Supreme Court appeal that the decision "demonstrates an unconstitutionally hostility towards religion."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Distorting Mirrors

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Twice within two weeks, Bill Clinton has fulfilled one of the major duties of any American President: to see clearly a danger to American peace, at home or abroad, to speak in public candor about it, and to start acting to meet it.
And twice Mr. Clinton has found himself denounced by important parts of the American society that is the target of the terrorist danger he sees. 
 In politics and journalism, the President's call to Americans to speak out against armed bigotry is being widely and deliberately twisted and distorted. In business, the automatic reactions to his decision to impose a trade and investment embargo against Iran have been to call it useless or harmful.
When the next bomb is exploded in the next Oklahoma City, or when the U.S. has to decide whether Iran's nuclear plants have to be bombed before they produce weapons or after, these attacks against Mr. Clinton will no longer be important. But, as we wait, they serve as museum-quality specimens of how mean-spirited and suicidal American establishments can be when they really put their minds to it.
After Oklahoma, Mr. Clinton said in several speeches that those Americans who did not agree with fellow citizens who exercised their constitutional rights to spread paranoia at least should use their own right to speak against them. Platitudes -- but important ones, since so few Americans do stand to speak against hate warriors of right or left.
In one speech, Mr. Clinton spoke a few words about some hate-mongering coming by radio, another piece of important obviousness. They pounced -- the commentators, columnists and Democratic and Republican politicians who would not forgive Mr. Clinton if he said that the sun would rise tomorrow.
Some of the fury came from people who found that the shoe fit. But what was startling, and rather disgusting, were the charges, repeated endlessly in the mainstream press and TV, that by daring to mention radio, the President was scapegoating and trying to stifle criticism of the Government.
In politics, members of both parties clucked at Mr. Clinton and assured us that the country would not be taken over by extremist nuts. They are like a doctor who tells a patient he has a painful, spreading disease but probably won't die, so forget it.
As for business, it generally takes the attitude that the U.S. can use the lever of economic power only when it is in its business interests to do so. Last year Mr. Clinton damaged himself badly by bowing to the China-trade lobby and reneging on his pledge to use tariffs as pressure for human interests in China and Tibet.
So the business reaction to the Iran embargo was perfect knee-jerk -- it will do no good because Iran will sell its oil elsewhere when American companies stop buying their current share of about 30 percent. The truth is that the embargo is of major importance.
It weakens foreign confidence in Iran as an investment market and strengthens the domestic opponents of the increasingly unpopular regime.
Used properly by Washington, it will be notice to our allies that they can expect American economic pressure to back off from trading with a terrorist, nuclear-bent Iran. Representative Peter King, Republican of New York, says he will ask Congress to add on a boycott of foreign companies that do business with Iran. That should focus the attention of our allies on whether they prefer to do business with Iran or America.
Most important to American ethics, the embargo will end the contribution of American capitalism to Iran's drive to become a military nuclear power within 5 to 10 years, with Russian and Chinese help.
So the embargo should strengthen Mr. Clinton when he delivers the critical message to Mr. Yeltsin: The Russian decision to build a nuclear plant for Iran is a danger that the U.S. cannot tolerate.
The Clinton people naturally do not wish to push Mr. Yeltsin to the advantage of his Russian enemies. But that is not as great a danger as allowing Russia to sell Iran the power of nuclear blackmail or nuclear terrorism.
Bill Clinton has started the work of engaging with domestic and foreign terrorism, with allies abroad or without them. That's the story, and a lot more important than the distorting mirrors being held up to that work, so cynically, so destructively.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Wheat Prices Rise on Prediction Of China Deal, Later Confirmed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Wheat prices rose yesterday after the Agriculture Secretary predicted that the United State would approve a new wheat export package for China this week.
After the market closed, the Agriculture Department announced the deal, which allows China to purchase an additional one million tons of wheat at subsidized prices from the United States in the coming months. 
 Copper prices fell to a six-month low. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 1.34 point, to 236.64.
Wheat prices gained after the Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman, told reporters on Friday that he saw a "favorable, positive announcement" on a third package of wheat for China.
Yesterday, the Agriculture Department said China might make subsidized wheat purchases until June 30 under the Export Enhancement Program. China has already purchased more than four million metric tons of United States wheat, about 12 percent of all wheat exports since the marketing year began July 1.
Wheat for July delivery rose 7.75 cents, to $3.5875 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. On the Kansas City Board of Trade, wheat rose 8.25 cents, to $3.6275 a bushel.
The Kansas City and Chicago contracts are for the winter wheat crops that were planted last fall and will be harvested later this spring.
Spring wheat futures rose after heavy rain in the Midwest delayed planting and raised concern that this year's crop could suffer if it is planted too late in the season.
"It's cold, it's wet, and it's just been continual drizzling rain," said Mike Palmerino, senior meteorologist with the Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass. "That's delaying them from getting the spring crops planted."
Spring wheat for July delivery rose 9.50 cents to settle at $3.6950 a bushel on the Minneapolis Grain Exchange.
Copper prices fell to a six-month low amid expectations that manufacturers would use less of the metal as the economy slows down.
While recent economic indicators have given mixed signals about the pace of manufacturing activity, an unmistakable slowdown in the automotive and housing industries has weakened demand for copper, traders said.
"I'd say it is the auto and housing industries that are doing it to the market," said Bernie Schilberg, executive vice president with Schilberg Integrated Metals in Willimantic, Conn.
Copper for July delivery dropped 1.9 cents, to $1.252 a pound on the Commodity Exchange of New York, its lowest price since Nov. 11.

HEADLINE: John C. Bennett, a Theologian Of Outspoken Views, Dies at 92

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
The Rev. John C. Bennett, a theologian whose views on religion, politics and social policy influenced American thinking for decades, died on Thursday at a retirement community in Claremont, Calif. He was 92.
From 1963 to 1970, Mr. Bennett served as the 11th president of Union Theological Seminary in New York City. 
 "He was an early supporter of feminism, an ardent champion of the civil rights movement, an eloquent critic of U.S. involvement in Vietnam, a prophetic supporter of economic rights for minorities," the Rev. Holland L. Hendrix, current president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday. "All this far in advance of the popularity of these movements."
Mr. Bennett was a key figure in the ecumenical, or Christian unity, movement. He also made a lifelong study of Communism and repeatedly warned against turning the cold war into a religious crusade. By doing so, he said in 1960, "we make impossible the tolerance and humaneness which must yet come into international relations if there is to be a future for mankind."
Widely regarded as a quick, precise speaker and skilled debater, he dismissed the notion that his outspokenness was a violation of the separation of church and state. "Church-state relations in the United States have never meant that churchmen should separate their Christian ethics from political action," Mr. Bennett said in 1966.
That was a time in which he was growing increasingly disturbed about American involvement in Southeast Asia, so much so that he and Rabbi Abraham Heschel formed Clergy and Laity Concerned About the Vietnam War. But Mr. Bennett, ordained in the Congregational Church, was never a pacifist-above-all: in 1941, he opposed American isolationism in the face of Nazi conquests and was a co-founder with Reinhold Niebuhr of the magazine Christianity and Crisis.
John Coleman Bennett was born in Kingston, Ontario, the son of a Presbyterian minister. He studied at Phillips Exeter Academy and Williams College and did graduate studies at Oxford University in England and at Union Theological Seminary.
Though he was commonly referred to as "Dr. Bennett" because of his many honorary degrees ("five in one week from Catholic institutions," Dr. Hendrix recalled yesterday), Mr. Bennett never received a doctorate. He held various religious and teaching posts, joining the faculty of Union Theological Seminary, an interdenominational institution in Morningside Heights, in 1943. He became dean of the faculty in 1955 and was acting president for a brief time before assuming the presidency.
In 1966, Mr. Bennett was instrumental in forging an agreement between the seminary and Fordham University to pool professors, credits and library resources for religious studies. The agreement was believed to be the first contractual sharing of graduate resources in theology between a Protestant and Catholic institution.
In 1970, Mr. Bennett was one of three theologians invited by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to testify on the war in Southeast Asia. "More than any other theologian or moralist," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota said shortly afterward, "John Bennett knows how to put issues into historical, legal and moral contexts which allow thinking politicians to make sound judgments."
Mr. Bennett's principal books were "Christian Ethics and Social Policy," published in 1946; "Christians and the State" (1948), and "Foreign Policy in Christian Perspective" (1966). In retirement, he continued to write and lecture and to condemn nuclear warfare.
Mr. Bennett's wife, Ann McGrew Bennett, died in 1986. He is survived by two sons, John, of Claremont, Calif., and William, of Portland, Me., and a daughter, Elizabeth Hemmer of Sacramento, Calif.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Umpires Will Return Tomorrow

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Faced with a thorny problem in Toronto and the escalating problems managers and players were having with replacement umpires, the American and National Leagues reached agreement with major league umpires yesterday, ending their four-month lockout and completing the return to work of everyone who works on the field.
The difference is that major league management has a deal with the umpires, where none exists with the players. 
 Donald Fehr, the players' union leader, said he sent a note to the league presidents, Gene Budig and Len Coleman, and Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, congratulating them on their five-year agreement and "asking that they send us whatever magic potion they had; we'll see if it comes in the mail."
The umpires will return to work tomorrow with an agreement that will pay them 100 percent of their salaries for this season, even though they will have missed the first week and the season will be only 144 games instead of the usual 162.
"The umpires were neither penalized for the players' strike nor for the owners' lockout of the umpires," Phillips said after a news conference at a Manhattan law office. "That was critical as far as I was concerned to getting the deal done."
Under the terms of the new deal, the umpires' pay scale, which had ranged from $60,000 to $175,000 for those with 25 years in the majors, will range from $75,000 to $225,000 for umpires with 30 years in the majors. But that increase is not their only economic benefit.
All junior umpires will receive the same post-season bonus, $20,000, that all senior umpires have received, instead of the $10,000 that they had been getting. Pay for World Series umpires will rise from $5,000 to $17,500, and those who work the league championship series will get $15,000, instead of $5,000. The new division series will pay each umpire who works one $12,500. All-Star Game pay was doubled to $5,000.
Umpires will be able to work a division series and the World Series, meaning a possible post-season work pay of $30,000, instead of $5,000.
Management said that the overall economic increase for the five years was 16 percent, but individually, umpires could do much better. For example, Harry Wendelstedt, the only 30-year umpire in the majors, can earn a maximum of $282,500, instead of $206,000, a 37 percent increase. A rookie umpire, who always begins in the second year of the pay scale, can earn a maximum of $100,000, instead of $75,000, a 33 percent increase.
The leagues had been expected to maintain the lockout much longer than one week into the season, but once the Ontario Labor Board ruled last Friday that replacement umpires could not work games in Toronto, the pace of negotiations picked up considerably.
Not lost on the negotiators either were the very visible arguments managers and players were having with the replacements. Two runner-interference calls Sunday that resulted in the ejections of Managers Joe Torre of St. Louis and Tommy Lasorda of Los Angeles were particularly noticeable.
"I don't want to say the Toronto decision itself triggered the agreement or the performance of the scabs triggered it," Phillips said. "But I'd have to say those two factors were substantially contributory to the fact that the pace accelerated and we were able to get a deal."
Management representatives did not acknowledge that the replacement umpires or the Toronto decision had an impact on the talks or their negotiating position.
Coleman, the National League president, and Budig, the American League presidents, spoke only in positive terms of what it meant to have the dispute ended. Robert Kheel, the leagues' negotiator, spoke of the intensity of negotiations throughout the weekend.
Kheel said he and Phillips spoke by telephone Friday, Saturday and early Sunday, then met in his office beginning at about 8 o'clock Sunday evening. They reached a fundamental agreement, he said, by 3 A.M. yesterday, with some details still to be worked out.
The union's board of directors held two meetings via conference call, one at about 3 A.M., the other at 5:30 A.M. The board approved the agreement by a 9-0 vote, Phillips said. However, not all of the umpires approved it. Phillips said 3 umpires among the first 45 they called voted against the agreement.
Jerry Crawford, the umpires association president and a National League umpire, said the returning umpires expected to hear the typically negative reaction from fans and to have arguments with players.
"I'll be thrilled when I hear them boo because I'll feel right at home," he said of the fans.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Boycott of Iran by U.S. Appears Unlikely to Succeed

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 1

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's trade boycott of Iran appeared today to be unlikely to succeed. Washington is not expected to be able to persuade Japan to follow suit and ban its oil companies from trading with Iran, industry executives said.
Nor are European countries expected to back the Administration's initiative, which came in reaction to attempts by Iran to develop nuclear weapons and its support for terrorism. Britain, for example, said today that it would impose no such restrictions on its oil companies. 
 For consumers, most experts interviewed today suggested that no oil crisis was looming, and the embargo was likely to fall short of the United States aim of choking off Iran's revenues.
Nevertheless, oil prices rose moderately on world markets in response to the United States action. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil in the June futures contract closed up 12 cents at $20.50 a barrel after soaring to $20.80, the highest since last August. Oil prices have gained $3 a barrel over the last six weeks amid tightening world supplies. June unleaded gasoline gained 0.76 cent, to 64.15 cents a gallon.
But Japanese oil industry officials said the United States was unlikely to persuade Japan to suspend daily purchases of 600,000 barrels of Iranian oil, although Washington has already made such a request.
If Japan were to join the boycott of Iranian oil, nearly 40 percent of Iran's oil exports of 2.5 million barrels a day would be blocked out of world markets, energy experts in Europe estimate.
A prolonged action would deprive Teheran of a third of its annual hard-currency revenues, close to $4 billion, which would be a painful blow to an Iranian economy that is already in the throes of fierce inflation and economic depression.
But absent the unlikely event that the Japanese would join the boycott and that European companies would agree not to replace American oil buyers, oil industry experts say that the chief effects of the Administration policy will be to create more hardships for United States businesses, as the places they can work in the Middle East are diminishing.
"The use of oil as a weapon is costly -- it can cut both ways," Nordine Ait-Laoussine, a former oil mininster of Algeria, said in a telephone interview today. "At the moment it is American oil companies who cannot work in Libya, or Iraq or Iran." But companies from other countries are working there. "and Iran will discount its oil to sell it." he added.
Still, given the precarious balance between oil supplies and consumption, prices could rise further as a result of the Administration's ban.
American companies have been barred from buying oil from Libya since 1986 and from Iraq since 1990. Further, Russian production has dropped steadily in the last four years to six million barrels a day at present from 12 million barrels a day in 1991.
"There is a limit to how much oil you can keep out of the market without pushing prices up," said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in Manhattan, in a telephone interview. "It's like a Catch-22 situation. The more successful U.S. policy is, the price of oil is likely to increase by several dollars."
Iranian oil has been effectively banned from the United States since 1987, but American companies bought $4 billion worth of Iranian crude last year and refined it for sale abroad. The President's ban will halt that.
International oil companies said the overall impact of the American boycott would become clearer after 30 days, when the executive order takes force.
"If the Americans are very, very firm in their pressure, it will create real difficulties for Iran in dealing with third parties, too," said the president of a major oil trading company based in Monte Carlo, which ships a substantial amount of Iranian crude oil. "No one wants to defy America today."
Third parties, like independent oil traders and oil shipping companies, will play a major role, for Iran is expected to try to bypass the boycott and resell oil through them to America and other markets, oil industry experts in Europe said, and consequently the United States might have to put into place a heavy policing apparatus to which Japan and Europe would be unwilling to contribute.
To ease any supply crisis, some Europeans say, the United States will face renewed pressure from Russia, China and France to end United Nations sanctions that ban Iraqi oil sales.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
British investors have concerns, but good profits may allay them.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
JUST before the Federal Reserve reversed course and set American interest rates on an upward path 15 months ago, the London stock market hit a record high. With Britain and the United States at similar stages in the economic cycle, it was not surprising that shares in London, as on Wall Street, then went into a swoon.
Wall Street has since recovered, with the stock market in the last few months surging to new highs on a regular basis. But London, though perkier than it was a year ago, remains well below its highs, afflicted by a variety of worries. Among the market's most immediate concerns are the likelihood of a drubbing for the governing Conservative Party in local elections on Thursday and an increase by the Bank of England in official interest rates by half a point, to 7.25 percent, on Friday. The inflation outlook has not been helped by a sharp decline in the pound against the German mark. 
 Longer term, investors in British stocks remain unconvinced that the Government will be able to keep inflation in check, especially with the Conservatives under intense political pressure to reduce taxes and keep interest rates as low as possible in advance of the next general election, which must be held within two years. Most analysts expect interest rates to keep rising through next year.
On Monday, The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed at 3,220.40, 8.5 percent below its high in February 1994 of 3,520.3 but 12 percent above its low last year of 2,876.6.
The rest of Britain's economic fundamentals have been nearly ignored by the market. Last year's growth of 3.9 percent is expected to moderate to around 3 percent this year and next as higher interest rates act as a brake. The budget deficit and unemployment both continue to decline, and Britain has nearly wiped out its trade deficit on the back of increasing exports.
With the economy cooking along at its best rate in decades, corporate earnings are surging, seemingly giving investors plenty of reason to buy stocks. But the great question facing the London market is whether investors will put aside their other concerns to bet on continued strong industrial performance, giving the market a chance to rally.
"We're pretty positive on the U.K., and principally on the strength of the corporate sector," said Richard Davidson, a strategist at Morgan Stanley in London. "We're going through a period of excellent cash flow, dividend and earnings growth, but they've been largely ignored by a market caught up in worries about inflation and politics, both of which are overdone at this stage."
Mr. Davidson said British companies were enjoying an average of 15 percent profit growth this year, dividend growth of 8 percent and cash flow growth of 10 percent -- all on top of strong gains last year, and with solid prospects in store for the next several years as well.
Moreover, he and other analysts said, next week's likely rate increase and the possibility of even higher rates and increased inflationary pressures are already priced into the market.
To a certain extent, the British markets are suffering from global factors. The flow of money from the United States into international markets has fallen off, and much of what continues is moving into more cyclically sensitive markets in continental Europe to take advantage of strong economic rebounds there.
"The medium-term outlook is healthy without being exciting," said Joe Rooney, a strategist at Lehman Brothers International in London. "With bond markets in the range they're in at the moment and with good earnings and dividend growth continuing to come through, we would see the market moving to 3,400. As we progress through each quarter the trading range will be shifted upward as growth is digested by the market, until we reach a point where there's a shift in long-term interest rates."

HEADLINE: Income, Savings and Spending Rose in March

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
With the aid of farming subsidies, the income of Americans rose more strongly in March than it had in two months, and spending nearly kept pace.
The Commerce Department said today that income climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in March, up slightly from February's increase, while spending rebounded from its first decline in nearly a year, rising by five-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Analysts said the report suggested moderate growth and was a sign that the consumer-driven economic expansion had not run out of steam.
"The consumer is still alive and well and certainly not going into a shell," Robert Dederick, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said. "The consumer isn't shutting off the spending valve entirely. It's encouraging as we head into the second quarter."
Americans are also saving at a higher rate than in more than two years, and that could signal more spending ahead.
In another report, the Commerce Department said weakness in housing brought March construction spending to its lowest level in four months. Construction spending dropped four-tenths of 1 percent, marking the first time in nearly three years that it has fallen in three straight months.
Also, the ability of a typical American family to buy an existing home dipped in the first quarter as mortgage rates hit a recent peak, the National Association of Realtors said.
In another sign of an economic slowdown, the National Association of Purchasing Management said American manufacturing grew modestly in April, and price increases for materials eased considerably. The group's closely watched index has advanced steadily during the last 20 months, but the rate of growth has slipped this year.
That is in line with a Government report issue on Friday that its broadest gauge of economic activity slowed dramatically in the first three months of this year. The gross domestic product rose 2.8 percent at an annual rate, a little more than half the growth rate of the fourth quarter last year, which was 5.1 percent.
The Commerce Department reported today a revised spending figure for February to show a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent, in contrast to a previously estimated rise of one-tenth of 1 percent. The February spending decline was the first since April 1994.
Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, has tailed off since last year's spree.
"We assume that second-quarter spending will be a bit stronger, but April was probably about flat," economists for Merrill Lynch & Company said in a statement.
Analysts credit the slowdown at least in part to the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates seven times in the 12 months ended Feb. 1.
The March increase in personal income made it the fourth straight gain after being unchanged in November. The last time income rose more rapidly was in January, when it climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent. Farm subsidies in March and auto industry bonuses the month before helped inflate the total.
Private wages and salaries, the most closely watched component of income, increased just two-tenths of 1 percent in March and four-tenths of 1 percent in February. Disposable income -- income after taxes -- climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in March after gaining five-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
The combination of incomes and spending meant that the savings rate of Americans -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- rose to 5.5 percent in March from 5.4 percent the previous month. The savings rate is the highest since December 1992, when it was 8.3 percent.
The income and spending figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, disposable incomes and spending both rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Income rose to just under $6 trillion in March and spending was at $4.79 trillion.

HEADLINE: Cy Endfield, 80; Blacklisted Director

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 1

 BODY:
Cy Endfield, a director who was blacklisted in the United States before moving to Britain and filming the bloody epic "Zulu," died on April 16 at his home in Shipston-on-Stour, Warwickshire, England. He was 80.
Mr. Endfield was born in Scranton, Pa., and studied at Yale University before trying his hand at theater in New York City and Montreal. In 1940, he went to Hollywood. His first film was "Inflation," a 15-minute piece commissioned by the Office of War Information but rejected on grounds that it was anti-capitalist. 
 After serving in the Army in World War II, Mr. Endfield wrote for radio and television while working on a series of low-budget features. A recurring left-wing slant to his movies drew the attention of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, which in 1951 put him on the Hollywood blacklist.
Mr. Endfield moved to Britain, and worked anonymously to avoid distribution problems in the United States. The first film to carry his real name again was "Hell Drivers" (1958), a violent thriller starring Stanley Baker.
Mr. Endfield made 21 films in all. The best known was "Zulu" (1964), based on a battle between British soldiers and the Zulu army in South Africa in 1879.
This big-budget epic featured Mr. Baker and Michael Caine as two rival army officers forced by the battle to work together, and it set the relatively unknown Mr. Caine on the path to stardom.
Mr. Endfield's other movies included the fantasy "Mysterious Island" (1961) and "Sands of the Kalahari" (1965), starring Susannah York.
He is survived by his wife, Maureen, and two daughters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Billions Suffering Needlessly, Study Says

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In spite of a few notable health gains, billions of people worldwide suffer needlessly from disease and preventable illnesses because of poverty and a lack of access to health services, the World Health Organization said today.
In its first annual survey of global health, the organization said that more than two billion people, about 40 percent of the world's population, suffered varying degrees of sickness at any one time. Much of this disease and illness, the report said, is preventable and tied to widening gaps in health, education and access to care between the rich and the poor. 
 Officials said poverty was the greatest underlying cause of disease, suffering and death, with more than one-fifth of the world's 5.6 billion people living under conditions that provide little or no resources for preventing or treating their illnesses. More than half the world's people cannot get the most essential drugs and about a third of the world's children are undernourished, the organization said.
The report, released simultaneously in Geneva at the 48th World Health Assembly and at a briefing here, noted that life expectancy around the world had increased to 65 years from 61 years in the last 25 years. In other promising news, infant mortality has fallen by 25 percent in the last 15 years and polio has been eradicated in the Western Hemisphere in the last three years. But such gains could easily be reversed, officials said.
"For many millions of people for whom survival is a daily battle, the prospect of a longer life may seem more like a punishment than a prize," Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, the W.H.O. Director General, said.
Dr. David Brandling-Bennett, deputy director of the Pan-American Health Organization, part of the world health agency, said in an interview that increased life expectancy through past health gains was now presenting new problems.
"The millions of lives that have been saved and the better chance of survival have led to an increase in the number of older persons throughout the world, many of whom develop heart disease, diabetes, cancer and other chronic diseases," he said. "Unfortunately, developing countries are poorly equipped to deal with these new diseases."
Dr. Brandling-Bennett said the new annual health survey would be used as a benchmark against which to gauge future progess against the world's ills. He said international efforts were under way to eradicate polio, measles and tropical guinea worm disease by the year 2000, as well as eliminate leprosy and childhood tetanus.
The report said life expectancy and the health conditions related to it were closely linked to poverty and each country's per capita gross national product, with the poorest countries having almost half the life expectancy of the richest. Life expectancy has reached 78 years in Japan, Iceland and Sweden and 76 in the United States. But the survey said it was only 43 in Uganda and would probably decrease there and in the Ivory Coast, the Central African Republic, Congo and Zambia over the next few years because of little money to spend on health.
The report said ischemic heart disease, caused by obstructed blood vessels, was the deadliest disease in the world, killing 4.3 million people in 1993. The next deadliest is acute lower respiratory infections, mainly pneumonia, in children under 5. The infections killed 4.1 million people in 1993, the latest year for which data are available.
The next greatest killers are cerebrovascular disease, including stroke, which killed 3.9 million people in 1993; diarrhea in children under 5, which killed 3 million; chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, 2.9 million; tuberculosis, 2.7 million; malaria, 2 million; measles, 1.2 million and heart failure and other cardiac diseases, 1.1 million.
Big health challenges for the world include AIDS, other sexually transmitted diseases and tuberculosis, the report said.
More than 13 million adults were infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, in 1994 and another 6,000 people are added to the list each day, the report said. By the year 2000, the cumulative worldwide total of infection by H.I.V. could reach 30 million to 40 million, with 10 million developing AIDS by that time, it said.
Other sexually transmitted diseases are rising, with 250 million new cases reported each year and particularly afflicting people 20 to 24 years old. Rates of these diseases are rising worldwide, even in developing countries, reflecting among the young a lack of education and the means of protecting themselves, officials said.

HEADLINE: Times Mirror Goes Outside For New Chief

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company, the media conglomerate that publishes The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, made a surprise announcement this evening that it had named Mark H. Willes, the vice chairman of General Mills Inc., its next president and chief executive.
The appointment of Mr. Willes was remarkable for several reasons. He has no prior experience in the media business and has not been well acquainted with the Chandler family, which still controls Times Mirror. Within the tightly knit newspaper world, a top position is rarely filled by an outsider. 
 In addition, there had been a competition for the top job between two executive vice presidents of the company. It was expected that one of them would be chosen.
Times Mirror, which is based here, is one of the country's pre-eminent media groups. But it is struggling like many of its rivals to find its place in the burgeoning world of electronic media and decided that it needed a financial expert at the top.
Curtis A. Hessler, who is an executive vice president in charge of Times Mirror's electronic media operations, and Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, were regarded as the front-runners to succeed Robert F. Erburu, who will reach the mandatory retirement age of 65 later this year. Now the two executives have been passed over, which is raising concerns within the company that one or both might ultimately leave.
The company had planned to introduce Mr. Willes, who is 53, at its annual meeting on Tuesday, but it rushed out the announcement this evening as word of the appointment spread. He will become president and chief executive on June 1, and will assume the additional title of chairman on June 1, 1996, according to the company's announcement.
Mr. Willes spent 15 years with Minneapolis-based General Mills, the $8 billion consumer products company known for its breakfast cereals and other prepared foods.
"He brings a strong focus on financial performance, marketing excellence and quality," Mr. Erburu said in the statement.
Referring to Mr. Willes's previous service with the Federal Reserve, Mr. Erburu said, "His broad interests and prior public service career will enhance his leadership of a major media company." Mr. Willes became president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis at the age of 35, serving from 1977 to 1980. He was with the Federal Reserve system for 11 years.
Mr. Willes, a native of Salt Lake City, received his bachelor's degree from Columbia College, New York, and a Ph.D. from the Columbia Graduate School of Business in 1967.
He will enter the company at a critical time. While Times Mirror is a powerful force in Southern California, it was hurt by the region's weak economy of recent years.
Times Mirror separated its substantial cable television interests from the publishing operations last year by combining the cable holdings with those of Cox Communications in a $2.3 billion deal. Times Mirror had revenue of $3.35 billion last year.

HEADLINE: Washington Approves Pequot Annexing of Land

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 1

 BODY:
Federal authorities said today that the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe in Ledyard, owner of the Foxwoods Casino, can legally annex into its reservation 247 acres of undeveloped land adjacent to the casino, thus removing the property from local control and taxation.
The decision, announced late in the day by the United States Department of the Interior, was immediately condemned by local officials in the communities around the casino and by Connecticut's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, who said he would appeal the decision. 
 The Mayor of Ledyard, Joseph A. Lozier, said that local opposition to the annexation, which has raged in the southeast corner of the state since the tribe filed its application in 1993, was partly about taxes and zoning, but also about power.
The Pequots, a tiny tribe of less than 400 people, have purchased thousands of acres of land in Connecticut, and announced ambitious economic development plans ranging from a theme park to high-technology manufacturing using the proceeds of their gambling and hotel businesses. Specific plans for the 247-acre site are unclear, however. Tribe offices were closed for the day when the decision was announced.
A statement issued by the counsel to the Interior Department, John J. Duffy, also left a number of jurisdictional questions unanswered. The statement said that the towns around the casino "will not lose any tax revenue from this decision" because the Pequots had agreed to make voluntary payments in lieu of taxes, and that the land could not be further developed by the tribe without further Federal approval, including an environmental review.
Mr. Blumenthal said he doubted that those rules could legally be imposed. Once lands are designated Federal trust property for use by an Indian tribe, Mr. Blumenthal said, all development decisions are up to the tribe.

HEADLINE: Councilman Feels Fallout Over His Changed Stand

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Life on New York's City Council rarely affords any of its 51 members a chance to break from the pack and establish a political reputation that extends beyond the legislator's own district.
Last week, Guillermo Linares did just that. And he's been paying the price ever since. 
 In the days since Mr. Linares switched sides and cast the deciding vote in favor of a controversial plan for a huge Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, the Hispanic Councilman from Washington Heights has been the target of harsh attacks from many of his constituents.
Although he has been lauded by some elected officials who say he acted on conscience, many critics feel he forsook the very merchants in his heavily Dominican district whose cause he has championed in his five years in office.
Those holding that view were very much in evidence yesterday at an angry press conference held on the steps of City Hall by owners of small businesses and bodegas. They gathered as much to condemn the plans to build the $12 million supermarket as to assail the 44-year-old Mr. Linares as a "traitor," "back-stabber" and "sellout." Others protested outside his Washington Heights office yesterday.
The vote last week of the Manhattan Borough Board, which is composed largely of the City Council members from Manhattan, was considered the most crucial step in getting the Pathmark project under way.
Before Mr. Linares changed his mind, opponents predicted confidently that they had the votes to kill a project that had caused deep divisions between Hispanic residents of East Harlem and their black neighbors. The ethnic makeup of Mr. Linares's Washington Heights district is 44 percent Hispanic, 33 percent non-Hispanic white and 23 percent black.
Until now, Mr. Linares, New York's first Dominican-American elected official, has been widely heralded as a fresh voice of the emerging Dominican community in New York. He has been hailed as a healer and peacemaker, taking to the streets to calm unrest after he fatal shooting in 1992 of Jose Luis Garcia by a police officer in Washington Heights.
Now, being the subject of such bitter protest and anger -- most strongly by some Hispanic officials and bodega owners -- has been particularly wrenching for Mr. Linares.
"This has been a very, very intense period for me," he said, in an interview yesterday. "I knew, as I made this decision, that people would react very strongly because their expectations would not come through. But I had to make the decision that I thought was in the best interest of everyone."
A soft-spoken man who speaks in slow, deliberate cadences, Mr. Linares said he feels at peace with his decision, through he acknowledges it may have cost him political support and even some friendships.
In addition, he and Council officials say he has received some threats. "I'm not going to walk down the street alone right now," he said in an interview.
Plans for the store have been the subject of intense political, ethnic and business feuding in recent months. Opponents, many of them Hispanic, insisted that the huge store would drive small neighborhood shops out of business, and they criticized the government subsidies called for in the plan. But the proponents, most of them black, said the new store would create jobs and finally bring the selection and low prices of a supermarket to a minority neighborhood.
Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Councilwoman from the Upper West Side of Manhattan and a supporter of the Pathmark project, called Mr. Linares' vote "sensible" and said he "was genuinely concerned about the future of economic development in distressed areas." She added, "He believed if this market was defeated, it would jeopardize future development."
But Antonio Pagan, a Councilman from Manhattan's Lower East Side, said he worked for months with Mr. Linares on a strategy to defeat the Pathmark project. "He is a man with no word, a sellout," Mr. Pagan said. "He is a someone who betrays and lies to his colleagues. He has violated one of the principal rules of Latino social conduct: that your word is gold or you have no soul. It was not an act of courage. It was an act of cowardice."
Others contend that Mr. Linares must have been offered some compelling inducement to change his mind.
"Everybody who knows him was surprised," said Alfredo Rodriguez, the owner of two Associated Food Stores in East Harlem and a longtime friend who had worked with Mr. Linares to attempt to defeat the Pathmark plan. "I just don't understand it."
Mr. Linares said he was persuaded just hours before the vote that if the project was shelved it would choke off, for years, plans for any future economic development either in East Harlem or any other depressed area in New York City.
"The killing of a project like this sends the worst message you would want," Mr. Linares said. "All along, this was difficult for me because I recognized the importance of the bodegas in our communities. But that should not impede opportunities for job creation."
It is impossible to determine how lasting the political impact will be. But many storeowners said that they had been financial supporters of Mr. Linares in his past campaigns and that they will never contribute again.
Reflecting on his vote, Mr. Linares said yesterday that "the only anguish I have is that there were friends that were involved in this with me and that they probably feel that I did not really come through for them. But I'm very, very firm that I did the appropriate thing."
Then he added: "I do what I think is right. Then I live with the consequences."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Grace Names New Chief, But Questions Remain
The board of W. R. Grace elected a former chairman and chief executive of American Cyanamid, Albert J. Costello, to succeed J. P. Bolduc, the Grace chief executive who resigned after a vicious struggle.
But analysts suggested that Mr. Costello's election may have raised more questions than it answered and that the extraordinary events that have shaken Grace in the last two months may not be resolved. Wall Street was not cheered by the news, pushing Grace shares down $1.375, to $52.25. D4.
 
$6 Billion Utility Merger Planned
Two big Midwestern utilities, Northern States Power, Minneapolis, and Wisconsin Energy, Milwaukee, announced plans for a $6 billion merger. Their aim is to become leaner in readiness for tough competition ahead. D2.
 
Roche Delays Genentech Purchase
Roche will not exercise its option to acquire the rest of Genentech by a June 30 deadline, but has extended the purchase option four years. News of the postponement sent Genentech stock down $2.50, to $47.875. As part of the new agreement, Roche will acquire worldwide marketing rights outside the United States to Genentech's existing drugs, as well as any drugs in development. In return, Roche will share development costs and pay Genentech royalties on sales. D4.
 
Mobil Reducing Work Force
Mobil said it would lay off 4,700 workers, or more than 9 percent of its work force, by the first quarter of 1996, which it said would allow pre-tax savings of $1 billion a year. Mobil's stock rose $3.875, to $98.75. D4.
 
Others Urged to Join Iran Boycott
Warren Christopher called on United States' allies to punish Iran with economic sanctions of their own and called Iran an "outlaw state" that had spent hundreds of millions of dollars a year on terrorism. A6.
 
The success of a trade boycott against Iran appears in doubt, for Washington would need to persuade Japan to ban its oil companies from purchasing Iranian oil as well. D5.
 
Oil service companies are likely to bear the brunt of the export ban, with a loss of some 3,000 jobs anticipated. Corn and rice exporters also face losses. D5.
 
Income and Spending Rise
With the aid of farming subsidies, incomes rose more strongly in March than they had in two months, climbing six-tenths of 1 percent. Spending rose five-tenths of 1 percent. D2.
 
Newspaper Circulation Drops
Nine of the 10 largest metropolitan dailies in the country lost weekday circulation, continuing a downward pattern. D8.
 
$10 Million Campaign for Scent
The image of a nude man posed on a star is the centerpiece of an ambitious $10 million campaign by the Lancaster Group USA to introduce Nightflight into the American men's fragrance market. Lancaster describes its scent as fresh and seductive, with elements of pineapple, sandalwood and marzipan. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D9.
 
Ex-Salomon Official Moves to Utility
David Wittig, a former managing director of Salomon Brothers, will become an executive vice president at Western Resources, a Kansas utility, advising its chief executive. D4.
 
Worries Trip London Stocks
The London stock market, though perkier than a year ago, remains well below its highs. Among the market's varied concerns are a predicted drubbing of the governing Conservative Party in local elections on Thursday and an interest-rate increase by the Bank of England. Market Place. D10.

HEADLINE: 2 Big Utilities Plan to Merge In Deal Valued at $6 Billion

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Two large and strong utilities in the Midwest, the Northern States Power Company and the Wisconsin Energy Corporation, said yesterday that they would merge into a new company with a combined market value of about $6 billion.
Analysts said the deal, which could put pressure on other utilities to seek partners, showed how quickly the industry was preparing for an era of fierce competition. 
 The merger would create a new company called the Primergy Corporation, which would be the nation's 10th-largest utility owned by investors. The deal is subject to approval by state and Federal agencies.
Under the merger plan, the shareholders of both utilities would trade their shares for shares in the new company. The current shareholders of Northern States, which is based in Minneapolis, would own about half the new entity, as would the shareholders of Wisconsin Energy, which is based in Milwaukee.
Northern States employs 7,000 people and provides electric power to 1.4 million customers and natural gas for 400,000 clients in Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wisconsin and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. Wisconsin Energy, with 5,000 employees, provides electric power to 945,000 customers and natural gas to 350,000 client in areas of Wisconsin and the Upper Peninsula.
Analysts said the utilities, which offer low-cost power and have reduced staff, would cut more jobs and become even stronger as a single company. The utilities said they expected to achieve savings of about $2 billion over 10 years.
The merger would leave the companies in a strong position to defend their turf and perhaps raid that of other utilities when deregulation took hold, analysts said.
Some states, including California, are considering allowing customers to bypass their local utilities and buy power directly from outsiders. Large industrial customers across the country have already received reductions in rates from their current utilities and want to be able to buy inexpensive power from outside sources. And the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is considering making the nation's power transmission system more accessible to independent producers.
In the Primergy deal, Northern States and Wisconsin Energy would keep their headquarters and operate under their current names. The holding company would be based in Minneapolis.
The shareholders of Northern States would get 1.626 shares of the new company for each current share, while the holders of Wisconsin Energy would get one share of Primergy for each current share.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Northern States rose $1, to $45.25, and those of Wisconsin Energy rose 75 cents, to $28.50.
"This merger gets us in front of the changing energy marketplace," said Richard A. Abdoo, the chairman, president and chief executive of Wisconsin Energy.
Mr. Abdoo, who is 51, will become vice chairman of the new company when it is formed and chief executive in 1998.
The chairman, president and chief executive of Northern States, James J. Howard, said the merger would let the companies offer a modest reduction in rates for their retail customers and freeze rates for customers through 2000.
"By doing that, we will help our communities attract new business, add jobs and strengthen the economy in our combined service territory," he said.
Mr. Howard, who is 59, will be chairman of the merged company and chief executive until 1998.
By keeping down costs, utilities like Primergy could put more pressure on states with higher-cost power, like California, New York and New Jersey, to allow more access to cheaper electricity. Low-cost companies could also prompt some higher-cost utilities to seek mergers.
Barry Abramson, a Prudential Securities analyst, said that large utilities in the Northeast might eventually have to find merger partners in order to compete, but they would have a difficult time doing so because they have high rates and costs.
The merger of Northern States and Wisconsin Energy would form a company with annual revenue of $4.2 billion and assets of more than $10 billion.
Mr. Abramson said that with the new company's annual dividend of $1.62 a share, the shareholders of Northern States would get the same payment level that they receive now, while the holders of Wisconsin Energy would see an increase of about 10 percent in their dividend.
The companies said they expected to complete the deal by the fourth quarter of 1996.

HEADLINE: The Iran Embargo

 BODY:
A United States trade embargo is not a foreign-policy weapon to be casually employed. Whether or not it has a crippling effect on the target country, an embargo is a powerful symbol of Washington's ire, and should be used only against countries that threaten American security and principles. Iran fits that definition.
President Clinton made the right call when he followed his foreign-policy advisers rather than his economic advisers and imposed a complete ban on trade and investment with Teheran. Mr. Clinton acted to punish the Iranian Government's open support for terrorism and its pursuit of nuclear weapons. Besides its continuing death threats against the novelist Salman Rushdie, Teheran has been implicated in the murders of Iranian political figures abroad. Iran is also believed to be behind deadly car bombings from Beirut to Buenos Aires. 
 In addition, American intelligence agencies are convinced that Iran, which sits on more energy resources than its civilian economy will ever need, is pursuing reactor and other nuclear technologies from Russia and China to develop atomic weapons. Curbing international terrorism and nuclear proliferation are rightly among the Clinton Administration's highest foreign-policy priorities.
Until now, European oil-consuming countries and nuclear suppliers like Russia and China have been unwilling to restrain their commerce with Iran. Meanwhile, diplomatic efforts not backed by economic pressure have done little to change Iran's dangerous behavior. Under these circumstances, the United States is justified in acting on its own and encouraging others to follow its example.
The embargo will end purchases of Iranian oil by American companies for resale overseas, which last year amounted to $4 billion, or one-fifth of Iran's oil revenues. American companies were already barred from importing Iranian oil. The President's executive order will also halt remaining United States exports to Iran. By barring the trade of American companies, Washington may have a chance of persuading its allies to apply economic pressures of their own.
The Administration also acted to head off efforts by Senator Alfonse D'Amato to legislate a wider ban that would have attempted to punish foreign companies doing business with Iran. This would needlessly antagonize the same allied governments Washington is trying to persuade to join the embargo.
Imposing sanctions that major allies are likely to ignore always runs the risk of cheapening the credibility of sanctions in general. But the dangers from Iran are sufficiently great to override this risk. The Administration should now strengthen the case for other countries to join the embargo by spelling out the minimal steps Iran must take to get the sanctions lifted.
Over the past 28 months the Clinton Administration has been extremely reluctant to impose international trade penalties for political purposes. Iran's support for terrorism and drive for nuclear weapons make it an appropriate exception.

HEADLINE: REBEL SERBS SHELL CROATIAN CAPITAL

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, May 2

 BODY:
Rebel Serbs attacked the Croatian capital today, firing rockets that slammed into a central square here and spread death and mayhem among people strolling in the warm spring air.
The city authorities said five people were killed and 121 were hurt when three rocket-propelled cluster bombs hit the downtown area and another six hit the southern outskirts near the Zagreb airport. The United States Ambassador, Peter Galbraith, confirmed that rockets tipped with shrapnel-spraying cluster bombs had caused the damage. One landed about 100 yards from his Embassy. 
 The rocket attack, which shook buildings throughout the center of the city, came in response to an offensive begun yesterday by the Croatian Government that today captured most of a pocket of land held by separatist Serbs in western Slavonia, about 75 miles southeast of the capital.
The Croatian attack the day before shattered a "permanent cease-fire" signed last year by Croatia and the rebel Serbs, who went to war in 1991 to resist joining a newly independent Croatia that they perceived as threatening. The pocket represents a small part of the 30 percent of Croatia controlled by Serbs since the 1991 war.
The Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, announced today that the offensive ended after the surrender of Okucani, a town where many of the 13,000 separatist Serbs in the enclave live. "The action of the Croatian police and army is closed," he said.
But it appeared more likely that the ramifications of Croatia's flagrant violation of the cease-fire, in the largest offensive since 1991, were just beginning to unfold.
While he seems to have secured a significant, if small, military victory and demonstrated that the Croatian Army is growing stronger, President Tudjman has angered the United Nations and set back negotiations with the Serbs to the point where it will be difficult to revive them.
The Serbs made their anger abundantly clear in the rocket attack today. The charred wreckage of several cars could be seen smoldering shortly after one rocket hit central Strossmayer Square. Windows along the square were smashed, sidewalks were littered with rocket fragments and sirens pierced the air as ambulances responded.
The abrupt, direct impact of a war more often seen on television screens in the Croatian capital appeared to stun a city whose growing number of new cars and boutiques have given it an increasingly western European feel.
Police officers cordoned off a wide area and the city authorities closed schools for 48 hours. An eerie silence descended for several hours on central streets amid apparent incredulity that rockets could fall out of a clear blue sky on a European city of one million people. One rocket hit a school near the Defense Ministry, and several children were injured.
While Bosnia's capital has been devastated by three years of fighting and Serbia's has been squeezed by international sanctions, Zagreb had become a relative oasis from the physical misery of the Balkan conflict. This normally secure city is used by the United Nations, foreign diplomats and others as the main access point for relief, peacekeeping and mediation missions in the region.
It was the Croatian capital's first taste of real war since it was bombarded by the Yugoslav Air Force in 1991.
"Sending a rocket full of cluster bombs into a European capital is a repugnant act clearly intended to kill many people," Mr. Galbraith said. "It's an act that can only be intended to provoke a full-scale war." But he added that the United States had warned Croatia that such attacks might occur in response to the Croatian offensive in western Slavonia.
Later in the day, the United States evacuated about 35 people from Zagreb, mostly dependents of American Embassy staff and nonessential personnel.
The Orkan rockets, a type manufactured in the former Yugoslavia, were apparently fired from multiple-rocket launchers from the closest positions held by Serbs, about 25 miles south of the capital near the town of Petrinja.
Prior to the outburst of fighting during the last few days, the Serbs had seemed ready to engage in a slow diplomatic process aimed at settling their differences with Croatia. Those negotiations had secured a measure of economic cooperation, including joint use of an oil pipeline from the Adriatic coast.
The future of the recently revamped United Nations peacekeeping mission to the country now appears in doubt, and the Serbs have made clear through the attack on Zagreb -- and another more limited one on Karlovac -- that their response to the offensive will not be passive.
"There is a great chance that a high price will be paid by Croatia in terms of our overall effort to achieve a peaceful settlement," said Fred Eckhard, the chief United Nations spokesman in Zagreb. Negotiations had been set back by "many, many months," he added.
The United Nations is in the process of cutting its force in Croatia from 12,000 to 8,750. To satisfy Croatia's concerns, the United Nations had committed itself to redeploying some of those soldiers in a way that might prevent the Serbs of Croatia from getting arms from Serbia and Serb-held parts of Bosnia. With the Serbs enraged by the Croatian attack, such a deployment now appears virtually impossible.
Prime Minister John Major said today that Britain would withdraw from the United Nations forces in the former Yugoslavia if the trend toward a wider war in Bosnia and Croatia continues.
The United Nations Security Council issued a statement late on Monday demanding that Croatia "put an end immediately to the military offensive launched by its forces in the area of western Slavonia."
The Security Council also urged the Serbs and Croatia to "comply with the existing cease-fire agreement," suggesting that the Croats should withdraw to the front lines prior to the offensive. Such a withdrawal appears very unlikely, given the huge popular enthusiasm stirred here by the Croatian military success.
Using tanks and MIG-21 fighters acquired despite an arms embargo on all countries of the former Yugoslavia, more than 3,000 Croatian troops stormed into the Serbian enclave in a pincer movement from the east and west early on Monday, apparently meeting scant resistance.
By today, they appeared to have secured the entire length of the E-70 highway that runs through the pocket and was the declared target of the offensive. The Croats also marched into Okucani.
The road was reopened last December as part of the economic accord between Croats and Serbs. A violent incident on the highway last Friday night in which a Serb was stabbed and three Croatian motorists were then killed by gunfire was the immediate catalyst for the raid.
But the capture of the road appears to have been no more than a pretext for the Croats. The taking of Okucani suggested that the real aim was to capture the whole enclave, which bulges into Croatian territory from Serbian-controlled northern Bosnia. The Serbs' control of the enclave has long made it difficult to travel between Zagreb and the important central Croatian industrial city of Slavonksi Brod.
At least 5,000 Serbian refugees poured southward from of the western Slavonia pocket over a bridge on the Sava River into areas of northern Bosnia controlled by Serbs, United Nations officials said. About 600 armed Serbs in the town of Pakrac surrendered after the fall of Okucani. There were also unconfirmed reports of heavy casualties near Okucani.
The fate of Serbs remaining in the enclave was unclear.
President Tudjman promised that "all Croatian citizens of Serbian descent" would be guaranteed full respect of their "human and civil rights" -- something that did not happen when Croatian Government forces massacred Serbs during attacks on Serbian enclaves near the Adriatic coast in 1993.
The President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, condemned the Croatian offensive as "a criminal act against a civilian population and a flagrant attack on comprehensive efforts aimed at establishing peace in the region."
But Mr. Milosevic also condemned the rocket attack on Zagreb by Serbs. "Yugoslavia condemns the bombing of cities and casualties among the civilian population," he said. "The bombing of cities by either side and suffering by the civilian population must be most severely condemned."
Mr. Milosevic, who set in motion the dissolution of Yugoslavia with a brand of aggressive Serbian nationalism that destabilized the former federation, has recently sought to portray himself as a moderate man and a peacemaker. But he has not been prepared to recognize Bosnia or Croatia, despite mounting pressure from Western governments.
The Serbs now appear certain to seek a withdrawal of the Croats to the front lines that prevailed prior to the offensive before any cease-fire is signed. President Tudjman seems equally certain to reject such a request, setting the stage for what may be a tense stalemate, a slow drift toward increased fighting or, perhaps, a rapid plunge into another war.
