HEADLINE: A Bond Fund Strategy Too Clever by Half;
Fidelity Stumbles in an Attempt to Repeat Its Success With Stock Funds

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It has been about a year since Fidelity Investments, the country's biggest and most powerful mutual fund company, announced to the world that it was on the way to becoming as big a force in bond funds as it was in the stock funds that had made it famous.
And Fidelity said it was using the same method that had worked so well in stocks: spend lots of money to hire the best and the brightest money managers, do the most thorough research and use the considerable financial muscle of the company to dominate the markets in which it invests. 
 A year later that plan has ended in disaster. Many of the young managers, along with their boss, have left, been forced out or been reassigned. Thousands of Americans who believed in them and in Fidelity suffered huge losses from Fidelity's heavy bets in Mexico and in the complex securities known as derivatives. Many investors pulled their money -- billions of dollars -- from the company's funds.
Of course, last year was one of the worst ever for almost everyone who owned a bond or bond mutual fund. Lots of fund companies stumbled by betting that interest rates would continue to decline, even after the Federal Reserve started raising rates in February 1994.
But the trouble at Fidelity runs far deeper than just one bad call -- it stems from the aggressive culture of the company, a unit of the FMR Corporation of Boston. Fidelity has always wanted to be the biggest and the best and make money at the same time. And it believed that its expensive approach to stock picking would be easy to transfer to the bond market. So, unlike many of its competitors, the company was willing to scour the most obscure corners of the bond market and take big bets in the hopes of making big hits, the same way it did with stocks.
But as it turned out, the Fidelity case was akin to Ferrari wanting to dominate the market for small sedans -- by building them with the same high-performance engines it puts in its race cars. It may have been an accident waiting to happen.
The Fidelity story also reveals some dirty little secrets that the mutual fund industry, busy selling Americans on the idea of one-stop shopping, would rather investors not know: the very things that make a company good at managing some kinds of investments may make them bad at running others. And the way a fund company is run affects the investments that their customers get.
Fidelity declined to comment yesterday on its bond funds and canceled interviews that were scheduled with a reporter. The company may name a new bond chief as early as today; the president of Fidelity, J. Gary Burkhead, has been managing the fixed-income department since the end of January.
Thomas J. Steffanci, the head of the Fidelity bond business who left in January, would not comment on his strategy or what went wrong at Fidelity, a spokesman said yesterday.
But at a news conference last year trumpeting Fidelity's fixed-income successes, he said, "It is fair to say that we're part of the school that believes that passive management is passe."
Using the arcane language of his trade to hint at what the company was up to, he added, "Over the next decade adding value to fixed-income investing would not come from just making duration bets." In plain English, that meant Fidelity planned to do more than simply bet on the direction of interest rates. In addition, the company and its investors would make money "finding new investment opportunities and identifying harder-to-find market inefficiencies," he said.
That may not sound too startling, but it is far different from what most bond managers do. In general, they try to make their portfolios match a benchmark index of bonds or a sector of the bond market, the yardstick against which their performance is measured. They may put additional small bets on interest rates or hold bigger than average positions in corporate bonds in an effort to do slightly better than their benchmarks. But in general they do not stray very far. But in stock investing, the best way to beat the benchmark is to buy things that are not in it, and that is what Fidelity decided to do in bonds. To that end, it hired two dozen new bond specialists, including analysts who covered obscure little foreign markets and those familiar with the complicated and sometimes risky financial instruments known as derivatives.
"Growth in areas we consider key to our strategy -- global, quantitative techniques and specialized trading -- have been dramatic," Mr. Steffanci said.
Most of Fidelity's competitors focus on macro-economic factors like inflation and interest rates and rarely analyze individual bonds.
By contrast, the portfolio managers at Fidelity evaluated individual companies and securities, often in offbeat places, and played down broad economic trends.
Ralph G. Norton 3d, managing editor of IBC/Donoghue, a company that publishes mutual fund newsletters, said that last November he attended a Fidelity seminar "on international investing and how great South America is." When he asked about potential currency devaluations and other economic problems, he added, "They said, 'We think the companies down there are plenty strong." Several months later Mexico devalued the peso and the market for its stocks and bonds collapsed.
Indeed, Fidelity placed a heavy emphasis on Latin American debt last year. Part of the explanation was the willingness of the company to give a lot of responsibility to young, relatively inexperienced managers. While competitors like Putnam Investments boast of tightly knit teams of managers who work under experienced leaders, Fidelity has encouraged its managers to experiment, using computers that try to think like people and developing funds that tap into trends like skirt lengths and sun spots.
Robert K. Citrone fit that pattern. He joined Fidelity in his 20's, out of business school, with an interest in the debt of emerging markets but without much experience. His enthusiasm proved infectious, and by early 1994 Fidelity owned $7 billion of emerging market debt and was rumored to be the largest lender to Mexico.
And those bets were not limited to clearly risky funds with emerging markets in their names; they also showed up in conservative sounding Fidelity Short-Term Bond and the company's Balanced and Puritan funds.
The Fidelity stock analysts are expected to become strong advocates of investments they like and persuade money managers to buy them. Mr. Steffanci wanted bond managers to do the same, said John Rekenthaler, an editor at Morningstar Inc., which analyzes mutual funds.
"Tom Steffanci was explicit about this early in his tenure -- he said Fidelity had great equity funds, and he wanted to make the bond people like the stock people," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "He wanted them to start staking themselves and pounding on the table."
And there were other similarities. Because it is a big buyer of initial public stock offerings, Fidelity is often able to have deals tailored to its needs. It began to do the same in bonds, buying a lot of derivatives designed for it and even purchasing whole issues of municipal bonds that no one else would buy, based on what Fidelity considered to be its superior research.
As a whole, this approach is anathema to traditional bond fund managers like Ian MacKinnon, who runs the rival bond funds of the Vanguard Group. He said he did not believe that anyone could run a bond fund like a stock fund.
Moreover, he added, there is a danger in placing big bets, in deviating too far from the risk characteristics of the bond market. Companies like Fidelity, he said, "have a willingness to deviate from those risk characteristics, which leads to spectacular returns in some years and ludicrous ones in others."
And that is exactly what happened. After Mr. Steffanci joined Fidelity in 1990 and started implementing his strategy, the company's previously mediocre bond funds started outperforming their peers. In 1993, for example, Fidelity's taxable bond funds beat 76 percent of their competitors and the tax-exempt funds beat 81 percent, the company said.
The fund managers took big risks to get those numbers. For example, a computer analysis by Carpenter Analytical Services in Hanover, N.H., shows that in early 1993 Fidelity's long-term Government-bond fund became sharply riskier than the bond market as a whole.
Last year, however, the tables were turned. Though a few of Fidelity's funds, particularly its convertible bond fund, continued to prosper, many of its largest funds tanked. For example, its short-term bond fund was in the bottom 5 percent and six other funds were in the bottom 30 percent during the last 12 months. The company's international bond funds were hit particularly hard.
As a result, investors pulled about $6 billion from Fidelity's bond funds last year. Total assets in those funds dropped by 23 percent, compared with 13 percent for the rest of the industry.
Fidelity insiders say the management of the company tried to rein in the bond department late last year after things went wrong. In any event, by January both Mr. Steffanci and Mr. Citrone had both left.
Analysts say the company has gotten rid of many of its derivatives investments and Latin American debt, and has adopted a more conservative approach all around.
"I think they've gone back to more plain vanilla," said Eric Kobren, who publishes Fidelity Insight, a newsletter.
But that may leave the company in a bit of a quandary. If it drops or downplays its bond funds, it risks losing customers, including the many companies for which it manages retirement accounts. Yet if it abandons its high-risk, high-performance strategy, the only other way to succeed in bond funds is to keep costs very low. And Fidelity is not a low-cost provider, said Geoff Bobroff, a consultant to the fund industry.
"On the one hand, they want to be able to do research on weird things that no one else is looking at, and add value that way," said Amy Arnott, an analyst for Morningstar. "But they also don't want the problems they ran into last year."

HEADLINE: U.S. Fails to Enlist European Allies in Iranian Trade Embargo

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, May 2

 BODY:
The United States effort to get other countries to join a trade embargo of Iran faltered today when leading European nations rejected the idea, and, in Bonn's latest sally against Washington, a German official called the American initiative wrong.
Japan, too, gave the idea a cool response. Officials in Tokyo said they had received no formal American request for support and, if they did, they would study it seriously. But, reflecting longstanding differences with Washington over Iran, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official indicated that Tokyo preferred dialogue with "what are called moderates in the Iranian Government, so they will be more cooperative." 
 European countries, too, have long differed with Washington over its attitude to Teheran, saying they prefer "critical dialogue" to isolation as a means of curbing Iran's support for international terrorism.
The policy protects widespread efforts to promote trade ties with oil-producing Iran. While Germany, for instance, lists Iran as a "low-level" trade partner, it imports Iranian carpets and oil and sells machinery, electrical goods and chemicals there. And, by Iranian accounts, Germany is Teheran's most important trade partner.
President Clinton announced on Sunday that he would sever all United States trade and investment with Iran, seeking to halt Iranian support for terrorism and to block what Washington calls Iranian efforts to develop nuclear weapons. Secretary of State Warren Christopher urged Washington's allies on Monday to impose their own embargoes.
But a spokesman for the European Union said in Brussels today that the organization was "not going to respond to this initiative" because its policy of "critical dialogue" left each of its 15 members free to conduct relationships with Iran.
The French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, told reporters in Paris, "We do not believe in unilateral embargoes," though he expressed sympathy for American criticism of Iran over human rights and other issues.
Criticism of the American embargo was only the latest in a series of German signs of displeasure with Washington in recent times over other issues, notably the dollar and trade.
Today, the Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, told a German radio station, "We do not believe that a trade embargo is the appropriate instrument for influencing opinion in Iran and bringing about changes there that are in our interests."
"The right thing to do is to conduct a political dialogue with Iran," Mr. Rexrodt said. "Only political dialogue can bring Iran to behave responsibly."
Paradoxically, the American initiative coincides with an attempt by Germany to revive its trade with Iran, which sank in recent years because of Iranian failure to pay debts as its economy stumbled.
In 1992, Germany's trade surplus with Iran stood at some $5 billion, five times the surplus recorded in 1994. In 1992, Iran was Germany's 16th largest export market. Last year it ranked 41st.
Last February, however, the Government drew Israeli and American criticism by re-instituting export guarantees worth some $110 million dollars a year to protect German traders. The export guarantees had been suspended since the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, and, as soon as they were revived, a German Government delegation left for Teheran to discuss debt recycling and the use of the new guarantees.
At the time, German politicians dismissed Washington's criticism of the guarantees, saying the United States had offered no proof that Iran was a sponsor of terrorism.

HEADLINE: Pataki Nominates Regan to Head M.A.C.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 2

 BODY:
Former State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has been nominated by Gov. George E. Pataki to be chairman of New York City's Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Mr. Pataki today called Mr. Regan, a Republican who resigned in 1993 after 14 years as comptroller, "one of New York's foremost municipal finance experts." 
 The selection is subject to confirmation by the State Senate. The post carries no salary and Mr. Regan's term would be for four years, according to a spokesman for the Governor, Christopher Chichester.
Mr. Regan would succeed Eugene J. Keilin, who was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1993 to replace Felix G. Rohatyn. The Municipal Assistance Corporation was set up during New York City's fiscal crisis in the 1970's as a vehicle for the city to borrow money by issuing bonds.
Mr. Regan was elected comptroller in 1978 and re-elected in 1982, 1986 and 1990. He resigned to join the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson. Previously, he had been a Buffalo city councilman and Erie County executive.
Mr. Regan said he supports Mr. Pataki's plans to cut taxes and spending and to "return fiscal sanity to New York."
"The Governor's plan for change should have been undertaken 10 years ago," Mr. Regan said in a shot against Mr. Pataki's Democratic predecessor, Mr. Cuomo.

HEADLINE: Budgetary Matters Intrude On Call for Medicare Unity

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Republican Congressional leaders today invited President Clinton to join them in forging a bipartisan policy to control Medicare costs and keep the program solvent. But they found themselves struggling against White House assertions that their primary motivation was to balance the budget at the expense of the elderly.
At a news conference today, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, asked Mr. Clinton to meet them in the Capitol for a discussion of Medicare and asserted that spending on the health insurance program for the elderly could be separated from the rest of the budget. But they cut the news conference short and walked offstage under a barrage of questions on the relationship between Medicare spending and their plans to balance the budget while cutting taxes. 
 Mr. Gingrich said there was an urgent need to shore up Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, now expected to run out of money in 2002. "This has nothing to do with the budget," he said.
But Democrats and some Republicans insisted that Medicare was inseparable from the rest of the budget because its growth was responsible for a large share of the projected increase in Federal spending during the next decade.
At a hearing of the House Ways and Means Committee to discuss Medicare, Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, told the Republicans, "You want to be bipartisan only when it suits your needs." He said the Republicans were not bipartisan in the first 100 days of Congress, when they pushed their Contract With America through the House over Democratic objections.
A White House official said the Republicans were looking to Mr. Clinton to provide them with "political cover" for changes in Medicare likely to upset many of the 36 million beneficiaries.
Mr. Clinton will lay out his approach to Medicare on Wednesday in a speech to the White House Conference on Aging. Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, said Mr. Clinton was unlikely to accept the invitation from Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich.
"You have to admire their chutzpah," Mr. Sperling said of the Republican leaders. "They have a tactic a day, a gimmick a day, to avoid their basic obligation to tell the American people the specifics of their budget for the Contract With America, the contract they ran on, brag about and gloat over every chance they get."
Administration officials say the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund will run out of money in 2002 if Medicare law remains unchanged. Options for keeping the program solvent are all distasteful to politicians: Congress could reduce payments to doctors and hospitals, limit the services available to elderly people or raise payroll taxes for workers.
After two days of consultations, Republican leaders of the House and the Senate were unable to agree on how to deal with Medicare in the blueprint for Federal spending known as a budget resolution. Federal law says Congress should complete action on the budget resolution by April 15. But the Republicans are so nervous about Medicare that the Budget Committees in the House and the Senate have not begun drafting the resolution.
Democrats said they would not help Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole out of their political predicament. Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, an expert on Medicare, said he wanted the Republicans to "stew in their own juice until they realize that their Contract With America will harm senior citizens just as it harms children."
President Clinton's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said on Monday that the Republicans were "essentially calling for the largest Medicare cut in history to pay for tax cuts for the well-off." He said Medicare should be discussed only in the context of comprehensive efforts to improve the health care system.
At the Ways and Means Committee today, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, repeatedly refused to be drawn into a discussion of specific ways to rescue the Medicare trust fund. That infuriated committee members.
The chairman, Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, said Dr. Shalala sounded like "a broken record." He said Mr. Clinton proposed virtually no steps to shore up Medicare in the budget that he sent to Congress in February.
Representative Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky, told Dr. Shalala, "If you don't want to suggest anything, then we are going to do it ourselves without your assistance." Representative Mel Hancock, Republican of Missouri, said: "Truman talked about a do-nothing Congress. We ought to be talking about a do-nothing President." Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, said, "I see a huge crisis in leadership by the Administration."
Senator Dole, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said: "The choice for President Clinton is very clear. He can either heed the warning of his own Cabinet members and join us in preserving Medicare, or he can heed the advice of his political pollsters and decide that his re-election is more important than his responsibility or his relevance."
Dr. Shalala said, "It is ironic that those who are suddenly interested in the plight of the Medicare trust fund have advocated policies that exacerbate the insolvency of the trust fund." One such policy, she said, is the plan by House Republicans to reduce the tax on Social Security benefits received by people with substantial income from other sources.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said he was amused to see Republicans appealing to the President for guidance on Medicare. "They are frozen like deer in headlights," he said. "They have the votes to do anything they want, but they don't want to do it unless we give them a program."

HEADLINE: Class Notes

BYLINE: By Seth Mydans 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
This is one college course where Jaime Bardacke always stays late, a course where professors find themselves cutting off persistent questions and ushering students to the door. It is a course where a lecturer may feel it necessary to preface his remarks, as Roger Waldinger did recently, with, "I'll just tell you what I think and you can boo at me if you want."
It is the new hot-button course at the University of California at Los Angeles, "The History and Politics of Affirmative Action," hastily organized this semester to address one of the most contentious issues on the public agenda, one that has affected the university system itself. 
 In 20 lectures over 10 weeks, professors from the fields of law, history, sociology and economics are addressing aspects of a subject that one of the organizers, Scott L. Waugh, the university's dean of social sciences, calls an ideal prism for studying all of American society.
Though most lecturers have been painstakingly circumspect about revealing their personal beliefs on the divisive issue, the multiethnic class of some 100 undergraduate students has not.
Pointed questions from the students peppered the lecture by Dr. Waldinger, a sociology professor, on "Affirmative Action in Light of the Immigrant Experience." At the end of class, agitated groups of students lingered in the room to attack his thesis that blacks still need affirmative action but that other minorities do not.
"The whole class stays afterward instead of fiddling with their stuff five minutes before the end," said Miss Bardacke, a sophomore who plans to major in history. "People try to keep things civil, but it's such a heated issue that it's hard to feel you're not being attacked when people are voicing their opinions."
Some students, like Hanh Thuan Nguyen, arrived armed with their own research. When Dr. Waldinger's lecture was over, she hurried to the lectern to challenge him chart for chart and graph for graph.
Afterward, Miss Hanh, a Vietnamese immigrant, lingered in the sunny courtyard, exchanging personal experiences with Kimberley Kirkwood, an American-born black, and Christina Abilando, who emigrated eight years ago from Cameroon.
"I didn't have a 4.0 grade-point average," Miss Abilando said. "I came here because of affirmative action. I think it is for disadvantaged groups."
Affirmative action has moved to the forefront of public debate in recent months with a proposed California ballot initiative that would end many race-based preference programs. Gov. Pete Wilson supports the initiative and has made the issue a central one as he prepares to run for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996.
The university itself has become a focus of the debate after Ward Connerly, a regent for the University of California system, called for an end to such preferences in admissions. The U.C.L.A. Chancellor, Charles E. Young, quickly took a strong stand against Mr. Connerly, saying affirmative action had benefited the university and should continue.
One of the course organizers, Carol Peterson Hartzog, vice provost of the College of Letters and Science, emphasized that the interdisciplinary course was intended to inform and to foster discussion, not to present a point of view. The lecturers were selected for their research into various aspects of affirmative action but without regard to, or even knowledge of, their personal views.
"The course is not meant to defend the university's policies or to strengthen our position," she said.
Taking into account the passionate divisions the issue arouses, Dr. Hartzog said she had distributed a flier at the start of the course clarifying the difference between dialogue and confrontational debate.
"Dialogue creates an open-minded attitude and an openness to being wrong and to change, to listen to the other side," she said. "Our purpose here is not advocacy but to help the students to become as well informed as we can and to be able then to develop their own well-reasoned opinions."
Readings in the course include selections by such well-known social commentators as Seymour Martin Lipset, Andrew Hacker, Henry Louis Gates, Dinesh D'Souza and Shelby Steele. Course materials also include the positions of both Dr. Young and Mr. Connerly.
In a future lecture, James Sidanius, a psychology professor, said he would describe his new research showing that both racism and the concepts of fairness and equity play roles in the attitudes of whites toward affirmative action.
In another lecture, Julian Eule, a law professor, said he would present his own scholarship on the role of the courts in reviewing voter initiatives like the current affirmative action ballot measure. As "unfiltered majoritarianism," Mr. Eule said, ballot measures tend to be stacked against minorities more than legislative action.
In his lecture, Dr. Waldinger offered a potentially divisive thesis that minorities other than blacks have historically succeeded without the help of affirmative action and that such preferences could be dispensed with today for all groups except blacks.
Color-blind "equal opportunity" is the ideal standard, he said, and preferential programs are justified most clearly for blacks because of their "greater past discrimination and its persistent legacy."
His comments raised a host of objections from the students. Black students spoke out in solidarity with American Indians, and Hispanic students in solidarity with blacks.
"I don't want to get into this argument about who suffered more; we're all here," said one student, Monica Serafin. "I don't like the way he sets African-Americans against Latinos. I'd rather stay away from that."
But tough issues like this will be hard to avoid. The course's next scheduled lecture was titled, "Affirmative Action in Higher Education."

HEADLINE: Displaced Aerospace Workers Face Grim Future in California Economy

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif.

 BODY:
Martha Sias had no idea what she was producing before she was laid off from her high-security job as an assembler of military aircraft parts for the Lockheed Corporation, but she says she was very good at it.
"You have your blueprints here; you have your parts here," she said. "You sit in a little cubicle, and you're making that one part. What it goes to, where it goes to, they don't tell you." 
 Like so many of the hundreds of thousands of jobs making military and aerospace equipment that were the underpinnings of the California economy for decades, it was great work. "You've got good benefits, good money, and you're always moving up," Ms. Sias said. "Your money never stays the same. It's always increasing."
But in November 1993, Ms. Sias's dream job ended suddenly. At the age of 43, she was caught in a tidal wave of layoffs caused by declines in military spending and commercial aircraft manufacturing. She became one of 210,000 people who have lost defense and aerospace manufacturing jobs in California in the last eight years.
Even as California recovers from its long recession, there is little likelihood that defense and aerospace work will significantly revive, and more workers are losing their jobs.
These are the people who led the scientific and military boom throughout the cold war, but now there are only sketchy statistics to tell what has become of nearly a quarter of a million displaced machinists, assemblers, engineers, scientists and managers.
And for those like Ms. Sias, who are eager to retrain, even less is known about what jobs are available and what specialities are in demand in Southern California's shifting economy.
"It's scary -- there are no answers," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles. He said he received constant inquiries from relocation agencies seeking information on needed skills and on growing industries.
"With the data we get, it is very hard to determine anything that specific," Mr. Kyser said. "If somebody asks how many multimedia jobs are there, we just can't tell them."
Los Angeles Trade Technical College, in partnership with the University of Southern California and the National Society of Professional Engineers, thought it had an answer. In 1992 and 1993 it trained 40 former aerospace workers, most of them with advanced scientific degrees, in the emerging technologies of environmental cleanup.
"When we started the program, the only stocks on the stock market that were going up were environmental engineering firms," said Hilda Tomberlin, dean of career and technical education at the college. "It was very exciting."
But Government priorities shifted, the industry never took off, only 16 of the graduates found jobs in that field, and the course in environmental technologies was dropped.
Similarly, little data exist on how well former aerospace workers have done in finding new jobs, although there are many sad stories, including those of an electronics engineer who works at McDonald's, of a $75,000-a-year project manager who plans to open a grocery store, and of the many people who have been retrained only to find that their new skills are as unmarketable as their old ones.
A 1993 study published by Paul M. Ong, a professor of urban planning at the University of California at Los Angeles, found that one-third of the former aerospace workers who applied for unemployment insurance faced long-term unemployment, compared with only one-fifth of claimants nationwide.
The report found that only 17 percent found new jobs in the aerospace industry. Of those who found work outside the industry, only one-third were able to stay in California. Average earnings dropped by about one-third.
Another report now being prepared by the Rand Corporation paints a somewhat brighter picture, one that seems at odds with both the U.C.L.A. report and with anecdotal evidence supplied by organizations running job placement programs, including trade unions and public agencies.
"Some of our aerospace people have been out of work for two or three years," said Mary Hart, coordinator of the Job Club at the employment development office in Torrance, just south of Los Angeles. "These are high-level professional people -- project managers, accountants, marketing people, sales representatives, sales managers, customer service managers. I could start a marvelous company with all these people if I had the money."
In its study of unemployment figures, Rand found that about 9 percent of aerospace workers were unemployed as of 1993, compared with 7.8 percent in nonaerospace durable manufacturing. This was more than double the unemployment rate for aerospace workers in 1990 (4.2 percent), said the report's author, Bob Schoeni. He said 74 percent of professional technical workers, mainly engineers, who found new jobs were re-employed within their specialty, although re-employed aerospace workers overall experienced a 16 percent drop in wages.
Many former aerospace workers did land on their feet, like Leiv H. Blad, a manager of manufacturing research with Lockheed who in 1991 accepted a generous retirement package after 23 years with the company. He took over a small company, Hub Engineering, where he is trying to apply his technical knowledge to the commercial manufacture of composite materials.
Ms. Sias is one of 16 students in a federally financed retraining program at Hub Engineering, working alongside a 49-year-old sheet-metal mechanic who is now supported by his wife, and a 48-year-old precision assembler who lives on $212 a month in general relief and $91 in food stamps and recently received a notice evicting him from his mobile home.
The students in this program were recruited with a questionnaire distributed by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represented 13,000 workers in 1988, most of them at Lockheed. Of these, only 2,500 still hold their jobs.
Retraining can mean something different for top-level executives like John Forster, who supervised 10 project managers at TRW Inc. before losing his job in 1992.
"These high-end managers have to retrain in basic skills," said Mary Ann Pranke, the marketing director for the Private Industry Council in Carson, a Los Angeles suburb, one of 58 such job-placement groups in the state with financing from the Department of Labor.
"They used to turn their reports over to their secretaries," she said. "Now they have to learn how to type their own reports."
Both the former managers and their former workers must also learn to search for work in a marketplace that does not always welcome them.
"They don't want us because we worked in aerospace," Ms. Sias said flatly. "First, we made too much money. Second, they tell us we are overqualified. Third, 'Have you ever done this kind of work before?' No, but just give me a blueprint or your schematic and I can build it. You want me to build you a doorknob, I'll build a doorknob."
Placement counselors also say employers, particularly in small companies, are worried that the highly specialized aerospace workers are less suited for jobs that require flexibility, and fear that they would desert them if a higher-paying job opened up in aerospace.
"Some commercial companies don't believe aerospace employees are productive," added C. J. Jackson, local president of the Electronics and Space Technicians Union, in which 8,000 of the 12,000 members have lost their jobs. "Most of our people are still out of work."
One of them is Joseph Smith, an expert in repairing Apache attack helicopters for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, who concedes that he became "pretty well stagnated" after performing the same specialized tasks day after day, year after year. At the age of 49, he is studying to be a telecommunications and microcomputer technician, but, he said, "There's no guarantee, when I get done with that, that I'm going to be able to get employed either."
Age itself is a problem for many job hunters. Though employers almost never acknowledge it, older workers say it is common knowledge that long experience can, paradoxically, be a handicap. The U.C.L.A. study found that long-term unemployment was particularly common among workers 55 and older.
"The human resources people can read into a resume," said Jerry Steiner, a 59-year-old former executive at the Northrop Corporation who supervised 55 people and handled $200 million in procurement orders a year. He said he earned more than $85,000, 25 percent to 30 percent more than he could have earned in commercial industry.
"I cannot put down 'over 30 years' experience' or that I served in the military from 1958 to 1960," he said. "These things they can put together and realize you are over 50, and they won't even talk to you."
A footnote was added by Dale Herron, president of the Engineers and Scientists Guild, an aerospace union that once represented nearly 2,000 engineers at Lockheed, of whom about 800 remain. "The people who dealt with secret defense disciplines have a harder time being placed because they can't tell you what they did," he said. "It's ironic, but it happens."
Carll N. Pontius Jr. graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1959, "right after Sputnik," and like many of the brightest young people of his generation he hitched his future to the space race, working first at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena and then at TRW.
The current tide of cutbacks is the end of that era of boundless horizons, Mr. Pontius said, and when he lost his job, he turned his back on his past. At the age of 53, he supports his family as a ski patrolman and an ambulance attendant, and he is about to receive a degree as a registered nurse from Los Angeles Harbor College.
The only problem, as he embarks on his new life, is finding a nursing job. Mr. Pontius said 85 percent of last year's graduating class were still unemployed.

HEADLINE: Proving Racial Bias, Worker Finds, Is No Easy Task

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 28

 BODY:
For six years, Raymond Hunter tried to get someone to listen to his complaint of racial discrimination on the job. But when he finally got to court, he saw his claim converted into a routine labor dispute and dismissed by a Federal judge.
"All I want is for someone to look at this thing and tell me if I'm right or if they are," said Mr. Hunter, who has filed an appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia seeking to have his discrimination claim restored. 
 Mr. Hunter, 56, was laid off twice, in 1989 and 1991, from his job as a boiler operator for the H. L. Yoh Company of Radnor, Pa., and replaced by men whose operating licenses were later judged by state officials to be fraudulent or invalid.
Mr. Hunter, who was out of work for two years, contends that he was the victim of racial prejudice. The company said it was only following the contract, replacing Mr. Hunter with men with more seniority when it was forced to reduce its work force. In all, the company laid off 20 workers, including 17 who are white and 3 who, like Mr. Hunter, are black.
What happened to Mr. Hunter's complaint in the court system is not unusual, said Paul Schacter, a Newark lawyer who specializes in civil rights litigation. "It's very, very difficult to prove discrimination," he said. "There are a lot of obstacles, and it's difficult to prove what is in someone's mind."
For the worker involved, it can make a big difference whether his claim is treated as a bias case or a contract violation. For example, under his bias claim, Mr. Hunter was seeking damages for emotional distress; that kind of compensation would not be available if his case was considered purely as a labor contract dispute under Federal law.
Of the 400 complaints of racial discrimination in employment filed with the State Division on Civil Rights in 1994, only 43 led to monetary awards. The total won by all 43 plaintiffs was $256,572, or an average of $6,000 each. More than half of the 1,744 complaints of all types of discrimination that the division closed last year were found to have no probable cause or were withdrawn by the plaintiffs.
Mr. Schacter said the only way to win a civil rights case against an employer is to demonstrate that the company's statements "are not worthy of belief."
Michael J. Ossip, one of the lawyers who represented the Yoh company, said a plaintiff must do even more under rulings by Federal courts in the Third Circuit and by the United States Supreme Court. "It's not enough to prove that the employer's stated reasons for dismissal are false," he said. "You must also demonstrate there was intentional discrimination sufficient to have played a determinate role in the decision."
Mr. Ossip said that in depositions Mr. Hunter was asked why he thought his layoff was due to his being black, and he replied, "Well, what other reason was it?"
Mr. Hunter began working for the Yoh company in Jan. 25, 1988, as a boiler operator at the AT&T Bell Laboratories Corporate Education Center in Hopewell, N.J. The Pennsylvania company was under contract to do all maintenance work and operate the steam generation plants at the center.
On Feb. 9, 1989, Mr. Hunter was promoted to lead boiler operator. But by June, he was laid off in favor of another employee who the company said had the right to bump, or replace, Mr. Hunter under its contract with Local 68 of the International Union of Operating Engineers. The man had more seniority but not the training or the licenses that Mr. Hunter had.
"You can't bump up and replace someone four classifications higher than you," Mr. Hunter argued.
The union supported the company's position, however, and Mr. Hunter still has a complaint of racial bias against the union pending before the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
Within two months of being laid off, Mr. Hunter was invited back because the man who had replaced him was found to be unable to properly operate the water and heating systems at the Corporate Education Center and was dismissed at the insistence of AT&T.
The New Jersey Department of Labor found that two supervisors at the Yoh company had falsely certified that Mr. Hunter's replacement had the proper training for a boiler operator's license.
Mr. Hunter filed a complaint with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, which found probable cause to investigate. After he was back on the job as lead boiler operator, the company asked Mr. Hunter to drop his complaint. Against the wishes of his family, he said, he agreed, but only after demanding that the company give him a letter attesting to his professional competence and value to the company.
"I thought that would give me job security, but I was wrong," he said.
In 1991, AT&T decided to close the building Mr. Hunter was working in, and he applied for a lesser position as a boiler operator at lower pay that was opening up in another part of the Hopewell complex. He began working at the job on May 6, 1991. But by July 1, he was again bumped by a man he had supervised at the Corporate Education Center, who had more seniority but not the training that the new job required, Mr. Hunter said. That man's license was rescinded by the New Jersey Labor Department when he could not document that he had the necessary training.
This time, however, instead of recalling Mr. Hunter, the company told the state it would train the replacement worker and make sure that he qualified for the job. Mr. Hunter filed grievances with the union and the company, which were rejected, and an unfair labor practice charge against the union with the National Labor Relations Board, which ruled against him.
At that point, Mr. Hunter filed a suit in New Jersey Superior Court contending that he was the victim of racial bias. Lawyers for the Yoh company responded by going into Federal District Court and arguing that the matter was pre-empted by the National Labor Relations Act since the issue of whether the company discriminated against Mr. Hunter or acted unlawfully could only be determined by reference to the collective-bargaining agreement between the company and the union.
Judge Garrett E. Brown of the Federal District Court agreed. He also rejected Mr. Hunter's claim under the Federal labor act because it requires claims to be filed within six months. Mr. Hunter did not file his lawsuit until nearly two years after the last incident of perceived bias because the state's law against discrimination has no such time constraint.
Mr. Hunter continued his education during the two years of unemployment and obtained his gold license, the highest of five grades of engineering licenses in his field. In June 1993, he was hired by Trenton State College and is now the school's chief operating engineer.
Mr. Hunter said he had fought so hard and long to win a judgment against the Yoh Company because he had finally obtained a good-paying job in his field only to see "the company take it away from me by helping white operators get fraudulent licenses."
Mr. Ossip, the lawyer for the Yoh company, said he understood how strongly Mr. Hunter held his belief in his claim. "I don't doubt that he believes he was the victim of racial discrimination," he said. "But I also don't doubt that he wasn't."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Plans Software for Easier Systems Management

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Promising to reduce the spiraling costs of managing computer networks, I.B.M. is expected to announce the first in a line of new software today that will integrate and automate the management of large computer systems from the most advanced mainframes to the lowliest desktop machines.
The software, called the System View series, is intended to meet the growing needs of corporate computer managers, who have seen their jobs become increasingly complicated as companies have added disparate networks of personal computers and data servers to their traditional mainframe systems. 
 Although these new, decentralized systems promised to lower costs and increase efficiency, they have often proved harder and more expensive to manage than mainframes, which can be monitored from a single site.
System View offers a coordinated set of tools to enable administrators to automate a range of management tasks that are now done by hand, including revising software and monitoring disk storage space.
"These are the kinds of things that customers have been waiting for," said Frank Dzubeck, president of Communications Network Architects, a Washington consulting firm.
The first version of the software, which I.B.M. said would be available today, is designed for the RS/6000, a server that runs the Unix operating system. Versions that run on OS/2 and MVS, I.B.M.'s operating systems for personal computers and mainframes, will be available by the end of the year, while a version for OS/400, I.B.M.'s midrange operating system, will arrive early next year, the company said.
Although the software is based on these different operating systems, it will be able to manage networks made up of different brands of hardware and software, including those from all of I.B.M.'s major competitors. And as evidence of I.B.M.'s move away from proprietary technology, the company also plans to introduce versions that run on software sold by Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems and others.
"We're in the software business at this part of I.B.M., and so I'm interested in developing and making the very best software no matter what platform it's on," said John M. Thompson, a senior vice president who was named head of the company's software business in January.
I.B.M. hopes to get a jump on Hewlett-Packard, a leader in network-management software, which is developing its own comprehensive approach. That new software, code-named Tornado, will not be available until August, according to Scott Safe, a marketing-programs manager at Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Thompson said I.B.M. planned to design future versions so that independent software vendors could easily write new applications to be integrated with System View.
"I think it's a big step forward," said Waverly Deutsche, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "We're getting a strong message that network management is going to be one of the areas that I.B.M. sees as critical to its future."

HEADLINE: Foreign Policy Can't Ignore Environment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You miss a key point of the speech of Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser (news article, April 28) that relates to Mark Hertsgaard's April 8 Op-Ed article on the Berlin climate change conference. The United States was isolated at Berlin because it is pursuing an isolationist foreign policy at home. 
 We must make such connections if we are to redefine "national security"; global climate change and other threats require it. Mr. Lake made reference to the "new threats" of environmental degradation and population growth; but in discussing only "old threats" in his speech (that is, military), you miss the point. Failure to broaden our concept of national security lies at the root of isolationism and the heart of today's debate.
Those who wish to reduce our foreign involvement are caught in outmoded ideas of national security and preparedness. The United States can no longer discuss security without paying attention to the environmental and economic impacts of climate change, such as flooding and losses to the insurance industry. And it can no longer discuss preparedness without taking a precautionary approach to address these and other threats.
Just as Harry Truman, facing an unfriendly Congress, accomplished the Berlin airlift en route to a second term, President Clinton should begin shaping United States foreign policy for the 21st century.
Putting climate change and other emerging national security threats on the foreign policy "radar screen" would benefit the United States economically and environmentally.
Redefining our foreign policy will require bipartisanship and take time. New issues like climate change show that the task is to rethink, not reduce, foreign aid.
 
SETH DUNN
Washington, April 28, 1995
 
The writer is with U.S. Climate Action Network.

HEADLINE: Indictments Seen on Third-World Loans

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
An investigation of the market for developing-nation bank loans by the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Federal Reserve Board is expected to result in indictments soon, people close to the investigation said yesterday.
In their joint investigation, the District Attorney's office and the Federal Reserve are focusing on a small group of young loan traders who worked at big commercial banks and their possible role in the unauthorized sale and trading of millions of dollars of bank credits lent to developing nations in exchange for kickbacks, the people close to the investigation said. 
 Many of the bank loans were sold at deep discounts to their face value in 1988, 1989 and 1990, after big banks made huge provisions against the billions of dollars they had lent to the developing world in the late 1970's and early 1980's. Investigators suspect that a few loan traders at some big banks may have cheated their own institutions by selling credits to third parties at below-market prices and then shared the profits with the third parties.
In the late 1980's, the biggest American banks vied with one another to make big provisions against their shaky credits to such Latin American nations as Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela, which had borrowed heavily in the early 1980's.
One focus of the joint investigation is on traders who previously worked at the First Chicago Corporation's First National Bank. The bank sold its loans as fast as most of its competitors, and at some of the deepest discounts, and in January 1988 added $240 million to its reserves for troubled foreign loans after making a similar $800 million provision in 1987. At that time, First Chicago alone had $3 billion of such troubled loans. The January 1988 provision increased that bank's reserve for shaky developing-nation loans to $1.32 billion, or about 40 percent of its total loans to countries in the developing world that were having loan problems.
As a result of the January 1988 provision, First Chicago reported a loss of $96.5 million for the fourth quarter of 1987, while a year earlier it had declared a $64.2 million profit for the fourth quarter of 1986. Altogether, First Chicago had losses of $570.7 million for 1987 because of its large provisions. They allowed the bank to sell the loans that it had with Mexico, Argentina, Brazil and other developing nations at a rapid rate in 1988, 1989 and 1990. During the fourth quarter of 1987, for example, First Chicago charged off $38 million of such loans as it began to sell and trade such obligations at a big discount to their face value.
Although it is now a much more regulated and orderly market, in the last years of the 1980's, the market for loans to developing nations was murky at best. The Federal Reserve generally did not take much interest in the growing market until the early 1990's, after the market had acquired a reputation for some unregulated dealings.
Three traders at the Security Pacific Corporation, for example, assembled a 90-page report dated Feb. 27, 1989, reconstructing the sale of $416.4 million of loans with Brazil, Mexico, the Philippines, Venezuela, Chile and other countries, contending that loans were sold at below- market prices in an organized fashion to the benefit of one of their colleagues. A Federal grand jury in Manhattan looked into the matter with the cooperation of the traders, but no charges were brought. Security Pacific was later taken over by BankAmerica.
More recently, however, the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Fed began looking into the market as a result of their joint investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the rogue bank closed by regulators in July 1991. As a result of the investigation, Daniel Young, a former vice president of Manufacturers Hanover, pleaded guilty in March 1994 in New York state court to a felony in misapplying bank property in connection with the 1990 sale of some Colombian bank debt. Manufacturers Hanover was merged with the Chemical Banking Corporation in 1991.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Japanese chip makers, a boom time mixed with caution.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
MUCH of Corporate Japan is closed this week for the so-called Golden Week holidays. But semiconductor factories will keep operating. Demand for computer memory chips continues to soar, defying predictions that the chip shortage would turn to glut this year.
But good news for chip producers here does not necessarily mean good news for their stocks. Indeed, while the shares of American chip companies have generally outperformed a strong American stock market, the shares of Japan's big chip makers have generally performed worse than the slumping Japanese market. 
 One reason is that most American semiconductor companies, like the Intel Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc., specialize in chips and gain directly from a booming market.
The major Japanese semiconductor companies, however, are large conglomerates, like Hitachi Ltd. and the Toshiba Corporation, that make everything from televisions to turbines. While semiconductor sales might be strong, the other businesses of these companies are being hurt by the weak economy in Japan and by the appreciation of the yen against the dollar.
Another factor has been the fear that demand for chips, which has been fueled by strong worldwide sales of personal computers, may end at any time. Recently, those fears have been ebbing.
"I don't think we are done buying PC's," said Steven Myers, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities in Japan. "I don't see any sign that this is suddenly going to come to an end." He said that with prices relatively high for memory chips, Japanese companies could still make money on them even at the current exchange rates of roughly 84 yen to the dollar.
With stocks weak and chip demand strong, there should be a way to invest. Mr. Myers recommends the NECCorporation, among the big chip makers. It has led the other companies in moving semiconductor manufacturing overseas, insulating it somewhat from the effects of the strong yen.
Taketoshi Yamamoto, an electronics analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo, has "strong buy" recommendations on two specialized stocks -- the Kyocera Corporation and the Rohm Company -- whose fortunes are more closely tied to the semiconductor market than those of the big conglomerates.
Kyocera is the world leader in ceramic packages for microprocessors and other sophisticated chips. It is also heavily involved in the fast-growing mobile telephone business in Japan. Rohm is a maker of specialized semiconductors for video processing and some niche markets.
Yet another approach is to invest in companies that make the equipment used to make semiconductors. Peter Wolff, an analyst at CS First Boston in Tokyo, likes Tokyo Electron Ltd., which is Japan's largest vendor of such equipment and has a huge order backlog. Mr. Myers of Jardine Fleming likes Tokyo Electron and the Advantest Corporation, Japan's leader in semiconductor testing equipment.
But Joseph Osha, an electronics analyst with Smith New Court (Japan) Ltd., says it is already too late to invest in semiconductor equipment companies. He argues that growth in sales of chips will slow in 1996. That slowdown will spook semiconductor companies into cutting back on capital spending in 1996, slicing the profits of companies like Tokyo Electron and Advantest.
"It is not necessary to assume that the world semiconductor market will collapse in 1996 to believe that capital spending will weaken," Mr. Osha wrote in a recent report. As for stocks of semiconductor equipment manufacturers, he said, "the time to sell is now."

HEADLINE: Personal Health;
Breast scans may indeed help women under 50.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
IT is hard enough to get healthy people to go for checkups that might pick up hidden cancers while they are still curable. But when experts argue among themselves about who should get various tests and how often, reluctance can turn into outright refusal.
With regard to screening mammograms for women under 50, practitioners say the current debate about their lifesaving potential is prompting many women to avoid the test even as a growing number of studies points to its ability to reduce breast cancer deaths in women of all ages. 
 In 1989, the American Cancer Society, the National Cancer Institute and 11 other national organizations recommended that women from 40 to 50 years old have a mammogram every one to two years and that those 50 and older should have one annually. Then, late in 1992, a 7-year study of screening mammography done in Canada showed no benefit to women under 50. In fact, women in their 40's who were in the screening group in that study actually had a higher breast cancer death rate than women who were not screened, a finding no one could explain.
Despite widespread criticism of the design and execution of the Canadian study, the National Cancer Institute retracted its advice, saying there was no proof that routine mammography benefited younger women. Instead of a blanket screening recommendation for all women in their 40's, the institute recommended routine mammograms only for those whose family history placed them at an unusually high risk of breast cancer. No other organization went along with the change, but the publicity given to the cancer institute's revised recommendation angered most mammographers and left women confused.
 
Why the Debate
 The matter is not inconsequential, in terms of either money or lives. Each year 40,000 women under 50 learn that they have breast cancer, and each year there are 10,000 deaths of women who developed breast cancer from the age of 40 through 49. Only about one in five of those cancers occur in women with family histories of breast cancer.
While the numbers of cases and deaths are much higher among women over 50, the years of life saved are much greater when a 45-year-old woman is cured than when a woman of 65 is. Still, many more younger women must be screened to find one cancer than is the case among women over 50. As Dr. Russell Harris and Dr. Linda Leininger of the University of North Carolina School of Medicine recently put it, "In our rush to control the terrible problem of breast cancer, it is easy to forget that, in the best of circumstances, the many must be screened to benefit the few."
And because mammograms often detect suspicious areas in the breast that warrant further tests or biopsies but that turn out not to be cancer, there are issues like medical costs, mental anguish and physical trauma to consider when deciding whether routine mammograms are worthwhile for younger women. Experts must determine whether the benefits are likely to outweigh the risks and whether administering the examination is both practical and economical.
There are many reasons why it may be more difficult to show a life-saving benefit of screening mammography in younger women. Women in their 40's are considerably less likely to develop and die from breast cancer than are women 50 and older. In the studies completed so far, less than a third of the participants were in their 40's when screening began. Women in their 40's are more likely to have very early stages of breast cancer and so their life expectancy is naturally longer whether or not their cancers are found through screening. The older forms of mammography used in the studies may be less sensitive to cancers in the denser breasts of younger women.
Such factors suggest that larger studies and a longer follow-up -- 10 or more years -- using the newest and most sensitive equipment may be needed to see benefits in younger women. It now appears that the Canadian and other studies on which the institute based its new advice may not have been large enough or long enough or used refined enough technology to demonstrate a lifesaving benefit for younger women.
 
Emerging Benefits
 In a new analysis published last month in the journal Cancer, Dr. Charles R. Smart, formerly of the National Cancer Institute and now of Salt Lake City, and his co-authors found that when all eight scientifically designed studies of screening mammography in younger women were combined, there was a 14 percent reduction in breast cancer deaths among those screened. This was not statistically significant, but when the Canadian study's aberrant results were left out, there was a statistically significant 23 percent benefit associated with screening.
Dr. Smart reported that the longer the study, the more likely it was to show a benefit of screening mammography for younger women. He concluded that women who had regular, high-quality mammograms today were more likely to have cancers detected at an earlier and more curable stage than participants in all eight studies he examined.
But the chances that future studies will show an unquestionable benefit of screening mammography in younger women are not good. Dr. Smart pointed out that to demonstrate an unequivocal 20 percent reduction in breast cancer deaths in women in their 40's would require a study of nearly one million women. Thus far fewer than 180,000 such women have participated in all the studies combined. Nor is a convincing finding likely to emerge from a new trial in Britain, which will be offering annual screening to one-third of 195,000 women in their 40's.
There have been several indications that when cancer is found in a younger woman through mammography, it is likely to be at least as curable as cancers found in women from 50 to 64, for whom an annual mammogram is uniformly recommended. When a breast cancer is discovered, chances of cure depend on the tumor's size, its growth patterns and whether cancer cells have spread to nearby lymph nodes.
In a study published in the current issue of The American Journal of Radiology, Dr. Belinda N. Curpen, now at Notre Dame Hospital in Quebec, and colleagues at the University of California School of Medicine in San Francisco reported that in 44,301 screening mammograms, 75 cancers were detected in women 40 to 49 and 128 were found in women 50 to 64. The detection rate was 3 per 1,000 examinations for the younger women as against 5.5 per 1,000 examinations for the older women, suggesting that few cancers were missed in either group.
There were no significant differences between the two groups of women in the size, stage and lymph node spread of the cancers found. If anything, the radiologists concluded, the younger women had a slightly more favorable prognosis than did the older women. The authors concluded that if, as all agree, mammography benefits older women, it should have a comparable benefit for younger women. One just has to wait long enough to see it.

HEADLINE: 16 Police Officers Are Indicted In Bronx Precinct Graft Inquiry

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Sixteen police officers, including three sergeants, have been indicted on charges of robbery, burglary, larceny, filing false police reports and insurance fraud in a sweeping corruption investigation of the 48th Precinct in the Bronx, senior law enforcement officials said yesterday.
In addition, seven other officers assigned to the station house in the East Tremont section -- including one sergeant -- are to be suspended from the force today and could face dismissal. Although these officers were suspected of criminal wrongdoing -- in some cases witnessing a crime and not reporting it -- the Bronx District Attorney's office told police officials that sufficient evidence to obtain an indictment had not been collected. 
 A senior police official said that officers from the Internal Affairs Bureau would begin taking indicted officers out of their homes in handcuffs overnight and would conclude the arrests this morning. The official would not say how many officers had been arrested last night nor release the names of the officers to be arrested and suspended, but shortly before midnight, at least 10 officers were taken in handcuffs through a side door at 315 Hudson Street in lower Manhattan, where the police Internal Affairs Bureau has offices. A police barricade had been erected at the front entrance to the building.
The indictments handed up by two Bronx special grand juries in recent days are to be unsealed today, law enforcement officials said.
The indictments and administrative actions mark the second time in just over a year that large numbers of officers in a New York City precinct have been implicated in a corruption scandal. Last year, more than 30 officers were arrested in the 30th Precinct in Harlem on charges ranging from assault to drug dealing.
Senior police officials expressed particular dismay over the broad dimensions of the case -- involving nearly 10 percent of the officers in the 48th Precinct -- and because most of the offenses cited came since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton took office.
"With all the major accomplishments we made in the reduction of crime in the last year, I'm disappointed that some of that may be clouded by the alleged actions of a few," said Assistant Chief Rafael Pineiro, the Bronx police borough commander.
Police officials said the 16 indicted officers included 10 people who have already been removed from the field and placed on desk duty. Several of them, the officials said, have helped in the investigation by naming other officers. The sergeants implicated include two from the 48th Precinct and one from the 40th Precinct, also in the Bronx, suspected of committing insurance fraud within the 48th Precinct.
A senior police official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said he did not expect many more officers from the 48th Precinct would be implicated, although other officials said the Police Department was looking at many other officers in such adjoining precincts as the 46th, the 44th and the 52d.
"The people we are bringing in in the 48th are everyone who is known," the senior police official said, though he added that the suspects would be urged to name other officers believed to be involved in criminal activities after they are arrested.
At the precinct stationhouse yesterday and last night, there was more activity than usual, with police officers coming and going between regular shifts. Some of the officers wore grim expressions.
Police officials would not say precisely what the indicted officers were said to have done. But they did describe the insurance fraud case, saying that a sergeant had reported his car stolen, then dumped it at a car repair shop to be stripped for parts.
The investigation into the 48th Precinct was the first major corruption inquiry into a single precinct that was initiated by the Police Department itself. Under pressure from the Mollen Commission, which held public hearings in late 1993 identifying pockets of suspected corruption in the East Tremont, University Heights and Morris Heights neighborhoods of the Bronx, the Internal Affairs Bureau began a series of sting operations in the 48th Precinct to detect corrupt officers.
Mr. Bratton's aides said the Commissioner was clearly upset about the case. Speaking of the brutality and corruption found over the last year in the 30th Precinct in Harlem, one senior police official said, "We thought after the three-oh, it would have put a damper on it."
Mr. Bratton spoke with Bronx police commanders and police union leaders yesterday, and then taped a video to be distributed today to precincts around the city explaining what had happened in the 48th Precinct. Late last night, he toured the streets of the precinct.
Trying to find a silver lining to the crisis, police officials said they developed new investigative techniques in pursuing the 48th Precinct case that included more sophisticated sting operations and patterning types of arrests and complaints to single out suspected officers.
"I hope the message is learned that there are certain things this department will not tolerate," Chief Pineiro said, "and we have shown we are in the position to conduct these investigations to a successful conclusion."
Officials said the pattern of corruption found in the Bronx precinct was somewhat different from that of the 30th Precinct, where crews of four or more police officers were accused of beating up suspects, dealing narcotics and stealing drugs and guns from traffickers. In the 48th, most of the offending officers worked either alone or with partners, the officials said, adding that the crimes were more "opportunistic" than planned.
The differing patterns of police crime in the 48th and 30th Precincts reflected the differing patterns of the drug trade in Harlem and the central Bronx. Because upper Manhattan is a wholesale center where drug dealers from all over the metropolitan area shop for their drugs, the officers arrested in Harlem were often tempted by large sums of money or caches of the finest cocaine they found on the job.
The East Tremont section, by contrast, is dominated by small-time drug dealers hawking heroin and crack on the streets. Officers who stole did so for petty amounts, officials said.
And while almost all the officers to be arrested or otherwise disciplined in the 48th Precinct worked on the overnight shift, the officers arrested in the 30th Precinct worked on all shifts.
Joseph Mancini, a spokesman for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said he could not comment on the indictments. "We don't really know very much," he added.
Since brutality and corruption often go hand in hand, Police Department officials and outside investigators said patterns of abuse complaints in at least several other precincts in the city suggested the possibility of worse corruption problems than in the 48th.
Former staff members of the Mollen Commission said their preliminary investigations indicated severe corruption problems in a broad swath of the city stretching from Harlem to Washington Heights and into the central Bronx. They said there was another deep pocket of suspected police corruption and brutality in central Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: March New-Home Sales Up 3%, Quelling Hope for Fast Recovery

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes inched up in March but remained far below the levels of a year ago, the Commerce Department said today, dashing hopes for a quick recovery in the housing sector.
Sales gained 3 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 577,000 units. But that followed a revised decline of 12.5 percent in February and left the March sales a steep 20 percent lower than the pace of a year ago. 
 The report provided further evidence that a year of increases in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve had succeeded in dampening consumer demand. Higher borrowing costs have hurt sales of cars and trucks as well as houses.
And while mortgage rates have eased since the beginning of the year, they remain 1.5 percentage points higher than they were in late 1993.
"We have had some decline in mortgage rates, but it would take a much larger drop to offset the impact of a weaker overall economy," said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
Sales rose in the West and Midwest but fell in the Northeast and South.
Despite reports of bad weather in California in March, sales of new homes in the West soared by 38.7 percent, to a rate of 172,000, the biggest monthly increase since a rise of 48 percent in December 1981.
Sales in the Midwest were up 11.7 percent, to a rate of 115,000.
But home sales dropped 14.1 percent in the Northeast, to a rate of 55,000 a year, and fell 13 percent in the South, to 234,000 a year. It was the largest monthly fall in the South -- the nation's biggest regional housing market -- since a decline of 15 percent in May 1994.
Previously, the department said the sales of new homes had fallen even more sharply in February, by 14 percent, to a rate of 551,000. It revised that up to a rate of 560,000 units, still the lowest since 554,000 in May 1992.
"The data on home sales, combined with the latest automobile sales data, indicate that both these interest-rate-sensitive sectors of the economy are continuing to falter," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.
The big auto makers reported on Monday that their sales dropped sharply in April.
