SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1778 words

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Pataki's Ratings Are Low Over Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Four months into Gov. George E. Pataki's administration, large numbers of New Yorkers are concerned that he is moving too swiftly to shrink state government and believe that his policies will damage their quality of life, according to the latest New York Times poll.
While newly elected officials typically receive a bounty of public good will, only a third of New Yorkers said they approve of the Republican Governor's job performance and only a quarter expressed a favorable opinion of him. Even when the public's disaffection with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was peaking last October, his job approval rating stood at 46 percent -- 13 percentage points higher than Mr. Pataki is getting now. 
 Beneath Mr. Pataki's low ratings runs a deep vein of public anxiety about his austere budget, now the center of heated debate in Albany. New Yorkers have said they do want change in Albany, but in the latest poll, large margins say they disapprove of his specific proposals to reduce or freeze state spending in several major areas.
When asked if they thought the Governor's plan to cut state assistance to the State University of New York by one third was a good idea, 79 percent said it was not. Asked if his proposal to freeze state aid to public schools would help or hurt education in the state, 56 percent said they thought it would hurt. And 92 percent of the poll respondents disapproved when asked what they thought of the plan to reduce home health care for the elderly poor "as part of the effort to try to balance the budget."
And while a thin plurality of people said they believed that Mr. Pataki's plan to cut income taxes by 25 percent over four years would generally help the economy, two out of three New Yorkers said they would prefer a smaller tax cut if it meant that state services would be preserved.
In one of the unexpected findings of the poll, there were relatively small differences between regions. Just 39 percent of respondents upstate, Mr. Pataki's political base, said they approved of his performance, compared with 26 percent in New York City, where Mr. Pataki's support has been weakest.
Mr. Pataki has said repeatedly that the electorate handed him a mandate last November to make government smaller. "We will begin where the people want us to begin -- reducing the size and cost of government and getting rid of unnecessary and counterproductive programs," he said in his inaugural address in January.
But the poll found that the public is wary of Mr. Pataki's agenda. Most of the people surveyed were unwilling to abandon many of the programs the Governor wants to reduce or eliminate.
There were a few positive trends for Mr. Pataki. Despite Democratic efforts to portray him as a weak leader, 49 percent of registered voters said Mr. Pataki has strong leadership qualities, an increase of 14 percentage points from October.
And though only 27 percent of these people said they have a favorable opinion of Mr. Pataki -- a surprisingly low number for a new Governor -- that is still 9 percentage points higher than in the fall.
The statewide telephone poll of 1,205 adults was conducted April 26 through April 30 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Zenia Mucha, the Governor's director of communications, said Mr. Pataki's own pollsters are finding that he has a significantly higher approval rating.
"The only point on which your numbers and our numbers agree is the fact that New Yorkers recognize Governor Pataki's strong, principled leadership and know that he is going to bring about the sweeping, fundamental change that the people have demanded," she said.
The public's opinion of Mr. Pataki may have been influenced by the intense advertising campaigns that have been waged for and against his budget over the last three months. But because large amounts of money were spent on both sides, it is difficult to gauge whether the Governor's image was damaged or enhanced.
Over all, the poll found that that the Governor was standing on unsteady political ground. A virtually unknown State Senator before last year, Mr. Pataki won with just 49 percent of the vote, largely by capitalizing on anti-Cuomo sentiment without sharply defining himself to a restive electorate bent on change.
The poll suggests that many people who voted for Mr. Pataki did so out of anger or weariness with Mr. Cuomo and are not firmly allied to the new Governor even now.
Many respondents were like Elaine Nichols, a 56-year-old clerical worker from Otsego County in central New York. In a follow-up interview, Ms. Nichols said she is a Republican who voted for Mr. Pataki last year because she was tired of Mr. Cuomo. But now, she said, she is concerned that the new Governor's budget cuts will put people on the unemployment lines while his tax cuts will aid only the wealthy and not people like herself.
"He's pushing, pushing, pushing too fast, and it's cutting everyone out of work," she said. "A lot of people with a lot of money don't get hurt, while we poor people do."
Mr. Pataki also seems to remain something of an enigma to many people; 42 percent of those surveyed said they still do not have an opinion of him or do not know enough about him to form one.
And those who do have opinions tend to have negative ones. Fifty-two percent said they think Mr. Pataki does not care about their needs and problems. Forty percent said they believe the overall quality of life will diminish under Mr. Pataki, compared with 27 percent who thought it would improve. And 42 percent said he is moving too quickly to change the state's direction, compared with 27 percent who think he is proceeding at the right pace.
There was a strongly partisan quality to many of the answers. Fifty-eight percent of the people who identified themselves as Republicans or Conservatives said they approved of Mr. Pataki's performance, compared with 17 percent of those who called themselves Democrats or Liberals.
Answers also varied widely based on the respondent's race. Four out of five blacks disapproved of Mr. Pataki's performance, while whites were almost evenly divided: 43 percent said they approve of his performance, and 38 percent said they disapprove.
There was a broad consensus cutting across racial, regional and economic lines that Mr. Pataki's tax cut plan may be too ambitious. Fifty-three percent of people earning $75,000 a year or more -- those who would benefit most from his tax cut proposal -- said they would prefer a smaller cut in order to preserve state services. Larger proportions of lower-income New Yorkers said they also supported the smaller cut.
Even Republicans were ambivalent on this issue, with 50 percent saying they would prefer a smaller tax cut and 39 percent saying they support Mr. Pataki's plan.
The question posed was: "Governor Pataki has proposed a 25 percent cut in income taxes over four years. He has also proposed to reduce spending on government services by 4 percent, or $1.2 billion. Would you prefer that tax cut, or would you prefer a smaller cut that would require a smaller reduction in government services?"
The New Yorkers surveyed said they did agree with the Governor on at least one point, reducing state spending on welfare. Fifty-six percent said current benefit levels are too generous. Mr. Pataki has called for cutting welfare grants by as much as 25 percent.
Sixty-two percent said welfare mothers should not receive greater benefits when they have additional children, a policy that many Republicans support but that Mr. Pataki has not yet proposed.
More than 90 percent of the people polled endorsed the policy of requiring welfare recipients to work for their checks, with 61 percent saying this should include mothers. That mirrors findings in recent national surveys.
But New Yorkers rejected the idea of setting time limits on welfare, saying the poor should be allowed to receive benefits as long as they work for them. Mr. Pataki has proposed cutting off welfare payments to able-bodied single adults after 60 days, a policy firmly opposed by Democratic lawmakers.
Asked which problems they want Mr. Pataki to focus on, people ranked crime, welfare, taxes and education about equally.
On the state budget, now 34 days late, New Yorkers sided with the Governor, defying accepted Albany wisdom that governors are held responsible for late budgets. Only 9 percent of those surveyed said it was solely Mr. Pataki's fault that the budget is overdue. Twenty-six percent blamed the Legislature while 58 percent laid blame equally on the Governor and legislators.
In follow-up interviews, respondents often expressed anger about specific budget cuts proposed by Mr. Pataki. "I did vote for him and now I'm sorry," said Gertrude Sunk, a 77-year-old Columbia County resident who fears she will lose home health-care services if Mr. Pataki's budget is approved. "I thought he would help us. It seems he is against us."
The poll also showed that 24 percent of registered voters have favorable opinions of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's chief political patron last year, compared with 45 percent who have unfavorable ones. Mr. D'Amato's Democratic colleague, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, was viewed favorably by 45 percent of those registered voters and unfavorably by 15 percent.
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted from April 26 to 30 with 1,205 adults throughout the state. Interviews were done in either English or Spanish.
The random sample of telephone numbers was provided by Survey Sampling Inc. of Fairfield, Conn.
Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines in the residence, as well as to adjust for variations relating to the region of the state, race, sex, age and education.
According to statistical theory, in 19 out of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in New York State.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based only on residents of New York City, it would be plus or minus 4 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of the questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Continue Surge As News Cheers Traders
The stock market roared into record territory once again, led by a friendly bond market, good corporate earnings and new signs of a cooling economy.
The Dow industrials surged 44.27 points, to 4,373.15, and other indexes followed. "This was a beautiful day," one analyst said. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.24 percent, its lowest level in almost a year. D10.
In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.3745 marks, but rose to 83.71 yen. D17. 

A Kerkorian Adios to Chrysler?
Preliminary Talks Are Held
Chrysler lawyers have held preliminary discussions with Kirk Kerkorian's representatives to find a way to end the billionaire's takeover bid, people with knowledge of the telephone talks said. The matter is not resolved, but the talks gave the strongest sign yet that the bid could end. D3
 
Senate Vote Broadens Tort Bill
The Senate approved an amendment that greatly expands the scope of a bill intended to reduce the damages awarded in civil lawsuits, but the measure is now so sweeping -- covering all civil suits in Federal and state courts -- that it may lose support. A1.
 
Ford and Toyota Post Higher Sales
Ford and Toyota defied the industry pattern by reporting better sales in April. Ford's sales rose 3.6 percent and Toyota's 2.1 percent. D3.
 
Fidelity Names Fixed-Income Chief
Fidelity Investments named Fred Henning Jr. the new director of fixed-income and money-market investments in a move to shore up its troubled bond fund business. D2.
 
Traders Indicted on Bank Fraud
The Manhattan District Attorney accused four traders of stealing money from First Chicago, Algemene Bank Nederland and Banco Ganadero of Colombia. D3.
 
Warburg Pessimistic on Profits
S. G. Warburg, weakened, said profits for the year ended March 31 would be well below market expectations. D4.
 
Argentina Expected to Get Loan
The World Bank is expected to approve an initial $500 million loan today -- part of a $3.8 billion package -- to shore up Argentina's troubled banking system. D4.
 
T.C.I. Plans Internet Venture
Tele-Communications Inc. is joining with a Silicon Valley venture capital firm to form a company to offer high-speed access to the Internet computer network over cable systems. The new company will be headed by William Randolph Hearst 3d, the former publisher of The San Francisco Examiner. D9.
 
Unified Disk Standard Urged
American computer companies urged Japanese and European consumer electronics companies to end their format rivalries and develop a unified standard for the digital videodisks being developed. D7.
 
Paper Prices Aid Georgia-Pacific
The chairman and chief executive of Georgia-Pacific said a surge in pulp and paper prices was expected to help the company ride out a slump in the construction market. D22.
 
Auto Makers Quarrel Over Vans
Chrysler and Ford are squabbling over whose mini-van has more space. Ford complains that Chrysler, in boasting about the interior volume of its new mini-van, has been inaccurately maligning the Ford Windstar. Advertising. D9.
 
Bank Acquisitions Are Slowing
Several large banks are slowing their acquisition of smaller banks, assessing whether they need more branches as customers increasingly use A.T.M.'s and bank by phone. In any event, prices may drop, they reason. Market Place. D10.

HEADLINE: From Washington, The Fading Pension

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
For more than a decade, the Government has been tinkering with the nation's pension system, largely in the name of two good causes: cutting the deficit and making retirement benefits more equitable.
The cumulative effect of all the tinkering, however, has been anything but good, says a growing chorus of pension experts and economists. The changes, whose impact is only now being fully recognized, threaten the retirement benefits of many of the 41 million workers covered by traditional company-financed pension plans, they say. Because some changes are just kicking in and come into play over many years, baby boomers as well as those who have recently entered the labor force, the so-called Generation X, will be most affected. 
 Some of the impact is already being felt, by higher-income executives now entering retirement. Eventually, the experts say, even those at modest income levels will feel the pain.
There are four major forces at work.
One series of changes drastically restricts the amount of money that businesses can put aside each year as long-term savings to finance traditional pensions. That reduces the tax deductions that businesses can claim for this purpose, thus raising more revenue for the Government. Under these changes, the Government now requires employers to slash pension contributions when employees are young, counting on the companies to make up for it many years later. This long delay in financing raises questions about whether the pensions will be there when the employees retire.
A second set of changes, completed in 1993, has lowered the maximum salary used to calculate future pensions to $150,000. While seemingly generous today, that amount, after adjusting for decades of inflation, could fall short in providing an adequate retirement income for young workers and is already restricting pension contributions for some of them.
A third set of changes, begun more than a decade ago, was aimed at limiting pension benefits available to the most affluent workers by capping the amount that the plans can pay out each year and still qualify for favorable tax treatment. Because of adjustments for inflation, the cap for retirement at age 65 has gone up a bit lately, to $120,000. But caps for early retirement were severely restricted last year. For now, these changes mostly affect early retirees with relatively generous pensions.
The last factor is the exploding number and complexity of regulations needed to carry out these and many other changes. The costs of compliance can be high -- small companies must now spend about $500 a year a worker -- giving many employers another excuse to drop traditional pensions. In their place, employers are often sponsoring 401(k) plans, which involve less red tape and are mostly financed by employees. And some companies are offering no plan at all.
The unintended consequence of all the changes, the experts contend, is a further unraveling of the safety net that American workers have long counted on for their later years. Along with growing fears about the Social Security and Medicare systems, these concerns will serve only to remind most Americans that they need to rely more on their own resources for retirement.
The situation has become so dire that Congress must act quickly "to reverse Government policies that are strangling private pensions and threatening their financial soundness," warns the Committee for Economic Development, a group that represents large companies, in a report being released today.
Officials at the Treasury and Labor Departments and at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal agency that takes over failed pension plans, all declined to comment yesterday on the record. But they say the health of the nation's pension system is improving and that the outside critics may be cherry-picking unusual examples to support their case.
To be sure, even the critics say the dire outcomes that they forecast can be avoided. That will require even more tinkering, they say, but of a kind that reverses the current direction.
For now, the critics say, Washington's policies are restricting the flow of dollars into the huge pension portion of the national savings pool at a time when the Government says a higher savings level is crucial to the long-term health of the country.
Indeed, while other factors are also at play, last year's contribution per worker for traditional pensions, known as defined benefit plans, was nearly 50 percent below the peak in 1978, adjusted for inflation, and barely above the level in 1964, according to Sylvester J. Schieber, vice president for research at the Wyatt Company, a benefits consulting group.
The tinkering, during both Democratic and Republican administrations, has come in a series of disconnected and often obscure legislative steps going back to 1982, including provisions tucked into a bill last year approving the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Under the 1994 legislation, Congress sharply lowered the maximum pension for highly paid workers who take early retirement. Under a typical plan, a company previously allowed an employee, eligible at 65 for a $120,000 pension, to receive $94,200 if he retired at 55, Mr. Schieber said. But the Government's new rules now limit the payout to $53,558.
Given the trends, workers of more modest means who are approaching retirement will be affected before long, the experts warn. "The way Congress has been ratcheting down pension contributions every two years or so, I expect that within a decade people making $40,000 or $50,000 who stayed with one company will not be able to collect full pensions," said Edwin Hustead, a vice president at the Hay/Huggins Company, another benefits concern.
But it is the Generation X worker on whom the pension contributions ax has fallen most sharply. Under the latest rules, contributions to a typical plan for a 25-year-old employee have been slashed nearly 80 percent during the early years of the worker's career.
The shortfall is supposed to be made up during the second half of the employee's career by increasing contributions as much as 18-fold, according to Wyatt. That means Generation X workers must wait until then to have 75 percent of the contributions made to their plans. In the past, there were much smaller differences in contribution levels based on age.
The experts fear that some companies will not be around when the bigger contributions are due. A failure by an employer in the early or middle years of a worker's career could thus mean sharply reduced retirement benefits or added burdens on the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. They worry, too, that employers that are around may choose to dump older workers for younger ones, thus avoiding the big payments, or to terminate their pension plans.
Another complex rule with consequences for younger, less affluent workers involves the new $150,000 salary cap for calculating future benefits.
Mr. Schieber cited the example of a 35-year-old worker making $35,000 a year. The law requires companies to project likely pay increases, and if the employer adopts 5.5 percent as an annual average, the calculation shows that the worker will make $165,000 in the year he turns 65, or $15,000 more than the cap. Therefore, the Government says, only the portion of the employee's current pay that can be extrapolated to $150,000 at age 65 -- in this case, $31,752 -- can be used to calculate this year's pension contribution. This kind of approach, critics say, could leave many workers with a smaller pension.
In its report being released today, the Committee for Economic Development also cites the cost of complying with anti-discrimination provisions as a serious drag on pension financing. Under such provisions, a pension plan must provide significant benefits for rank-and-file workers, not just executives, to qualify for favorable tax treatment.
Complying with these rules, which run more than 600 pages, requires "an army of lawyers, actuaries and accountants, who often seem to be the major beneficiaries of the legislation," the report says.
A Hay/Huggins study estimated that the costs in 1990 of complying with 11 major pension regulations came to $455 an employee for a company with 15 or fewer workers. More rules have been added in the last five years. (The annual cost for the largest companies, which can spread the burden over a much bigger work force, is about $50 an employee.)
Many of the fairness rules dealt effectively with serious abuses, said Thomas Ochsenschlager, the senior tax partner at the Grant Thornton accounting firm. "There was a time when we could, and did, work up a plan that was totally qualified under the law, but would benefit only the owners of a company," he said.
But now, with administrative costs so high, Mr. Ochsenschlager said he concurred with the business committee's proposal to exempt companies from the rules if they make pension benefits proportionate for all workers based on their salaries, up to the $150,000 cap.
Something will have to change, nearly all the experts say. They argue that Washington needs to find a way to cut the deficit other than nibbling away at pension benefits.
"On the one hand we want to collect all the taxes we can today," said Olivia S. Mitchell, a professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and executive director of its Pension Research Council. "On the other, we want to increase retirement savings."
When it comes to pensions, the experts say, the hard reality is that you can't do both.

HEADLINE: A First Step on Cuba?;
Americans Say the Accord on Immigration Might Be Followed by Other Agreements

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's new policy on Cuban immigration, the product of the highest level of American-Cuban cooperation in more than a decade, could signal a new level of engagement between the two countries.
Moreover, the new immigration policy -- made possible by an agreement secretly negotiated by senior diplomats from the two countries and announced on Tuesday -- could be followed by engagement on other areas of mutual interest, like the fight against narcotics or environmental problems, American officials said. 
 At the least, the Administration's decision to admit the 21,000 Cubans being held at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station and to send future "boat people" back to Cuba is expected to have immediate major benefits for both Governments.
For the Clinton Administration, the new policy will head off rioting at the base and prevent a surge of boat people like the one last summer, American officials say. For Fidel Castro, it will spare him the embarrassment over the boat people, who have scared off European and Latin investors and tourists. The Cuban leader is also happy to see Guantanamo emptied of 21,000 Cubans, these officials said, because the presence of thousands of angry anti-Castro refugees there was viewed as a security threat.
The new immigration policy may also indicate a new pragmatic approach to Cuba in which Washington will sometimes be willing to offend Cuban-American groups -- which condemned the decision to repatriate future boat people -- when it is convinced it is pursuing the wisest policy.
Administration officials say they have not written off the Cuban-Americans or Florida's 25 electoral votes in the 1996 Presidental election. Rather, they insist, they were selecting the policy with the best chance of keeping the immigration situation from exploding this summer.
To handle this delicate subject, the Administration secretly sent Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff, the third-ranking official in the State Department, to talks with Ricardo Alarcon, the chairman of Cuba's National Assembly. It was the highest-level meeting of American and Cuban officials since United States diplomats maneuvered to stop the Mariel boatlift from Cuba in 1980.
Cuban-American groups said they were outraged that the Administration did not consult with them. They also expressed alarm that the cooperation exhibited in sealing the accord could portend a full normalization of relations with Cuba.
Senior Administration officials deny that the immigration agreement is the first step toward normalizing relations. "It's nothing more than one of several agreements we've reached with Cuba on immigration," said a White House official.
The policy could also pave the way for the Administration to roll back some of the sanctions imposed on Cuba last August to punish Mr. Castro for not cutting off the flow of boat people last summer.
The steps under consideration, Administration officials said, include making it easier for scientists, artists and academics to travel between the two countries and relaxing restrictions that prevent many Cuban-Americans from visiting relatives in Cuba. Senior Administration officials insisted these steps would not weaken the three-decade-old trade embargo against Cuba and are not intended to reward Havana.
"We want to take steps that we believe will lead to the evolution to democracy in Cuba," a senior Administration official said.
But some Republicans in Congress scoffed at the notion that the measures will cause Mr. Castro to take substantial steps toward democracy. Others held strategy sessions today to devise ways of countering the new policy. One proposal would forbid the Defense Department from using money to repatriate political refugees from Communist countries. Also under consideration is a proposal to accelerate approval of legislation to tighten sanctions on Cuba.
"Senator Helms thinks it's very important that Congress reassert that its policy is to isolate Castro and not cooperate with him," said Mark Thiessen, a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The Administration argues that any further opening to increase the flow of ideas to Cuba is nothing more than carrying out the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992, which Bill Clinton endorsed as a presidential candidate. The act tightened the economic embargo but also outlined steps to increase telecommunications ties and the flow of ideas between the two countries.
Representative Robert Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who sponsored the act, said increasing ties between Cubans and Americans is a certain way to undermine Mr. Castro. "The opening up of telecommunications provided probably greater problems for Castro than economic pressure," he said. "It doesn't help Castro to have Cubans-Americans talking at night to relatives in Cuba about their quality of life and plans for the future."

HEADLINE: Economic Data Show a Slowing Of U.S. Growth for Rest of Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The Government index designed to forecast the economy fell in March for the second consecutive month, pointing to subdued growth for the balance of 1995.
While the data suggested that the economy would continue to slow in the next six months, factors ranging from a solid job market to strength in stocks suggested, some analysts said, that the slowdown would come without a recession -- nearly the model of the "soft landing" of noninflationary growth sought by Federal Reserve policy makers and hoped for by the markets. 
 "Things are really slowing down here," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber and a former president of the Forecasters Club of New York. "But I don't think we'll have a recession."
Investors were heartened by the latest evidence of a soft landing, with its promise of low inflation that keeps the value of bonds intact. That helped bond prices surge, sending interest rates to their lowest level in nearly a year. [Page D20.]
The bond rally spilled over into stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 44.27 points to another record. [Page D10.]
The markets were also bolstered by a separate report from the Commerce Department showing that new orders for factory goods edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in March. It was a surprisingly weak performance in light of partial figures published last week showing that orders for the durable goods component -- items lasting three years or more -- had risen six-tenths of 1 percent.
"It's further confirmation that the manufacturing sector and the economy in general have slowed sharply in the first half of the year," said John R. Williams, a top economist at Bankers Trust.
The index of leading indicators, created to call turns in the economy, is not the most reliable barometer. But investors often choose to see what they want in economic reports. And investors right now seem to be anxious for signs that the Federal Reserve's strategy of raising interest rates to moderate the pace of the economy has worked. The Fed has raised short-term interest rates seven times since February 1994.
The Commerce Department said today that the index declined five-tenths of 1 percent for the month, the biggest decline in two years and the first back-to-back declines since the late summer of 1992.
This followed a dip of two-tenths of 1 percent in February and an unchanged reading for January.
Despite a rule of thumb that three consecutive declines in the forecasting index portend a recession six to nine months ahead, few analysts believe one is anywhere in sight. The necessary "earmarks," particularly a deterioration in the job market and in incomes, "are just not there," Mr. Williams of Bankers Trust said.
Indeed, based on some later figures, economists said the index would post an increase for April as stock prices advanced smartly and consumer expectations rebounded after three straight declines.
And even if the index fell for a third time, the department cautioned that a reversal in its direction did not signal a turn in the business cycle unless the move was of "significant" size and scope as well as duration. The two declines so far have not been very big nor particularly widespread, with less than 60 percent of the components moving negatively, on average, in February and March. This is why the rule of thumb is not so reliable.
The probability of recession has now edged up to only about one in eight, estimated Michael P. Niemira, an economist with Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
In March, 6 of the 11 index components were negatives while 3 made positive contributions and the other 2 were either unchanged or so little changed as to round to zero.
The biggest drag was vendor performance, a gauge of how long it takes for companies to get orders delivered from their suppliers. Faster service implies few of the bottlenecks that characterize an overheated economy.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is said to watch this with particular interest, but analysts are widely agreed that no recent figures are likely to change the view that monetary policy is "on hold" and will likely remain so pending some economic results for the second half of the year.
Growth at about a 2 percent rate for the April-June quarter is now a typical prediction, down from a 2.8 percent pace in the first quarter.
Other negative items in the March index were lower consumer expectations (since reversed), lower prices for materials especially sensitive to business conditions, a shorter average workweek, a decline in building permits, and fewer new orders for consumer goods and materials.
The rise in stock prices was the biggest force supporting the index, followed by higher contracts and orders for plant and equipment and a rise in unfilled orders to factories for long-lived goods.
First-time claims for state jobless benefits were unchanged and the money supply rose so little as to have no impact on the index.
Companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent and four-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, the Commerce Department report also showed.
This meant that the ratio of coincident to lagging indicators, which is considered a useful alternative predictor, declined for the third straight month, though less than in February.
The report on factories showed orders for nondurables skidding seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the biggest decline since July 1993. Orders for durables were up five-tenths of 1 percent, slightly less than the estimate of six-tenths of 1 percent estimated last week.

Graph runs from October 1993 through March 1995. (Source: Commerce Department) (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: New Fulton Market Lease Includes Big Rent Increase

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In an apparent breakthrough in attempts to keep the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, the city reached an agreement yesterday on a new lease with a major trade association at the market and won substantial rent increases.
Rents for seven wholesale companies in the structure known as the Tin Building will increase to a total of $650,000 a year in the first three years of a 10-year lease. The dealers now pay a total of $72,000 a year. 
 The agreement signaled a coup for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The 40 wholesale seafood dealers in the market have said a united front was needed to resist steep rent increases. Lawyers for two other trade groups in the market said yesterday that they would resist the city's demands for rent increases, adding they they had not given up the idea of moving the market outside the city or challenging the increases in the courts.
But Joseph L. Forstadt, a lawyer for one of the groups opposing the proposed increases, conceded that yesterday's agreement lessened the possibility of a mass move by the dealers to another location.
"It does not foreclose it," said Mr. Forstadt, "but it certainly puts a damper on it."
Steven D. Dryer, a lawyer for the Fulton Market Fishmongers Association, the group that signed the agreement, said he doubted that the rent increase would lead to higher retail seafood prices in the New York area. The market is the region's major supplier of fish and seafood for retail stores and restaurants.
Giuliani administration officials initiated the negotiations in March after noting that rents -- totaling about $270,000 a year for about 30 companies -- had not been raised since 1982. The city is the landlord for most of the three-block area along South Street in lower Manhattan, where the market has been located for more than 150 years.
Asserting that the Genovese crime family is entrenched at the market, the Giuliani administration has asked the City Council for authority to license and regulate all companies and employees in the market. The Council is expected to approve the proposal later this month.
The seven companies that agreed to the lease, members of the Fishmongers Association, do business in the building that was badly damaged by arson on March 29. Randy Mastro, Mr. Giuliani's chief of staff, and Mr. Dryer said that the total annual rent for the building will be $450,000 starting in May 1996, $550,000 in May 1997 and $650,000 in May 1998.
Increases after that will be based on rises in the consumer price index or in the assessed real-estate value of the property. The rents can not be reduced, even if the index or real-estate values decline, Mr. Mastro said. The lease is for 10 years, with the association having the right to renew it for 15 more years.
Mr. Mastro said that the city expected to begin extensive repairs soon on the Tin Building, so-called because of its aluminum siding, and that rent increases will be phased in over the next 12 months as sections of the building are reopened.
The dealers are now operating only on the ground floor of the three-story structure. The lease is with the association, which assesses rents from its members based on the space they use in the building.
Mr. Dryer said that members of the Fishmongers Association felt that they had no choice. "My clients believe this is a large amount of money to pay," he said, "but the city is going to repair a burned out building and give us a long-term lease."
Mr. Mastro said that a fire insurance policy would cover $2.7 million of the repairs but that the total renovation costs were not clear.
Mr. Mastro said the the agreement had been reached despite warnings by some dealers that higher rents would force merchants to leave New York or go out of business. "Now we see there is a commitment not only on the city's part but also by major businesses to stay in the market and to improve the climate for everyone," he added.
Until the fire, the Fishmongers Association handled about 25 percent of the market's business, Mr. Mastro said. The market is the nation's largest wholesale seafood center, with 1,000 jobs. It generates between $800 million and $1 billion annually in sales and in wages, the city says.
The city's Economic Development Corporation, the agency negotiating the leases, is expected to begin talks next week with the New York Wholesale Fishdealers Association, a trade group that represents 12 companies in the market.

HEADLINE: Gains in Sales At Toyota and Ford in April

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation defied the auto industry's pattern today by reporting better sales in April.
But even with the gains, the overall record of the industry remains weak this year and suggests that Americans are retreating from the buying boom that helped produce record profits for domestic producers in 1994. 
 The deliveries of cars and light trucks for Ford rose 3.6 percent from April 1994 on the strength of the company's 19th consecutive monthly record for trucks. Toyota, the largest foreign-based auto maker, said daily sales rose 2.1 percent.
Still, auto sales in the United States fell 6.1 percent last month from the level a year earlier. European manufacturers as a group posted an increase in sales, but they accounted for less than 4 percent of the market. Sales by the Big Three domestic auto makers were down 6 percent, while sales by Asian companies dropped 9.5 percent.
It was the fourth consecutive month of declines in auto sales, and came against a backdrop of other evidence suggesting that the American economy was slowing down. The Government said today that its main economic forecasting gauge reported the biggest drop in two years, partly as a result of weakening consumer demand.
An economic slowdown does not necessarily mean that consumers will sharply reduce their purchases of cars and other expensive items. But it suggests that they may be getting more particular about the way they spend.
"There are other things people want to do with their money at this point in time," said Art Spinella of CNW Marketing/Research in Bandon, Ore.
In 1984 new vehicles ranked third on the list of large purchases that people planned during the next 12 months, the surveys by the company found. In January of this year new vehicles ranked 11th, behind "everything from in-home computers, high-end electronics and home improvements to taking vacations," Mr. Spinella said.
The auto makers have predicted a healthy 1995 for the industry. Economists at Ford, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation say they expect vehicle sales to match or surpass the levels of 1994.
But "business isn't as good as it should be, given the fundamentals," an analyst for Ford, Joel Pitcoff, said.
A number of factors might have exaggerated the decline in sales from April 1994 to April 1995.
The month had five weekends last year and none was an Easter holiday weekend. Weekends are normally strong selling periods and holiday weekends are weak. April of this year had five weekends, but one included Easter.

HEADLINE: 4 Traders of Foreign Debt Are Indicted for Defrauding 3 Banks

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Four traders in foreign debt have been indicted on charges that they defrauded First National Bank of Chicago, Algemene Bank Nederland N.V. and Banco Ganadero of Colombia.
The three indictments, which were announced yesterday, said the traders were covertly taking fees that belonged to the three banks. 
 A former banker for First Chicago, Waldemar N. Jezler, 42, is accused of brokering transactions in Brazilian trade credit obligations through his firm in Rye, N.Y., Tandem Trading Inc., from October 1989 to June 1990.
The three other traders, Carlos A. Abadi, 35, a former assistant vice president at First National; Miguel C. Timponi, a former vice president of Algemene, which is now ABN-Amro, and Juan B. Echeverri, a former executive vice president of Banco Ganadero, "shared in the fees paid out by their employers in connection with the trade commitment transfers" made through Tandem, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said at a news conference yesterday.
Mr. Jezler, who left First Chicago in 1990, paid $2 million of kickbacks to the three traders, the District Attorney's office said, and the four men together paid more than $6 million into foreign bank accounts and offshore corporations. In addition, Mr. Jezler, Mr. Tandem and Mr. Abadi are charged with failing to report as income the $6 million diverted to the offshore corporations. The four traders were arraigned in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday.
The indictments, handed up by a state grand jury, also charge four companies: Tandem Trading; Merlin Overseas Ltd. of St. Johns, Antigua; Nacional Holdings Ltd. of St. Johns, Antigua, and Vikingo Corporation of Tortola, British Virgin Islands, with involvement in the scheme to defraud the banks.
A lawyer for Mr. Abadi reacted sharply to the indictments. "These charges are an injustice to Mr. Abadi and his family," said Bill Schwarz, who is representing the former First Chicago banker.
"Carlos Abadi is a highly ethical professional who served his employer loyally and always acted in its best interests," Mr. Schwarz added. "He is completely innocent and will be vindicated."
Mr. Abadi was senior foreign debt trader for First Chicago in New York until he left the firm in 1991. He now runs a money management firm that mainly handles investments for wealthy Latin Americans.
Mr. Jezler did not respond to messages left with his office at Tandem Trading in Rye, and Mr. Timponi did not return telephone calls left at his home in Miami. Mr. Echeverri, who lives in Coconut Grove, Fla., could not be reached for comment.
The four traders each face one count of grand larceny, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years in prison. They also face bribery, conspiracy and fraud charges, each of which carries a sentence of up to four years in prison.
First Chicago, the parent of First National, reacted cautiously to the indictments. "All corporations, particularly financial institutions, rely on the integrity of their employees," the bank said in a statement. "It's always distressing when a former employee is accused of improper behavior," the company added, noting that "the accused has the opportunity to defend himself," and "accordingly it would be inappropriate to comment further on this case."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips Against the Mark, But Advances a Bit on the Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark yesterday as worries about British and French elections continued to strengthen the mark.
The dollar edged up against the yen, however, as the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and the Japanese Trade Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, met in Vancouver, British Columbia, for the first day of talks on automotive trade. 
 Political uncertainty in Europe typically bolsters the mark, the currency of the Continent's strongest economy. Yesterday, dealers sold British pounds for marks ahead of local government elections in England and Wales today. The ruling Conservative Party, which has been badly trailing the opposition Labor Party in opinion polls, is expected to fare poorly. The pound fell to 2.2203 marks, from 2.2269 marks on Tuesday.
Dealers also again sold French francs for marks on worries that the winner of Sunday's presidential election in France would not maintain the Government's policy of supporting a strong franc. The mark rose to 3.5675 francs from an early low of 3.5595 francs, though the mark was down from 3.5689 francs on Tuesday.
"Political uncertainty in the U.K. and France" is bolstering the mark, said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at Long Term Credit Bank of Japan in New York.
A strong mark hurts the dollar because dealers often sell dollars to buy other currencies for mark transactions. The dollar has dropped 9 percent against the mark so far this year.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3745 marks from 1.3787 marks on Tuesday. The pound rose to $1.6154 from $1.6152. The dollar was quoted at 83.71 yen, up from 83.63 yen.
The dollar recovered from early losses against the yen after Mr. Kantor said that the auto trade talks with Japan might be extended to tomorrow and that "we're prepared to make progress within the next three days." The United States is pressing Japan to further open its auto and auto parts markets.
"Kantor's comments brought the dollar back against the yen," said Vicki Schmelzer Alicea, a dealer with Westdeutsche Landesbank in New York. "But the market is still very nervous about whether anything will come out of this."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Phasing out protection for textiles may take a silver bullet.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
DOES the right hand of the Clinton Administration know what the left hand is doing?
Bill Clinton ran for the White House as a global economic realist, the President who would champion high-paying, high-technology jobs while allowing senescent industries to go gently into that good night. But the bureaucrats who must turn these fine sentiments into day-to-day policy have apparently not gotten the message, digging in against efforts to open markets to everything from Chinese honey to Colombian roses. 
 Actually, the idea that bureaucrats are undermining White House trade policy without the President's knowledge is the charitable view. While President Clinton fought for the last round of global trade liberalization, he never sweated the details. And plans announced last week for phasing out protection for clothing and textiles -- what Kimberly Elliott, a researcher at the Institute of International Economics, calls "the last great bastion of protectionism" -- suggest the President is, at the very least, a passive accomplice to the regression of his own Administration.
No part of the recent world trade agreement was greeted with more enthusiasm by free traders than the commitment to untangle a rat's nest of quotas and tariffs that has governed world trade in apparel and textiles for three decades. Ms. Elliott and Gary Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, estimate that unlimited imports would reduce clothing costs in the United States by 18 percent.
Price breaks would almost certainly be steepest at the low end -- underwear, children's apparel, cotton pants and shirts -- where the struggling middle class does its shopping. "The benefits should add up to as much as the House Republicans' proposed middle class tax cut," said Robin Lenier, a lobbyist for clothing retailers, "and it wouldn't cost Washington a penny."
What's more, the jobs at risk are not the ones America has been mourning since the 1970's. They typically pay less than $7 an hour. And if there is one clear lesson from a decade of booming employment and slipping wages, America has no problem replacing bad jobs.
But as the retailers are discovering, it will take a silver bullet to kill the global quota system
known as the Multi-Fiber Arrangement. The United States has 10 years to get with the program, and the Washington bureaucrats who just firmed up plans to phase out protection are plainly in no hurry. Phase I (1995-97) includes such treasured items as parachutes and seat belts. Phases II and III, extending to 2004, cover just 11 percent of the categories where quotas actually bite.
Retailers initially expected that some of the pressure on clothing prices would be relieved by a parallel agreement allowing the volume of imports entering under quota to expand. But the numbers hammered out at Geneva are too modest to make a dent: Demand for clothing is still likely to outpace quota-constrained supply.
That will leave the domestic industry sitting pretty until it falls off a precipice in 2005. Some 150,000 jobs, albeit very low-paying jobs, would be put at risk in a single year rather than phased out over a decade. "We knew the phase-out schedule would be backloaded, but this is worse than we feared," Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, lamented.
The smart money says it will never come to that. Once the precipice is in view, Congress will likely break the trade accord, extending the quota unilaterally. As a last resort, domestic apparel producers could ask the International Trade Commission to impose "temporary" quotas to save them from injury from the expected surge of imports -- a tactic akin to that of a parent killer who demands mercy as an orphan.
There is no shortage of villains. Rita Hayes, the Commerce Department official who wrote the rules, has close ties to Congressmen from the Southern textile states. So does Jennifer Hillman, the deputy to the United States trade representative in charge of apparel. Her boss, Mickey Kantor, has made no secret of his sympathies, announcing just one day after public hearings that there would be no changes in the proposed phase-out schedule. And, of course, there is Mr. Kantor's boss, Bill Clinton, who appointed them all.
But in a tepid defense of the President, Ms. Lenier points out that his Administration is merely going along with a game that started long, long ago. "The program stinks -- and the program's 30 years old," she said. While Republican Presidents were ideologically committed to free trade and not beholden to the apparel makers' unions, they, too, avoided tangling with the textile lobby.
The tragedy here is President Clinton's inability to break free from interest group politics as usual. The New Democrat pledged to reconcile liberal sympathies for the losers in the capitalist free-for-all with the new realities of a globally integrated economy has been left with the dirty work of defending the industrial dinosaurs.

HEADLINE: Second Night of Caution at Auction

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Where has the passion gone? While the buyers were out in full force last night at Christie's sale of contemporary art, caution was the watchword. Works sold, but few takers were willing to reach for the stars and push prices beyond their estimates.
The sale totaled $11.3 million, not too far below Christie's estimate of $13 million to $17 million. Of the 52 works offered, 44 found buyers. Sotheby's sale of contemporary art on Tuesday night made $13 million, also below the house estimate of $15.7 million to $22 million. At Sotheby's, 36 of the 46 works found buyers. Americans dominated the buying on both nights. 
 "There were a lot of buyers tonight, which shows the market is healthy," said Diane Upright, who heads the contemporary art department at Christie's in New York, after the sale. "That things sold within the estimates shows that we're evaluating our market accurately."
Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in America and the evening's auctioneer, said he was pleased with the number of bidders. "There was confidence in the market, which was borne out by the percentage of works sold," he said.
Like Sotheby's sale, Christie's contemporary-art auction featured more classic works by artists including Roy Lichtenstein, Jackson Pollock and Jasper Johns, and fewer works by stars of the 1980's. Christie's only had two million-dollar-plus works, Mr. Lichtenstein's "Kiss II" and Jackson Pollock's "Eyes in the Heat II," and many by artists like Donald Judd, Frank Stella and Morris Louis in the $300,000-and-under range. "Above $1 million, the market is still thin," Ms. Upright said.
Last night's sales results were proof. By far the star of the evening was "Kiss II" (1962), one of Mr. Lichtenstein's famous comic-book images of a couple kissing. An unidentified telephone bidder won the painting after fighting it out with an unidentified man in the salesroom. The price was $2.5 million, right at Christie's low estimate.
The seller was Masao Wanibuchi, a Tokyo-based tailor who had bought the painting in May 1990 at Christie's in New York for $6 million, still the record for the artist. Mr. Wanibuchi, who sold Andy Warhol's "Shot Red Marilyn" for $3.6 million at Christie's last fall, tried his luck again last night, but he was willing to take a big loss. "It's a satisfactory price in the current market," Mr. Burge said.
Mr. Lichtenstein has been the one of the highest-profile artists not only of the week, but also of the last six months. "The Nurse" (1964), another comic-book image of one of his prototypical blondes, was sold at Sotheby's on Tuesday night to an unidentified American collector bidding by phone for $1.6 million, just above its estimate of $1.5 million. Last fall, the SoHo dealer Holly Solomon, sold "I . . . I'm Sorry" (1965-66) to Eli Broad, the Los Angeles collector, for $2.5 million, its high estimate.
(Final prices include the auction house's commission, 15 percent of the first $50,000 plus 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
Unlike the Pop art, the important Abstract Expressionist did not fare well. Pollock's "Eyes in the Heat II" (1947), a densely painted work in which the artist applied silver-colored paint with both a palette knife and a brush, and also squeezed his paint onto the canvas directly from the tube, failed to sell. Although there were two bidders in the salesroom, no one was willing to pay more than $880,000, far below its estimate of $1.2 million to $1.8 million.
Another Abstract Expressionist work, Clyfford Still's "Untitled" (1946-47), also went unsold. Bidding never rose above $480,000, far below its estimate of $750,000 to $950,000. (Still has notoriously poor results at auction.) But two small untitled Rothkos had lots of takers. One from 1960-61, estimated at $180,000 to $220,000, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $266,500. Another, from 1959, sold to Abigail Asher, a dealer, for $354,500, well above its $250,000-to-$300,000 estimate.
Gerhard Richter also brought some life to the auction room. "Alster" (1963), a dreamy view of Alster, a lake in the center of Hamburg, estimated at $150,000 to $180,000, was sold to a telephone bidder for $299,500, far above its high estimate of $180,000. At Sotheby's on Tuesday night, another Richter, "Corner of the Cathedral" (1987), was expected to sell for $300,000 to $400,000 but soared to $662,500.
Sculpture is one area of the market that has been strong recently. Last night Isamu Nocuhi's "Sun" (1963), an exquisitely carved white marble circle that had sat in the architect Gordon Bunshaft's East Hampton, L.I., garden, was bought by Larry Gagosian, the Manhattan dealer for $552,500, just above Christie's $450,000 estimate. The sculpture was sold by the Museum of Modern Art, which had been bequeathed it by the architect Gordon Bunshaft and his wife, Nina. The proceeds are to go for acquisitions in the museum's department of painting and sculpture.
Alexander Calder, once considered recession-proof, was tested again last night. Among his works for sale at Christie's were "Five Points" (1957), a large black-painted steel sculpture from the estate of the cartoonist Robert Osborn and his wife, Elodie, was expected to fetch $600,000 to $800,000. It sold to Ms. Asher for $640,500. A large Calder mobile, "Double Gong" (1953) failed to sell at Sotheby's on Tuesday night. After an estimate of $1 million, bidding stopped at $880,000.
While work by 1980's artists has been scarce this week, what was for sale last night did well. An untitled bronze sculpture by Joel Shapiro from 1986-87 was bought by an unidentified American collector for $288,500, nicely above its $250,000 high estimate and a record price for the artist. And Eric Fischl's "Love" (1981), estimated at $70,000 to $90,000, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $195,000.
One artist who has been having a renaissance for some time is Andy Warhol. This was true last night, too. Warhol's "Double Elvis" 1963), a portrait of Elvis Presley as a cowboy against a silver background, based on publicity stills from Presley's 1960 Western "Flaming Star," was expected to bring $600,000 to $800,000 and brought only $497,500 from an unidentified telephone bidder.
But the biggest surprise of the evening came from Warhol's "Nine Multicolored Marilyns (Reversal Series)," from 1979. Suddenly the salesroom erupted with bidders. At one point, three Christie's employees on the telephones were calling out bids, and hands were waving in the audience. As the price rose, the number of bidders diminished until it was down to two. An unidentified American collector bidding by phone was the winner, paying $585,500, nearly twice its high estimate of $300,000. Mr. Burge proclaimed the moment "an old-fashioned duel," but many people were perplexed. The Marilyn Monroe Reversal series is not rare.
"Somebody spent a lot of money on a very boring Warhol," said Elaine Dannheisser, a prominent New York collector. "Obviously they had a lot of money and didn't know what to do with it."

HEADLINE: Europe Still Gives Big Doses of Money To Help the Arts

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 1

 BODY:
Lionel Jospin is a socialist and Jacques Chirac a conservative, but when it comes to cultural policy, it is hard to tell they are competing fiercely for the French Presidency in Sunday's runoff election: both have pledged to keep pouring vast amounts of taxpayers' money into the arts. This is, of course, a French tradition.
While most American cultural institutions depend largely on wealthy patrons and corporate sponsors for financing, governments here have long sustained the arts. Indeed, France's subsidy system today is considered essential to keeping Anglo-Saxon culture at bay. True, the candidates are also acting out of self-interest. France's cultural elite, pampered by President Francois Mitterrand over the last 14 years, would very likely savage any politician who threatened its privileges. So instead, Mr. Jospin and Mr. Chirac are busily wooing leading artists and intellectuals. 
 France's movie lobby, for example, is already confident of continued aid. "Cinema is a topic of consensus in the French election campaign," said Daniel Toscan du Plantier, the president of Unifrance, an association of movie producers, directors and actors. "The candidates have run after us."
Yet perhaps the main difference between French and American approaches to culture is to be found in the electorate itself. With polls showing that a majority of French like the cultural fare they are spoon-fed by the Government, there are no votes to be had from attacking public-sector financing of the arts. Much the same could be said throughout Europe. An economic recession has squeezed cultural budgets and sharpened competition for funds in some countries. In Eastern Europe, the collapse of Communism has decimated long-entrenched subsidy systems, leaving many opera, dance and theater companies close to bankruptcy.
But in contrast to the United States, it is rare today to find a European politician or policy maker who views the arts through either a moral or an ideological prism. Rather, in a region steeped in history, culture is considered a source of national pride and a main ingredient of national identities.
At present, European governments routinely spend 5 to 15 times more per head on culture than the United States. Further, the new Republican leadership in Congress is contemplating large cuts in economic support for the National Endowment for the Arts and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which currently receive around $450 million a year.
Only in Britain has government financing of the arts been held down as a matter of policy rather than of economic necessity. But culture has not been singled out for punishment: Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Government has been cutting public spending across the board, alienating doctors and nurses as much as performing artists and museum directors. "There's a feeling the arts should better justify spending taxpayers' money," said Jeremy Eckstein, a researcher at the London-based Policy Studies Institute, explaining the Government's position. "But we don't have the vociferous right wing you have in the United States. We have a long way to go before we get into a situation like that."
In fact, even in Britain, optimism is stirring following the decision to use some of the profits of a new national lottery to build or renovate theaters, museums and concert halls. But program financing may still be in short supply. "Lots of people are suspicious that the Government will reduce its own support because of the lottery," Mr. Eckstein said. Lord Gowrie, the chairman of the Arts Council of England, which this year will spend $300 million on culture, is a constant campaigner for more funds. "It is no use having a marvelous new national center for dance and ballet, for instance, if we cannot afford to pay people to dance in it or if our best dancers are being trained to emigrate," he warned recently.
Elsewhere in Europe, it is not unusual to hear theater and museum directors complaining about frozen budgets. Yet the principle of government support for the arts -- and public broadcasting -- is not challenged. Rather, culture is generally viewed as a public service that, despite some corporate sponsoring of cultural events, the public sector is expected to provide. What varies is the way cultural spending is defined (one-third of Denmark's $1.5 billion cultural budget, for instance, goes to libraries) and how taxpayers' money reaches cultural institutions. Further, some countries separate, say, conservation of monuments from financing of the performing arts.
Direct comparisons between cultural budgets are therefore tricky. In Italy, with its wealth of museums, churches and archeological sites, management and preservation of the national heritage is the responsibility of the Ministry of Cultural Assets, which has an annual budget of around $1.2 billion. On the other hand, subsidies for opera houses, orchestras and the movie industry, totaling around $700 million a year, come from the Department of Tourism and Performing Arts.
But in many European countries, financing of both the performing arts and construction of new museums is increasingly being shared by regional and municipal governments that recognize culture to be an important magnet for tourism. The new Guggenheim Museum being built in Bilbao, Spain, for instance, is being paid for largely by the country's Basque region. And Barcelona's new Contemporary Art Museum was jointly financed by the Barcelona and Catalan governments.
In Germany, culture is subsidized almost entirely by the governments of the 16 federal states and three city states, Berlin, Hamburg and Bremen. In 1989, for example, only 5 percent of the $7 billion in tax revenue spent on the arts and museums came from the central government, although this share has since risen as Bonn has moved to aid the five federal states of former East Germany. Andreas Johannes Wiesgand, director of the Bonn-based Center for Cultural Research, has estimated that private patronage of the arts represents only 2 to 3 percent of what the public sector provides in Germany. And the share would be even smaller if government support for public radio and television companies were included.
The director of the London-based International Arts research bureau, Rod Fisher, said Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, Norway and France were the European countries with the most developed systems of public financing of the arts. "Things are becoming more difficult everywhere," he said, "but compared to the United States, culture is very well supported in much of Europe."
The last detailed attempt to compare cultural spending in the United States and Europe dates back to a report by the Policy Studies Institute published in 1990 but based on 1987 data. Its broad conclusion, though, is still thought to be valid: that public expenditure on the arts and museums in the United States is far less than in five selected European countries.
The study backed its conclusion by calculating arts expenditure as a percentage of total public expenditure and of the gross domestic product as well as by comparing local, regional and central government arts expenditure per head. For 1987, it estimated total public-sector arts expenditure per head to be $4 in the United States, $19 in Britain, $41 in the Netherlands, $43 in France, $48 in what was then West Germany and $55 in Sweden.
France stands out, though, because its strong tradition of centralized government gives the Culture Ministry enormous power, a power that was reinforced under Mr. Mitterrand, who set the target of giving the ministry 1 percent of the Government budget. In practice, it was achieved only in 1993, and the ministry's share has slipped to 0.91 percent this year. But both Mr. Jospin and Mr. Chirac have pledged to meet this target -- equivalent to about $3 billion per year -- if they win Sunday's election. And they agree that after the outgoing President's concentration on Grands Travaux, or great works, in Paris, it is time to give more attention to the provinces. All that France's artistic world still needs to know, then, is the name of the next Culture Minister.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Home Desk 

LENGTH: 1679 words

HEADLINE: The Last Open Space May Come With Tees

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
LIKE the pioneers, they talk about land, wide-open, green and rolling. But their quest in the exurban wilderness is not for a farm in God's country; it's for a $400,000 house with a view of the 18th hole.
"We knew if we bought a place here that no one would put a house in front of us," said Dan Wyckoff, as he and his wife, Jenna, looked out at the vast expanse of fairway beyond their window at Ivanhoe Estates, a 400-acre gated community about 35 miles northwest of Chicago. 
 Golf communities used to be the destinations of retired snowbirds looking for a warm place for the winter: in Florida, Arizona, California and Texas. But now, golf communities are going up in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and they're booming in the Midwest. There are 38 just in the 11 counties surrounding Chicago.
A farmhouse may still sit next to a video store, or a stable of horses may stick their heads out of their stalls on a busy highway, but the landscape feels like wall-to-wall malls, office parks and housing. Those who can afford to buy a house facing the fairway count themselves lucky to look out on some of the last open space in the neighborhood.
Anne and James Marshall live on the 18th fairway at Crystal Tree, a gated golf community about 25 miles southwest of Chicago. With 450 homes ranging from $200,000 to $1.7 million, it was carved out of 600 acres of woodland and old farm fields five years ago.
The Marshalls followed the bulldozers that molded the earth into treacherous sand traps and water hazards for the golf course designed by Robert Trent Jones Jr.
"We ate dirt for two years, ankle deep in mud, trying to figure out where the 18th hole was going to be," Mr. Marshall said. His wife added: "We watched the clubhouse being built. There was a certain romanticism to it."
About 12 percent of the nation's 15,000 golf courses are linked to residential development. Among new courses being built, the percentage of golf communities has stabilized at about 30. Many of the communities are gated, and about half have private courses. The other half allow the public to play for a daily fee of $25 to $100.
In most cases, you don't have to live in the community to play on a private course, but, like the residents themselves, you do have to join the club, which costs an initial $25,000 at Crystal Tree and $50,000 at Ivanhoe, plus annual fees.
Residents inside the gates say they need them for security. But they are also a status symbol. "A lot of times, there's nobody even guarding the gate," said Tim Nugent, who helped his father, Richard Nugent, build the golf course at Ivanhoe. "People buy into these places because they want a sense of belonging. If you say you live at Ivanhoe or Desert Mountain, in Arizona, people know what that means."
Richard McElyea, the president of Economics Research Associates, a real estate consulting firm in San Francisco, said: "Just being inside the gate, so to speak, increases the value of the property by 5 to 10 percent. If you have a to-die-for view, say, over the water, or the 18th green, sometimes that's a 100 percent premium."
And each club has a certain position on the social ladder.
"Crystal Tree is like good old South Siders who stay close to their roots," said Maureen Haberkorn, whose husband, Jack, the owner of the Bonus Electric Company, is president of the golf club. The Haberkorns keep a cooler of beer on the deck for thirsty golfers nearing the 13th hole, which is at their back door.
Mr. Haberkorn, the son of a firefighter, said: "There's no old money here at all. All the children of the industrialists are on the North Side."
Mrs. Haberkorn walks every morning with friends. "One of the girls said she hadn't felt this sense of camaraderie since high school," she said. "And it's the truth."
The Chicago suburbs were once prairie where Indians roamed thousands of years before the first colonists. Now the landscape is rolling bunkers, emerald green fairways and 3,000-square-foot villas big enough to house whole tribes of golfers.
"We're on the edge of civilization out here," said Courtney Luc, standing by her 12-person hot tub overlooking the ninth hole at Ivanhoe. Ms. Luc, a part-time legal secretary, doesn't golf, but she loves walking on the course.
Her husband, Jerry, the president of an electronic control systems company, recalled: "The first night we were here happened to be the Fourth of July. It was really dark and there weren't any people around and a coyote was howling."
Joe Rice went in search of this land about 10 years ago, after his old club losts its course in Deerfield, Ill., when the property was sold for housing.
He found it at a little rural crossroads called Ivanhoe: "I hacked my way through the woods, which was full of mosquitoes," he said. "When I saw the lake, I knew this was it."
What Mr. Rice had stumbled upon was an old golf course built in the 1930's, complete with a 15-acre lake to irrigate the greens and two log cabins to house barrels of beer to irrigate the golfers.
Mr. Rice's club bought all 225 acres for $2 million and built a $3.5 million 18-hole course and a $12 million clubhouse, while residences were developed around it.
Golf roots go deep in Chicago. In 1893, industrialists imported the game from Scotland and formed the Chicago Golf Club in Wheaton, one of the first clubs in the country.
There is even a village called Golf (pop. 454) that sprang up about 15 miles northwest of Chicago, simply because the chairman of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad made his engineers stop the train there so he could play a round or two at Glen View Club, one of his favorite clubs. Another train would pick him up later.
The game has long been associated with the rich and the powerful. And the course is still the place where deals are made and character is revealed.
"I wouldn't trust anyone who cheats on a golf course," said Robert Hendricks, a vice president for Anixter Inc., a wiring systems distributor. He and his wife, Sharon, live near the 17th tee at Royal Melbourne, a new golf community northwest of Chicago near Long Grove, Ill. "Like giving the ball the old foot wedge in the woods," he continued. "Golf is a game of honor."
Mr. and Mrs. Hendricks knew enough to site their house near, but not too close to, the 17th green -- away from the line of fire.
"There's one house on the 15th hole that's a natural," Mrs. Hendricks said. "If you pull hook the ball on your second shot you can put it right through the window."
Broken windows are such a problem in some communities that unlucky residents have to install plexiglass, and the club may set up a "window fund," in case some golfer doesn't fess up.
Golf is known largely as a white sport. Of the 24 million Americans who play it, fewer than a million are members of minority groups, said Hugh White, the vice president of research at the New York Times Sports/ Leisure Magazines Group. While club managers at golf communities are quick to say that no bylaws keep minorities out, the lack is glaring.
Elliott Williams, who has played public courses in Chicago for 26 years, said he had never tried to join a private one. "Blacks have been excluded economically, because this is a game that requires a moderate to good income," he said. "And we're just getting to that level now."
Mr. Williams, who owns the Williams Insurance Group in Midlothian, Ill., plans to build a golf community on the South Side of Chicago that he said would welcome African-Americans and serve as an inspiration for young black players.
"It would be upscale housing," he said. "It will be a mixed community, not a private black country club."
Unlike towns that have taken decades to evolve, these instant golf community landscapes seem bland and devoid of character. But to their residents they are oases of peace and a certain controlled beauty.
At Royal Melbourne, Jerry and Dee Cwiok go out their back door and play a few holes in the evening. They watch the frogs in the pond, and the big heron fishing. Mr. Cwiok loves the smell of grass at night, when the water system goes on.
Golf courses have long been notorious for their heavy use of pesticides, but greenskeepers say they have come a long way from the old days, when DDT was used to kill the earthworms that made the greens messy. Many residents said that they were concerned about the use of pesticides on golf courses but that they trusted their greenskeepers to use them judiciously.
"My son plays in the pond near our house, and there are plenty of frogs and turtles," said Dr. David Goldrath, a urologist who lives at Wynstone, a private gated community near Ivanhoe and Royal Melbourne. "We are concerned about the chemicals, which is why we don't live right on the course. But with all these wetlands here, they have to be careful."
Golf has a way of shaping not only the landscape, but also the players' experience as they move through the landscape.
"I like the transition in and out of woods," said Richard Nugent, who designed the course at Ivanhoe. "I like the spatial experience, of being tight and enclosed -- and then coming through an open space. It's also an infinitely varied space: the smells of plants, the sounds of birds. At one hole the wind's in your face; at the next, it's at your back."
As wild plants and animals retreat from the march of Chicago's suburbs, these manicured open spaces, especially those with native grasses, wetlands and a patch of untouched brambly woods, are becoming refuges for species adaptable enough to survive golf carts and bent grass.
Some think this is plenty wild enough.
Ray and Sue Dignan have two sons, Ray Jr., 10, and Kevin, 5. Both boys are already golfing at Crystal Tree, but they also watch the fox lope off into the woods beyond the green in back of their house.
"Look over there," Mr. Dignan said, pointing to a small woods behind a fence. "It's like the northern woods of Wisconsin. It's the best-kept secret on the South Side of Chicago. It's not a flat cornfield. It's a gem."
