HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
In Search of a Pulse At High Point

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., April 29

 BODY:
It is claw-and-ball time again in America.
Wending its way from the more than 2,100 companies exhibiting their wares at the International Home Furnishings Market here to a store near you next fall is a tidal wave of prosperous conservatism, furniture that recycles the accouterments of grand houses in grand locales: Newport, R.I.; Savannah, Ga.; Charleston, S.C.; the Hudson River Valley; the south of France; Ireland; the English countryside, and the Scottish Highlands. A few of the pieces are great, many are indifferent, most are brown. 
 What's "in" at the spring edition of America's leading furniture fashion show -- which ends its twice-yearly, two-week run Friday afternoon -- is the past. And as seen by the 69,000 designers, store buyers and journalists from around the world, what's "out" is individuality and most decorative statements that allude to life on the verge of the 21st century.
Six months ago, the talk at High Point, a sleepy, azalea-bedecked city of 70,000, and its environs, was of adventuresome furniture designs and a growing economy. Conversations have now turned to concerns about rising interest rates, a weakened dollar, stagnant new-home sales and that old standby, consumer apathy. In less-than-buoyant times, safety -- namely old-fashioned neo-classicism -- sells.
"There isn't much to see, is there?" the interior designer Mario Buatta said with a sigh.
Still, the industry is growing, but slowly. According to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association, a trade group, $19.8 billion worth of home furnishings was ordered by retailers in 1994, nearly a 10 percent increase over 1993's $18 billion. Analysts predict that orders will reach $21.3 billion by the end of 1995.
Restrained design isn't necessarily a bad idea, of course, either financially or esthetically, but bringing back bread-and-butter basics means more than simply cranking out yet another dozen or two of design history's greatest hits. One trick to enticing wary consumers is to present furniture that looks comfortably familiar but transcends its regularity with a subtle shock of the new.
Several manufacturers rose to the challenge. Rather than promoting the imperial, impersonal grandeur of the famous so-called cottages of Newport, the E. J. Victor company came up with a tidy, tightly edited assortment of livable reproductions authorized by the Preservation Society of Newport County. Notable among the custom-quality upholstered armchairs and bits of chinoiserie was an English Georgian secretary whose diminutive but authentic dimensions -- approximately 30 inches wide, 18 inches deep and 7 feet tall -- made it one of the rare grand historic reproductions that would fit in even the smallest apartment.
Led by Sir Humphrey Wakefield, a fast-talking baronet with an eye for the eccentric, Baker's Stately Homes Collection introduced a line of exuberant Irish Georgian furniture outfitted with details that disregard conventional rules of proportion. Pediments look twice as large as necessary, hairy-paw feet are swollen to bovine breadth, and grapefruit-size ram's heads jut along the front of a marble-topped console table.
Baker also introduced a plainly finished mahogany table whose discreet neo-Gothic silhouette looks as modern now as it must have when a Russian Czar commissioned the original, now in the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, in the early 1800's. That piece and another Stately Homes entry -- a Dutch center table inlaid with folk-art stars -- looked far fresher than the strangely stodgy French Provincial line seen at Baker's usually hip spinoff, Milling Road.
Stodgy, too, were Mark Hampton's additions to his European Country Collection for Hickory Chair, a division of Lane. Bulky and made of coarse-grained oak, the 17th-century-inspired canopy bed and Tudor esque tables seemed out of character for the urbane Mr. Hampton, who has shown himself to be a master of mass-produced furnishings with the panache of the custom made.
Especially disappointing, given the premarket hype and the involvement of the popular English decorator Jane Churchill, was the Royal Country Retreats collection by Drexel Heritage -- lumbering "adaptations" of noble British country-house furniture given coarse paint jobs and clumsy carving.
One happy side effect of all these backward glances, however, was that fresh ideas stood out in even bolder relief.
From Calligaris were rows of simple polished birch side chairs, one with stencil-like leaf cutouts along the back. Brown-Jordan offered the brilliantly reductivist Venice canopy bed, a slender, cast-aluminum cage enameled a silvery shade of celadon. And at the booth of Mobili di Castello, an Italian company making its High Point debut, was a palazzo-style bookcase painted in robust shades of terra cotta and olive green.
From the L.& J. G. Stickley company, purveyors of fine Arts and Crafts reproductions, came a handsome copy of an early-20th-century wicker settee designed by Gustav Stickley for his home in Parsippany, N.J. Also exciting to look at was Bernhardt's cowboy-flavored camelback sofa, Durango, its softly swooping, velvety leather form detailed with nailhead curlicues.
John Houck and Roger Plaster of the J & R Collection continue to impress with their focus on sleek, sensible furniture that marries the palest of woods to the coldest of metals. Perched on gently arched, brushed-aluminum feet, their Bastille maple bookcases and matching two-door cabinet have the modest appeal of line drawings.
High Point's bad boy is Larry Laslo, the Manhattan designer best known for the calm, luxurious interiors of the Takashimaya store on Fifth Avenue. Straddling the tension-filled line that separates camp from homage, Mr. Laslo's Act II collection for Directional bonded a glamorous grab bag of inspirations -- Marilyn Monroe, Brancusi, film noir set designs -- into a rollicking collage of fashion-forward fantasy.
Act II provided a stylistic jolt in a market sorely in need of animation. Cubist side tables coated in silver leaf stood next to shell-shaped sofas, and beneath a supernovalike chandelier made of sharp, menacing crystals stood Mr. Laslo's piece de resistance, the Stiletto dining chair.
"It's my dominatrix look," said Mr. Laslo, who wrapped the chair in a tartish ensemble -- black patent leather, polished chrome nailheads -- that paid tribute to vinyl-clad vixens of the 1960's like Diana Rigg's Emma Peel and the European B-movie siren Ira Furstenberg.
Though prone to self-consciously groovy shapes and searing color combinations, Milo Baughman of Thayer Coggin turned out a surprisingly crisp collection. His Design Classics recalled the fresh-scrubbed modernity practiced by the 1960's interior decorator Billy Baldwin (not to mention a recent furniture line by Ralph Lauren).
Mr. Baughman's pale-wood sectional sofas and cubic chairs -- boxy, angular, free of distracting details -- were clean and precisely tailored, with the brisk, well-groomed look that is the quintessence of American interior design.
That is what High Point needs more of. There's always next fall.

C1) (Baker (top); Directional); Birch chair by Calligaris with Shaker-style seat.; Mobili di Castello's painted bookcase, imitating an Umbrian heirloom.; J & R Collection's footed Bastille bookcases.; From Thayer Coggin, 60's-style minimalism by Milo Baughman.; Baker's Russian Gothick console is copied from one in the Hermitage Museum. HEADLINE: Study Attacks F.A.A. on Child Safety Seats

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The main union of flight attendants yesterday renewed its campaign to make child safety seats mandatory on airplanes, aligning with the airlines and the National Transportation Safety Board, both of which contend that the Federal Aviation Administration's opposition makes no sense.
The union, the Association of Flight Attendants, issued a critique it had commissioned that rebutted the aviation agency's argument: that if parents had to pay for seats for babies who now fly as "lap children," many would choose to drive instead. That, the agency contends, would mean a higher death rate among travelers, since driving is more dangerous than flying. 
 "There are no valid economic reasons to believe that the conclusions drawn by the F.A.A. have a basis in fact," said the report's author, Darryl Jenkins, a visiting scholar at George Washington University who is a specialist in airline economics.
Mr. Jenkins, who said he had worked on developing fare structures at five major airlines, contended that the carriers had a poor understanding of families' financial decision-making despite having spent "hundreds of millions of dollars" to determine the price sensitivity of their customers, deciding what price they will pay and at what fare level they will either drive or stay home rather than fly.
And if the airlines have little understanding of this issue, the aviation agency has even less, said Mr. Jenkins, who described the agency's analysis of the safety-seat matter as too simplistic, partly because it failed to take into account air fares' decline in recent years.
Larry West, a spokesman for the aviation agency, said it had not yet had time to react to the new report but that "our message is not that they're wrong and we're right -- we all have the same goal." Still, he said, if bringing a baby along means extra cost, some travelers will be drawn to less safe means of transportation.
The latest round of debate on any requirement that children be restrained during air travel began last month when the National Transportation Safety Board, analyzing the crash of a USAir turboprop on approach to Charlotte, N.C., last July, concluded that a 9-month-old girl who had been ripped from her mother's arms by the force of the crash and thrown over three rows of seats would probably have survived had she been in a child safety seat. The board made a similar finding about a child aboard a United Airlines jet that crashed in a cornfield near Sioux City, Iowa, in July 1989.
And Chris Witkowski, the safety director of the flight attendants' union, pointed out yesterday that when a DC-10 encountered turbulence near Puerto Rico in 1990, the only serious injury among the 144 passengers was to an infant, riding on an adult's lap, who suffered a skull fracture.
Discussing his criticism in a telephone interview, Mr. Jenkins said the F.A.A.'s analysis ignored the economic experience of the last few years, in which declining air fares and new cut-rate airlines have drawn travelers out of their cars and into airplanes.
He also made another argument: that if children under 2 were required to have their own seats, the airlines would surely find a low-cost way to accommodate them.
"If there are two people willing to pay a fare, we're not going to lose those two fares over an airline seat for a baby," he said. "What drives everybody batty over this is the airlines have said that themselves."
So far, no airline has required safety seats on its own, perhaps fearing that to do so would put it at a competitive disadvantage. But Mr. Jenkins predicted that some airlines would soon offer free seats to babies on off-peak flights, as a marketing tool.
In the midst of the renewed debate, an aeronautical inventor in Smyrna, Tenn., is offering an entirely different solution: a baby seat that does not take up an adult's seat.
The inventor, Thomas E. Bennington, has been making the rounds with his product, which is designed to rest between the feet of an adult passenger and fasten to the jet's floor the same way that regular seats do, on tracks that run the length of the plane.
"It guarantees free seats for kids in a full airplane," said Mr. Bennington, who patented the design in 1993 and holds two other patents on aeronautical devices. His mock-up is in its fourth version and has attracted the interest of some safety engineers, but he has not yet found a manufacturer. The aviation agency is looking it over but has offered no judgments.
Mr. Bennington, a pilot, started his design work while on strike against Eastern Air Lines. He is now manager of flight operations for Capital Air, in Smyrna.
"I've always been concerned about loose infants," he said. "They're like little baby rockets during impact."
The seats would differ from plane to plane, because the distance between the floor tracks differs. As a result, the seat would have to be provided by the airline, not the parent. It would probably cost several hundred dollars, Mr. Bennington said, and would be used in front of the window seat, to avoid blocking the row.
The seat is 11 inches wide. It would fold flat to fit in an overhead bin when not in use. The design also includes a net behind the parent's heels that would prevent bags stored under other seats from sliding forward into the baby.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 4 about a campaign by the Association of Flight Attendants to make child safety seats mandatory on airplanes misidentified the type of plane in which a baby was torn from her mother's arms by the force of a crash last July and killed. She was on a twin-jet USAir DC-9, not a turboprop.

Were it adopted, the product would presumably quell a debate on whether child safety seats should be required on airplanes. (Fritz Hoffman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Europe's Muslim Population: Frustrated, Poor and Divided

SERIES: Wary Strangers -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: MARSEILLES, France

 BODY:
In the streets rising from Marseilles's old port, couscous is easier to find than croissants. Cockney neighborhoods in London are now bazaars for Muslims from Bangladesh. Muezzins call Turks to prayer from new minarets in Cologne.
With 10 million to 13 million Muslims living in Western Europe, conservative and far-right politicians, including some voices in the French presidential campaign, have appealed to prejudice against the Muslim presence. 
 "France must firmly oppose clandestine immigration," Jacques Chirac, the conservative French presidential candidate, said recently. "Too often the laws of the republic are openly flouted."
Americans would find many of the European slogans familiar: Legal and illegal immigrants are taking your jobs, ruining the neighborhood, hurting the schools, increasing your taxes, swelling the welfare rolls, making the streets unsafe. And some politicians play on Europeans' fears of terrorism rising from the Muslims in their midst.
But five weeks of interviews in France, Germany, Britain and the Netherlands, where the largest concentrations of Muslims from Asia, Turkey and North Africa live, reveal a far more complex portrait.
Scores of interviews with Muslim immigrants who came to Western Europe to work in the 1960's, and with their children who were raised in Europe, depict a population that is divided and traumatized, weakened by unemployment and humiliated by dependence on social welfare.
The interviews described a Muslim population stymied by cultural values it does not share, having done little to integrate over the years. Many in the older generation, now largely retired or unemployed, appear disconnected from the societies they live in. Rather, they are trying to reconnect with the one they left behind, watching television programs broadcast by satellite from their native lands.
Adding to the cultural dissonance, their sons and daughters are no longer connected to Muslim tradition, many seeking to adopt the views and values of European society. In fact, most Muslims in Europe are not political or even particularly religious -- a silent majority who want simply to carry out their lives as best they can.
Still, the anxiety about Muslims has been raised to the level of geopolitics. This year the Secretary General of NATO, Willy Claes of Belgium, pronounced militant Islam as important a strategic threat today as the Soviet Union was before Communism imploded in 1989.
"At the moment, I'd say the fantasy part of the perception of militant Islam as a menace in Europe is greater than the reality," said Francois Burgat, an expert on militant Islam at the National Center for Scientific Research at Aix-en-Provence, France.
The fears, however exaggerated, have been fed by the arrest in Europe of scores of Muslim militants, mostly from North Africa, on charges of stockpiling weapons and explosives for use back home.
Islam's recent and highly visible presence in Europe has run into resistance, analysts say, for many reasons: bigotry, the religious zeal of some Muslim immigrants, the inability of some new arrivals to adapt to a dominant European culture, the alienation that is common among Muslim youths.
 
 
Divided
Opposing Values Generate Tensions
 In Heerlen, a Dutch town of 35,000 near the German border, Sheik Ahmed Ali Saroukh fidgeted with a cup of tea in a grimy factory that was transformed seven years ago into Masjid Al Nour, the Mosque of Light, as he pondered how to turn the town into a center of Islam.
The preacher, who came to Herleen about five years ago from Morocco, wants to put up a minaret on the building, topped by a loudspeaker to broadcast the call to prayer five times a day, starting at dawn.
He advocates that Dutch women who are teachers in Heerlen wear a veil in schools when teaching Muslim children and that boys be segregated from girls. He also wants the local hospital to build a mosque for the handful of Muslim patients who end up there and serve them meat prepared under Islamic regulations. There are about 750,000 Muslims in the Netherlands, out of a total population of 15 million.
"The fact that they allow us to have mosques does not mean they love us," Sheik Saroukh said, stroking his graying beard. "On the contrary, they fear us. The proof is they are fighting us every step of the way as we try to claim our rights. They have different values from us. The Dutch man and his wife work. They raise dogs, not children. We want our women to raise children and stay protected at home."
While Sheik Saroukh attributed the failure to achieve his goals to Dutch discrimination, his principal obstacle is Heerlen's deeply divided population of 2,500 Muslims from Morocco, Turkey and some Arab countries, many poorly educated and unemployed, heavily dependent on the generous Dutch welfare system.
The sheik's mosque attracts a minority of older-generation Moroccans. But whether it is a small Muslim community in nearby Aachen, Germany, or a large one like the estimated 150,000 largely North African Muslims in Marseilles, France, religious militancy has widened the generational divide.
Mohammad el-Jashi, 32, a Moroccan mechanic technician who lives in Venlo, the Netherlands, wants to become part of Dutch society.
"Sometimes militants here ask for ridiculous things, like segregated schooling," he said. "We didn't have that in Morocco. I went to a mixed school until I left at 15 to join my father. My heart remains in Morocco, but my head says we stay here where my family is better off."
And in Heerlen, a breakaway group of Muslims established their own mosque in space lent by a liberal Christian missionary center a few blocks away on Putgraaf Street. There, a 32-year-old Palestinian named Khalil Shahine was contemptuous of Sheik Saroukh.
"Before conquering Europe for Islam, which is a hope, we should concentrate on building up our weak, illiterate societies, our people, with education and knowledge," Mr. Shahine said.
Mostapha Dalouj, 36, a physicist by training who accepted a job as social worker in Venlo after learning Dutch but failing to land a job in his area of expertise, said that repeated rejection was pushing him to avoid assimilation into Dutch ways.
"I came by choice from Morocco, equipped with a fair idea of Western societies," he said. "But until now I can't understand what they mean by integration. I want to be a Muslim living in Holland. But that does not mean I want to melt completely in this society and disappear, which is what the Dutch want. When I say that I speak to my children in Arabic, they answer: you are a racist. I am just trying to teach them some of the tradition."
Amizian El Hussein, 51, an unskilled Moroccan laborer, came to the Netherlands three decades ago. "I don't know if we changed or the Dutch have changed," he said. "When I came here I didn't think much of religion. Like most who came here, I was illiterate, but the living was good and there was no friction. They treated us well, and we behaved better than the young generation now.
"I now find myself praying regularly," he added. "My children have had problems in school. Some have dropped out. So now, when I look back, I can't blame it on the Dutch really, but it is true they have become resentful of foreigners and we are not doing as well as we used to."
 
Integrated
A Job Can Make All the Difference
 Leila Yehiawi, 36, a sociologist in Marseilles, is a daughter of an illiterate Algerian father who is now retired from working as a laborer. She is part of the second generation that has emerged as the heart of Europe's Muslim communities.
Unlike many of her generation, she is highly educated and successful. Fluent in French, which she speaks with a native Marseilles accent, Ms. Yehiawi considers herself well integrated but deeply committed to the North African immigrants who did not make the transition into French society.
She works as a teacher and counselor at Lycee Jacques Raynaud, a vocational training school whose 250 students are largely Muslims who dropped out of other schools.
"My students accuse me of being a traitor because the image I reflect is one of success in an atmosphere of failure," she said. "Many of these kids come from homes where both parents are unemployed. They are lost as second-class citizens to whom France is inaccessible. Some adopt Islam as an exhibitionist factor to signal discontent, but, in reality, they are yearning to be equal citizens. Their problem is idleness and deprivation."
But of her own eight brothers and sisters, only two have jobs. "This high rate of unemployment is new, and it is the problem facing our communities -- not Islam, not militancy and not what is happening in Algeria," she said. "Work is the backbone of integration. The lack of it leaves a fertile ground for exploitation by fundamentalists."
Salah-Eddine Bariki, a 43-year-old Algerian who works at Radio Gazelle, a local station broadcasting ethnic programs in Marseilles for minorities, said it was absurd that Muslim communities could be the bedrock of an Islamic revolt.
There are an estimated 150,000 Muslims in Marseilles, with 43 places of worship. But a recent survey of foreigners living in France by the National Institute of Demographic Studies, which polled 13,000 people over eight months, found that 68 percent of those from Algeria considered themselves to have no religion.
Only 10 percent said they practiced Islam regularly, and 22 percent occasionally. Half of the men and a quarter of the women between 18 and 25 said they were involved in a relationship with a French-born person, and 87 percent of those born to Algerian parents considered French their mother tongue.
The problem, Mr. Bariki said, is not Islamic militancy but unemployment, in a country where more than 12 percent of all workers are jobless, with far more than that unemployed among the immigrants.
Hans Korz, a 58-year-old Dutch coordinator of welfare and rehabilitation consultant for the government in Venlo, said the same was true in the Netherlands, where unemployment is about 8 percent.
"Among immigrant youths, largely Turks and Moroccans, it is 60 percent for those between 17 and 25," he said. "The problem is not social, cultural or ideological. It is economic in the first place."
Many Moroccan immigrants, however, say that part of the problem lies in the resistance of Dutch society to foreigners who want to become part of it.
 
Feared
A Few Militants Fuel Suspicions
 Despite lack of evidence that militants have made significant inroads, some officials believe that Europe is in danger of being taken over by a wave of fundamentalism.
Patrick Lalande, a Paris prosecutor who specializes in terrorist affairs, said such thinking dominates French and other European government circles. Indeed, over the last year France, Germany and Belgium have arrested or expelled close to 200 Islamic militants on charges of subversion and arms trafficking.
The most important activity by such militants is logistical support -- buying weapons or sending faxes on behalf of armed groups in Algeria and fundamentalists battling the Governments of Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan and countries in the Persian Gulf region.
Members of one such group, the Algerian Fraternity in France, which included Moroccans, Algerians, Tunisians and one Egyptian fundamentalist, were arrested in France in July. Some members were found near the French-Spanish border loaded with arms and military uniforms on their way to Algeria. But most of those expelled were thrown out for nonmilitary activities like fundamentalist propaganda.
"We are facing a sort of Islamist international assault made up of networks of militants with connections to fundamentalist countries including the Sudan, Afghanistan and Iran," Mr. Lalande said. He said the militants' focus was not France or Europe, adding, "I think their main objective is to take over North Africa."
One way in which France has tried to cope with its estimated five million Muslims, the largest population in Europe, is to encourage what it calls "French Islam" -- promoting, through progressive Muslim preachers born in France, a modern, secular outlook for the religion.
It is still a modest effort, and far from successful. The French-appointed imam of the mosque of Paris, Dalil Boubaker, often says there is no contradiction between Islam and living in a secular society.
This approach has yet to prove convincing to orthodox believers. On the other hand, Muslim militants have yet to prove they can attract a significant following.
Sheik Mohammad Abelhadi Doudi is a staunch supporter of the Islamic Salvation Front, which is battling to establish an Islamic state in Algeria, and administers a mosque in Marseilles. He says that after more than a decade of trying, his militant version of Islam is simply not enough to win adherents who are unemployed, speak French and are exposed to "temptations" of Western life.
"If I give a young man a Koranic verse, does it solve his problems?" he said. "No. I have been doing this for 14 years, but it's like sowing the sea. Even if there are fruits, they are small and bitter. Islam cannot breathe freely in the West."
NEXT: Western Europeans react to Muslims in their midst.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.C.C. Hands Murdoch Victory on Ownership
 Rupert Murdoch won a big victory, even as the F.C.C. found his Australia-based News Corporation in technical violation of rules that limit foreign ownership of television stations to 25 percent. 
 The commission, as expected, gave him a clear map of how to win a waiver of the compliance rules, to retain the 99 percent ownership of eight television stations that are the heart of the Fox network. D5.
 
Dow Breaks 4,400, Then Retreats
 Blue-chip stocks fell as traders locked in gains ahead of today's employment report. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped as much as 37 points, crossing 4,400 for the first time, before closing down 13.49 points at 4,359.66. D6.
 
Retail Growth Weak in April
 Large retailers reported weak sales growth in April, with discount chains like Wal-Mart and Target posting the best results. The worst results were reported by moderate-priced and more expensive apparel chains, notably Ann Taylor Stores, which said its same-store sales were off 6.7 percent. D3.
 
YPF Chairman Dies in Plane Crash
 Jose Estenssoro, the chief executive and president of YPF S.A., the Argentine oil company, was killed in a plane crash in Ecuador. He was widely respected for transforming YPF into a model of efficiency. It was a heavily subsidized state monopoly when he assumed control in 1990. B8.
 
Reebok Price-Fixing Settlement
 Reebok International agreed to settle charges that it fixed retail prices for its Reebok and Rockport footwear and will pay $9.5 million in Federal and state antitrust claims. D2.
 
AT&T Names a New Computer Chief
 Ending a five-month search, AT&T appointed Lars Nyberg, an executive at Philips Electronics, to take charge of its beleaguered computer business, AT&T Global Information Solutions, succeeding Jerre L. Stead, who abruptly quit in January. D3.
 
Wanted: Reliable Data Compiler
 The Commerce Department is seeking a private custodian to compile and update its index of leading indicators and two companion gauges of economic turning points. D2.
 
Panel Urges Pension Changes
 A corporate group, the Committee for Economic Development, proposed that raises in Social Security benefits be held below the inflation rate and that all benefits exceeding what a worker has paid into the system be taxable. D2.
 
A Town vs. a Corporation
 Occidental Petroleum is the target of a giant class-action lawsuit concerning a chemical leak near Robstown, Tex., with most of the town's 12,000 residents as plaintiffs. "It's either the biggest fraud in history," said a lawyer in the case, "or the worst personal-injury case in Texas history." B18.

In Search of Monster Ratings
 NBC will broadcast "Jurassic Park" on Sunday, having paid $50 million for the broadcast rights to the hugely popular 1993 dinosaur movie. For NBC, it's a way to strengthen its ranking during the May "sweep" period; marketers including Burger King, Ford and Nike, expecting to garner huge audiences, are paying $650,000 for each 30-second spot. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D5.
 
Of Tires, Ownership and China
 Did Goodyear steal a tire factory? A seemingly absurd question, but a suit accusing it of having done so could bring a penalty of as much as $3 billion. It also illustrates the risks involved in doing business in China, home of the disputed plant. Market Place. D6.

HEADLINE: CLINTON OPPOSES MOVE TO TOUGHEN EMBARGO ON CUBA

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, which has taken steps in recent days signaling a new cooperation with Cuba, told Congress today that it opposed key parts of a Republican-sponsored bill that seeks to do just the opposite -- further isolate Fidel Castro.
A letter from a State Department official criticized the bill, which is intended to strengthen the 33-year-old American trade embargo against Cuba, on the ground that it would anger allies of the United States and force Washington to violate several international agreements. 
 The Administration detailed its objections within days of announcing that it would send all future Cuban boat people directly back to the Communist island nation. Many Cuban-American groups harshly criticized the sudden shift in immigration policy when it was announced on Tuesday, accusing the Administration of seeking rapprochement with Mr. Castro and betraying Cubans seeking freedom.
The bill that would bolster the embargo is sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who heads the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs. Supporters of the bill argue that putting additional pressure on Cuba now, after its loss of aid from the former Soviet Union, would topple the Castro Government.
Among other things, the bill would carry out these provisions:
*Ban American imports of sugar from any foreign country that buys sugar or molasses from Cuba.
*Deny visas to foreigners who use, manage or profit from property in Cuba that was expropriated from Americans.
*Reduce American contributions to the World Bank and other international financial institutions if they make loans to Cuba.
*Allow almost 6,000 American individuals and companies with claims of expropriated property in Cuba to sue foreign companies in American courts if the foreign companies are now profiting from those properties.
In opposing large parts of the bill, as in announcing the plan to repatriate future Cuban boat people, the Administration has shown a new willingness to flout the wishes of Cuban-American groups, especially the Cuban-American National Foundation, a conservative group that is the most powerful voice in that community.
"We recognize we may face criticism from certain domestic political quarters, but the potential foreign policy troubles this bill will create outweigh those concerns," said one senior Administration official.
Administration officials said they hoped to work closely with Congress to rework the bill.
Marc Thiessen, a spokesman for Mr. Helms, said today, "The fact that the Administration wrote a detailed six-page letter seeking changes indicates that the bill is going to pass and end up on Bill Clinton's desk."
In its letter to the House International Relations Committee, which was sent Friday and released today, the State Department said it was opposed to the provision that would bar countries that import Cuban sugar or molasses from selling sugar to the United States.
Allies like Canada and the European Union would view the provision as a violation of international trade agreements, the letter said. If enforced, the Administration warned, the provision could even prompt other countries to order trade retaliation against the United States.
"These provisions would also undermine the longstanding U.S. policies on secondary boycotts, as in the case of the Arab boycott of Israel, which the United States had long and vigorously opposed," said the letter, which was written by Wendy Sherman, the State Department's chief liaison with Congress.
The Administration also criticized the provision that would deny visas to foreigners who use or profit from property that the Cuban Government expropriated from an American.
The provision casts its net too wide, the letter said, because it could penalize shareholders in mutual funds investing in companies that profit from such confiscated property, or even the children of executives whose companies use confiscated property.
Moreover, some Administration officials say the bill would hurt America's relations with its allies more than it would hurt Cuba.
Jose Cardenas, Washington representative of the Cuban-American National Foundation, said today that it would be difficult for Congress and the Administration to forge a compromise.
"The intransigence on the Hill toward negotiating with the Administration on this is very strong," he said. "And I don't see it abating for some time because people feel so angry and betrayed by the decision to repatriate people to Cuba."
Some Cuban-American groups are also concerned that the White House is considering the relaxation of some restrictions it imposed on Cuban travel last August, when it sought to punish Havana for not doing more to stop the wave of boat people who were fleeing the island nation.
The Administration's new strategy toward Cuba emerged from a six-month policy review headed by senior officials, who concluded that new approaches were needed because the long trade embargo had failed to bring democracy to Cuba. The officials included Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff, Samuel Berger, the deputy national security adviser, and Morton Halperin, a senior official on the National Security Council.
Their views prevailed over the hard-line, mid-level Latin American specialists at the State Department, who favored as little cooperation with Havana as possible, officials said.
The Administration had high praise for a part of the bill that calls for provision of food, medicine and other assistance to help any new Cuban government that emerges that is intent on making the transition to democracy.
But the letter released today sharply criticized a provision that would cut Washington's contribution to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund if they lend money to the Castro Government. The letter also criticized the bill's call for slashing about $200 million in economic aid to Russia if it maintained an observation post in the island nation. The letter said it was reasonable for Russia to maintain the post to verify Washington's compliance with arms control agreements.
Representative Burton belittled the criticisms of the bill, saying the Administration's Cuba policy was "directed by left-wing people who want to take the pressure off of Fidel Castro."
He said the bill sought to create incentives to insure that foreign companies "not do business with Castro or buy expropriated American property, thus propping up his Government by giving him hard currency."
Mr. Burton expressed confidence that the bill would pass. The bill has nearly 50 co-sponsors in the House and 21 in the Senate, among them several Democrats, including Senator Bob Graham of Florida and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
Canada, Britain, France and the European Union have all protested the bill, saying the United States has no right to interfere in their trade with a third country.
Canadian officials have warned that if Canada's $500 million in sugar exports to the United States are barred because the nation imports Cuban sugar, then the United States might face retaliation against a like amount of exports to Canada.
"The people supporting this bill are ready to put up a naval blockade around Cuba," said Wayne Smith, a Cuba scholar who headed the United States Interests Section in Havana in the late 1970's. "They keep on wanting to ratchet things up. But the Administration just can't go as far as these people insist. At some point it had to resist."

HEADLINE: New Pressure on Japan to Open Car Market

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WHISTLER, British Columbia, May 4

 BODY:
The United States increased pressure on Japan today to open its markets to American automobiles and auto parts, with President Clinton warning of a "strong response" if no deal is reached.
Without significant progress in the trade talks here, officials said, the president's National Economic Council is likely go forward with a list of more than $1 billion in Japanese products that would be subjected to punitive tariffs. The council is to meet over the weekend. 
 Negotiators for both sides voiced increasing pessimism today about the prospects for an agreement. On Friday, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and the Japanese trade minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, are to resume direct talks to see if there is any chance for a breakthrough.
Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton told The Detroit Free Press that "the United States is committed to taking strong action" if no deal is reached.
The paper's Friday issue quoted the President as saying the hard-line negotiating stance taken by Mr. Kantor "is my line, it is my conviction."
"I have worked for over two years on this," Mr. Clinton said. "We've tried all those other things and they have not worked, so we are going to have to be very strong.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Assails Clinton on Mexico Bailout

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
House Speaker Newt Gingrich contended today that the White House had not provided full disclosure on the financial bailout deal with Mexico and that the Administration had violated a three-week-old Federal law by extending a $3 billion midterm loan to Mexico last month.
Mr. Gingrich raised his accusations in a letter to President Clinton in which he said that the Republican-controlled Congress "will not countenance such willful lawbreaking by the executive branch." But the Speaker did not threaten any specific action against the Administration and one of his senior aides confirmed that no immediate action was planned. 
 The White House played down the significance of the letter. The President's chief counsel, Abner J. Mikva, said in a statement that the White House had complied with Congress and that he had asked to discuss the matter with Congressional officials in mid-April.
On Jan. 31, the President authorized a $20 billion loan through the Exchange Stabilization Fund to help stabilize the Mexican peso. He acted on his own after opposition mounted in Congress to an earlier plan that required legislative approval.
At issue now is the Mexican Debt Disclosure Act of 1995, which House and Senate conferees amended to a $3.1 billion supplemental military appropriations bill on April 5. The legislation, which Mr. Clinton signed into law on April 10, was intended to force the Administration to provide a broad range of documents, some of them classified, about the bailout plan before any more money could be sent to Mexico.

HEADLINE: Unusual Leader in a Dallas Campaign

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 4

 BODY:
In Dallas, winning mayoral candidates always seem to run with the blessings of the business establishment. And in a lot of ways, Ron Kirk fits the mold.
Mr. Kirk, a lawyer in a top-drawer downtown firm, is the candidate with nearly all the big-name endorsements, ranging from wealthy real estate developers to the former Dallas Cowboys quarterback Roger Staubach. Mr. Kirk has attracted more than twice the money raised by either of his two major rivals and, as Saturday's election approaches, his television commercials are commanding plenty of air time. 
 But in one way Mr. Kirk, who was Secretary of State under former Gov. Ann W. Richards, would be different from all the Dallas mayors before him. He is black, and if elected he would be the first black mayor of any major city in Texas.
To be sure, many people here view this nonpartisan mayoral election as fundamentally similar to past ones, in which the city's business barons anoint the chosen.
"The white power structure decided it was time to have a black mayor and move Dallas into the 1970's," quipped Joseph Stewart, a political scientist at the University of Texas-Dallas.
Still, in a city with a long history of racial divisions, political, economic and geographic -- most blacks live in South Dallas, most whites in North Dallas -- the most recent poll suggests that Mr. Kirk may have assembled a remarkable coalition.
But while the poll shows Mr. Kirk leading the race, it also indicates a large undecided vote, meaning that he is by no means guaranteed of victory, especially if he fails to capture a majority of votes on Saturday and is forced into a runoff four weeks from now.
The Dallas election is already historic in that it marks the first time that candidates from each of Dallas's major ethnic groups are given a shot at winning.
The poll, published by The Dallas Morning News last Sunday, showed Mr. Kirk with 30 percent of the vote, followed by Domingo Garcia, a Hispanic City Councilman, with 23 percent and Darrell Jordan, a white former prosecutor and onetime president of the Texas State Bar, with 19 percent. Twenty-two percent were undecided. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Dallas, the nation's seventh largest city, has a population of 1 million, of which 48 percent are white, 30 percent are black and 21 percent are of Hispanic ancestry. But whites have generally been a greatly disproportionate percentage of voters in city elections, and this year they may line up far more solidly behind Mr. Jordan than the poll suggests.
Moreover, Mr. Kirk's support in black neighborhoods, while broad, may not be particularly deep, raising questions about turnout in parts of the city that have historically had very low voter participation.
"This is not a black campaign," said Rufus Shaw, a black political consultant, radio commentator and columnist who has not endorsed anyone in the race. "This is a black in a white campaign. This is a guy white folks have chosen."
"If he wins, this won't be something revolutionary for black people, like Harold Washington or Marion Barry or Maynard Jackson," Mr. Shaw said of Mr. Kirk, referring to men who were recognized as black political leaders before being elected Mayor of Chicago, Washington and Atlanta, respectively.
In interviews, all three mayoral candidates here predicted a runoff, and all three agreed that Mr. Kirk would be one of the surviving candidates.
Mr. Kirk clearly bears the front-runner's mantle. At a recent televised debate sponsored by the League of Women Voters, his major opponents plus several of the other seven, lesser-known candidates, including a forklift driver and a fast-food worker, took turns jabbing at him as a tool of the establishment.
Afterward, Mr. Kirk said he was unfazed. "I guess when you're the lead dog," he said, "the view for the rest of them gets pretty boring."
While each candidate says he wants to play down racial factors, race is clearly an issue, especially since there is not much to distinguish their views on major issues.
In a recent forum sponsored by The Morning News, the candidates all agreed they wanted to be tough on crime, fight tax increases, avoid strict affirmative action quotas and keep the city's downtown sports arena from moving to the suburbs.
Mr. Garcia and Mr. Jordan, in a furious bid to make the runoff, have traded shots at each other.
When Mr. Jordan's campaign sent a letter to Republican voters, signed by several supporters and proclaiming that "Darrell Jordan has the intelligence, courage, breeding and educational background to represent us well," Mr. Garcia accused him of playing "the race card" to white voters, an accusation that Mr. Jordan dismissed as absurd.
Mr. Kirk, who is 40, and Mr. Garcia, 37, are both Democrats, while Mr. Jordan, 56, calls himself an independent with empathy for the Republican point of view. They are running to replace Mayor Steve Bartlett, a former Congressman who is not seeking a second four-year term.
Mr. Garcia, who is Mayor pro tem on the City Council, has repeatedly tried to remind voters that he is the only major candidate to have held public office. "The choice in this election basically is between replacement players who haven't played a game in the major leagues, and an experienced veteran," he said at a recent debate.
Though the Mayor here is considerably less powerful than his counterparts in many other major cities -- Dallas has a city-manager form of government -- the post is symbolically important, and Mr. Kirk's election as the first black mayor -- or Mr. Garcia's as the first Hispanic mayor -- would be especially so.
"This is like the class president," said Mr. Shaw, the political consultant. "He can't even send someone to the office. He can't make someone get out of their chair. But symbolically, it is the first picture in the yearbook."

HEADLINE: City Life's About the Same Under Giuliani, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Most New Yorkers say the quality of life in the city has neither improved nor worsened since Rudolph W. Giuliani became Mayor in 1994, according to the latest New York Times poll.
Although many residents cited an improvement in police protection, poll respondents said the Giuliani administration has had little effect on daily life in the city, despite the steep budget cutbacks begun by the Mayor in his first 16 months in office. 
 The telephone poll, based on the responses of 495 residents, found that 52 percent of New Yorkers approve of Mr. Giuliani's performance, down from 61 percent in October.
The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. The survey was conducted April 26 to April 30.
Midway through the survey period, the Mayor released his proposed city budget for the next fiscal year, which included the largest reduction in spending since World War II.
Looked at one way, the results of the poll were less than a ringing endorsement for the Mayor, who has stressed his commitment to improving the city's quality of life. When asked, "Do you think the overall quality of life in New York City has improved, gotten worse or has stayed about the same" since Mr. Giuliani became Mayor, 24 percent answered "better," 22 percent said "worse" and 53 percent responded "about the same."
"He hasn't made anything worse, and he hasn't made anything better," said one respondent, Gina Gonzalez, a foster mother who lives in the Bronx. She had said she approved of the Mayor's performance, and added in an interview after the poll was taken, "I'd say he was a so-so Mayor."
But the results of the poll can be considered another way. The Mayor slashed his first year's budget by more than $2 billion and reduced the work force by 15,000. Even with that, the results seem to support his contention that most New Yorkers have not suffered as a result.
At the same time, the poll results at least suggest that city residents are wary about further cuts. Mr. Giuliani's proposed budget for the next fiscal year would reduce spending on city agencies by more than $1 billion, and on welfare and Medicaid programs by $700 million.
When respondents were asked: "In general, do you think New York City should increase the services it provides, decrease them or keep services about the same," a mere 6 percent said services should be decreased, 35 percent said they should be increased and 55 percent said they should be kept the same.
Another poll, taken April 27 through April 30 by the Gallup Organization for New York Newsday, found that the Mayor's approval rating has dropped sharply. Last October, 67 percent of respondents approved of the Mayor's performance and 26 percent disapproved. In the new poll, published today, 44 percent of respondents approved and 46 percent disapproved. The telephone poll, of 824 New York residents, has a sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
The Times poll asked residents to evaluate four essential services. A majority of those polled said three of those services -- education, parks, and garbage pickup -- have not changed at all under Mr. Giuliani. Only in police protection did a significant number of residents say they noticed an improvement.
That question was: "Since Rudolph Giuliani became Mayor, do you think police protection in the city has improved, gotten worse or stayed the same?" Forty-two percent said police protection had improved, compared with 4 percent who said the same about education, 20 percent about parks, and 16 percent about garbage pickup.
The recent sharp drops in the crime rates have been the Giuliani administration's most touted successes. While some law enforcement officials have said the reductions occurred because Mayor David N. Dinkins increased the size of the police force, and because of demographic changes, Mr. Giuliani has said that his aggressive law enforcement and a redeployment of police forces led to the improvements.
The absence of any strong reaction to most of Mr. Giuliani's policies may also reflect that those hit hardest by his budget have been those who receive welfare and Medicaid benefits. Telephone polls tend to underrepresent those at the lowest end of the economic spectrum, because many do not have phones.
A majority of those questioned in the Times poll, 65 percent, said they approved of the Mayor's plan to make it more difficult for people to apply for welfare.
New Yorkers are split on whether Mr. Giuliani is moving too fast in his efforts to change the city's direction, although few seem to think he should move faster. Asked if they thought the Mayor was "moving too fast to change New York City's direction, or too slow," or "at about the right speed," the poll found that 35 percent say he is moving too quickly, 37 percent say the right speed, and 10 percent say too slowly.
"Let's give him a chance," said Theo Joseph, a retired resident of Jamaica, Queens, who also said he approves of the job the Mayor is doing. "He's only been Mayor for a year or so, and he had this big deficit to deal with. I really hope he can turn things around, but I'm dubious."
The poll continued to show a wide gap between whites and blacks in their perception of the Mayor's performance. While 75 percent of whites approve of the job the Mayor is doing, 68 percent of blacks disapprove. The percentage of whites and blacks who said the quality of life hasn't changed under Mr. Giuliani was about the same, just over half of each group. But 30 percent of whites say life has improved, while only 9 percent of blacks say that. The percentages were almost precisely reversed on the question of whether life has become worse.
Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's director of communications, said the poll was encouraging. She said Mr. Giuliani's ratings were about the same as his electoral vote, even after 16 months of budget cutting.
"Compare that to all the critics and pundits and experts who said that by cutting the budget the Mayor was going to destroy the city," Ms. Lategano said.

HEADLINE: John Edwin O'Toole, 66, Leader In Advertising for Three Decades

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
John Edwin O'Toole, a lifelong advertising executive who was one of the most articulate spokesmen for the agency industry, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Greenwich, Conn., and Carefree, Ariz.
The cause of death was leukemia, said Joyce Harrington, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Advertising Agencies, of which Mr. O'Toole was a past president and chief executive. 
 Mr. O'Toole, a soft-spoken man with a dry wit, was born in Chicago in 1929. As a young man he intended to enter the newspaper business and in 1951 graduated from the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University.
After a year in the Marine Corps though, Mr. O'Toole returned to Chicago in 1953 and took a job as a junior copywriter at the advertising agency now known as BBDO. A year later, he moved to Foote, Cone & Belding, beginning an association that would last for the next 31 years.
He rose steadily at Foote, Cone, now the flagship agency of a holding company called True North Communications. After a decade as a copywriter, he was sent to the agency's Los Angeles office in 1964 as creative director. In 1967 he returned to Chicago, again as creative director, and a year later was elected a member of the agency's board.
In 1969, he was named president of Foote, Cone & Belding in New York. He became president of the parent company, then known as FCB Communications, a year later. In 1981, he was named chairman.
Under his stewardship, Foote, Cone's business grew strongly. From 1970 to 1985, when he retired, billings rose to $2 billion from $241 million.
His retirement was brief.
In 1987, he was named director of the Washington office of the agency association, known on Madison Avenue as the Four A's. Two years later, he was elected president and chief executive. He served a five-year term, representing the industry's interests with clients, the press and governments during a time of ferment and challenges that included the industry's worst recession since the 1930's. He retired at the end of his contract in January 1994.
Two months ago, he was inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation.
He wrote extensively about the business, including a book, "The Trouble with Advertising," in 1981, and numerous articles for a wide variety of publications, including The Atlantic, Newsweek and The Columbia Journalism Review.
Mr. O'Toole is survived by his wife, Phyllis Treadway O'Toole, and two daughters, Ellen O'Toole Hoeffel of Manhattan and Sally O'Toole Whitesell of Greenville, S.C.

HEADLINE: Allan O. Hunter, 78, Head of Fannie Mae In Decade of Growth

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Allan Oakely Hunter, a former Congressman from California who led the Federal National Mortgage Association in the 1970's, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 78.
Mr. Hunter, who lived in Bethesda and Naples, Fla., died after a heart attack, said his wife, Dixie Lee.
He was elected to Congress in 1950 as a Republican from Fresno, Calif., and served two terms before losing a re-election bid in 1954 and resuming a private law practice. 
In 1970 Mr. Hunter was named by President Richard M. Nixon as chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, a private corporation that buys mortgages from direct lenders, freeing up money for more lending.
Under his stewardship, which ended in 1981, Fannie Mae grew in importance as a mortgage lender. But in the late 1970's, sharply rising interest rates caught Fannie Mae in the same trap that snared other mortgage lenders.
"Fannie Mae had tremendous problems when the rates they were paying to borrow rose above the rates they were lending on mortgages," said Stan Strachan, editor of National Mortgage News, a weekly that covers the mortgage industry.
Mr. Hunter's first marriage, to the former Geene Hunter, ended in divorce. Besides his wife, Dixie Lee, he is survived by three children and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Can It Be? Buffett Is Mortal?

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Warren E. Buffett, America's folksy billionaire investor from Omaha, confessed recently that his investment in USAir Group was a result of "sloppy analysis" that might have been caused by "hubris."
Now, hubris is something Mr. Buffett, 64, might be allowed, given his record since he started buying six-packs of Coke for 25 cents and reselling the bottles at a nickel apiece as a child in the late 1930's. Today, he is worth more than $11 billion and the stake his company bought in Coca-Cola just a few years ago has more than quadrupled to about $5.9 billion. "It took only 50 years before I finally got it: The real money was in the syrup," Mr. Buffett quipped recently. 
 But sloppy analysis? Few people have ever accused him of that. Yet Mr. Buffett's mea culpa, along with some less-than-stellar forays into the stock market in recent years, suggest the unthinkable: The legendary Mr. Buffett is in a bit of a slump.
A look at some of his biggest investment disappointments -- including USAir, Salomon Brothers, the PNC Bank Corporation and Champion International -- shows that Mr. Buffett has at times strayed from his own axioms for success. Among those axioms: Don't try to time the market; invest in businesses with histories of steady earnings growth; invest for the long term; don't invest in something that you don't fully understand; invest in managements with proven track records, and don't get involved in the management.
Mr. Buffett also seems to have fallen victim to a problem familiar to many ordinary investors: letting the desire for better-than-average returns blind one to the weaknesses of the companies in which one invests.
It's not as though Mr. Buffett is about to be knocked from his pedestal. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company that is his investment vehicle and of which he owns 41 percent, still produces returns that are the envy of Wall Street, outperforming the Standard & Poor's Index of 500 companies by double digits year after year. It's just that his performance has slipped noticeably since he began stepping in as a savior of companies threatened by hostile takeovers in the late 1980's.
From 1965 through 1986, Berkshire Hathaway's net worth increased at an average compound annual rate of 23.63 percent, beating the S.& P. 500 by 14.38 percentage points. From 1987 through 1994, its average return slipped to 21.87 percent, narrowing its edge over the broader market to 10.02 percentage points. The decline was a bit like that of the baseball star Wade Boggs: After hitting an untouchable .345 over a decade, Mr. Boggs's average fell to a merely mortal .259 in 1992 and a merely sterling .302 in 1993.
Mr. Boggs's fans wondered what had gone wrong. And now, some investors are asking what, if anything, has gone wrong at Berkshire Hathaway.
One answer is that under pressure to maintain his fabulous returns, Mr. Buffett began to ignore some of his own advice. At the end of the 1980's, he started putting money into high-yield investments in companies threatened with hostile takeovers -- companies he has admitted he didn't always fully comprehend. The change in strategy was exemplified by Mr. Buffett's forays into USAir, Salomon, and the paper and wood products giant Champion International.
These investments were made by buying convertible preferred stock, which pays a high interest rate and can be converted into common stock. Mr. Buffett is reputed to have once called these instruments "Treasury bonds with lottery tickets attached." Their effective yield for Berkshire Hathaway was around 15 percent.
One mistake led to another. Stuck with some troubled companies, Mr. Buffett decided to get involved in managing some of them and he has not proved adept at that. He had to step in to act as chairman of Salomon after it was rocked by a 1991 scandal involving false bids at Treasury auctions. Four years later, he is still struggling with the firm.
Salomon, USAir and Champion also violated another Buffett rule: They had erratic earnings histories.
And had Mr. Buffett hewed more firmly to his principle of buying and holding, he could have made a lot more money from the one-third stake in Capital Cities/ABC Inc. that Berkshire Hathaway sold in late 1993. Holding on to the stake for 12 more months would have brought in an additional $217.5 million at today's price. Mr. Buffett ruefully highlighted the missed opportunity in his company's latest annual report.
Such missteps are taking a toll. Berkshire Hathaway's earnings dropped last year, to $494.8 million from $688.1 million in 1993, because of a $173 million write-down of the investment in USAir and a $33 million hit on the Salomon equity holdings. The stock of Berkshire Hathaway, now at $22,950, has risen roughly in line with the overall market this year, but is 7.5 percent below its all-time high.
Mr. Buffett declined to be interviewed for this article. But he has told stockholders on more than one occasion that investing is a lot more difficult these days than it was in Berkshire's earlier years, when a lot of "low fruit" hung ripe for the picking in the stock market.
Peter Russ, an analyst at Shelby Cullom Davis and a staunch admirer of Mr. Buffett, said that to some extent Mr. Buffett was a victim of his own success. Because he has so much money to invest, and because stocks are trading at such high price-earnings ratios, it has become more and more difficult for him "to find mispriced companies in wonderful situations," Mr. Russ said.
"The past seven years have been very difficult for the Warren Buffett style of investing," Mr. Russ said.
Some investors also think that the price of Berkshire Hathaway stock has gotten too far out of line from the value of the companies in which the company has invested. Pasadena Growth Fund sold its Berkshire Hathaway shares in late 1994, the managers Jim Mair and John Tilson explain, because "the premium got too high." Charles T. Munger, Mr. Buffett's partner and the vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has recently sold stock in the company.
To be sure, Mr. Buffett's biggest investments are big and successful enough to let him make mistakes and swallow a few hundred million dollars of losses without much overall effect.
In addition to the 100 million shares of Coca-Cola that he acquired between 1988 and 1992, his other very successful investments include the Geico Corporation, the Gillette Company and the Washington Post Company. And he still has a substantial stake in Capital Cities/ABC.
"He's the world's greatest investor,' said Robert G. Hagstrom Jr., a Philadelphia money manager who profited handsomely from his 1994 best seller on Mr. Buffett's investment strategy. "USAir is a pimple on a $16 billion portfolio." Even so, Mr. Hagstrom acknowledged that USAir was a major mistake and that Salomon had been a disappointment.
Looked at as bond investments, Mr. Buffett's holdings of convertible preferred stock in USAir and Salomon don't seem so bad because of their high yields. But as equity investments, they seem less smart. Because of the serious financial problems at USAir, Mr. Buffett has written down his original $358 million investment to $89.5 million. "He paid a lot of money and his conversion price was high," says Steve Gidumal, an airline analyst at Bear, Stearns.
In Berkshire Hathaway's 1994 annual report, Mr. Buffett recognizes his mistake. "This was a case of sloppy analysis, a lapse that may have been caused by the fact that we were buying a senior security or by hubris," Mr. Buffett wrote. "Whatever the reason, the mistake was large."
Mr. Buffett has also had to write down his Salomon convertible preferred investment by $33 million to account for his share of the investment bank's 1994 net loss of almost $400 million. Salomon's troubled client businesses lost $179 million in the first three months of 1995, though first-quarter trading profits of $239 million pushed the company out of the red for the first time in a year.
Investments in pulp and paper companies, especially those like Champion International that own a lot of trees, have historically been a good hedge against inflation. But while Champion's senior securities, another convertible preferred investment, have provided a good return, the company lost money from 1991 through 1993, though its share price has risen recently.
And, despite a high and rising stock market, some of Mr. Buffett's other recent stock picks don't look so good. A stake of 8.3 percent, or almost 20 million shares, that Mr. Buffett acquired in 1994 in the PNC Bank Corporation still trades at below its acquisition price of $503 million, and was valued at $411 million at the beginning of the year. PNC is the holding company for the Pittsburgh National Bank.
But it is at Salomon, a unit of Salomon Inc,. where in 1987 he stepped in to buy $700 million of Salomon convertible preferred securities to rescue the firm from the investor Ronald Perelman, that Mr. Buffett faces some of his greatest challenges.
Altogether, Mr. Buffett has invested more than $1 billion in Salomon, and Berkshire Hathaway holds just over 20 percent of the firm's total voting rights.
In recent weeks, more than 20 managing directors have deserted the investment firm, many of them because they were unhappy with his plan to limit their annual compensation to $400,000 unless certain profit targets are met. The exodus forced Mr. Buffett's managers to modify the plan somewhat to keep top talent.
But great players, whether in Major League Baseball or on Wall Street, have a way of breaking their slumps. And for Mr. Buffett, the recent rally in Salomon stock, which has jumped from $32.25 in March to $37.375 yesterday, may be a signal that in the long term, the old Buffett magic is still there.

HEADLINE: Committee Proposes Whittling of Social Security Benefits

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Warning of a looming crisis for future retirees, a panel of top corporate officials and university presidents proposed today that increases in Social Security benefits be held below the inflation rate and that all benefits exceeding what a worker has paid into the system be taxed.
These recommendations from the Committee for Economic Development, a bastion of the American business establishment, were among the more far-reaching of an ambitious plan to avert growing problems in Government and private retirement programs and a dangerous drop in national savings. 
 "The pension and retirement system in America is headed for disaster unless steps to prevent it are taken now," said Lawrence A. Weinbach, chief executive of Arthur Andersen & Company and head of the committee panel that conducted the study. "It's underfunded, it's overregulated, and it's about to be overwhelmed by unprecedented growth in the retirement-age population."
While avoiding specific figures, the study did not shrink from proposing solutions that only recently have begun to gain a bit of acceptance among policy makers. For at least the last decade, all talk of making Social Security less generous -- even for future retirees -- was deemed political suicide.
With the ratio of active workers to retirees expected to drop over the next 35 years to only about 2 to 1 from today's 3.4 to 1 -- and outlays exceeding income by the year 2013 -- the panel called for paring cost-of-living adjustments "above a basic floor," essentially adopting a means test by taxing all benefits above levies paid into the system and further raising the retirement age.
The normal retirement age is already set to rise gradually to 67 years from the current 65, beginning in 2003, but this does not fully compensate for the rise in life expectancy, and there has been no change in the early-retirement age of 62.
In addition, the committee said, there should be a phase-in of a lower "replacement ratio," the proportion of retirement benefits to a worker's earnings history. It also said that the earnings limit for Social Security recipients should be increased substantially to encourage the elderly to remain in the work force.
The bulk of the report, however, dealt with private pension plans and a series of budget-driven legislative changes in the 1980's that have reduced the appeal of such plans.
Not only have deductibility and benefits been limited, but also "excessive Government regulation has sharply raised the cost of administering plans and significantly limited pension contributions," Mr. Weinbach said. "Regulatory costs have soared, with a devastating impact on pension formation, hitting the smallest employers the hardest," he said.
In constant dollars, employer contributions dropped 51 percent between 1980 and 1991 while total private pension contributions dropped 22 percent between 1985 and 1991.
The panel called specifically for restoring the full funding limit for defined benefit plans to its pre-1987 level of 100 percent of projected liability and for basing retirement tax preferences on accumulated lifetime income rather than only on current-year income.
Moreover, a worker should not be allowed to withdraw before retirement pension-fund money contributed by his employer, the committee proposed.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Retreat Ahead of April Employment Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks retreated yesterday after two days of record-setting gains as traders locked in gains ahead of today's employment report.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped as much as 37 points yesterday, crossing 4,400 for the first time, before closing down 13.49 points at 4,359.66. 
 The rally this week had been fueled by reports pointing to subdued economic growth, suggesting that interest rates would remain stable, and by strong corporate earnings. A rally in bonds, which continued yesterday, had also bolstered stocks.
"Everything is going right," said Mario Gabelli, the chairman of the $8.2 billion Gamco Investors fund group. "You've had very strong earnings and an enormous rally in the bond market in the past four months that's provided a significant kick to stocks."
But traders were cautious yesterday over whether the report on employment in April would support the notion of a slowing economy. Statistical quirks could cloud the picture of the economy provided by the data. In recent days, analysts have lowered their estimates of April employment growth, partly to reflect the effects of a strike by 32,000 workers in California.
"You've got a pivotal employment number out tomorrow," said Todd Clark, managing director in equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw. "We've had a nice run, and it's time to take some chips off the table to try to reduce risk."
The retreat accelerated as four rounds of computer-guided sell orders bombarded the market beginning at 2:40 P.M., according to Birinyi Associates Inc. All told, the orders knocked more than 40 points off the Dow industrials.
Trading was heavy on the New York Stock Exchange, with about 436 million shares changing hands, compared with 392.9 million shares on Wednesday.
Among broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 0.06 point at a record 520.54. The Nasdaq composite index fell 3.51 points, to 846.75.
Philip Morris, Alcoa and General Motors led the retreat in the Dow. Philip Morris slumped 2, to 70 5/8. Salomon Brothers lowered its investment opinion of the stock.
"People have had a very nice total return in Philip Morris this year and some decided to take profits," said Marc Cohen, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. The tobacco and food company's stock has returned 42 percent so far this year, with dividends.
Bullish forecasts from companies at Hambrecht & Quist's annual technology conference spurred buying in technology shares.
Intel rose 2 1/2, to 109 7/8, after reaching a record 111 1/2. National Semiconductor gained 3/8, to 25 1/8; Microsoft advanced 5/8, to 81 1/2; Applied Materials climbed 1, to 62, and Vishay Intertechnology jumped 3 1/8, to 65.
"Nobody understands the depth of demand in this semiconductor cycle," said Charles Howley, equity trader at Soundview Financial Group Inc. "This mad scramble is not just because of personal computers; it's spreading over to telephone handsets and other technology."
But other computer stocks gave up their gains. I.B.M. fell 1/4, to 93 3/4, after rising as high as 96 1/8. Compaq Computer closed down 1 3/4, at 36 7/8, after soaring as high as 39 1/2.
Brokerage firms also held the spotlight, as the recent rally in financial markets spurs optimism about stock and bond sales. Merrill Lynch added 7/8, to 45 3/4; Dean Witter, Discover gained 3/8, to 45, and Salomon rose 5/8, to 37 3/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally a Second Day, With Yields Lowest in Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds rallied yesterday for a second straight day and sent yields to their lowest point in more than a year on further signs of an economic slowdown and expectations that a Government report today will show weakness in the job market.
Bonds began to gain yesterday after the Government said that first-time filings for unemployment benefits rose by 20,000 last week to 371,000, the highest since July 16. Economists had expected a 4,000 drop in claims. 
 Traders said the report added to the widespread belief of a soft landing in which economic growth would slow to 2.5 percent, or just enough to keep inflation in check.
The price of a 30-year bond jumped 29/32 , to 10523/32 for a yield of 7.16 percent, down from 7.24 percent. At one point the price was up over a point and a half for a yield of 7.12 percent. It was the long bond's lowest closing yield since it fell to 7.10 percent on April 26, 1994.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.50 percent, off five basis points from the previous day, while the 10-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.87 percent, down seven basis points.
"The burden of proof is on the bears rather than on the bulls," said Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, "and that's a significant change in market sentiment. People generally expect bonds will keep rising."
Mr. Donne said the market had been helped by the view that the dollar's slide against the yen was more of a Japanese problem than an American one.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director of ASB Capital Management of Washington, said the bond market had gained this week on cumulative statistical evidence of a weaker economy, starting with the report last Friday that the gross domestic product in the first quarter grew by only 2.8 percent, down from fourth-quarter growth of 5.1 percent.
Since then have come reports that construction spending declined four-tenths of a percent, the third straight month of declines; that April auto and light-truck sales on a combined basis declined 8.5 percent from March, and that employment conditions have declined for two straight months.
Further, Mr. Carpenter said, new-home sales were able to rebound only 3 percent from the February decline of 12 percent. "And within that statistic," he added, "we are told that new single-family home sales are at a 7.3-month supply, the highest since July 1990, when the housing market was essentially flat on its back."
Then the leading economic indicator series declined five-tenths of a percent, the second straight monthly decline. Also, factory orders came in flat, "and today right off the bat we saw a substantial increase in unemployment insurance claims," Mr. Carpenter said
"What we have is evidence of a slowdown that is being more deeply imbedded and visible within the economy," Mr. Carpenter said. "All of this reported weakness in the economic real sector is clearly driving the bond market to a point where Treasury bonds are now lower than last June."
In addition, he said, the markets are viewing the dollar situation differently. "There is a growing perception by investors that the dollar must and will strengthen out near term and longer term," he said, citing gains by the Mexican peso and Canadian dollar in the last two weeks.'
But he added that it was difficult to engineer a soft landing, comparing it to a "Boeing 747 landing on the Navy's shortest aircraft carrier, in a typhoon, in the rain, at night and without the benefit of a tail hook."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
With Many on the Sidelines, The Dollar Has a Mixed Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen yesterday as the market watched for signs of a breakthrough in trade talks between the United States and Japan.
But it slipped against the German mark, which continued to gain strength against the French franc and other European currencies in advance of the runoff round of French presidential elections on Sunday. 
 Currency dealers described the trading as light. Financial markets in Tokyo were closed yesterday and will be again today as the Golden Week of holidays winds down there.
In addition, a number of traders chose to sit on the sidelines and wait for today's United States employment report for April. The figures are expected to provide more evidence that the American economy is sufficiently slowing to keep the Federal Reserve from again raising short-term interest rates. Higher rates tend to slow the economy and stem inflation, and also typically bolster a currency by making investments denominated in it more attractive to foreign buyers. The Fed's policy-making committee next meets on May 23.
"There is a lot of waiting in the market," said Win Thin, an economist at IDEA, a financial advisory firm in New York. "The market doesn't want to make too much of a move ahead of these things."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 83.80 yen, up from 83.71 yen on Wednesday. The dollar sold for 1.3710 marks, down from 1.3745. The British pound rose to $1.6172 from $1.6154.
Senior trade representatives from the United States and Japan met yesterday for a second day in Vancouver, British Columbia, on opening Japanese markets to foreign auto parts and increasing the number of dealers who offer American cars.
The Clinton Administration has threatened to impose sanctions against Japan if no breakthroughs are made in the three days of meetings. There has been little progress reported so far.
