HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Fall on Signals Of Slower Car and Home Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices fell yesterday on signs that slower sales of new cars and houses would depress demand for the metal.
On other commodity markets, crude oil prices rose, but the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities dropped 0.42 point, to 235.06. 
 Copper prices, which surged as recently as March on shrinking stocks, have fallen 9.6 percent in the last four weeks on expectations that a slowing economy will reduce consumption. Copper is used extensively by auto makers and home builders.
Yesterday, the Chrysler Corporation said it might cut its forecast of vehicle sales in the United States in 1995 by about 2 percent, to 15.2 million, because of weaker-than-expected sales in April.
The housing market has also been weak. Earlier this week, the Commerce Department said sales of new single-family houses rose 3 percent in March after two months of steep declines, disappointing economists who had hoped falling mortgage rates would attract more buyers.
"All that has built up to a softer fundamental picture for the market," said Richard Hirsch, vice president of Deutsche Sharps Pixely, a metals trading company in New York.
Copper for July delivery fell 2.95 cents, to $1.2245 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange of New York, the lowest price for an active contract since Oct. 26.
Traders also predict that a 17-month drop in stockpiles held in London Metal Exchange warehouses is about to end.
The price of crude oil rose, recovering from a two-day drop, with strong demand from refiners struggling to meet an increase in gasoline demand this summer.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Aiming to Privatize Index of Leading Indicators

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Commerce Department announced today that it was seeking a private custodian to compile and update its index of leading indicators and two companion gauges that anticipate or track turning points in the economy.
Although the index, the Government's chief forecasting gauge, has fallen into particular disrepute among many professionals for emitting false signals of recession or failing to warn of actual ones, the report is widely followed and Commerce Department officials expressed confidence that somebody would be found to take over the work. 
 The Government spends $300,000 to $400,000 a year in compiling and updating the three business-cycle indexes, which are an outgrowth of work first published in 1938 by Arthur F. Burns and Wesley Mitchell.
"The indicators will not go away," said Everett M. Ehrlich, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. "We're only finding them a better home."
But Mr. Ehrlich indicated that if no one was interested in what he called "a compelling brand name," the agency would drop it. Unlike other Government reports on the economy, the leading, coincident and lagging indexes do not involve primary data collection, only mathematical compilation of data supplied by business, academia and other Government agencies.
The privatization effort is inspired by a need to free resources for a sweeping overhaul of the department's national and international statistics, a job it has called similar to that of a tailor trying to measure a sprinting athlete for a suit of clothes.
"We need to redirect our resources away from statistical programs, such as the cyclical indicators, that no longer require a Government role, and towards these most pressing statistical issues," Mr. Ehrlich said.
Another step announced in the initial implementation of the strategic review announced today was to begin featuring an index of real gross domestic product based on its "chain type" annual weights measure instead of the "fixed weight" measure it currently highlights.
Both are currently calculated but the change means greater attention paid to shifts in relative prices, eliminating a bias that builds up when no allowance is made for the fact that a surge, say, in the price of cotton prompts switching to other fabrics.
The chain-type methods reduced G.D.P. by about half of a percentage point in both 1993 and 1994, but officials said the change in presentation did not imply any significant change in assessment of the nation's economic potential.
In addition, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis will treat Government spending on such capital equipment as buildings, roads and medical equipment as depreciable investments instead of assuming -- as is now the case -- it is consumed in the year or purchase.
The bureau will also install an improved theoretical basis for its estimates of depreciation and capital stocks used in calculating profits and related income components for the national income accounts.
A complete explanation of the changes is included in the April issue of the Department's Survey of Current Business, published today.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chile Fears a Delay in Trade-Bloc Entry

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 2

 BODY:
With negotiations over Chile's admission to the North American free-trade bloc scheduled to begin next month, trade officials and business leaders here are worried that the United States, engulfed in domestic concerns, could delay its promise to bring Chile into the pact.
Eduardo Aninat, Chile's Finance Minister, said in an interview that he saw no obstacles in Mexico, Canada, or Chile that would deter the quick approval of Chile as a trade-bloc member that the United States promised at a meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders in Miami last December. 
 But Mr. Aninat said that despite bipartisan support in the United States Congress for expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement -- or Nafta, as it is widely known -- Chile's entry may be slowed by fallout from the Mexican devaluation crisis and by gridlock over an ever more complex domestic policy agenda.
"It is a bit dangerous for me to give this opinion, but there is a possibility that they will say, because we are so occupied with upcoming elections and a new Congressional political agenda, 'Chile, come back another time,' " Mr. Aninat remarked.
He said that while such a delay would not be a disaster for Chile, "it will be very disappointing and a very sad point in U.S.-Chilean relations."
Chilean membership in the North American trade group has been anticipated ever since the Bush Administration said in 1992 that Chile, with the most advanced economy in Latin America, would be the next country admitted to the trade group. The Clinton Administration has reiterated that commitment.
The Administration has cited Chile as a test case for economic integration of the Western Hemisphere, in which almost all the countries in the region would reach a trading accord over the next decade.
In the last decade, Chile has become the model for economic change in Latin America as it privatized most state enterprises, slashed tariffs, liberalized investment markets, and opened its doors to foreign capital. The result has been 11 years of uninterrupted growth, with an average annual rate of 7 percent for the last eight years. Inflation slowed to 8.9 percent last year from 15 percent in 1992; unemployment is currently 5 percent, and Chile has one of the highest savings and investment rates in the region.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said recently that bipartisan support for a free-trade pact with Chile remained strong, and that the Administration was committed to obtaining so-called fast-track authority from Congress this year.
Under such an arrangement, used in gaining approval of both the North American trade accord and the more recent world trade pact, the Administration negotiates the details of an agreement and the House and Senate vote only to approve or block the pact without amendments.
"We believe that the United States and Nafta partners are on track with respect to Chile's accession to Nafta," said Charlene Barshefsky, a United States deputy trade representative, in a telephone interview from Washington. "We have met not only as Nafta partners, but working relations are very good and the commitment on the part of all the countries involved is very firm."
American trade officials said that trade and finance ministers from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Chile are to begin formal negotiations on June 7 and that if all goes well, Congress is expected to vote on an agreement providing for Chilean membership near the end of the year. But expectations that Chile would gain rapid approval have been fading since late December, when Mexico devalued the peso, causing chaos in financial and credit markets in Latin America and sending investors running for cover.
Critics of the North American trade pact in the United States, like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, have called on the Administration to abandon plans to expand the North American agreement to all of Latin America unless regional labor and environmental rules are included. Republicans dismiss any such rules as unacceptable, under pressure from American businesses that fear the same rules may be applied to them in the United States. The controversy has cast uncertainty on the expansion of free trade through the Western Hemisphere.
And the Republican-controlled House has been occupied of late with legislation promised in the Contract With America, and is next expected to emphasize conservatives' agenda items that were not addressed earlier in the year.
Clinton Administration officials say they are uncertain where the Senate stands on expanding the North American trade alliance.
Claudio S. Garcia, president of Chile's American Chamber of Commerce, which represents United States companies with business interests here, said that the Mexican crisis had "splashed a bucket of cold water on the issue of Chile and Nafta" but that his organization was continuing to lobby in Congress, seeking to shift the tide.
"It appears today that there will be difficulty getting fast-track Nafta through the United States Congress," said Gert Rosenthal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, which is based here. "If Nafta is delayed for Chile, the biggest casualty will be the spirit of the Miami conference, this concept of Western hemispheric integration that the United States has been promoting."
Mr. Rosenthal said that delaying Chile's entry into the North American trade group would send the wrong message to other Latin Americans and to Asian countries, which the United States is trying to persuade to open markets and broadly liberalize their economies.
Chile, a relatively small nation of 13.5 million people in an area of less than 300,000 square miles, is rich in natural resources like copper, timber, fish, iron ore, nitrates and precious metals. Last year, it had exports of $11.64 billion, of which $2.01 billion went to the United States -- mainly fruit, vegetables and forestry products. Chile imported $11.36 billion last year, of which $2.64 billion came from the United States, including vehicles, electronic equipment and other consumer goods.
Mr. Aninat said he was still optimistic that fast-track authority was possible, and he foresees an approval process in which Congress passes a fast-track measure by September, formal negotiations begin in October, and a draft of a new agreement is sent to Congress in January or February.
Yet some Congressional trade experts consider such a timetable very optimistic, and think that fast-track authority may not be completed until shortly before Christmas.
Mr. Aninat said that if fast-track authority was delayed, the United States would be missing a prime opportunity to establish an early trading agreement with a country where imports are growing 26 percent a year, one seen by many Asian nations as a platform for trade with the rest of Latin America.

HEADLINE: AT&T Appoints Chief for Its Flagging Computer Business

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Ending a five-month search, the AT&T Corporation yesterday appointed Lars Nyberg, an executive at Philips Electronics N.V., to take charge of its beleaguered computer business.
Mr. Nyberg, 43, will become chairman and chief executive of AT&T Global Information Solutions on June 1. He succeeds Jerre L. Stead, a highly regarded manager who abruptly quit in January to take the helm of the Legent Corporation, a relatively small software company based in Herndon, Va. 
 AT&T hoped to capitalize on the growing combination of computing and communications when it acquired the NCR Corporation for $7.4 billion in 1991. But the strategy has since proved disappointing.
Though the Global Information Solutions division had revenues of $8.5 billion in 1994, it has struggled to turn a profit. In the first quarter of this year, the unit, which is based in Dayton, Ohio, posted an operating loss of $143 million, costing AT&T shareholders about 5 cents a share in lost earnings, according to Richard Toole, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. Widely considered to be an also-ran in the cutthroat computer industry, AT&T, like many of its competitors, has seen its profit margins squeezed in recent years. Under Mr. Stead's energetic leadership, the unit, which employs 46,000, cut costs and began to transform itself from a hardware seller into a provider of custom information systems to large corporate customers.
Mr. Nyberg, who was in Europe, was not available to comment on his future strategy for the company yesterday, but he was urged to act quickly.
"They have to find a way to gain market share in whatever part of the business they are competing in or get out," said Richard Buchanan, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, Inc., an industry consultant in Cambridge, Mass., that includes AT&T among its clients. "When the current business cycle turns down, there is going to be a major shakeout in the industry. If you are not a volume business, then you are dead."
During his 20 years at Philips, Mr. Nyberg, who was born and raised in Sweden, held a variety of positions in sales and operations in Europe. He was head of the company's data systems division, which was sold to the Digital Equipment Corporation in 1992. Most recently, he led the Communications Systems division, one of the few Philips divisions that registered a loss in the most recent quarter.
"Under Lars's leadership and with a sound strategy and strong team in place, I believe GIS can meet the challenges it faces and make a valuable contribution to AT&T," said Robert E. Allen, the company's chairman, in a statement.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Rise to 9-Month High

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits shot up an unexpected 20,000 last week to the highest level in more than nine months, the Government said Thursday.
The closely watched four-week moving average, which is considered a more accurate barometer of the labor market than the weekly figure because it irons out weekly fluctuations, also posted a nine-month high. 
 Analysts were surprised by the increase and said it could translate into a higher unemployment rate later this spring.
The Labor Department said claims for unemployment pay in the week ended last Saturday climbed to 371,000 from a revised 351,000 and were the highest since 385,000 filings in the week ended July 16 last year.
The four-week average climbed by 7,250, to 351,750, pushing through the 350,000 threshhold for the first time since July.
Initial jobless claims have jumped unexpectedly for two consecutive weeksand have been edging up since the start of the year. Analysts said the trend fitted in with the picture of a cooling economy and they see the labor market continuing to weaken.
Seven states reported increases in initial claims exceeding 1,000 on an unadjusted basis in the week ended April 22, the latest period for which the data are available.
They were Massachusetts, with 3,830 additional filings; New Jersey, 3,664; Connecticut, 2,273; North Carolina, 1,655; New York, 1,628; Wisconsin, 1,588, and Rhode Island, 1,302.

HEADLINE: Cutting the Rent Tax Generates Votes, Not Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York City's budget imbalance and related threats from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to begin cutting basic services has focused attention on the program to eliminate the city's tax on commercial rents outside the Manhattan central business district south of 96th Street (front page, April 28). 
 This tax cut is in no way designed to stimulate jobs; rather, it is meant only to please a political constituency of small-business owners in the boroughs.
By comparison, the Mayor offered a full program of pro-growth tax cuts coupled with sound structural reforms during his 1993 campaign specifically crafted to revive the city's private sector (which had lost 400,000 jobs since 1989). Indeed, that program was almost exclusively based on my economic forecasts and analysis.
Rather than implementing these pledges, the Mayor disavows ever having made them. The result has been stagnation in the city, even as the nation enjoys the fruits of the best economic conditions since the 1960's. The exclusion of the city's crucial business core from the rent tax cut adds yet another inequity in the tax code and insures that the city will continue to founder.
Structural balance in the budget -- which depends not only on reducing costs but also on economic growth -- will not be achieved.
Slashing basic services such as sanitation, fire, libraries and infrastructure also hurts our prospects for economic growth. Since the Mayor's invidious $185 million proposal to cut the rent tax is designed to generate votes rather than jobs, it should be shelved.
 
STEPHEN KAGANN
New York, May 1, 1995
The writer, Giuliani campaign economic adviser, was chief economist to Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.

HEADLINE: El Salvador: A U.N. Success Story

 BODY:
With the departure of its peacekeeping mission from El Salvador last Friday, the United Nations can celebrate a quiet victory. Three years after the initial peace agreement was signed between the Salvadoran Government and guerrilla insurgents, a divided society has begun to heal. Lawlessness, human rights abuses and bitter mistrust have given way to the beginnings of a civil society.
For the United States, the U.N. mission in El Salvador has been a bargain. American taxpayers underwrote a misguided proxy war there during the 1980's to the tune of $6 billion. Out of a total cost of $800 million for reconstruction, the American contribution is about $250 million, and out of U.N. costs of $110 million, Washington paid around $30 million. Member countries are making up the rest. 
 But the U.N. provided much more than needed funds for El Salvador. It served as a trusted mediator in a place where trust was in short supply. It presided over elections in which the F.M.L.N., the party of the guerrilla insurgents, participated for the first time as a legitimate political organization. It supervised the demobilization of the guerrilla forces and the hated National Police, the training of a new civilian police force and the removal of human rights abusers from the armed forces.
Despite these successes, big challenges remain. The reform of the judiciary, one of the goals of the peace process, has barely begun, and no return to civility can be sustained without it. The reintegration of demobilized fighters on both sides has been delayed. Unemployment is at 60 percent. The electoral system is still flawed. Donor countries, particularly the United States, will need to help maintain the reform and healing.
Both sides in the Salvadoran conflict realized that they could not win an outright victory. Both sides were exhausted. Americans' appetite for financing the abusive Salvadoran military was fading. Still, in a time when the role of United Nations peacekeeping is being questioned, El Salvador stands as a heartening example of success.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japanese Auto Trade Talks End in Failure

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
A last-ditch effort to avoid a major confrontation with Japan over trade in automobiles and parts failed last night, and Clinton Administration officials said they would decide today what kind of trade sanctions to impose on billions of dollars in Japanese goods imported into the United States.
The breakdown came after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Ryutaro Hashimoto, ended three days of on-again, off-again talks in Vancouver, British Columbia, declaring that their differences were far too wide to bridge. 
 While many of the issues they were debating have long plagued relations between the two countries, , the breaking point was Japan's refusal to allow its auto makers to enter into a "voluntary plan" to increase substantially their purchases of American-made auto parts.
"They were ideologically rigid," Mr. Kantor said in a telephone interview yesterday evening. "They are well aware that we will meet this weekend, and, as President Clinton promised, we will be very strong in our response."
Mr. Kantor contended that the Japanese Government, while accusing the United States of "managing" trade between the countries, was actually seeking to protect its own industry from American competition. "They have managed trade themselves for years," he said. "They give hypocrisy a bad name."
The National Economic Council, the counterpart of the National Security Council, is expected to recommend today that Mr. Clinton order the publication of a list of Japanese products -- perhaps totaling $5 billion to $10 billion -- that will be subject to tariffs as high as 100 percent. The tariffs, to be levied primarily, but not exclusively, on auto parts, would go into effect in 30 days -- although the final list of products affected by the import tax is likely to total only a few billion dollars.
The Administration pursued a similar strategy with China earlier this year over that nation's unwillingness to protect intellectual property rights on American music, films and other products, forcing an agreement that was reached just hours before the tariffs were scheduled to go into effect. American officials are hoping that the same thing will happen in this case.
But there is considerable reason to question whether Tokyo will back down. The issue has become a heated one in Japan, and there is speculation that Mr. Hashimoto, a leading candidate to become Japan's prime minister in the near future, may need to appear to stand up to the United States, especially when many Japanese believe that Washington is keeping the dollar weak to harm Japanese industry by making its goods less competitive overseas.
Over the next several weeks, American companies will be given a chance to review the Administration's list of proposed tariffs, and will be able to argue for the removal of items that they rely on to produce automobiles and other goods. "We really can't tell how big the final list will be," one Administration official said last night, "but it will be bigger than any you've seen before."
Administration officials concede that they have embarked on a risky strategy, even though Japan has backed down before when threatened with sanctions. Now, the precarious state of the Japanese economy and the troubles facing the Japanese auto industry since the yen's surge in value against the dollar give Tokyo much less room to bargain.
Moreover, Japanese officials seem to be betting that the United States does not want to provoke a confrontation that would ruin either next month's summit meeting of industrialized nations in Halifax, Nova Scotia, or this summer's anniversary of the end of World War II in 1945. Both capitals have been working to turn the anniversary into a celebration of the two countries' "global partnership." A trade skirmish would send just the opposite signal.
Currency traders have warned that the dollar could take a further beating if the two countries are engaged in a heightened economic confrontation. Since the beginning of the year, the dollar has fallen by about 16 percent against the yen.
Japanese officials have repeatedly threatened to counter any sanctions by filing an action against the United States at the World Trade Organization in Geneva, the successor to the organization built around the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Mr. Hashimoto repeated that warning yesterday, Mr. Kantor said. The trade representative professed to be unconcerned. "We would welcome a review by the W.T.O. of all of Japan's automobile practices," he said.
In private, American officials are more concerned. They fear Japan would attract considerable support if it attacked any American laws that called for unilateral action against another country's products. Tokyo argues that such laws violate world trade agreements.
"It is a risk for both sides, because it is very possible the Japanese could win," said Clyde Prestowitz, the head of the Economic Strategy Institute, a group that argues for free trade under tougher worldwide rules. "I'm not sure either side wants to try it."
American officials note, however, that sanctions would be in effect while any complaint is heard, a process that could take months, if not years. They are betting that Japanese auto companies, which have been deeply divided over how to handle the American demands, would rather settle than endure the economic damage of a lengthy fight.
Over the last two years, since Mr. Clinton and former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa signed a "framework accord" for settling trade disputes, the two countries have made far-reaching accords. But none of the issues have been as contentious as autos, which are by far the biggest part of Japan's huge trade surplus -- more than $63 billion last year -- with the United States.
Mr. Hashimoto is a formidable opponent. In a country that reveres quiet control, he is unusually outspoken, and this week in Vancouver he staged at least one incident in which he threw down his papers in frustration when dealing with Mr. Kantor.
In private, according to Japanese who have talked with him at length, he is quite dismissive of both Mr. Kantor and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. He has been known to toss aside the advice of career bureaucrats and reach deals on his own, as he did last year to resolve a dispute over American access to the Japanese glass market.
At issue currently are three main areas of contention.
The first centers on American efforts to get Japanese auto dealers to sell Ford, Chrysler or General Motors cars.
The second involves demands by Washington for a loosening of regulations on the use in Japan of imported parts to repair cars; it is especially significant because a Government inspection system requires most Japanese car owners to make extensive repairs every two years.
The third and biggest source of contention -- and the hardest political problem to solve -- concerns American efforts to get Japanese auto makers to sign "voluntary agreements" that would vastly increase the number of American-made automobile parts they use.
Former President George Bush reached such an agreement four years ago in a visit to Tokyo when Japanese companies agreed to nearly triple their parts purchases from American companies, to roughly $19 billion a year. The result was a mixed success. Japanese companies vastly increased the number of American parts they purchased for cars produced in the United States at "transplant" factories, where cars now average more than 50 percent American-made content. But the Japanese car makers failed to reach any of their vaguely described goals for increasing purchases in Japan, where parts makers are often owned or linked to big auto makers.
Mr. Hashimoto has repeatedly said that Japan must never again enter such an accord, because the Government should have no role in dictating purchases made by private industry. American officials insist that while some Japanese car makers have shown an interest in a new voluntary purchase plan, the Japanese Government has acted to discourage them.

HEADLINE: Europeans Struggle to Balance Old Ways With New Muslim Immigrants

SERIES: Wary Strangers: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 5

 BODY:
Michel Gourdin, a French baker in the northern Paris suburb of Garges-les-Gonesse, remembers the day a year ago when gangs of unemployed North African Muslim youths wrecked his shop in a riot.
One gang member, he said, had been killed by a rival Asian group, and the North Africans, believing that the French police had let the suspected killer go, attacked the local precinct house and then all the French-owned businesses in the neighborhood. 
 "What I don't understand," Mr. Gourdin said, "is that some of them are involved in hard-core gang robberies and drugs. The police know who they are, but they don't do anything. I think they are afraid of provoking an even bigger explosion here if they do."
Garges is a working-class town of 45,000 people with housing projects built for refugees from France's colonial wars in North Africa. Today it has been transformed, like other cities throughout Europe, by Muslim immigrant families who suffer from the same problems of unemployment, high crime and bewildering social change that affect the Europeans who also live there.
Europe's effort to integrate its minority of 10 million to 13 million Muslims is in crisis. The crisis is more than a profound cultural conflict. It is one with grave echoes of racism, fundamentalism and fears of terrorism, and whether Europe succeeds or fails could have important lessons for the United States, with its own large, new Muslim presence.
But for Europe, so far, many of the signs are troubling.
"The sad fact is that interaction is very difficult and rare," said Ian Hastings, a Briton who grew up in India and who has chosen to live in the cultural and ethnic mix that East London has become today.
From the British National Party in London's East End to Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front in Marseilles, racist far-right politicians openly appeal to white fears in the parts of Europe where local populations are being steadily replaced by immigrants.
Mr. Le Pen, a candidate in the first round of the French presidential elections last month, won 15 percent of the vote nationwide, his strongest showing in two decades. A young Moroccan man drowned after skinheads who the police say were attending a Le Pen rally here on Monday pushed him into the Seine.
On Thursday night, unidentified people sprayed anti-Islamic graffiti on the walls of the Grand Mosque of Paris and defaced the entrance with black tar.
Government crackdowns on legal and illegal immigration in European countries have been prompted in part by the fear of right-wing demagoguery if the influx is not brought under control. Such moves have helped steal the thunder from the far-rightists in Britain and Germany.
Though modern urban crime and chronic high unemployment do not discriminate between Muslims and Christians in the poor European neighborhoods where the local and immigrant populations coexist, they do contribute to rising tensions.
Interviews in France, Britain and Germany, three Western European countries with heavy concentrations of Muslims in urban neighborhoods, show a range of attitudes toward Muslims of various cultural and ethnic backgrounds. It is estimated that there are five million Muslims in France, one million in Britain and two million in Germany.
 
The French View
Sharing Problems, Not the Blame
In Aulnay-sous-Bois, a residential sprawl north of Paris, Communist and Socialist-dominated governments over the years built housing projects intended for local French low-income families. Most of these apartments are now occupied by Muslim immigrants from Algeria.
One of the few remaining ethnic French residents of one project is Yves Hiestand, a 48-year-old accountant who has been unable to work for the last two years because of intestinal cancer. He opened the door to the stairwell on the 12th floor the other day and wrinkled his nose in disgust.
"Drug addicts," he said, pointing to discarded plastic syringes on the concrete steps and to a bloodstain on the yellow stuccoed wall. "All North Africans," he said. "The police don't even care."
He paused as his next-door neighbor, a North African woman wearing a head covering, passed on the way to the graffiti-covered elevator. "She asked me to clear the addicts out of the stairwell this morning, but I refused," he said, "If I say anything to them they just call me a racist."
The French-owned stores on the ground floor of Mr. Hiestand's building have, one by one, been bought out by North African owners who cater to their clientele with signs in Arabic. One French butcher remains.
He borrows the butcher's car because Mr. Hiestand can no longer afford one of his own on a disability payment that leaves him a little more than $600 a month to support himself and his two school-age sons, Yann and Rick.
"It's not safe to ride the buses, and taxis won't even come in here after dark," he said. "It's like being a prisoner in your own country."
Mr. Hiestand blames French social-welfare and immigration policies for creating the situation, and he supports Mr. Le Pen's far-right movement. On the walls of his sparsely furnished three-room apartment he keeps a small arsenal of guns and knives and a collection of military memorabilia from his days as a paratrooper in Senegal.
In Aulnay, Mr. Le Pen won 20 percent of the vote, but he came in ahead of all other candidates in more than a score of cities from Marseilles to Metz, Colmar and Dreux on a platform promising to send three million of immigrants back where they came from to make room for three million unemployed French workers.
Such arguments may make little sense, but they appeal to racism. In fact, Islamic immigrants are among the hardest hit by France's 12.2 percent unemployment rate, with joblessness in many North African neighborhoods running at about 40 percent.
 
The British View
Harmony Depends On a Balanced Mix
Unemployment is just as big a problem in the Brick Lane neighborhood of the Tower Hamlets section of East London, once the center of the Cockney world. Today the street signs are in Bengali and English.
A total of 161,000 people live here, 37,000 of them -- 23 percent -- from Bangladesh, with a smattering of black African and Caribbean immigrants. The rest, the English, tend to call all the other groups "blacks."
"I was born in the East End -- I live here because I belong here," said Eileen Whitmarsh, a 58-year-old resident who lives 10 minutes from Brick Lane in a city housing project on Ellsworth Street. "I can't say we like what's going on now -- the indigenous people feel like second-class citizens," she said. "They feel as if the outsiders are getting preference."
Local city government is not permitted to build subsidized housing, she said, but makes public land available to private housing associations only if they promise to build plenty of five- and six-bedroom apartments.
"That is clearly for Asians," she said. "If there's a mosque to be built, someone always finds the money and the land for that, too."
Mrs. Whitmarsh works with Asian children in a school for the mentally handicapped, and says she has become friends with many Bengladeshi and Pakistani families.
"People are people," she said, "but now the English people who have lived here all their lives are being displaced by immigrants who are taking over."
Mr. Hastings, the Briton who grew up in India, came here 15 years ago and now lives in one of the buildings put up on land made available by the Tower Hamlets city council. A teacher-trainee, he works hard at getting the Asians and the English to live together.
"My eldest daughter has been going to a Church of England school with a mix of students," Mr. Hastings said. "But now she has to go to the next level and it's 95 percent Bengladeshi, and that is a problem. We've opted for a central London school that tends to be more mixed, but it means a 40-minute daily train ride each day for my daughter."
The anti-immigration British National Party has been accused of egging on skinheads in the area, who have clashed with Asian gangs. Early last year, with tensions running high, newspapers predicted that local government elections in May would produce strong majorities for the party, but it was defeated, even losing the majority it had held in the Millwall district.
An election to fill a vacancy in the Weavers ward of Tower Hamlets at the end of February confirmed the trend with a victory by the opposition Labor Party candidate, Mohammed Ali; David King, the British National Party candidate, won 16 percent.
"The people in this area have a long history of fighting racism," said Pola Manzilla Uddin, an emigre from Bangladesh who has been a Labor Party councilor in Tower Hamlets for six years.
"It's always been a neighborhood full of immigrants -- the Jews and the Irish came before us, but we have a different skin color, we stand out and we'll be here longer than those groups were," she said. "Our children are the ones who are going to determine whether we live in a racist society for the next 50 years, or live in a more balanced, caring community."
Unemployment in Tower Hamlets last year ran close to 27 percent, two and a half times the national average. In Bradford, a manufacturing city 200 miles north of London, the jobless rate approaches 50 percent in some Pakistani neighborhoods, said Ralph Berry, a local councilor. There are 45,000 Pakistanis in the city, a ninth of the population.
Mr. Berry's living room, high on a hill in a mostly white neighborhood in Bradford's southwest, overlooks the Grange School, where 80 percent of the 1,000 students are Asian. "One child from this area goes to that school, which was built for it," he said.
The Grange school welcomes visitors with English, Urdu and Hindi greetings on the door, and its motto is "achieving together." Richard Thompson, the principal, said he saw his primary mission as preparing young Britons of whatever race or color for the society they live in now, not the one they came from.
"Some of my female students want to wear the veil, and they can if they feel they need to," he said. "I could stamp on it, but it isn't important. The important thing is for these British Muslims to be equipped with an education that allows them to live useful lives here," he said.
 
The German View
Far Right Fuels Fundamentalism
Two fundamentalist mosques, both in the predominantly Catholic, Rhineland city of Cologne, have been making headway in the Turkish Islamic population in Germany. The Turks have long been among the most secularized populations of the Islamic world.
The more radical of the two mosques, known by its Turkish initials I.C.C.B., runs an Islamic cultural and shopping center on the Niehler Kirchweg, a residential street in the Nippes section of Cologne.
A green Islamic flag flies above it, and on holidays the smell of barbecued lamb rises up to the fifth-floor apartment of Jurgen Kerstin and his wife, Regine, who live with their daughter in the building next door. Nippes is home to about 111,000 people, 12,000 of them Turks.
"We've always had Turkish neighbors, and we've always gotten along with them," Mrs. Kerstin said. "But these people are different -- the women always wear veils now, and they come on weekends to attend the Koran school."
In the Nippes city hall, Vural Emre, who came from Turkey 33 years ago to work in the Ford plant in Cologne and has since become a German citizen active in the Social Democratic Party, said he thought he knew why such movements had taken root.
Turks who had felt safe living in Germany suddenly felt dangerously exposed when right-wing German radicals, protesting a wave of foreign immigrants seeking asylum in Germany, began firebombing Turkish homes in late 1992, he said. More than 20 Turks and other foreign immigrants died in such attacks between then and the end of 1993.
The attacks declined after the German Parliament changed the Constitution in mid-1993 to make it harder to claim asylum. German far-right parties advocating the expulsion of foreigners failed at the polls in national elections last October.
But there are still problems, however petty.
Bernhard Henrici, the head of the Nippes district council, took a visitor up to his 15th-floor office, with a panoramic view from the Rhine to the Eifel hills to the west.
"Look around and try to count how many satellite dishes you see on the houses down below -- all of them are tuned to channels from Turkey," he said. Mr. Emre retorted, "Yes, and all of them had to sue their German landlords to get permission to put the dishes up."
The little three-story houses that Ford helped build to house him and the German workers at its plant in Nippes have since been neglected. Mr. Emre says the only German neighbors he has left on the Konigsbergerstrasse are widows like Maria Karbath.
Mrs. Karbath, 80, said she does not mind that the only grocery store in the neighborhood is run and staffed by Turks and carries Turkish staples.
"If I got sick and needed help, I know that I could call on any one of my neighbors and they'd take care of me," she said. "I'd rather depend on my Turkish friends than on the Germans."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unemployment Rate Jumps As Number of Jobs Falls
The nation's unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, in April and the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years, as the slowdown in the economy spread to the job market.
The most startling figure in the employment data was the 9,000 decline in payroll jobs. And for the second straight month, the number of factory jobs declined. Analysts regarded the numbers as the most definitive in a series of reports showing a sharp deceleration of the economy. Indeed, fears are being raised that the Fed's anti-inflation campaign may have been overly severe. Page 1.
The unemployment rate in New York State increased to 6.8 percent and rose to 6.3 percent in New Jersey. In New York City, the rate was up slightly, to 8.6 percent. 38.
 
U.S. and Japan Break Off Talks on Automotive Trade
The United States and Japan said talks over trade in automobiles and auto parts had ended in failure. The Clinton Administration plans to decide what kinds of trade sanctions to impose on billions of dollars in Japanese goods imported into the United States. 1.
 
Drive for Legal Overhaul Is Trimmed
Senate Republicans scaled back their effort to limit damage awards in liability suits, hoping to attract enough votes for passage on Monday. The revised proposal would extend the damage cap in product liability suits but only to cases against businesses or government entities with fewer than 25 full-time employees. The revised measure would not cap punitive damages in medical malpractice cases. 10.
 
Dow Falls 16 on Jobs Report
The Dow industrials declined in a second day of erratic trading, falling 16.26, to 4,343.40, as the decline in new jobs, the first in more than two years, raised the prospect that corporate earnings would slump. 39.
A rally in the bond market helped the dollar gain slightly against the major currencies. The dollar rose to 1.3730 German marks from 1.3710 marks on Thursday and edged up to 83.96 yen, from 83.80. 34.
 
Group in Bid for Grace Unit
An investment group of former W. R. Grace executives is teaming up with Constantine Hampers in his $3.5 billion bid to buy National Medical Care, W. R. Grace's health care subsidiary. The group, called Quad-C, is based in Charlottesville, Va., and is headed by Terrence Daniels, a former Grace vice chairman who led the acquisition of National Medical Care in 1984. 37.
 
New York Fines Prudential
Prudential Insurance has agreed to pay a $5 million fine for disregarding rules requiring that agents and the policy forms they use be approved by New York State. It was the biggest fine ever levied by the New York Insurance Department, but the department said there was little effect on consumers. 38.
 
Trump and Pritzker Settle Feud
Donald Trump, left, and Jay Pritzker have settled their long-running legal feud over the management of the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York, which they jointly own and which the Pritzker family's Hyatt Corporation manages. People familiar with documents signed by both sides this week said the settlement cleared the way for renovations at the convention hotel near Grand Central Terminal. Mr. Pritzker said he hoped that work on the hotel "could begin soon." 37.
 
Borrowing by Consumers Increases
Consumer borrowing accelerated during March at the fastest pace since last summer. Led by a $6.7 billion increase in credit card use, installment borrowing rose 17.9 percent, to $13.8 billion. In February, consumer credit rose a revised $7.7 billion. 38.
 
Nintendo Delays New Game Machine
Nintendo of America confirmed that its Ultra 64 video game player would not be ready in time for Christmas. The company said it would unveil the machine in November, but not introduce it until April 1996. Analysts said the delay could hurt competitors nearly as much as it did Nintendo, because consumers may put off buying any machine until the Ultra 64 becomes available. 34.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cigarette Makers, in New Direction, Move to Raise Prices

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Displaying new confidence that the heated legislative climate surrounding the tobacco industry has cooled enough to permit a price increase, the largest United States cigarette makers raised their wholesale prices yesterday by 3 cents a pack, or nearly 4 percent for premium brands.
The first announcement was made by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, only a week after its parent, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Company, announced disappointing first-quarter earnings and declining tobacco sales. The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest maker of cigarettes, confirmed late in the day that it was matching the Reynolds price increase. 
 David Adelman, a tobacco analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said yesterday that Brown & Williamson, the dominant American manufacturer of discount brands, had informed its distributors that it would increase prices by the same amount. He attributed the information to his father, Lawrence, also a tobacco analyst at Dean Witter.
A spokesman for Brown & Williamson in Louisville, Ky., Tom Fitzgerald, said, "We only discuss prices with our customers," declining to confirm Mr. Lawrence's report. There was no response to messages left at Brown & Williamson's corporate parent in London, B.A.T. Industries
The R. J. Reynolds price increase, the first since November 1993, when the company raised prices 4 percent, is effective immediately and affects all its premium and discount brands. The price rise is the company's second since "Marlboro Friday" in April 1993, when Philip Morris cut cigarette prices by 40 cents a pack in an effort to compete more aggressively against discount brands, and RJR Nabisco followed suit.
"Certainly the price increase will be beneficial to the Reynolds earnings," said Roy D. Burry, a securities analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. "They couldn't raise their prices due to the health care debate in Washington, but now things have cooled off, and they feel they can increase their prices by this amount."
He referred to calls by Democrats for health care legislation that would have included increased taxes on tobacco to pay for the proposed health benefits. With a Republican majority in Congress this year and the failure of the Clinton Administration's health care proposal, tobacco companies no longer fear a tax increase that would raise prices to consumers.
R. J. Reynolds, the nation's second-largest cigarette maker, also announced the resignation of James C. Schroer, its executive vice president for marketing and sales. "I think this was inevitable, given the missteps the company has made over the last 9 to 12 months in their marketing programs," said Gary Black, a tobacco analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Mr. Schroer was second in command to the president and chief operating officer, Andrew Schindler. No successor has been named.
"Rather than cut prices to stunt share losses, RJR is more inclined to make management changes," Mr. Black said.
Karen Daragan, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris USA, said the price increase was intended "to help recover inflationary costs." It will affect the company's premium cigarettes like Marlboro, as well as its Basic and Cambridge discount brands.
Mr. Burry of Oppenheimer referred to the tobacco industry as a "price oligopoly, following the industry's restructuring, returning to the way it was before Marlboro Friday."
Smokers may face another general price increase down the road as well. "They usually raise prices around the middle of the year and then again at the end of the year," Mr. Burry said. Should there be another price rise "that would be a total of more than 6.8 percent, too much of a price increase all at one time," he said.
RJR announced its price increase early enough to affect the market, and Wall Street seemed to approve. RJR Nabisco was up 12.5 cents, closing at $28.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Philip Morris closed at $71.50, up 87.5 cents. Its announcement came after the New York market had closed.
The price increases by R. J. Reynolds amount to 3.4 percent a pack for the company's premium brands, or 3.7 percent including excise taxes, Mr. Black said.
Brown & Williamson will benefit most from an increase, Mr. Burry said, since 3 cents a pack at wholesale amounts to a 4.9 increase on its principal discount brand, GPC. Another increase at the end of the year would mean close to a 10 percent price rise for the year.
An increase of 3 cents a pack at the wholesale level could amount to a 6 percent rise for private-label manufacturers, Mr. Black said, adding that "having the first price increase in 18 months is good for the industry."
Nationally, the retail cost of premium brands averaged $2.25 before Marlboro Friday, $1.85 afterward, then $1.89 after the November 1993 increase. The cost, after yesterday's rise, will be $1.92.
Mr. Adelman of Dean Witter said analysts would be watching to see how much of the price increase "will stick."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rises to 5.8% In Clear Sign of Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
The slowdown in the economy spread visibly to the job market in April, as the unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, and the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years, Government figures showed today.
Analysts regarded this as the most definitive in a series of recent reports showing a sharp deceleration of the economy. The trend has started to raise fears that the Federal Reserve's anti-inflation campaign may have been too severe. 
 Yet while today's report on the labor market, the first comprehensive gauge of economic conditions for April, included many signs of weakness, various special factors made it unusually difficult to interpret. Still, most analysts concluded that the results were not as bad as they first appeared, and few saw the expansion, which recently entered its fifth year, as being near an end.
"The rise in unemployment confirms that the economy has slowed down, although this is not a sign of recession," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
The bond market, seeing the jobs report as evidence that the Federal Reserve would not push interest rates up further, rallied on the job figures, pushing long-term interest rates down to about 7 percent, the lowest level in more than a year. [Page 35.]
Stocks tumbled, then recovered half their losses as investors were apparently reassured that the economy was not in collapse.
Analysts said the lower long-term rates could help revive the housing sector, one of the main casualties of the Fed's ratcheting up of interest rates in seven steps from February 1994 to February 1995. Lumber and home furnishings were among the weakest industries in the job report.
The dollar's skid in world currency markets, which tends to help exports by making American goods more affordable abroad, is also seen as a prop for the economy in the months ahead.
Factory jobs, which have been on a steady upward trend since late 1993 and are relatively immune from the seasonal and other distortions that affected other elements of the report, have declined for two straight months. Furthermore, factory hours have eased from unusually high levels.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich called his department's report "disappointing," but expressed no alarm and avoided comment about any possible easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
"There is some cause for concern," Mr. Reich said in an interview. "But there's no evidence that the economy's going into reverse."
Irwin L. Kellner, a senior economist at Chemical Bank, said the Fed "should hold steady until further notice." Indeed, much of the impact of its earlier tightening of credit is still to be felt.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has said the central bank could relax policy even in the face of somewhat higher inflation figures if it discerned long-term trends like a cooling economy that could lead to lower inflation. But other current trends -- notably high prices for many raw materials and semi-processed goods -- may convince the Federal Reserve that even with a cooling economy inflation may not yet be subsiding.
The most startling figure in the employment data was no doubt the 9,000 decline in payroll jobs, an item to which economists normally attach considerably more significance than to the unemployment rate.
The fact that jobs did not increase was a surprise even to those who had realized that a quirk of the calendar would severely limit growth and who had adjusted their expectations because March job gains significantly benefited from unusually warm weather that "stole" jobs in construction and recreation that would normally have shown up in April.
Other factors were a strike of 23,000 grocery workers in California and what officials said was a minimal effect from the late start of the Major League Baseball season.
The biggest obstacle to clear interpretation of the payroll survey was a peculiar calendar pattern, combined with the Labor Department's attempt to adjust the figures for recurring seasonal swings. In each of the preceding three years, which dominate the adjustment calculation, there were five weeks between the March and April surveys, allowing a maximum time for seasonal job gains to be captured in the statistical net. But this year there were just four weeks, meaning there was one less week of seasonal hiring.
This year's tally had to show enough jobs to overcome a big hurdle of 841,000 jobs that the process assumed to be the proper adjustment as a result of the 1992-94 experience.
By a very rough estimate, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, put this calendar effect at 70,000 to 234,000 fewer jobs in April, a range that analysts said was so wide as to be of little use.
Still, it was clear, she and private analysts said, that job growth has slackened from last year's rapid pace, with even the temporary-help category showing a decline of 21,000 in April. This, along with overtime, is one of the "easy" first options when employers seek to pare labor costs.
The average private-sector workweek, the report also showed, lengthened slightly, but factory hours slumped by 36 minutes and factory overtime fell by 24 minutes. These declines were magnified, officials cautioned, by time off for Easter and Passover.
And while the index of aggregate weekly hours inched up a tenth of a point, to 131.8, its factory component plunged 1.6 percent. "The bottom has really dropped out" in manufacturing, said H. Erich Heinemann, economist for Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, who predicts a "hard landing" for the economy in 1996.
The department's survey of households, from which the unemployment rate is calculated, also portrayed job-market deterioration, and it was little affected by seasonal distortion.
Altogether, 428,000 more people were out of work in April, as a result of job shrinkage of 202,000 and a rise of 226,000 in the labor force. That lifted the total number of unemployed to 7,665,000. A large proportion of these were people re-entering the labor force and those on temporary layoff, the report noted.
An almost equal number of people, 7,710,000, held two or more jobs, with 6.2 percent of all employed workers in this category, up from 6 percent in April 1994.
The median duration of jobless spells jumped to 8.5 weeks in April from 7.9 weeks in March, with much of the increase reflecting those out of work 15 weeks or more.
Unemployment rates rose among all major demographic groups except Hispanic workers, with those aged 24 to 54 accounting for the overwhelming share of the joblessness.
Before rounding, the overall jobless rate was 5.7744 in April, up from 5.4615 in March, a rise of a full three-tenths of a percentage point.
Today's report also showed an increase in average hourly earnings of six-tenths of 1 percent, but analysts remained calm since this is not only a volatile series but also one that has recently shown a tendency to jump in the first month of a new quarter.
Geographically, the jobless rate rose just a tenth of a point, to 6.1 percent, in the Northeast, while increasing three-tenths of a point in the Midwest (to 4.9) and five-tenths of a point in the South (5.5) and West (6.8).
Statistically significant increases for individual states were posted in Illinois (1.3 points, to 5.7), Massachusetts (1.3 points, to 5.9), Florida (1.2 points, to 5.6), North Carolina (eight-tenths of a point, to 4.7) and Ohio (seven-tenths of a point, to 4.5).

HEADLINE: Borrowing by Consumers Surges In Increase Led by Credit Cards

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing accelerated in March at the fastest pace since last summer even as the overall economy was losing momentum, Government figures showed today.
Led by strong credit card use, installment borrowing rose by a higher-than-expected $13.8 billion in the month, the Federal Reserve said. 
 In February, consumer credit rose a revised $7.7 billion. Previously, the Government said borrowing increased $8.2 billion in February.
"It takes a lot for the average American to put his credit card in his pocket," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass.
Today's report showed that installment credit was rising at a 17.9 percent annual rate in March, the largest advance since 21.3 percent in August, when the economy was stronger. In February, the growth rate stood at 10 percent.
Some analysts advised against reading too much into the unexpected leap in borrowing. "There may have been a seasonal quirk" in the statistics, said Dana Saporta, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. She noted that the Easter shopping season fell later this year than in 1994.
Economists pay particular attention to the Fed's credit statistics because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Before today's report, economists were expecting the Fed to report an $8.8 billion increase in consumer credit in March.
While consumer spending fueled the strongest economic and employment growth in 10 years in 1994, consumer demand has stumbled this year after seven interest rate increases by the Fed.
After showing little change in the early 1990's, consumer borrowing began surging more than a year before the Fed started raising short-term interest rates on Feb. 4, 1994, to cool the economy as a way of restraining inflation.
At the same time, use of credit cards increased as card issuers offered cash rebates and travel discounts, and supermarkets installed credit card scanners on checkout lines.
While consumer borrowing continues at a fast pace, the overall economy has been losing steam. Commerce Department figures show the economy's growth slowed to a 2.8 percent annual pace during the first three months of the year.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" shows net change in total consumer installment credit outstanding from Oct. 1993 to March 1995. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: 3 States' Heaviest Political Guns Try to Save Their Military Bases

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The elected officials from the three states had all come to the hearing held aboard the aircraft carrier Intrepid yesterday to argue the same basic point, that the Federal Government was making a terrible mistake in trying to close down their military installations.
 Each state had trotted out its heavy artillery: from New York, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver; from New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg, and from Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland alongside Senators Joseph I. Lieberman and Christopher J. Dodd. 
 Each speaker was trying to persuade a special Presidential commission -- charged with reviewing the Pentagon recommendations in the latest round of military downsizing -- that someone in the Department of Defense in Washington had horribly miscalculated the potential savings of closing their state's bases.
 "With all due respect, the D.O.D. alleged cost savings are bogus," said Representative Christopher Smith of New Jersey, seeking to rescue the Lakehurst Naval Warfare Center. "If someone working for me costed out a program or scenario so shoddily, I'd fire him for the good of the order."
 "For whatever reason," said Senator D'Amato, speaking on behalf of the Rome Laboratory, a high-tech military research installation, "the Air Force overestimated, and I believe with knowledge, the potential savings of closing Rome Lab. They have deliberately distorted the costs."
 "The numbers don't add up," said the Connecticut Governor, Mr. Rowland, testifying on behalf of New London and Stratford, Conn., installations, "logistically or financially."
 At issue were thousands of civilian and military jobs that pump millions of dollars into the economies of their respective states. And like contestants on a high-stakes game show, all of the players were well aware that the odds of winning the prize of getting their installation removed from the Pentagon hit list were slim. In two previous rounds of military downsizing, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which convened yesterday's hearing, has only reversed about 15 percent of the Pentagon's recommendations. The eight-member commission is to begin voting on the current list at the end of June.
 But first the commission must complete a nationwide tour that has involved stops at similar hearings in Guam; Great Falls, Mont.; Baltimore, and Delta Junction, Alaska. As they have elsewhere, the commissioners who traveled to the west side of Manhattan yesterday were greeted with a flurry of slides, charts, graphs, maps, speeches and, in the case of the Lakehurst contingent, a 10-minute movie. At times, even the commission chairman, Alan Dixon, a former Senator from Illinois, was unable to suppress a yawn.
 But for those arguing on behalf of their states, the proceedings were tense, a last chance to show the commissioners first-hand what the human cost of their decisions will be. Among the most vocal participants were 500 workers from Lakehurst in Ocean County, who came to the hearing on 10 chartered buses, wearing blue T-shirts proclaiming their installation "the heart of naval aviation" and raucously cheering each official who spoke on their behalf. The installation, which provides a variety of support and repair functions for the Navy, is scheduled to be closed, resulting in a loss of 1,383 civilian jobs.
 "I make over $60,000," said Mauricio Borrero, 35, a manager who has worked at Lakehurst for 12 years. "There's no place else in the county I am going to make that kind of money."
 Another New Jersey installation on the chopping block is the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, which employs 2,445 workers and has packed off untold tanks, trucks, helicopters and crates of ammunition to battlefields around the world. Under the Pentagon proposal, those tasks would be taken up by various commercial ports along the East Coast. But Lillian Liburdi, the director of the port department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, told the commissioners that such plans were unrealistic and that the region's other ports, as well as commercial ports in Savannah, Ga., Charleston, S.C., and Jacksonville, Fla., were ill-equipped to handle military shipments.
 "I am very concerned," she said, citing the extraordinary space and security that would be required at those commercial ports, all under extreme time pressure, during a period of military mobilization.
In all three states, the common threat of the Pentagon's hit list brought together an all-star cast of strange political bedfellows: at one point, New York's Assembly Speaker, Mr. Silver, a Democrat, crouched alongside the state's Republican Governor, Mr. Pataki, and the two men -- at war in New York's protracted budget negotiations -- casually whispered back and forth.
 For several minutes, Governor Whitman, a Republican, sat next to Senator Bradley, the Democrat who defeated her in a bitter 1990 Senate race, and Senator Dodd, a veteran Democrat, found himself heartily seconding the presentation of his state's freshman Republican governor, Mr. Rowland.
 In New York, where several installations face closing or reduction, the delegates at today's hearing devoted half of their 105-minute presentation to Rome Laboratory. Indeed, at the conclusion of the Rome testimony, which led the hearing, Governor Pataki and Senator D'Amato left for the day, leaving Representative Susan Molinari to lobby for the retention of all the family housing at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Representative Gary Ackerman to fight for the life of Fort Totten in Queens.
 Rome Lab is the centerpiece of a $12 million state proposal to develop a high-tech corridor, along the lines of the Route 128 corridor around Boston, to lure a range of technology businesses to upstate New York. The Air Force lab develops sophisticated methods of battlefield control and surveillance and employs more than 1,000 people. It has tens of millions of dollars worth of contracts with area institutions and companies, including Cornell University, Syracuse University and Nynex.
 "Basically, I'm a businessman," said Ivan Seidenberg, the chairman and chief executive of Nynex, which has worked with the lab to create a series of interactive video networks linking teachers with far-flung students and doctors with far-away patients. "Rome Lab looks good on the balance sheet right where it is."
 That theme was echoed by James Robinson, vice president of Allied Signal, whose company is under contract with the Pentagon to produce tank engines at the Army Engine Plant in Stratford, Conn. Under the Pentagon plan, the plant would be closed and 1,600 civilians would lose their jobs.
 In raising skepticism about the Army's plan to relocate the factory's functions to other plants across the country, Mr. Robinson issued what sounded like a veiled threat. His company, he said, owns the heavy equipment essential to the engine-building process and was not inclined to move it elsewhere at the Army's behest. "At least," he said, "not for free."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Officials from three states attended a hearing yesterday to argue against closing military bases. From New Jersey were Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Senator Bill Bradley and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman; Aboard the U.S.S. Intrepid, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Gov. George E. HEADLINE: Unemployment Rates Up in New York State and New Jersey

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Economic growth in New York State continued to stagnate last month as the unemployment rate rose again, Labor Department officials said yesterday.
While the national unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point in April, to 5.8 percent, the rate in New York State increased to 6.8 percent, from 6.6 percent in March. But it was down from 7.8 percent a year earlier. 
 The unemployment rate in New York City remained virtually unchanged, rising to 8.6 percent, from 8.5 percent in March. The rate was 9.5 percent in April 1994.
The coast-to-coast slowdown reflected in the national employment data could mean continued weakness in the job market in New York and much of the Northeast, Labor Department officials said.
"As the nation hopes for a soft landing for its economy, the risk is that sometimes the brakes get locked, and I hope that is not what we are seeing now," said Anthony J. Ferrara, acting regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
In New Jersey, one of the few places in the Northeast that has kept pace with the rest of the country, the jobless rate rose to 6.3 percent, up from 5.8 percent in March and down from 7.2 percent a year ago.
No April data were available for Connecticut, which is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month. The Connecticut Department of Labor said the rate of unemployment for March was 5.3 percent, down from 5.8 percent in February.
In sharp contrast, California's unemployment rate rose to 7.9 percent in April from 7.6 percent in March.
While the unemployment figures in New York were indeed gloomy, Mr. Ferrara said the data reflecting the growth of new jobs were worse.
"New York had no growth whatsoever," he said. The state added only 32,000 jobs, he said, for a rate of four-hundredths of 1 percent, ranking New York 48th nationally, ahead of only Rhode Island and Hawaii.
At the same time, New Jersey added 78,000 jobs, or a 2.2 percent increase since March 1994. With that in mind, Mr. Ferrara attributed last month's increase in New Jersey's unemployment rate partly to the fact that more people in the state were actively looking for work.
But he said the disappointing prospects nationally "could only have a dampening effect on New Jersey."
Mr. Ferrara also cited what he described as a critical economic juxtaposition over the last year in New York City. He said that while government was shedding 30,000 jobs, private industry created 21,000 jobs.
"There are some people who would see that as positive sign, and others who would not," Mr. Ferrara said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rally in Bonds Helps the Dollar Gain Against the Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly higher yesterday, helped by a rally in Treasury bonds.
Speculation that the United States and Japan could reach an agreement on automotive trade also helped the dollar stay steady against the yen, dealers said. 
 The dollar initially fell after the United States Labor Department reported a sharp rise in unemployment in April. The report dashed any remaining hopes in the currency markets that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on May 23. Higher interest rates typically bolster a currency by making deposits denominated in it more attractive.
But the bond market rallied on the employment data, bringing the dollar back. Higher United States bond prices help the dollar because foreign investors must first buy dollars to buy the bonds.
"The dollar was primarily driven by the bond market rally," said Hillel Waxman, manager of currency trading at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.3730 German marks from 1.3710 marks on Thursday. The dollar edged up to 83.96 Japanese yen from 83.80.
The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent. The report was seen as providing strong evidence that the Fed's policy of higher interest rates to slow the economy had succeeded and that the Fed would have to stop raising rates.
Although rates in the United States may have peaked, many traders said they were reluctant to sell dollars for yen as the United States-Japan auto trade talks continued. "The next thing the market is waiting for is the outcome of the talks," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York.
In other currency trading, the British pound fell after British interest rates were left unchanged. The move by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, after a meeting with the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, surprised dealers, who had been expecting an an increase of half a percentage point, to 7.25 percent.
The decision on interest rates came a day after the ruling Conservative Party had been roundly defeated in local elections in England and Wales. Uncertainty about the stability of Prime Minister John Major's Government has plagued the pound this year. So far this year, the pound has fallen 11.74 percent against the mark.
In New York, the pound fell to $1.5972 from $1.6172.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Issue Is Jobs

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
"The Turk" is the name professional football players have given to the low-level management functionaries who, in training camp, have the gruesome task of summoning players to the coach's office, where they receive the news that they are being dropped from the team.
The talk with the coach can last 5 or 10 minutes. The player then packs his bags, gets in his car and leaves. It's a brief, devastating scenario. Ferocious 300-pound linemen whose raison d'etre is to pound other mortals into mincemeat live in absolute fear of a visit from the Turk. 
 Thanks to the downsizing phenomenon, a similar kind of fear exists now in both the corporate and governmental workplace. As the ruthless combination of corporate power and conservative politics increases its dominance over American life, legions of faithful and mostly middle-class American employees are tormented by the fear that they will be the next to walk the employment plank.
On Monday, the Mobil Corporation announced it would cut the work force at its Fairfax, Va., headquarters by one-third, eliminating 1,250 jobs. As soon as the announcement was made, Mobil's stock hit a new high.
On Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Department announced it would cut its work force by 27 percent, or 3,788 jobs. (To get a better sense of the human impact, think in terms of 3,788 families.) The move was seen as an effort by Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary to ward off Republican calls for the entire department to be abolished. The G.O.P. would also like to eliminate the Commerce, Education and Housing and Urban Development departments.
Top corporate executives and rabid conservatives see the forced expulsion of workers from the workplace as a good thing. It is an extremely efficient way to suck money up from the middle classes to the elite. The lead headline in Thursday's Wall Street Journal said: "Amid Record Profits, Companies Continue to Lay Off Employees."
Forget for a moment all the talk about guns and immigrants and hatred of the Federal Government. Turn off the radio. Take a deep breath. Americans are angry and anxiety-ridden because tens of millions are already unemployed or temporarily employed or employed only part of the time. Millions are working without benefits or working two and three lousy jobs because one just doesn't pay enough. And millions more who are employed can hear the downsizing buzzsaw coming ever closer.
Poll results released Thursday by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion showed that one in three Americans have had trouble meeting their monthly expenses for housing, "and a similar number were financially pressed when medical attention was needed." The poll found that "more than one in four Americans experienced difficulty purchasing clothes that were necessary and one of every six Americans found it difficult to buy food which they needed."
That is a recipe for anger and anxiety. But when the anger is expressed, it is seldom directed toward the corporate elites or the politicians who do their bidding. Downsized and otherwise exploited American workers leave their work stations as humbly and quietly as the ex-football players leave training camp. When it comes time to rage, they find something or someone else to rage at.
The most recent figures from the Federal Reserve show that the richest 1 percent of American households have nearly 40 percent of the nation's wealth. The top 20 percent of American households have more than 80 percent of the nation's wealth.
And how are Americans voting at the moment? For politicians who will do everything in their considerable power to increase the disparity.
It's a given (disgraceful but true) that in the current climate the poor will be savaged. What is interesting to me is how so many in the middle and working classes are being clobbered but refuse to recognize who is doing the clobbering. By chasing scapegoats of all kinds -- Mexicans creeping across the California border, teen-age mothers, PBS -- they are, in effect, giving their oppressors carte blanche. Hit me again, they seem to be crying. And the corporate elite and their political stooges are more than happy to oblige.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Vote for Supermarket Deserves No Praise

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Supermarket Success" (editorial, May 1), you loudly praise City Councilman Guillermo Linares for casting the decisive vote in favor of Pathmark in East Harlem. But what you call his "political courage" is nothing but an insensitive vote against the small merchants of East Harlem that he claimed to support until just before his vote. 
 It is greatly unfair to the small merchants that a big outside corporation be allowed to enter the neighborhood with tax exemptions, $12 million in loans ($7 million below market rate), and city and state grants, while they struggle to break even. It is unfair to allow in a megastore like Pathmark, while for decades the small merchants have struggled in the midst of increasing city taxes, high rent and declining sales.
Mr. Linares's vote is not an act of political courage, but rather an act of cowardice and treason against the political and economic empowerment of East Harlem's Latino community.
 
RAMON SILVERIO
President
Congreso Nacional Dominicano
New York, May 2, 1995
