HEADLINE: Don't Rush to Sanctions

 BODY:
President Clinton's advisers meet today to decide whether to impose trade sanctions on Japan after failure to reach agreement on opening up Japanese markets for foreign automobiles and automobile parts. Japan's auto market is the right target for an aggressive American stand because it is closed to foreign suppliers and accounts for almost 60 percent of the $66 billion bilateral trade deficit. But instead of imposing sanctions on its own, Washington should work through the new World Trade Organization, created with American support to deal with this kind of grievance.
Japan imports only 4 percent of its automobiles and trucks and 2.4 percent of its car parts. American manufacturers are partly responsible. They have refused to sell small cars that the Japanese crave and have only recently built cars with steering wheels on the right-hand side, where the Japanese expect them. But there are Japanese problems as well, including a distribution system that shuts foreign cars out of showrooms, and Government regulations that impose costly inspections on parts on the pretext of guaranteeing safety. 
 The United States and Japan have reportedly made progress in knocking down both of these barriers. But Japan has rejected a demand that its manufacturers renew a "voluntary" pledge to use more American parts in their new models. Tokyo takes the justifiable position that it has no business telling private companies whose parts to buy.
If Washington tries to win with unilateral sanctions what it could not win in negotiations, it creates two problems for itself. Sanctions can trigger trade wars -- which explains why currency markets often greet American threats by driving down the dollar. The Administration's tactic of riling currency markets seems poorly timed, coming when the dollar has sunk to record lows against the German mark and Japanese yen.
Imposing, even threatening, sanctions also betrays Washington's commitment to trade rules it helped establish. America fought to make sure the World Trade Organization would have real power to resolve disputes. The Trade Organization's rules forbid unilateral, discriminatory sanctions.
Under rules that went into effect at the beginning of the year, Washington can seek the appointment of an international trade panel to hear its complaint that Japan's non-tariff barriers effectively nullify commitments to engage in open trade. Under the old rules, Japan could have vetoed an adverse ruling; under the new rules it cannot.
Washington fought for tougher dispute resolution so that it could force trading partners to play fair. But instead of giving the procedures a chance, the Administration is threatening to set its own rules, a model Washington will regret when other countries follow.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Hotels Offer Deals and Toys

BYLINE: BY BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
AN 8-year-old I know is paid for chores in "milk caps" for the Pogs game, a wildly popular commercial version of a Depression-era sidewalk game in which the goal is to flip over your opponent's disks. For this child, playing the game is less crucial than collecting and organizing the caps and the bigger "slammers" that make them flip over. He and others his age should be fascinated to learn that both Holiday Inn and Howard Johnson's are awarding special versions of the caps to young guests this summer as part of their programs.
Starting Memorial Day, Holiday Inns will give each young guest a box containing one slammer and four caps depicting endangered species; Howard Johnson's will give children 18 years old and younger a game package that includes three caps depicting Sega computer game characters. 
 Many other hotel and motel chains feature tie-ins with cartoons or video games along with special summer rates or discounts; marketing specialists say that children often choose a family's lodging.
 
Deals for Adults, Too
 Here is selected information on summer promotion offerings, mostly focusing on appeals to adults' wallets.
Inter-Continental Hotels and Resorts calls its promotion Spectacular Options, which includes a discount plus an option such as an upgrade. This will be offered daily from May 26 to Sept. 5 at 31 of 33 properties of Inter-Continental and its partner hotels in the United States, Canada and Mexico. As a sample, at the Inter-Continental in New Orleans (where rates generally drop in the steamy summer), the rate will be $105 rather than the regular $200; at the Lenox in Boston, $146 instead of $190; at the Maui Inter-Continental Resort in Hawaii, $159 rather than $290. In addition, guests may pick one option: an upgrade to a suite; an adjoining room at half-price; a $25 or $15 credit (depending on the hotel) toward food and beverage, and double airline mileage or overnight parking.
Only some rooms at each hotel are available at these prices. Scott W. Boone, vice president for sales, said 10 percent of rooms was the minimum number set aside for the promotion, but most hotels offer more. Inter-Continental: (800) 327-0200.
Marriott Hotels and Resorts offers Two for Breakfast weekend discounts Thursday through Sunday at hotels and suite properties, and all week long at resorts. All 200 domestic and Canadian Marriott full-service hotels, and 26 resorts, including two in Mexico, are participating. Marriott says the savings are 30 to 40 percent; for example, the Wind Watch in Hauppauge, L.I., offers Two for Breakfast at $115 a night, compared with a regular rate of $155; the Denver City Center, at $79, as against $119. The promotional rate includes breakfast, of course. Marriott is providing a frequent-guest tie-in with the Visa Rewards program. Under this, 20 percent of what a customer spends at the Marriott is credited toward a future stay at a Marriott. Gordon D. Lambourne, director of public relations, says that the program is "widely available." The "weekends" number for Marriott is (800) 872-9563.
At 57 Hyatt hotels and resorts in the United States and the Caribbean, guests get a free night after three consecutive nights between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Hyatt: (800) 233-1234.
The Radisson Hotel chain of more than 300 properties worldwide is again offering Shades of Summer, this year tied in to the Six Flags theme parks. The room rates are 30 to 50 percent off advertised rates, the chain says, making them $69 to $159 a night. Last year, half the hotels offered breakfast with the rate; this year, a third do, according to Joan M. Cronson, a spokeswoman. At United States Radissons within 100 miles of the Six Flags parks in Los Angeles, Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, St. Louis and Jackson, N.J., guests will receive a $4 discount coupon for a one-day admission ticket or a coupon providing a two-day pass for the price of a one-day. The rooms available at the special rates average 10 percent of the total, according to Ms. Cronson. The rates must be requested on reservation. Radisson: (800) 333-3333.
Westin's Kids Club is going into its second summer at 50 hotels and resorts in the United States, Canada and Mexico. From May 27 to Sept. 4, children under 18 stay free and those under 12 eat three meals a day free from a special menu, when eating with their families, room service included. Nine Westins are not participating: the Biltmore in Coral Gables, Fla.; the Algonquin and Plaza in New York; Walt Disney World Swan in Orlando; the Biltmore in Phoenix; the Governor, Portland, Ore.; the Westin Resort in Vail, Colo.; the ANA in Washington, and the Westin Mont-Royal in Montreal. Westin: (800) 228-3000.
Sheraton's Summer Suresavers, from Memorial Day to Labor Day, is a modification of a year-round program. Anyone making a reservation asks for the Suresaver rate, and is quoted the lowest available price except for corporate rates for big companies. At the Sheraton New York and Sheraton Manhattan, the Summer Special is offered from July 5 to Sept. 10 at $169 a night for two, with breakfast included. In both promotions, discounted rooms are limited in number. Sheraton: (800) 325-3535.
 
For Kids: Caps and Casper
 Now for the games and goodies. Holiday Inns always allow children 19 and under to stay free in parents' rooms; some Inns also allow children 12 and under to eat free with their parents year round. In summer, starting May 8, more than 1,100 of the 1,600 Holiday Inns in the Americas provide three free meals a day for children, as well as the Pog gifts. Holiday Inns: (800) 465-4329.
Howard Johnson's Kids Go HoJo is in its sixth year. Between Memorial Day and Labor Day, children under 18, who stay free in their parents' rooms, may choose as a gift a Fun Pack with crayons and games, including the milk caps, or a video with Sega game tips, starring Sonic the Hedgehog and other heroes of the youthful. Howard Johnson's is offering special rates of $35 to $75 a night for up to four in a room, which represents a 10 to 15 percent saving, the chain says. Howard Johnson's: (800) 446-4656.
Choice Hotels, comprising the Sleep, Comfort, Quality, Clarion, Friendship, Econo Lodge and Rodeway labels, is plunging in on May 20 with promotions featuring Casper the Friendly Ghost, soon to appear in a movie, and later with "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: the Movie." The promotions, ending Aug. 31, offer children chances at prizes, from $250,000 in cash down to a discount coupon for Pizza Huts. The 1,292 Comfort Inns offer a large free breakfast; the Sleep Inns have a smaller version. Comfort, Clarion, Quality and Sleep Inns: (800) 221-2222. Econo Lodge, Rodeway and Friendship Inns: (800) 424-4777.
Starting June 5, some 2,000 Best Westerns are featuring Willy the Whale, soon to be seen in "Free Willy 2: The Adventure Home" due for release July 4. Free activity books based on the movie will be given away, and there will be contests to win free parties for 20 that include a screening of the movie, popcorn and a soda. Best Western: (800) 528-1234.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 34; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1736 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Wonder World in the Mile High City

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
WHAT IS THIS SUDDEN outburst of innocence on the Denver skyline? Three major public works will be completed in the Mile High City this year. All three are good buildings. Each is different in style and function. But running through all of them is a return-to-childhood motif, a sense of lost wonder recalled, if not regained.
A Big Top airport. A Classics Illustrated library. A Those Were the Days ball park. These projects add up to a statement, a more or less subtle and, one hopes, benign form of infantilism projected in architectural form. The regression is not confined to Denver -- other American cities are crooning these architectural songs of innocence -- but the coincidence of these major projects amounts to a fundamental change in the city's image. 
 It's a broad departure from what Le Corbusier called the "cite d'affaires," the traditional downtown where men and reason ruled. Denver has a lot of bright new skyscrapers too, a product of the nationwide building boom of the 1980's. But to give this spiffy core a soul, the architects of these public works have looked beyond the grown-up world of business toward fantasy, play and memories of adolescent yearning. Like "Village of the Damned," the architecture of innocence is essentially a remake. Welcome to the City of the Saved.
 
The Stadium: Theme Park
 You cannot smoke in Denver restaurants, but they haven't yet put a stop to drinking, and the new Coors Field baseball stadium is a virtual Field of Suds. Not only is it named for a brewer, but a brewery is attached to the stadium, forming one of its walls. And the streets surrounding the ball park are awash with gentrified versions of old saloons.
Designed by the Kansas City firm of HOK Sport, architects of the superb Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, Coors Field is the latest of the new breed of ball park that is supposed to recall such sporting classics as Wrigley Field and Fenway Park. I couldn't get inside the stadium, which was closed at the time, but the building's strengths as an urban object are clear enough from the outside.
Like Oriole Park, Coors Field sits on the edge of downtown, bordered by rail yards, and it represents a thoughtful and successful effort at urban revitalization. Denver's Lower Downtown district is a zesty neighborhood of old loft buildings that until recently was mired in skid-row seediness. Now, "LoDo" is Denver's SoHo, a center for galleries, small shops and artists' lofts. Coors Field throws a major league team into the mix. It's quite a catch.
The design of the stadium, too, recalls that of Oriole Park: in the industrial-strength steel and red-brick structure, the incorporation of an old brick building into the architecture, the fluidity of space between inside and outside. Both stadiums frame dramatic views. In Baltimore, it's a downtown skyline; in Denver, a spectacular view of the Rockies.
The point of view of the architecture is something else again. Here, the Devil is in the details: rusticated stone bases, diaper patterns in the brick, ceramic medallions, turn-of-the-century graphics. With all that retro ornament, it's as if the stadium had been dipped in sepia.
Oriole Park has its retro touches, too, but they are held in balance by the building's sinewy structural framework. As a result, visitors to the stadium can see that modern design, far from being the polar opposite of tradition, is firmly rooted in the vernacular tradition of industrial building.
Coors Field has the same strong industrial bones. But they're hidden beneath an ornamental veneer that strikes a dubious equation between baseball and the memory of happy days of yore. The result is attractive but coercive. You can't enter the stadium without sinking into someone else's fantasy about your past, though after a few beers you may forget how miserable the old days could be.
 
The Library: 7-Story Village
 Michael Graves's colorful, quirky esthetic has often resembled a child's garden of classicism, the vision of an impressionable prodigy who has been given a box of colored pencils and asked to draw a courthouse, a library or one of the other civic buildings seen on a school trip downtown.
Denver's new Central Library, designed by Graves with the local firm Klipp Colussy Jenks DuBois, won't be officially completed until September. But the library opened to the public a few weeks ago, and its exterior is largely complete.
This, too, is a building that aspires to make a strong connection to its surroundings, though the context is stylistically the reverse of Coors Field's gritty urban texture. It's an ideal site, however, for Michael Graves: a Beaux-Arts Civic Center, with state and city office buildings surrounding a beautiful classical plaza. Over the years, however, the classical harmony has been eroded by buildings like Gio Ponti's 1971 Denver Art Museum, and by a typical downtown's vertical sprawl. Graves has made it his task to reconcile the classical formality of the Civic Center with the architectural jumble around it.
He has accomplished this, successfully, by breaking down the seven-story building into fragments, including a square tower with a pyramid top, a cylindrical turret and a central rotunda capped with a gutsy, copper-clad, Gehryesque crown. Stone cladding, in a range of Crayola colors, sets each fragment apart; each facade is different.
Like Graves's unbuilt design for the Whitney Museum, the library is an addition to an existing building, in this case a low, modernist structure designed by Burnham Hoyt in 1956, which Graves turns into yet another fragment. The overall impression is less a building than a village, or a small civic center in itself: Mr. Rogers meets McKim, Meade & White.
 
The Airport: Escape Routes
 Let's run away with the circus! Or, if we're too old to imagine dangling from a trapeze, let's take a taxi out to the new Denver International Airport. This Big Top of an airport delivers the oohs and aahs, starting with the grand tent structure that encloses the main terminal. Designed by the Denver firm of C. W. Fentress J. H. Bradburn & Associates, the tent is made of Teflon-coated fabric, pieced together like sails. Parallel rows of masts lift the roof into a range of abstract snowcapped mountain peaks. A technically sophisticated structure that picks up on the pioneering work of Frei Otto, the visionary designer of the tent structures for the 1972 Munich Olympics, the roof also recalls the fabric pavilions Gordon Bunshaft created for the airport in Jedda, Saudi Arabia, in 1981.
Slung between the two central rows is the roof of a great hall, the airport's central space. Entering the hall on the balcony level, you look down on the bustling concourse with a gleaming granite floor. The effect is similar to the plaza at Rockefeller Center, though looking up you see not skyscrapers but clouds of natural light filtered though billowing cloth.
Compared with most airports, this building feels good for the body. A walk along the main concourse, beneath the tall trees that rise from the warm granite pavement, is almost as pleasant as a mountain hike. The nature imagery evokes the reason Colorado draws new residents as well as tourists.
The inner child bursts out in the airport's public artworks. Whirling propeller blades, like those attached to 50's-era beanies, sprout from the walls of the tunnel through which shuttle trains pass on their way to the airport's far-flung concourses. Wheee! Loudspeakers blare a merry ta-ra-ra-boom-de-ay as the train pulls into the platform. In a living-art tableau, a herd of buffalo will be brought in to graze between the highway overpasses leading to the main terminal.
The three concourses, designed by Perez Associates of New Orleans, also develop the theme of innocence, though on a more specialized level. With ziggurats of glass and metal spanning their central courts, the concourses hark back to the dawn of modernism in Joseph Paxton's 1851 design for the London Crystal Palace. The reference takes on a particular meaning in the context of this airport, because the palace, built for the first world's fair, inaugurated the modern concept of globalism. The Denver airport shows where that idea has taken us: to international travel, and to the dish farms of the cable television companies clustered in Denver's industrial parks.
Indeed, there is something naive in the airport's use of natural imagery, for the airport itself will accelerate the transformation of the surrounding country into suburban sprawl. That's one theory for why the airport was situated 26 miles from downtown Denver. Within a few years, what is now ranch land will be carpeted with office parks and residential subdivisions. People will still come here for the nature, but they will have to go farther out to get to it. Perhaps the airport's stylized version of nature is to read as a kind of paradise lost: the rendering of God's own country into a man-made artifact.
A friend who lives in the mountains about an hour from Denver has a theory about these buildings. He says they are a result of the baby boomers' growing into their role as parents. They're reliving their childhoods, or perhaps creating the childhoods they wished they'd had, so that they can pass on something of value to the next generation. Perhaps these buildings are compensation for the innocence that was battered out of the boomers when they discovered that even they would grow old. A few years ago, the moan was "Oh, no, we're turning into our parents." Now maybe the idea is to reconstruct the parents they're turning into.
But there's something specifically urban going on here, as well, an effort to find a viable image so that the city itself can be passed on instead of dissolving into thin mountain air. As new industries continue to disperse the city along the highway, the identity of the central business district has been eroded. What has taken its place is the culture of travel and leisure: tourism, the arts, popular entertainment.
Once, tourism was an escape from the reality represented by cities; now it is reality, the city's most solid economic base. Once baseball was a pastime; now it is a major media-driven industry. Once the city was a place where businesses congregated. Now "the city" is itself a consumer product, recast as an escape from grown-up care. Cities 'R' Us.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Airport -- The main terminal of the new Denver International Airport is enclosed by a tentlike structure made of Teflon-coated fabric that looks like sails of a ship. The Library -- This fragmented, Crayola-colored structure sprouts pyramids and turrets, making it seem less a building than a village or a small civic center. The Stadium -- Coors Field, the latest of the new breed of ball park designed to recall such classics as Fenway Park, represents a successful effort at urban revitalization. (Photographs by Michael Lewis for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2670 words

HEADLINE: $2,000 or More: A Decontrol Odyssey

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WHEN Pam and Kevin Wolf spent $250,000 to completely renovate their rent-stabilized three-bedroom duplex apartment on Park Avenue six years ago, some of their friends questioned their sanity.
"They told us we were crazy to spend that much money fixing up a rental," Mrs. Wolf said, gazing across the grand gallery the couple created -- and which they will vacate in August. "But we planned on staying here for at least 20 years. Everybody else who lives here has been here that long. And we thought, where else could we get a 2,800-square-foot duplex on Park Avenue for $250,000?" 
 But the Wolfs guessed wrong. Rent controls for apartments renting for $2,000 or more a month that are occupied by tenants whose household income was more than $250,000 for two years running were effectively lifted in 1993. For tenants of such apartments who either voluntarily acknowledge they make that much money or are found to make that much, the choice is unpleasantly clear: either move out, stay temporarily through a series of appeals and delays, or try to negotiate a deal with the owner.
For those who move out, finding a comparable apartment at a price near to what they were paying is close to impossible, according to real-estate brokers who cite the hot rental market as one factor. For some grand eight- or nine-room prewar apartments that may have rented for several thousand dollars to rent-regulated tenants, market rents may now be "way over $10,000, maybe $15,000 a month," said Dolly Lenz, Sotheby's top-selling agent.
Cathy Blau, a broker on the Upper West Side, cited the case of one older couple whose rent skyrocketed. "They had a three-bedroom, three-bath apartment in a great prewar," she said. "Now they're looking at a one- or two-bedroom with one-and-a-half baths in a postwar in an entirely different location. They're scaling down everything." Ms. Blau said she had suggested to families with children in private schools that they look at houses in Riverdale.
In TriBeCa, Barrie Mandel of the Corcoran Group said that one couple to whom she is currently showing apartments could have bought the 3,000-square-foot loft they are now renting back in 1980 or 1981 for $50,000. They gambled, and kept paying the rent, which has risen to over $2,000. "The rent will now shoot up to $5,000 a month," Ms. Mandel said. "If they bought it then -- with the tax deductions -- they would have paid the equivalent of maybe six months rent." If they want to buy their loft now, it's on the market for $895,000.
Throughout Manhattan, where most of the decontrol is taking place, deals are being made. Some landlords in buildings that have been converted to co-ops and condominiums, but in which some apartments are still occupied by rent-regulated tenants, are offering to sell apartments to well-off renters at less than market prices. If that fails, sometimes they offer cash incentives to leave, according to high-end brokers like Ms. Lenz, who says that 30 percent of her sales in the last nine months have been to "luxury-decontrol people."
AT 40 Central Park South and its sister building, at 41 West 58th Street, both of which were constructed in the 1940's, 18 of 200 apartments were decontrolled because of the high-rent, high-income decontrol law. Tenants in 15 of the apartments have already negotiated higher rents. Neither side will give specific numbers, but the landlord said the deals were a compromise between the old rent and the market rent.
The landlord, H. Dale Hemmerdinger of ATCO Properties, said that as a result of the decontrol of the apartments, he would spend $8 million on renovations and was using his prediction of more forced vacancies in the coming years to borrow from banks. "We're fighting over the timetable," he said, "because nobody really knows exactly how many apartments will turn over in a given year." He estimated there would be at least 10 a year in the buildings.
In one complicated negotiation involving 20 apartments at a magnificent old landmark building on the Upper West Side, tenants negotiated a "lifetime tenancy" deal with the landlord, according to the group's lawyer. The rents will be keyed to existing rents but will rise by amounts negotiated between the landlord and the tenants hit or likely to be hit by the decontrol provisions.
In other buildings, landlords have given tenants 5- or 10-year leases at a compromise rent. "Say if they were paying $2,500 and the market is $5,000, they'll start at $3,500 or $4,000, to be brought up to market over the time of the lease," said Samuel J. Himmelstein, a Manhattan lawyer who frequently represents tenants. Mr. Himmelstein said he was not talking about the half-dozen luxury decontrol cases his firm was handling, but cases he had been told about.
While 869 decontrol orders had been issued by April 28, notifying renters that their apartments are no longer subject to rent regulation -- rulings that may be appealed -- an untold number of renters "saw the writing on the wall," as one tenant put it, and left.
Although no governmental agency is tracking these people, real estate brokers report they are showing up in ever-increasing numbers at open houses and making appointments to view co-ops and condos. One such couple, a plastic surgeon and his lawyer wife, bought a carriage house on the Upper East Side, one broker said. The surgeon will use the downstairs for his office, perhaps even reducing his monthly expenses.
Some of these tenants say that they are unable to buy. Mary Vetri, a rental agent for William B. May's downtown office, said many affected young people were not moving from their old apartments, even though the rent will rise. "They'll stay because they're in a bind: they're making a lot of money, but they don't have any down payment to buy," Ms. Vetri said.
She said that many such renters are "young Wall Street types" who may have rented an apartment for $2,100 a month a couple of years ago and whose rent has risen to a market level of perhaps $2,400, nothing like the huge increase that someone who had lived in a regulated apartment for 10 or 20 years would encounter.
Renters in large, prewar buildings -- often already converted to co-ops or condominiums -- who have lived in their apartments for years have received the biggest financial shock. One such tenant who, like the Wolfs, spent a large amount of money to on improvements, and who would speak only on condition of anonymity, called the law "brutally unfair."
"It protects rent-controlled tenants paying almost nothing who are in a far better economic situation that I am," he said. "I felt that we have been taken advantage of." Since he moved into his nine-room apartment in 1985, he said, his rent had gone from $2,200 to $3,250. If he had not made a deal with his landlord -- a deal he refused to discuss -- the rent would have gone up to $7,000, he said.
Another lawyer who specializes in tenant representation, Steven Smollens, criticized what he termed the "illogic and unfairness of a law that allows a man making $1 million a year to keep his $500-a-month apartment, but takes away the apartment of a husband and wife with four children in private school, with barely a dollar for a pizza tip."
The high-rent, high-income decontrol law was approved by the State Legislature two years ago after a bitter struggle. Both landlord and tenant representatives predict that when the rent-regulation laws come up for the required renewal by the Legislature in 1997, with a Republican administration in office in Albany, there will be another battle.
THE final report of Gov. George E. Pataki's Transition Committee on Housing and Community Development, dated Dec. 13, 1994, recommends phasing out rent regulations completely through vacancy decontrol -- the lifting of controls on all apartments as they become vacant.
A similar vacancy-decontrol policy was in effect from 1971 to 1974, resulting in the decontrol of 388,000 apartments, or about a third of the city's rent-regulated stock, according to the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. About 90 percent of those apartments were reregulated in 1974 with the passage of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, after a report by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy noted that rents had jumped precipitously on turnover. There were also complaints of tenants being harassed by landlords -- charges that were denied.
Currently apartments renting for more than $2,000 a month are, under the 1993 law, decontrolled when they become vacant.
Governor Pataki's transition committee for housing was headed by Charles J. Urstadt, the real-estate executive who was the architect of the first vacancy decontrol when he was Housing Commissioner under another Republican Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller. The committee's report also recommends extending decontrol to current tenants with household incomes over $150,000 who live in apartments renting for more than $1,500 a month.
Tenant and landlord groups are already gearing up for the legislative struggle to come.
Michael McKee, development director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, said he would join other tenant advocates on May 16 in chartering a series of buses bound for Albany, in the first tenant rally since Governor Pataki took office.
ON the other side, Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said that his group had already begun lobbying legislators.
"There's going to be a major battle in 1997, but that doesn't mean we're not doing anything now," said Mr. Spinola. "I don't think we'll be able to reduce the limits this year -- we'll try -- but I think maybe this year we'll be able to pass a law putting rent that's being withheld into escrow."
Mr. Spinola and his group contend that the escrow measure is necessary because some tenants, faced with a decontrol order, would unfairly claim "diminution of services" and not send in their rent. "After about eight months -- long enough to see they're not going to win -- they'll just run out without paying," said Mr. Hemmerdinger.
Mr. Hemmerdinger said that he was making renovations at his two back-to-back postwar apartment buildings -- 40 Central Park South and 41 West 58th Street -- that he would not have undertaken without luxury decontrol. He has hired two noted interior designers, Jed Johnson and Alan Wanzenberg, to draw up plans for elaborate granite and bronze lobbies in both buildings and for renovations to the entrance on Central Park South.
He said that he would redo the elevators at both and that he had spent in "six figures" resurrecting the garden courtyard between the buildings. He said he was installing an elaborate plastic-key and card security system that will restrict even the tenants to certain floors. He is replacing the buildings' old balconies with stainless steel ones.
"Like any landlord, you let the carpet get threadbare, let the elevators look seedy," said the outspoken developer and landlord. "Now I have motivation: I can't get the higher market rents unless my halls look good."
THE first step in high-rent, high-income decontrol involves a questionnaire. Under the system, landlords may send income questionnaires to anyone who pays rent of $2,000 a month or more. If the tenant replies that gross household income has not totaled more than $250,000 in each of the last two years, or if the questionnaire is not returned, an income check is run through the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. If the tenant answers yes, or if the income check reveals that the household is "over income," a decontrol order is issued.
At this point, negotiations often begin. The landlords interviewed all agreed that their first choice was to keep the sitting tenant -- but at a higher rent. Tenants can appeal decontrol orders, as landlords can appeal denials. The decontrol orders do not become effective until the expiration of the lease.
Until recently, Doug Oliver was a rent-stabilized tenant in an 11-room, high-ceilinged prewar apartment at 21 East 66th Street, a building that was converted to a condominium six years ago. Mr. Oliver was paying $2,700 a month when he received the decontrol questionnaire. Some of his friends in the neighborhood are paying that much for a one-bedroom apartment, he freely concedes.
When Mr. Oliver received the questionnaire, he decided that his days as a $2,700-a-month renter were numbered -- despite the fact, he said, that his highly variable yearly income as a commercial real estate broker had been over the threshold in only one of the two preceding years.
"The first year I had tremendous losses," he said. "But my second year was great. So even though I didn't qualify then, they can send these questionnaires out every year and I knew it wouldn't be long before I did."
At first, Mr. Oliver's instinct was to fight, and to drag the procedure out as long as possible, continuing to pay the $2,700 rent "probably until the year 2000." He called lobbying groups and "rushed down to Mike McKee's office and gave him a check for $5,000 to go to Albany and do something. I paid another $3,000 for old ladies to go picket. I gave a couple of Councilpeople contributions."
But then he and the conversion sponsor worked out a compromise: the sponsor would sell him the 11-room apartment, with three exposures, 28 windows and three fireplaces, for $1.23 million. The apartment has been appraised for more than double that figure, he said. As part of the deal, the condominium's sponsor required that if Mr. Oliver sold within three years of the purchase -- a process known as "flipping" the apartment -- Mr. Oliver would pay him a set sum, which he declined to disclose. With the mortgage and maintenance, Mr. Oliver said, he now pays about $15,000 a month before taxes -- more than five times his former rent. At market value the apartment might rent for between $18,000 and $20,000 a month, according to Ms. Lenz.
ALTHOUGH the apartment appears to be a sound financial investment, Mr. Oliver said that he made the decision at least partly because "once I got into a real out-and-out battle, they were right that someday they'd get it back, and I didn't want to live in my house under that threat; my home was in jeopardy."
Pam and Kevin Wolf, after their initial shock on receiving a questionnaire, also felt that their home was in jeopardy. In doing their $250,000 renovation six years ago, they had combined two rental apartments in the postwar white-brick building at 920 Park Avenue, at 80th Street. Their total rent was $4,100 a month. They said that with the landlord's permission they put in new windows, central air-conditioning and heat, some slate floors, Jacuzzis and an elegant winding staircase. They had remodeled every room.
When they move out this August, at the end of their lease, the rent on their apartment, they said, is scheduled to go up to $7,500 a month. "It sounds outrageous, but according to people who have been looking, the landlord will probably get it," Mrs. Wolf said. "This apartment works well for people who want to live on Park Avenue but can't pass stringent co-op rules."
Like Mr. Oliver, the Wolfs decided to buy -- but not in the same building. (The building at 920 Park is all rental, so they did not have the option.)
They declined to give the exact address or the price they are paying for their new apartment, but Mrs. Wolf deemed the monthly after-tax expenses "comparable" to the $7,500 they would have had to pay to stay where they are.
She said she felt that the new building, a landmark on Central Park West, would be more conducive to raising their two children, Jessica, 3, and Jared, 2.
"We're leaving the East Side for the West Side, for a more family-oriented building, where the children can Rollerblade in the lobby," Mrs. Wolf said. "Here one of the tenants once asked the doorman if the children and I couldn't ride in the freight elevator."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

LONG WHARF READINGS
Four new plays will be presented in readings at Stage II at Long Wharf in New Haven this week, followed by discussions between the audiences and the artists. Admission will be free, but donations, at a suggested $7, may be made at the box office.
Opening the series on Tuesday at 7:15 P.M. is Anthony Clarvoe's "Brothers Karamazov," based on the Dostoyevsky novel and directed by Gordon Edelstein, the theater's associate artistic director. Wednesday's offering at 8:15 P.M. is an acidic comedy called "The Smell of the Kill," by Michelle Lowe, in which three women at a dinner party, tired of their inattentive husbands, flip a coin to decide what dire fate will befall the men. 
 In "Poor Super Man," by Brad Fraser, on Thursday at 8:15 P.M. a male artist falls in love with his boss, a married man, and the consequences are a three-way stretch of urbanity, eroticism and hilarity. The final reading on Friday at 8:15 will be Jamie's Baker's "All Americans," a play about a black man who is hired as the basketball coach at a Southern university that refused to admit him as a student, regenerating old prejudices.
More than 70 new plays have been presented at Long Wharf in this manner since the workshops began in 1985. Nancy Fales, David Wiltse, Michael Henry Brown, Larry Shue and A. R. Gurney are among playwrights who have benefited from the exposure. Call 787-4282 to reserve tickets or obtain more information.
 
ORCHIDS TO BONSAI
 The Bartlett Arboretum of the University of Connecticut in North Stamford will holds its annual Spring Garden Fair on Saturday from 10 to 3 at 151 Brookdale Road. More than 10,000 annuals, perennials, wildflowers, herbs, ground covers, orchids and bonsai will be for sale, along with garden and gardening accessories displayed by vendors from throughout the tri-state area.
Demonstrations of pruning and instruction on the safe use of pesticides and the creation of a compost pile from yard and kitchen waste will be ongoing, as well as supervised activities for children.
Visitors are encouraged to bring blankets and picnics to enjoy on the grounds, and proceeds from anything they buy will go toward the arboretum's educational programs. Call 322-6971 for more information.
 
'BABAR' WITH MUSIC
 Francis Poulenc's music for Jean de Brunhoff's beloved "Story of Babar" will be performed by the New Haven Symphony Orchestra and narrated by Peter John Sacco, the orchestra's conductor, abetted by Babar's great-grandson, in three locations this week.
The programs are designed especially for children from 3 through 6 years of age, organized in cooperation with the Jewish Community Center of Greater New Haven. The symphony's Kinder Konzerts are an annual series in which two performances are given at each site.
This year's first appearances are scheduled for tomorrow at Warsaw Park, Route 243 in Ansonia at 9:30 A.M. and 10:45 A.M. Tuesday's location is the Jewish Community Center, 360 Amity Road in Woodbridge, and on Wednesday it's the Daisy Ingraham School at 105 Goodspeed Road in Westbrook.

 "Market Realism: Short and Long Term from the Mexican and United States Perspectives" is the subject of a panel discussion at a World Affairs Council lunch on Friday at 11:45 A.M. at the Hartford Club.

CHILDREN AND DRUGS
 In a scenario that youngsters from from third through ninth grade can understand, David Crane, Marta Kauffman and Michael Skloff have come up with a musical titled "Jekyll and Hyde."
The show will have two performances on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and noon at the Palace Theater, 61 Atlantic Street in Stamford, produced by Theaterworks/USA.
The main character is a teen-ager, Henry Meckler, premiere nerd of his school and resident chemistry genius. Desperately needing something to boost his social standing, he invents a substance that he calls More, which he imbibes, transforming himself into the personification of cool -- charming with women, aggressive with bullies and so on.
Henry needs more and more More to maintain his new persona, until it takes over his life and sends him into an academic and personal tailspin. Any resemblance to drug addiction among school children is purely intentional, but the aim is to entertain as well as inform children and their parents. Tickets are $5. Call 325-4466 for reservations or more information.

 The Norwalk Harbor Splash in South Norwalk has a crowded agenda today that starts with a rowing regatta from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. in which 200 men and women will participate.
A children's Gutter Regatta from 10 to 5 will be held at the Maritime Center at 10 North Water Street, in which staff members will help with the making of a small boat that will then be tested for seaworthiness.

Several events are free or carry a nomimal charge. Admission to the Maritime Center is $7.50, $6.50 for children 2 through 12 and people 62 and older. HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Round-Up Newcomers;
Moving Out to a Home on the Ever-Costlier Range

BYLINE: By DOUG McINNIS 

DATELINE: LANDER, Wyo.

 BODY:
IN California, Ken Marble lived in upscale Newport Beach, drove a Mercedes and owned a boat-cleaning business. Two years ago he traded the California life style for harsh winters, seven-day work weeks, and the uncertain financial future of owning a Western ranch.
His summer work day now begins at 4:30 A.M. when he irrigates his hay fields, and ends as the sun sets. But when calves are born in the later winter and early spring, the work day never stops. Every hour or two, round the clock, Mr. Marble checks the barn where pregnant cows are isolated. He could lose both cow and calf if he doesn't act quickly when something goes wrong. 
 He has already lost three calves this year, including one that was born unexpectedly on the range and died from hypothermia when it fell in a creek. Mr. Marble's Red Bluff Ranch is just 2,000 acres, small by Western standards. He raises only 60 calves a year, so every calf is critical to the ranch's profitability.
The 35-year-old Mr. Marble runs his ranch single-handed, a not uncommon practice in the West. He is part of an influx of outsiders who have bought Western ranches in recent years. Though still small, the migration is driving up the price of land in highly scenic sections of Wyoming, Montana and Colorado. Mr. Marble's ranch is cradled in one of the most desirable areas -- the foothills of Wyoming's Wind River Mountains, which crest in the clouds at the Continental Divide.
The newcomers are producing a domino effect. Some long-time ranching families are selling scenic ranches at premium prices, then taking their profits and buying much bigger spreads in less scenic, less costly areas of the West.
For instance, Dr. Tom Carlson, a veterinarian and rancher, sold his 600-acre horse ranch in Shell at the base of red cliffs in Wyoming's Big Horn Mountains. He then acquired 16,000 acres in the high plains near Medicine Bow and had money left over.
The domino phenomenon is driving up prices in even the cheaper areas, said Blair Newman, a ranch broker with Frontier Realty in Torrington, Wyo.
None of this is typical in ranch country. Usually ranchers sell to their children, or their neighbors. Bill Cheney bought his 11,000-acre ranch near Casper, Wyo., from his mother in 1973. He is now selling the ranch to his son, Bob. In both sales, the older generation gave the new one a price break, said Mr. Cheney.
"You have to sell the ranch at a discount to your offspring in order for them to be able to pay for it," he said.
By contrast, Mr. Marble and other newcomers made their money in other fields and they have little difficulty financing their acquisitions, or buying them outright.
Some of the new arrivals view their new holdings as an investment. They hope to make money off both cattle sales and the long-term appreciation in land prices. Others, such as Mr. Marble, say they are buying a new way of life.
Mr. Marble spent weeks traveling through Wyoming on high school vacations, passing ranches that were miles away from one another. "That's what really stood out -- the openness of it," he said. "Out of the blue I got this crazy notion that I wanted to buy a ranch. I had never been on a horse."
He runs the ranch by himself, without hired hands, and takes pride in the black Angus cattle he raises. He lives alone in a log cabin built not long after the Red Bluff was homesteaded in 1884. The home lies at about 6,000 feet.
From the ranch's highest point, at about 7,000 feet, Mr. Marble can see the Wind River range to the west and the foothills of the Big Horn Mountains 100 miles to the north. His companions are his livestock, two dogs and the deer, elk, antelope and rattlesnakes that abound in the area.
Mr. Marbles said he welcomed isolation. "It's not for everyone. You've got to be of that mindset. I love people, but I kind of like knowing that they're on the other side of the hill."
THE ranching business appeals to his preference for hard labor. In Newport Beach, Mr. Marble donned a wet suit each day and spent eight hours underwater cleaning the bottoms of pleasure boats. "You were soaking wet all day long. Visibility was about two feet. It was very demanding."
Mr. Marble bought the ranch in 1986, but leased his range land to other ranchers for the next six years while he continued to run his California business. Income from the boat service generated funds for ranch improvements, and a cash cushion he would need for his new vocation.
"It's like any new business -- you had better have cash reserves," he said. "It takes a year to prime the pipeline. It's a year before you have any calves to sell."
Since his arrival, he has made the transition from native Californian to high plains rancher. Foreign cars gave way to a beat-up 1983 Ford pickup, and he has been elected secretary-treasurer of the Fremont County Cattlemen's Association.
He still has much to learn. "I've bought cows [at auction] an established rancher wouldn't look at. It's very difficult to develop an eye for cattle."
Then, there are long days of herding cattle, repairing fence lines and maintaining ranch equipment and buildings. The toughest hurdles, though, are cyclical downturns in cattle prices and the devasting whims of Nature.
Last year Mr. Marble encountered both. The extended Western drought withered grasslands. With less to eat, calves bound for market weighed roughly 50 pounds less than those the year before. Then, fall calf prices plunged 17 percent, the worst year-to-year drop in 21 years. The combination cost ranchers well over $100 for each calf sold -- more than a quarter of their gross income.
"I knew the downside, but it's still a bit of a shock when you work all year for nothing," he said. "A lot of ranchers did that last year, and they'll do that for a couple of years more. The cattle numbers are too high and when they're too high something has to break, and that's the price."
MR. MARBLE looked at some 25 ranches before he settled on the Red Bluff. Though he got the asking price down roughly $100,000, he worries that $225,000 he paid for the ranch may have been too high for the economics of running cattle.
He would like to buy more land and run bigger herds. But rising prices in the Wind River region make that impossible for now, though high prices have some advantages. Mr. Marble estimates his ranch's value has doubled since he bought it.
But Mr. Marble said he wasn't in it to make money on real estate. He wants to be a rancher, and he said he was prepared to take a second job -- as many other ranchers do -- if he needs to. He's learning how to shoe horses, a job that is always likely to have customers in the West.
The ranching business "used to be easier, but not anymore," he said.
"The margins are too tight," he explained. "Forty years ago a family could survive on a ranch this size."
Mr. Marble, who is single, doesn't have to feed a family from the Red Bluff's cash flow. His only concern is to make the ranch succeed.
"I have nothing to lose," he said. "I don't have a family. If I lose it all, I'd start over again."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Crowd-Pleaser With a Mission

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: SOMERSET

 BODY:
ON a recent Sunday morning at the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens here, the Rev. DeForest Soaries Jr. stepped to the pulpit, looked out at one of the largest black congregations in New Jersey and announced that he had an important story to tell.
There was an incident the week before in Franklin Township, he said, involving white police officers and a black youth with a gun. The youth had been firing into people's windows. When a 27-year-old rookie officer approached him, the young man pointed a 9-millimeter handgun at the officer's head. The rookie and his partner wrestled the gun away and arrested him. 
 Just another police story? No, the minister said.
"You didn't hear about this because the officer didn't shoot," said Mr. Soaries, who then introduced the officer, his partner and several of his colleagues to the applauding crowd of 1,500. "We salute you for your courage. We believe in what's right. We'll fight you to the death if you mess with us, but we'll stand by you to the end if you do what's right.
"Lord," he continued, "we thank you for your grace that has spared our community pain at a time when tensions are high between blacks and whites. You raised up these two police officers who dared to use courage rather than power."
In its mix of showmanship and sincerity, it was a vintage performance by "Buster" Soaries -- a very public man who says it is his goal to improve the lot of the people who populate the tough Route 27 corridor that his ministry serves.
When the 43-year-old Mr. Mr. Soaries (pronounced SOR-ease) talks about his work and his mission, he speaks of a ministry with a hand in economic development, education, politics and, of course, religion. When his admirerers talk about him, they use words like dynamic and trustworthy, visionary and innovator.
"He is extremely bright and articulate, and his views are always thoughtful and well expressed," said Peter Verniero, who, as chief of staff for Governor Whitman, has consulted with Mr. Soaries, a political independent, from time to time. "He will tell you what he thinks is right rather than what he thinks you want to hear."
Local newspapers have called Mr. Soaries an unabashed self-promoter whose ego matches his desire to help people. And Mr. Soaries doesn't disagree.
"I'm not bashful or shy of my intent to make my voice known," he said in an interview at his church office, which is filled with books and awards. "We can send the message that there is something else happening besides complaining and anger and conflict. There is some good news."
Drive by the church, and you might mistake it for a white-brick schoolhouse in an open suburban setting. But a closer look reveals a church not far from neighborhoods where teen-age pregnancy, crime and drug abuse are common. As Mr. Soaries puts it, the church faces "the challenges of urban life without the environment of urban life."
The First Baptist Church was founded in the 1930's and has always been an important institution here. Under the direction of Mr. Soaries, who has been pastor since November 1990, the congregation has grown from 1,500 to 3,700 members. On a recent Sunday, the 11 A. M. service -- the third and last of the day -- was so packed that the overflow crowd watched the proceedings on a big-screen TV in the basement.
AWAY from the church, Mr. Soaries is a very busy man, overseeing the building of a nascent empire. In the pulpit, he touches on subjects like economic empowerment, educational challenges and spiritual growth, and, he says, these are the cornerstones of all his plans.
He is chairman of the First Baptist Community Development Corporation, a non-profit organization that is working with the state and local businesses to rebuild an 880-acre area near the southwest border of New Brunswick. Under a program called Renaissance 2000 that is being underwritten largely by corporate and community grants, the organization hopes to establish new low- and moderate-income housing, small businesses, primary-care health services, job training, day care, a credit union and a loan program. Youth development programs focusing on counseling and teen-age pregnancy prevention would be also be included. So would a new $4 million church complex (with seats for 2,000), scheduled to break ground this summer behind the existing church. Much of the cost will come from the congregation.
Mr. Soaries has also started a report card collection program at the church that assigns tutors to students who do not maintain a B average. He is the author of "My Family is Driving Me Crazy," a book geared to help adolescents deal with family issues. And he has produced three videos encouraging teen-agers to practice sexual abstinence.
"There are many churches in depressed neighborhoods, yet those churches often exist in spite of the neighborhood's needs," he said. "Our church has got to be more than simply a place where people pray."
Mr. Soaries says he is also preparing to start a Christian music record label, Proclaim Records. He is a member of the New Era Bank board of directors and chairman of the board of directors of the Boys and Girls Club of Newark. And writes a column for The Home News of New Brunswick.
"He writes about a variety of things and he's a pretty good writer," said Barbara Frankel, director of the newspaper's editorial pages. "He seems genuinely concerned about helping people not only in his church but in the community. I think he's very well-regarded in education and community circles."
This was not the line of work Mr. Soaries had intended for himself when he was growing up in Montclair, where his father was pastor of a small church. He aspired to be a professional baseball player.
When those dreams faded ("I was too short," he says) he became politically active, working with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Operation PUSH organization from 1973 until 1976.
He turned toward religion in the mid-1970's after his father died suddenly at age 48. "I felt that religious understanding was the most fundamental need that humans had," he said.
He received a bachelor of arts in religious studies from Fordham University in 1986, a master of divinity from Princeton Theological Seminary in 1989, and a doctor of ministry degree from United Theological Seminary in Dayton, Ohio, in 1992.
But political activism continues to be the hallmark of his ministry. In 1991, he led a coalition of black moderates and conservatives who declared their support for Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court. Two years later, he was often quoted in papers and television broadcasts denying claims made by Ed Rollins, Mrs. Whitman's political strategist, that black ministers had been paid off to suppress the black vote during the 1993 election, in which Mrs. Whitman became Governor. Mr. Rollins later retracted the claims.
"He asked me to pray for him," Mr. Soaries said about Mr. Rollins at the time. "I said I'd pray for his soul, but in the meantime I have to do something about his mouth."
These days, Mr. Soaries says he is questioned several times each week about whether he himself would consider running for office. Some people think he's up to the task.
"Buster possesses great integrity, a great intellectualism," said the Rev. Donald Hilliard, senior pastor of the Second Baptist Church Cathedral in Perth Amboy. "I feel that he has the guts for politics. I think he possesses great political and business savvy. I think he has the makings of a great visionary politician that will lift us to greater heights."
But Mr. Soaries says no.
"The last thing I'd want to do is run for office," he said, adding that he would prefer to concentrate on pursuing his various interests and spending more time with his wife, Donna, and their twin sons, Malcolm and Martin, named after Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
Not everyone agrees with his approach.
"One fellow said to me, 'If you spent less time trying to help the community, you'd be a better pastor.'
"But people can't just send their souls to church. They have to their bodies -- and sometimes those bodies are hungry and without jobs. We must do something for mind, body and soul, because religion should be meaningful to all three."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Rev. Deforest Soaries, preaching at his church in Somerset: "I'm not bashful or shy of my intent to make my voice known." (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)
 
Graphs: "Faith, by the Numbers" shows results of a poll conducted regarding the importance of religion.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
A Legal Battle Is Bubbling Over Fat-Free Cheese Patent

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD

 BODY:
Call him a dreamer, but Carl Wolf envisions a day when Americans will find rich foods downright unappealing.
As low-fat sweets, meats and dairy products flood supermarket shelves, he says, palates will evolve. That is why Mr. Wolf, the chief executive of Alpine Lace Brands here, has engaged in a battle to protect his recipe for fat-free cheese. 
 On March 7, Alpine Lace won apatent for its intricate process of making several kinds of no-fat cheeses. That same day, Mr. Wolf sued his much larger competitors -- Borden, Healthy Choice, Kraft and Schreiber Foods -- charging patent infringement.
"We spent a lot of money developing the technology for this product," he said. "Now we would like an economic reward."
Over the years, Mr. Wolf said, he has spent about $14 million in a quest for the perfect fat-free cheese. In 1990, he bought the rights for a specific recipe from a Wisconsin dairy scientist, Aly Gamay. Almost immediately, he applied for a patent to protect it.
But in the meantime, larger companies introduced their own healthful cheeses and began to dominate the market. Through "reverse engineering," Alpine Lace determined that certain parts of the rival companies' formulas violate its patent, Mr. Wolf said.
None of the companies sued would comment, except to say that they were reviewing the suit and the allegations.
"It was out of the blue," said Walt Casey, vice president of corporate communications for Conagra Inc., which makes the Healthy Choice brand. "We're studying all the information and trying to come to some conclusion."
For Alpine Lace, which has annual sales of about $132 million and represents a tiny fraction of the $6 billion cheese market, the suit could bring substantial profits. Mr. Wolf is hoping for unspecified damages and royalties from the four companies. If he wins, Alpine Lace could collect annual royalty payments of $3 million to $8 million from each.
Meantime, the company is reaping the benefits of publicity. Since it received the patent, its stock price has increased by more than 80 percent.
Mr. Wolf and his wife, Marion, started their cheese company in 1983 and have been focusing on low-fat products ever since. Alpine Lace products are manufactured in Illinois and Wisconsin, but about 40 employees work at the company headquarters in Maplewood, where all the accounting and marketing are done. The office also has a test kitchen, with industrial-size refrigerator, cheese slicer and toaster oven.
"We were one of the first to see an opportunity for this business in the early 80's," said Mr. Wolf, who grew up in Newark and now lives in South Orange. "It took a lot of work to make the product taste right and get the public interested, but now the time is right."
The Alpine Lace fat-free product line includes American slices, Parmesan and cream cheese. A trim 51-year-old, Mr. Wolf has the peculiar ability to make his products sound succulent.
"Last night after my tennis game, I ate a bagel with our low-sodium Muenster," he said. "If you want something more filling, our fat-free garlic and herb cream cheese can be mixed with fettuccine for a terrific fettuccine Alfredo."
The market for low-fat and fat-free cheeses is indeed growing, even if at first bite they might have been less than toothsome. Early low-fat cheeses tended to have a waxy consistency and would not melt well, Mr. Wolf said, but now they are tastier.
Mr. Wolf said that as baby boomers age, they are driving a national trend toward healthier, low-fat diets. Just as thousands of Americans have converted to diet cola and skim milk, he said, they will soon prefer fat-free cheese.
But if older Americans are filling their grocery carts with guilt-free treats, he said, teen-agers and people in their 20's are hesitating. To lure them away from Twinkies and Big Macs, Alpine Lace has hired a new spokeswoman: the model Kim Alexis. "She's young, she's healthy," Mr. Wolf said with an explanatory shrug. "And she loves her cheeses."

HEADLINE: ON CAMPUS;
Modest Rise in Tuition at State Colleges, With an Exception

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
In a departure from the dramatic increases of several years ago, most of New Jersey's state colleges will not raise tuition significantly next fall. An exception is Kean College in Union, where tuition will increase by almost 10 percent because of declining enrollment and stagnant state aid.
An improved economy is the main reason state college tuitions have stabilized in recent years, said Darryl G. Greer, executive director of the New Jersey State College Governing Boards Association, an advisory board to the colleges. Another major factor, he said, is that the state is now paying for costly salary increases negotiated with the unions for faculty and staff members. Tuition increases that sometimes rose above 10 percent in 1990 and 1991 were partly due to those increases. 
 "All of the unionized personnel received huge pay raises, but the state did not fund them," Mr. Greer said. "So the colleges bore the entire burden of that expense."
Although Governor Whitman recommended in 1994 that state college tuitions should not rise by more than 3.5 percent, she has not imposed an official cap. Tuition will rise by an average of about $125, or 5 percent -- a sharp drop from the 1990-91 average, 14 percent.
Usually, tuition increases do not differ significantly from one state college to the next. There have been exceptions: in the 1992-93 school year, Trenton State raised its tuition by 19.3 percent while the other schools hovered in the 4 percent range. That year, Trenton State added a $500 surcharge to its tuition to help offset higher salaries.
Even with an impending increase of 9.73 percent, or $203 per student, Kean College will still have the lowest tuition of all the four-year state campuses, at $2,288. Patricia Molden, the spokeswoman at Kean, said that without the increase, the college would have a deficit of $1.25 million. Besides covering the deficit, the increase will help underwrite several projects, including a library renovation.
Since the State Department of Higher Education was abolished last year, public colleges are required to conduct public hearings before their trustees vote on tuition increases. But officials at several state colleges said that so far, only a handful of students had attended.
"There seems to be hardly a whimper out there," Mr. Greer said.
At Kean last week, several students interviewed were not even aware of the increase. David G. Brown 2d, a Kean student who is president of the campus group that represents full-time students, said few people had voiced objections.
"We never, ever want an increase, but the fact is we are the most underfunded state college," Mr. Brown said. "The increase is definitely a big hit on us, but we since we are demanding improvements, we pretty much have to support it."
If tuition costs have stabilized somewhat, fees have not. To cover the cost of student clubs, athletics and other extracurricular activities, state college fees have risen by as much as 23 percent in recent years. This year, for example, the fees at Kean will increase by 9.9 percent, or $139, to help cover the operating costs of a new student center. And at Rowan College in Glassboro, students will pay $282 more to cover items like a new recreational complex and computer upkeep.
"There seems to be a lot of apathy on campus," Jason Levin, president of Rowan's student government, said of the fees. "People just don't realize they can affect the outcome of a tuition increase."
Mr. Greer, of the state college advisory board, said tuition increases would continue to depend on state financing, which is not keeping pace with inflation. Next year, the colleges will receive an average state-aid increase of less than 1 percent. He stressed that tuition covers only about a third of the cost of a state college education, which is about $10,000 per student.
Even though it has the second-highest enrollment of all the state colleges, Kean receives the least state aid. Next year, the average amount of state aid per student will be $5,100; Kean is scheduled to receive $4,053 per student. Enrollment has little to do with the amount of aid a school gets, Mr. Greer said.
This month, Kean will graduate one of its largest senior classes ever, a result of peak enrollment several years ago when the economy was unstable and more people were either returning to school or staying within the state for college. The projected enrollment for freshmen next year is not enough to make up for the loss of more than 2,000 seniors, Ms. Molden said. About 11,000 students are enrolled now.
"If a higher tuition means we can put more money into attracting students, that's fine with me," said Mr. Brown, the Kean student. "The more people we can get, the lighter our tuition burden in the long run."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
From Japan, Wall St. Looks Down Hill

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE American stock market rose to record highs last week -- at least if you measure it in dollars. But viewed from Tokyo, this market looks very different.
Measured in yen, the Standard & Poor's 500 fell to its lowest level in more than four years in April. Even with last week's surge in stock price, which coincided with a strengthening dollar, the index, measured in yen, is only 17 percent above the low hit in the 1990 recession. In dollars, the index is up 76 percent since then.
A chart-reader would immediately see a triple-top in the S.& P. yen chart. The American market peaked on June 12, 1990, challenged that high but fell short in April 1992 and then did it again in February 1993. It is now 23 percent below the peak. 
 Those statistics help explain why some foreigners are dismayed by dollar-based investments, but they also explain the increasing talk of foreign takeovers. In yen, American stocks look like bargains.
The accompanying chart shows the S.& P. 500 in dollars and yen since the end of 1969, when the index stood at 92.06. At its high close last week, the S.& P. was at 520.54, a gain of 465 percent. But over the same period the dollar has fallen from almost 360 yen, to about 84 yen. Measured in yen, the S.& P. has risen just 91 percent over more than a quarter of a century.
Those figures do not include dividends, and so understate total returns. An American investor who bought the S.& P. 500 at the end of 1969, reinvested all dividends and somehow avoided paying taxes throughout the period, would have earned a compound annual return, through the end of April, of 11.2 percent, with an inital investment of $100 growing to almost $1,500. But a Japanese investor would have seen an initial investment of 100 yen grow to 349 yen, a compound annual return of just 5.1 percent.
 FLOYD NORRIS

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Why Does the Market Keep Going Up . . . When Economic Trends Are Pointing Down

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
AMERICA'S trade deficit is as big as the gross national product of Switzerland. Ten dollars hardly buys a cappuccino in Tokyo. And President Clinton is telling Newt Gingrich that the ballooning budget deficit is now a Republican problem. Yet the stock market just keeps flying upward, and bond prices have recovered smartly from last summer's doldrums. Go figure.
Actually, the figuring is not so hard. While there is a gap between the apparent state of the United States economy and the markets that are supposed to be its barometer, economists are having no trouble coming up with theories to explain the paradox. What is hard is discerning the diamonds among the cubic zirconiums -- to make sense from sometimes overlapping, sometimes inconsistent views of what has put the wow in the Dow. Here are a few interesting ones.
 
Good News and Bad News
 No indicator of American economic decline stands out like the fallen dollar. Where just months ago commentators were aghast at the prospect that the greenback might slip below 100 Japanese yen, they are now wondering whether it will ever again see the light above 85 yen. Indeed, if the dollar hadn't fallen 15 percent against the yen since Dec. 1, hardly anyone would be puzzled why the Dow Jones industrial average had risen 16 percent in the same period. 
 And if it seems odd that the prices of securities are rising, even as the currency in which they are denominated is falling, that is because it is odd. M.B.A.'s bearing spreadsheets are puzzled, too. After all, if foreigners expect the dollar to keep falling, one would expect them to insist on higher returns.
But Richard Cooper, a Harvard economist and a former adviser to President Jimmy Carter, offers a plausible explanation. While some money managers have undoubtedly sold bonds and stocks to get out of dollars, he suggests that the extent of the globalization of capital markets has been exaggerated: Most dollar-denominated assets are still owned by people and institutions who count their wins and losses in dollars alone. "When all is said and done," Mr. Cooper argued, "the American securities markets are still domestic markets."
From this perspective, the depreciated dollar should increase the value of United States stocks because it increases the profits of American corporations abroad. The companies with Japanese and European subsidiaries benefit directly from the rising yen and German mark because the same level of earnings translates into more dollars in the earnings report. But the biggest winners are American companies that export -- or compete against imports. Detroit, for example, is now in the enviable position of being able to raise prices without fear that Japanese auto makers will be able to make further inroads into their home market.
When both the windfall earnings and the increased competitiveness are taken into account, concluded Paul Krugman, an economist at Stanford University, "there just isn't much left to explain."
 
Good News and Good News
 In the 1960's and 70's, inflation was seen as the Godzilla of economic problems. Each boom in the business cycle brought a frightening spike in prices, as the costs of raw commodities rose along with wages in response to increased demand. But prices -- especially the price of labor -- proved sticky: wage-driven inflation did not disappear as the economy cooled off. Indeed, the economy seemed cursed with an ever-accumulating residue of inflation as it entered each fresh economic recovery.
But the monster has retreated. Inflation fell more rapidly than predicted in the recession of 1980-82, and never rose much when the economy expanded for most of the rest of the decade. More surprising yet, the red-hot growth over the last year, which pushed unemployment to the lowest level since 1989, has seemed to have little impact on wages.
Perhaps most important, the Federal Reserve's determination last year to raise interest rates in the face of uncertain economic growth apparently convinced money managers that Washington's tolerance for inflation was near an all-time low. Better yet, when the Fed acted, it acted with finesse, steering the economy toward that magic place between inflation and recession known as the soft landing. "Everything is going right from the point of view of a long expansion," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
News of victory on the inflation front perks up bond prices for obvious reasons. Bonds are obligations to pay a fixed amount of interest each year. The lower the rate of inflation, the higher the purchasing power of future interest payments and the higher the value of the principal returned when the bond matures.
Thus, the market's relief that the new year did not ring in inflation helps explain the boom in bonds. But why would expectations of price stability add sizzle to stocks?
There is plenty of evidence for a strong relationship between stable prices and rising stock prices. "The stock market detests inflation," said Robert Lawrence, an economist at Harvard.
On the other hand, economic theory offers no straightforward explanation. Indeed, older textbooks suggest that investors in stocks should be indifferent to inflation because stocks represent claims on corporate earnings that rise with prices. One possibility, of course, is that investors' attitudes are colored by prejudices about unstable prices: Franco Modigliani, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, suggests that stockholders just don't get it -- they don't understand that inflation won't hurt them.
The more widely accepted view these days gives investors more credit. That's because they know about monetary policy and taxes. The worse inflation gets, says James Tobin of Yale University, the less likely that the economy will escape a recession once the Fed clamps down on credit. And because recessions cut corporate profits, inflation is the enemy of stockholders.
A more elegant argument is that investors, unlike economists, read the fine print in the tax laws. Because corporate depreciation schedules are not indexed to inflation, higher inflation rates mean higher effective rates of taxation on profits.
Whatever the reason, said Robert Shiller, an economist at Yale and a specialist in the psychological underpinnings of economic choice, it is no longer in dispute that "the markets hate inflation." Because of this consensus, the success of the economy in weathering another peak in the business cycle without significant inflation is a plausible explanation for the bull market of 1995.
 
Hollowing Out
 Since the mid-1970's, the rich have become richer, the poor have become poorer and middle-class families have managed to hold their own only by working longer hours. Just why is still a matter of dispute: Explanations put varying weights on technological change, international competition, immigration, de-unionization and education.
What is hardly in dispute is Washington's failure to hold back the tide of redistribution with tax and spending policies. Indeed, changes in Federal tax laws in the 1980's favored high-income Americans at the expense of those in the middle.
Thus one explanation of the stock market boom that followed the 1994 election is that the income-distribution revolution of the Reagan years had been confirmed. Indeed, Congressional Republicans are pledged to cut the tax on capital gains. And most of the conservative flat-tax proposals would reduce tax rates on dividend and interest income, raising the after-tax return on capital.
A more tortuous link between higher securities prices and widening income inequality involves the fact that human skills are worth more than ever. Wages for unskilled workers and earnings on investments on physical capital apparently have not changed much in recent decades. What has changed is the reward for white-collar skills.
Much of this change has been captured by individuals in the forms of higher wages for specialized labor and profits in closely held businesses. But a portion is also being taken by corporations organized around human skills -- computer software companies, media conglomerates, investment banks and for-profit health care providers. The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, depended on profits from its computer reservation system to carry it through the long recession in the airline industry."Companies that are good at marshaling intellectual skills are doing very, very well," said Robert Hall, an economist at the Hoover Institution at Stanford.
Of course, knowledge-driven industries have been on the rise for many years. But it is striking how public awareness of their role has grown only in the last few. And it is at least plausible that bullish expectations for the knowledge industries are driving stock prices higher.
"The information sector," said Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University, "is half the economy."
 
Through a Glass, Darkly
 One way or another, most explanations for the current securities boom turn on expectations of higher profits -- and for good reason. Stock and bond prices are rooted in real-world prospects, and in the long run they reflect expected future income from securities adjusted for future interest rates. But the long run can be very long and the roots can be very loose.
Fischer Black, a pioneer in the mathematical modeling of securities prices, defined an efficient market as one in which prices are no less than half and no more than double the actual value. By that criterion, the run-up in both stock and bond prices since last November may be an accident, like the haphazard course of a tornado.
But why should the haphazard be so important? John Maynard Keynes, who among his many careers was a successful financial speculator, once likened securities investment to a contest in which the participants are asked to pick the six prettiest faces from a hundred photographs. The prize goes to the "investor" who most closely guesses the preferences of the other investors. Thus, while beauty -- here, akin to value -- acts as an anchor to choices, the process is riddled with the short-term consequences of second- , third- and fourth-guessing.
Mr. Keynes's analogy fits the Alice-in-Wonderland world that Mr. Shiller of Yale calls home to many investors. Mr. Shiller says rational stock players have no choice but to take the irrational very seriously.
"Symbols matter," he said,, "because they lead to self-fulfilling prophecies." Thus Mr. Shiller argues, for example, that breaking the 4,000 barrier on the Dow two months ago may explain subsequent gains.
Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard, agrees. "Explanations for why the stock market went up or down" she said, "belong on the funny pages."
