HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: AT THE GATE;
Eyeing a Veterinary Chain? Be Sure to Check the Teeth

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
INVESTORS are a soft touch for the pet business. As they scoop up shares of Petsmart, the superstore chain, or of Veterinary Centers of America, they often think fondly of their own cat or dog and don't fret overmuch about the economic fundamentals.
But these sentimental favorites -- Pet smart sells at a hefty 97 times trailing earnings and Veterinary Centers commands 124 -- are hardly bargains. And the latest member of the litter is no exception. 
 Pet Practice, a chain of veterinary clinics, is the creation of John H. Foster, a well-known venture capitalist who has taken four health care companies public since 1986. Typically, he targets a fragmented business like physical therapy and, by developing a network of facilities, achieves cost efficiencies unavailable to individual practitioners. Pet Practice, based in King of Prussia, Pa., approaches the structurally similar $7 billion veterinary care business the same way.
"The consolidation of the industry makes all the sense in the world," said Sheryl Skolnick, a health care analyst with Robertson Stephens. And animal health care is a lot simpler than the human variety. Investors don't have to worry about whether insurance companies will continue to pay for flea baths, financing for Medicare will be cut or political reformers will vote to change all the rules.
But shares of Pet Practice, which is to go public in June, are not as warm and fuzzy as they appear.
Although the company runs 55 clinics in eight states, it isn't making money. Last year the chain lost $1.5 million on sales of $36 million. That looks lackluster even against the modest profits of Veterinary Centers -- the only other publicly held company in the business -- which earned $589,000 on 1994 revenues of $42 million. (Petsmart has clinics in its stores, but they are leased to outside veterinarians.)
Pet Practice, which is less than two years old, "is at a much earlier stage of development," said Linda Killian of Renaissance Capital, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn. She thinks the company must expand geographically or into related fields, like pet food, if it is to succeed.
Despite the lack of a track record, Pet Practice shares are expected to be offered at between $13.50 and $16.50 -- roughly three times the company's sales per share, compared to Veterinary Centers, which sells for less than two times its per-share revenues. And Veterinary Centers isn't exactly cheap. Based on this year's estimated earnings of 40 cents a share, its stock has a lofty price-to-earnings ratio of 28.
Veterinary Centers has another leg up on its soon-to-be-public rival: it has expanded into related fields. The company bought several veterinary laboratories recently, and has entered into a joint venture with H. J. Heinz to produce specialty pet food. Also recently, Heinz invested $10 million in Veterinary Centers, raising its stake in the company to 27 percent.
Veterinary Centers doesn't have Mr. Foster and his proven track record behind it. While he is not personally involved in running Pet Practice, Mr. Foster does sit on its board. And its chairman, Stephen Nagy, is an executive vice president of Foster Management, the Philadelphia-based venture capital firm Mr. Foster founded and runs.
The Foster advantage can be big. While he refused to be interviewed about the pending deal, Mr. Foster's ability to reward investors, including himself, speaks for itself. Of the four ventures he has brought public, three have recorded sizable gains and the fourth, issued 11 months ago, is hovering around its offering price.
But there's a catch. Gains for two of those companies came in part from their takeover by Novacare, the rehabilitative services company Mr. Foster heads. No one thinks Novacare will buy Pet Practice.
And Mr. Foster's group, which will still own about half of Pet Practice after it goes public, plans to cash out some of its preferred stock and debt in the deal. That payment will eat up nearly a third of the $53 million Pet Practice wants to raise, while another $16 million or so will go to pay the company's other lenders, U.S. Trust and PNC Bank. After fees -- including a $500,000 payment to Foster Management for its help with the offering -- only $16 million will be left to open new outlets or finance growth.
So, investors in Pet Practice may be chasing the wrong tail. Then again, when people willingly pay $700 for a CAT scan for their cat or more than $1,000 a year for chemotherapy for their dog, it may be hard not to get excited about the investment possibilities.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
New Generation on Restaurant Suppliers Row

SERIES: SHOPTALK: An occasional look at commercial districts around New York

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
When Peter Chang, a 43-year-old native of Hong Kong, opened his store at 103-105 Bowery 12 years ago, there were just two other Asians in the restaurant supply business on the street. But when Mr. Chang walks along the Bowery today, he sees more than a dozen Asian restaurant suppliers.
He's not happy about it. The competition has caused Mr. Chang's profits to dwindle. "The profit is bad, very bad," said Mr. Chang, owner of Bowery Restaurant Supplies, a cluttered store between Grand and Hester Streets that offers everything from bamboo steamers to meat grinders. 
 The Bowery has long been home to the city's largest concentration of restaurant suppliers. Along a seven-block stretch from Hester to Houston Streets, there are roughly 30 businesses that keep most of the city's 22,000 restaurants stocked with 80-quart pots and six-burner ranges.
For years, the industry was overwhelmingly dominated by Jews and Italians, attracted in the early part of the century by low rents on a rundown street peopled by vagrants -- a source of cheap labor. "People would come by and ask to load and unload trucks or sweep up the floor," said Sheldon Lewis, 62, the owner of Empire Restaurant Supply, founded in 1923 by his father-in-law, Sam Mesirowsky.
But as Chinatown stretched north in the late 80's, ownership increasingly switched to Asians, many of them wealthy Hong Kong emigres fleeing the island before it reverts to Chinese control in 1997.
Not all the newcomers became suppliers. On Mr. Chang's block, where every storefront once housed a supplier, stand a Chinese restaurant, a nail salon, a greengrocer and a fish and meat market. Mr. Chang is the only supplier on his side of the block.
Mr. Chang estimates that 40 percent of suppliers in the area are Asian immigrants, 30 percent from Hong Kong and China and 10 percent from Korea. But Fred LaMay, 66, co-owner of King Glassware, at 112 Bowery, puts the number much higher. "I'd say 60 percent are Asian," he said, adding that there are 30 percent more restaurant suppliers than there were 10 or 15 years ago.
Wealthy Hong Kong natives have bought out many members of the old guard by offering astronomical prices for their buildings. Mr. LaMay said several people had come into his store, making enticing bids for his building. "We tell them we're not interested," he said. "We'll sell when we retire."
Mr. Lewis, who runs Empire at 114 Bowery with his sons, Craig, 39, and Jeffrey, 36, has also been offered large sums. "A guy across the street sold his building for 30 percent more than its market value," he said. The Lewises say that as 1997 nears, they expect prices to go even higher, and then they will entertain bids. Besides, they say, right now business is pretty good.
It wasn't always so. The 80's recession walloped many suppliers. "Every year since then, it's gotten a little better," said Mr. LaMay. But business is still not as good as it was in the early 80's when there were fewer suppliers doing more business.
Mr. Lewis said despite the many Asians in the business, he is able to attract Asian customers. And Mr. Chang estimated that 25 percent of his customers are non-Asian.
Language differences are sometimes a problem, but not impossible to bridge. A while back, a Chinese customer walked into Empire, and when Mr. Lewis asked him if he needed help, he tugged on his belt. "He wanted a belt for a mixer," Mr. Lewis said. "I finally figured it out. Sometimes they'll point to their eye, which means that they're just looking around." M.W.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ALPHABET CITY;
Anarchist Picnic: Pig and Pot (Dress: Casual)

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
It was 4 P.M. on a cool, overcast day. A multiethnic, multiracial cluster of 25 New Yorkers sat on stone pilings in La Plaza Cultural, a lot on the corner of Ninth Street and Avenue C. Their clothes were tattered and grimy. Most were squatters or homeless; they looked anywhere from 20 to 50 years old. Their long hair was straight and greasy, or multicolored, spiked or in dandruff-flecked dreadlocks. Some sported nose, lip and eyebrow rings.
With a few unwashed pocket knives, they carved up half of a roast pig, eating it with dirt-encrusted hands. They guzzled Midnight Dragon beer (straight from 40-ounce bottles). They smoked a lot of marijuana (in joints bigger than the average cigarette). And they shared their feast (just the pig, not the beer and marijuana) with a Rottweiler, a German shepherd and two pit bulls. 
 So it went at the second annual May Day "pig roast," an anarchist celebration with the look and feel of a pagan ritual. The daylong picnic was organized by a local squatter who goes by the name Jerry the Peddler.
"May Day was originally an anarchist holiday," said Jerry, a graying, blue-eyed Ninth Street resident who writes for a local underground newspaper, The Shadow, under the byline J. T. Peddler. "The Communists stole it and turned it into a workers' holiday."
And the significance of the pig (purchased for $170 from the Happy Joy restaurant in Chinatown)? "The pig symbolizes dead cops," one celebrant, Jerry Levy, 41, said with a broad grin. An adjunct professor in the social science department of La Guardia Community College, Mr. Levy, who appeared to be more interested in personal hygiene than most of his company, groused about what he termed "the police occupation of the neighborhood," specifically the authorities' response to the Tompkins Square Park unrest in 1989 and their more recent crackdown on Avenue C peddlers, which has pushed the vendors into La Plaza on Sundays.
Despite Mr. Levy's polemics, the group was mild mannered enough -- that is, until a photographer for The New York Times attempted to capture the event on film. The picnickers chased him, and then another photographer, away, before allowing a few snaps.
"It's a privacy issue," said Stanley Sydorowitz, 44, an unemployed pit-bull trainer who wore an army fatigue jacket and black jeans hardened with dirt. "They just can't come in and start taking pictures. When you're poor, your privacy is all you have left."
But they said they had nothing personal against the paper: in fact, many said they were faithful readers.
"Did you see the piece in the Sunday Times magazine about marijuana?" someone asked, referring to a cover article, "How Pot Has Grown," which appeared on Feb. 19. "That was great."
Much of the talk centered on drugs. One man went on about the virtues of exotic rolling paper for several minutes, as marijuana smoke filled the air.
A block east, police thronged Tompkins Square Park, the site of another May Day celebration replete with punk rock bands and rappers. It was organized by squatters on 13th Street, who are fighting eviction from the city.
"We're not in opposition to that group," said Jerry the Peddler. "It's just that I have a bad ear and I needed an alternative."
Jerry admitted that this year's pig roast was poorly attended. Last May Day, 200 people flocked to the event.
"Last year, we advertised with fliers," Jerry said. Next year, he promised a bigger celebration. "We're going to have three pigs," he said. "One for Giuliani, one for Pataki and one for Clinton."
 MONTE WILLIAMS

GRAPHIC: Photo: It was a May Day to remember, thanks to Jerry the Peddler (and Chinese takeout). (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The World: Power Grab;
Ground Rules For the Great

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
NO less a social philosopher than Wilt Chamberlain, in the days when he literally stood head and shoulders above everyone else on the basketball court, put the matter succinctly: "No man roots for Goliath."
 In business, as in sports, giants often attract not only resentment and envy, but they also find themselves accused of competing unfairly. And those crying foul often call for change in the rules. The designated Goliath of the technological world is the Microsoft Corporation, a 20-year-old company cofounded by a Harvard dropout named Bill Gates, who has become the richest man in America, both feared and admired. 
 Ten days ago, the Justice Department took its latest step in trying to curb Microsoft's relentless advance in computer software by suing to block its $2 billion purchase of Intuit, whose Quicken financial software is in 7 million American homes. The Government challenge can be seen narrowly as a garden-variety antitrust case, which contends that the merger would reduce competition in the market for personal-finance software. But the real worry -- shared by Government antitrust officials, Microsoft's rivals and some economists -- is that Intuit could give Microsoft a sizable lead in the emerging markets for home banking and electronic commerce, which have the potential to make billions of dollars. Microsoft, they point out, has already used its dominance of personal-computer operating systems with Windows to establish leading positions in word processing and spread sheets.
 Later this year, the Microsoft juggernaut plans to move into the fast-growing market for on-line computer networks, all of which are frontiers of the information highway. The fear is that Microsoft could end up hogging the road, at the very least collecting tolls for access and supplying many of the services over it, like home banking and electronic publishing.

 
 
<SC0>Fish or Cut Bait
 The Microsoft case is an important test for the Government, and its effects could be felt for years. It will help set the ground rules for competition in the information age.
 The stakes are especially high because the industries involving information technology are an engine of growth for the American economy and a huge supplier of well-paid jobs for American workers. The Government must carefully tailor any actions it may take, because a clumsy but well-intentioned effort could squelch innovation. The outcome could also mean higher prices and fewer choices for consumers.
 Everyone agrees that the economic principles that apply to the old smokestack industries do not apply to high-tech industries. But the debate focuses on what the new terms of trade in these industries mean for Government antitrust policy: Do they argue for a hands-off approach, or an enforcement that is guided by an enlightened view of how these markets work?
 "In these new markets, we're seeing a new kind of competition," said William F. Baxter, a professor at the Stanford University law school, who was chief of the antitrust division at the Justice Department from 1981 to 1983. "It presents a new problem for Government, and we're going to see it again and again."
 Economists and antitrust experts traditionally viewed competition in terms of prices and output. The assumption was that as the number of companies making a product declined, output would be restricted, prices increased and consumers left worse off. "Perfect" competition is a market where producers are plentiful and none can influence prices.
 In the world of computer software and microchips, markets are often guided by different rules, which can result in a near-monopoly position for the winner. For example, a company gains an enormous advantage if it can grab an early leadership position: It can dictate the standard for the industry. Microsoft and the Intel Corporation did exactly that when I.B.M. entered the personal computer business in 1981. Big Blue engaged Microsoft to supply the operating system software, which gives a computer its basic running instructions, and Intel to supply the microchip, the processing "brain" of a PC.
 Though many companies besides I.B.M. now make PC's, the I.B.M.-compatible machine dominates nearly 90 percent of the market, with Apple's Macintosh accounting for most of the rest. No one has yet been able to unseat Microsoft and Intel as the standard bearers in the industry. Their profits let them invest in the creation of succeeding generations of software and chips.
 Microsoft's Windows is the market winner, and has become the lingua franca of personal computing for millions worldwide. Yet many experts argue that Apple's Macintosh operating system is easier to use, even superior to Microsoft's. Today, though, new software applications are designed primarily to run on Windows.
 "In high-tech markets where standards are important, the big get bigger," explained Charles F. Rule, a partner at Covington and Burling, a law firm in Washington, who was head of the antitrust division at the Justice Department from 1986 to 1989. "That's how these markets work, and there's nothing necessarily wrong with it."
 Economists call this a "bandwagon" effect. "And in the last five years," said W. Brian Arthur, a professor of economics at Stanford, "the bandwagon has really been rolling from Redmond, Washington," where the Gates empire is ensconced. Size and success should not be penalized, he says. Yet he and an economist at the Stanford business school, Garth Saloner, have helped supply the intellectual ammunition for Government intervention to restrain Microsoft.

 
 
A Trojan Horse
 Mr. Arthur argues that Microsoft has used its clout to gain great advantage in applications like word processing (Microsoft Word) and spreadsheets (Microsoft Excel). Bundled with Microsoft 95, due in August, is the company's on-line service, Microsoft Network, which will almost instantly be on millions of more computers than rivals like America Online, Compuserve and Prodigy. If Microsoft acquires Intuit, it would have a major head start in electronic banking, he says.
 The Government, Mr. Arthur contends, should intervene to make sure that a company's control of one market does not give it a major edge in new high-tech markets -- to prevent one runner in a 100-yard dash starting at the 40-yard mark. In his view, that could mean blocking the Intuit merger to preserve competition in home banking and in on-line services making Microsoft Network have an arms-length relationship with Microsoft's Windows.
 The opponents of such intervention in the brave new frontiers of high-tech markets say the case for Washington stepping in is unproven, and criticize its surgical tools as blunt and risky. "We may not always like the results of market forces," said Mr. Rule, the Washington lawyer and former antitrust chief, "but I think the real danger here is having the Government try to direct and fine-tune the innovative process."

 
 
A Swift State of the Art
 Besides, says Jerry Hausman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, there is no evidence that Microsoft's dominant role in computer software or its purchase of Intuit would harm consumers. "If you restrain Microsoft, it is clear that it would help its competitors," Mr. Hausman said. "But even if Microsoft has a natural advantage in new markets, that is only bad if it uses its power to jack up prices. And that's a lot easier to do in old, static markets than in high-technology industries, which change quickly."
 The speed-of-change argument seems a powerful reason for the Government to be circumspect in pursuing antitrust cases in high-tech fields. And after a wide-ranging four-year investigation of Microsoft, the Justice Department last summer decided against trying to break up the software company or order sweeping changes in its business practices. Instead, Microsoft agreed only to alter the way it licenses its operating system to PC makers. The settlement was regarded as little more than a wrist slap for Microsoft, and it is now being challenged in Federal court.
 The classic cautionary example was the Government's 13-year case against I.B.M., which was abandoned in 1982. It was new technology -- small-scale computing using microchips -- that broke I.B.M.'s stranglehold on the industry instead of any actions taken in Washington.
 Mr. Baxter, the Stanford law professor, was the antitrust chief at the Justice Department who tossed out the I.B.M. case. Still, he believes there is an appropriate role for enforcement. He noted that merger cases require Government officials to make guesses about the likely effect on competition in the future.
 "No one would argue that we need more government in these industries," he said. "But there is a danger when a company's dominance is so prolonged that its power and entrenched position retard innovation. Just when those conditions are present, however, is not an easy call to make."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Feeling Down? How About a New Pollster?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Bill Clinton's Presidential crusade plunged into scandal in the 1992 primaries, his pollster, Stanley B. Greenberg, told him the campaign was in "meltdown" and helped devise a plan to cool it off. When Mr. Clinton faced George Bush in the general election, Mr. Greenberg explained to the candidate what was on America's mind. When Mr. Clinton scored gutsy legislative victories with his first budget and Nafta, Mr. Greenberg, by now the official White House pollster and political tactician, pshawed modestly. "I'm dealing with a President who has an intuitive sense of what's going on in the country," he told a conclave of political sages.
 So when Mr. Clinton's intuition, legislative agenda and political support headed south last year, the President did what seemed logical. Now he has four pollsters, including one, Dick Morris, who worked on his political comeback in Arkansas more than a decade ago. 
 Such is the allure -- the digital, high-level-of-confidence attraction -- of poll-takers to politicians. The public may regard pollsters as puppetmasters, dictating policy by telling Presidents and congressmen what will and won't win votes. But the analogy is inaccurate. Modern politics is a sort of gray magic, and pollsters are its sorcerers: cloaked Merlins at the sides of kings, with powers to foretell the future, smite enemies and recapture lost loves.
 Naturally, this is humbug. As pollsters themselves will tell you, they have no such powers. Yet the myth persists, for if politicians did not believe pollsters could tell the future, smite enemies and court friends, it is doubtful that they would hire one, much less four.
 And they are hiring a lot. Mr. Clinton may well be the most voracious consumer of survey data in Presidential history, but he is only a symbol of the times. Modern public officials and advocates pop polls like candy -- and, as Mr. Greenberg's case suggests, try new ones to catch the flavor of the moment.
 "They generally have the reputation of Svengalis," said William Schneider, the Washington political analyst, "because pollsters never just sell the numbers. They sell an insight into the minds of the American people. The pollster is supposed to have some mystic communion with the American electorate."
 "You got numbers, nobody else does," said one Democratic surveyor who demanded anonymity. "I go in to see the candidate, and this hack who's been in more campaigns than I'll ever see goes in. His argument's right; my argument's wrong. But I've got the numbers, and I'll win every time."
 Not that polling is sleight-of-hand. It has advanced leagues since Louis Harris gave John F. Kennedy survey results in his bathtub, and even since President Nixon read the polls and decided to ban oil drilling off the California coast. Computers and sophisticated sampling methods have made polls vastly more accurate. Pollsters have edged away (they say) from influencing policy and styled themselves as analysts.

 
 
Big-Name Surveyor
 But the mystique has only grown. In the health-care debate, for example, both political parties and virtually every lobbying group with a major stake has had big-name surveyors on retainer. Among Republicans and their ilk, the young pollster Frank Luntz -- adviser to Ross Perot and Newt Gingrich during their ascents -- now boasts a sort of rock-star cachet.
 Senator Phil Gramm of Texas employs the Republican pollster Linda Divall to crunch numbers for his Presidential campaign, but recently added Mr. Luntz to the payroll. That led Ms. Divall to note pointedly that she remained lead survey dog, a true enough assertion. "You don't hire someone like Luntz for his numbers," one Republican said. "You hire him for his advice."
 Among Democrats, Mr. Greenberg's dispassionate liberalism seemed perfectly suited in 1992 for Mr. Clinton's disciplined, economy-oriented campaign. But when key intiatives like health-care foundered and Democratic popularity began sagging last summer, the President broadened his polling circle to include Geoffrey Garin, an unpaid adviser. When the political roof fell in last winter, the White House added Penn+Schoen Associates, a New York firm.
 The latest addition, Mr. Morris, could be seen as a retreat to a battle-tested ally; Mr. Clinton recaptured the statehouse with his help. Or it might be viewed as a bow to the right. Mr. Morris's more recent clients have included Senator Trent Lott, the deeply conservative Mississippian, and former Senator Paula Hawkins of Florida.

 
 
Where Next?
 Some of this may be the casting about of a politician in difficulty. But much of it may simply reflect the fact that pollsters' worth increasingly lies in telling officeholders where public opinion is headed next. Any pollster with a Packard-Bell can generate an ocean of numbers; the trick is to find the one who can spot in them the next big wave.
 To be sure, political polls still ask about officeholders' popularity and ratings of national or local concerns, a sort of boilerplate whose results often speak for themselves. But their sorcery lies elsewhere, in questions that politicians and lobbying groups use to road-test their spiels, evaluate hypotheticals and otherwise probe for their strong points and opponents' frailties.
 "Seven or eight years ago, polling evolved into a system where you try to predict arguments," said David Doak, a Democratic political consultant. "You use polls as laboratories to pre-test messages, to see what works and what doesn't, for media guys like me to hone down later on."
 The public sees only the fruits of that research. In the last week, Republican leaders abruptly began to argue that Medicare must be reined in, not to balance the budget but because the program is careening toward bankruptcy and must be "saved." To no one's surprise, a nonprofit arm of the Republican National Committee, the National Policy Forum, has lately tested just that proposition in polls and focus groups.
 Mr. Greenberg used similar road-tests to help the White House construct its Nafta campaign in 1993, including the critical -- and ultimately inspired -- decision to take on the treaty's chief opponent, Mr. Perot.
 Other decisions are not so inspired. Last fall, the White House flooded news outlets with results of polls showing that buzzwords like "trickle-down Reaganomics," turned many voters against Republican campaign pledges. Mr. Clinton dutifully recited the words in speeches, and Democratic commercials parroted them on the air.
 Some experts say the blitz backfired, helping to turn the election from a series of local contests where Democrats stood a fighting chance into a national contest between an unpopular President and resurgent Republicans.

 
 
Perpetual Campaign
 In the American Enterprise Institute session where Mr. Greenberg spoke in 1993, Mr. Caddell told him that the White House he described sounded more like a perpetual campaign than a Presidency.
 Mr. Greenberg scoffed, but his reply was revealing. He said that these days, being President "is not simply a question of developing a policy proposal, presenting it to Congress and leaving Congress to do its work." Rather, he said, few politicians succeed without "a focused and sustained initiative to bring people forward."

HEADLINE: The World;
Vietnam Speaks English With an Eager Accent

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

 BODY:
QUOC KHOI carries the history of Vietnam on the tip of his tongue. As foreign powers have come and gone, Mr. Khoi, who is now in his 50's, has learned French, then Japanese, then English, then Russian. Vietnam is on its own now, and Mr. Khoi is again riding the linguistic wave of history: He is making his living teaching English.
 "Now I forget my Russian and my Japanese," he said recently, speaking his English words carefully to avoid mistakes. "Even French I almost forget. But English everybody in Vietnam must know because English is the language of commerce." 
 In the dimly lit classroom of Mr. Khoi's private language school in the center of Ho Chi Minh City, once called Saigon, students ranging in age from 12 to 50 gathered for an evening class, like many thousands of others across the nation. Asked why they were here, their answers were a jumble of eager but barely intelligible English. But the words "international language" came through clearly.
 Twenty years after the end of the war and the disappearance of Americans from Vietnam, this Communist country is in the throes of an English-language boom that has little to do with the past and everything to do with the nation's rush to join the international marketplace. The war seems all but forgotten as ordinary Vietnamese welcome American visitors not as former soldiers but as future investors.
 The titles of the English-language tapes for sale in the Xuan Thu bookstore tell the story: "International Business English," "English for Business," "We're in Business," "Good for Business." And for those who wish to refine their accents, there is "Sheep or Ship."
 The study of English seems to carry little cultural or historical baggage for the Vietnamese. There is neither resentment against American culture nor a deep fascination with it. Mary Kay Crouch, a professor of English at California State University at Fullerton who has helped set up English courses in Vietnam, said, "One of our proposals was to do some teaching of American culture, and I can tell you, people were not interested. They want to know how much money do I make and do I have a car and how do I live, and that's about it."

 
 
The Common Tongue
 Most American businessmen arrived in Vietnam only after the lifting of Washington's trade embargo a little more than a year ago, but their language preceded them. English was already established as the common tongue among the Japanese, Koreans, Taiwanese, Southeast Asians and Europeans who dominate the foreign presence and the market. Now that more Americans are arriving and the Government is encouraging foreign trade, the language is more prized than ever.
 "English has become the universal language in Vietnam, just as the dollar is the currency of choice," said Jeffrey Brody, a journalism professor at Fullerton who has spent time in Vietnam.
 The Vietnamese, in their eagerness to learn English, often approach foreigners to practice it. They listen to lessons on radio and television, both of which are state-controlled, and to tapes in their cars. In the evenings, farmers keep their families' suppers warm while their children attend English classes.
 Colleges are busy turning out English speakers as fast as they can. The Teachers Training College of Ho Chi Minh City offers night classes to 30,000 students, said Diane Fox, an English teacher at Portland State University who has also taught English in Vietnam. She said some of her former students in Vietnam -- and not even the best of them -- have quickly become wealthy teaching English.
In the midst of this bustle, there are few lonelier places in Ho Chi Minh City than the local Russian Cultural Center. At midday, the secretary, Nguyen Thi Nhi, sits alone in her office, and when a rare visitor knocks, she must telephone the director, Victor Stepanov, at his home. He is the only remaining member of a staff of 12 Russians that once included science and technology specialists, several language teachers and a specialist in propaganda. "We call it the lowering of interest in the Russian language," Mr. Stepanov said. "Now, no question about it, there is an overwhelming rush to speak English. It seems everybody speaks English now, if only a few phrases."

 
 
The Dead Language
 Not long ago, everybody was learning Russian. For the 15 years that Moscow was Hanoi's chief patron, more than 100,000 Vietnamese workers and 3,000 students were in the Soviet Union at any one time. Then the Soviet Union collapsed, Vietnam turned outward and Washington lifted its trade embargo. Russian quickly became a dead language for most Vietnamese, and a generation of Russian-language teachers had no one left to teach.
 Meanwhile, many qualified English teachers went into business with high-paying foreign companies. So the Russian teachers retrained, by the hundreds, to teach English. "My cousin was a Russian teacher," said T. T. Nhu, a Vietnamese-American who is a columnist for The San Jose Mercury News. "Now they are all madly trying to learn English."
 As a result, in a country where an older generation still speaks English with a French accent, a new generation of English speakers with a Russian accent is emerging. In search of what they hope will be a more authentic accent, Ms. Nhu said, some students are now traveling to Australia.
 In a land where youngsters once learned to shout "Hey, G.I.!" before they learned to read and write, children are again learning how to greet foreigners, even in places where they are rarely seen.
 One recent sunny morning in the mountain city of Da Lat, a 10-year-old girl holding a small boy on her hip stared curiously at an American as he sipped tea at an outdoor table.
 "Do you want to study English in school?" the American asked her, speaking in Vietnamese.
 "No," the girl said, walking away. "I don't want to study at all."
 But then she stopped and looked back. "Thank you!" she said in English. "See you again!"
 And the small boy on her hip waved and said, "See you again!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: When it comes to picking the language of commerce, the choice is clear. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Many Cubans Don't Share Havana's Pride in Pact With U.S.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, May 6

 BODY:
For days now, the sea has been calm and the sky clear along the waterfront and beaches that stretch for miles here. It is just the sort of weather that for more than 30 years has beckoned Cubans to board rafts and try to make their way across the Straits of Florida to seek political asylum.
But with the door to the United States now suddenly closed to migrants as a result of the immigration agreement that the United States and Cuban Governments announced on Tuesday, only fishermen, strolling couples and the unemployed are congregating at Havana's seaside promenades. 
 "Nobody is going to be going anywhere now," said one of those staring out at the sea, a young man with no job who gave his name as Gerardo Aviles and his age as 20. "There is no point in even trying to leave if you know the American Coast Guard is only going to hand you back over."
The Cuban Government has repeatedly stressed that point on television and in newspaper reports about the agreement. It has also described the accord as a major turnabout in United States policy and a triumph of Cuban diplomacy that obliges Washington to stop treating departing Cubans as refugees fleeing political oppression.
Last summer, when more than 30,000 people took to the seas, President Fidel Castro argued that the flow of people was no different than that from Mexico or many other third world countries: people leaving economic difficulties in search of a better life in a more prosperous place. This week's agreement, Cuban officials said, shows that the Clinton Administration now agrees.
"This agreement places migratory relations with Cuba at exactly the same level as migratory relations with other Latin American countries and other places," Ricardo Alarcon, president of Cuba's National Assembly and the chief representative in the talks with the United States, said shortly after the accord was made public. "In sum, this involves applying the same rules and procedures applicable to immigrants from other nations."
In an interview here, Cuba's Deputy Minister of Foreign Relations, Fernando Remirez, described United States policy toward Cuba as having shifted "180 degrees, undergoing a radical change" as a result of the immigration agreement. He said the accord could pave the way for direct bilateral talks on other issues, suggesting that some sort of cooperation in the war against drug trafficking, whether formalized or not, was a particularly promising area.
Mr. Alarcon and other officials have predicted that Mr. Clinton will soon lift the sanctions on travel and remittances that were imposed last August at the height of the refugee crisis. As Mr. Remirez put it, Cuban-Americans have already found ways to get around the restrictions, which have therefore lost their usefulness.
"These measures are going to be lifted at any moment," Mr. Alarcon said. "The situation of conflict that led to the implementation of these measures is increasingly distant."
Reaction to the accord on Cuban dissidents has been mixed. Elizardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, director of the Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation, described the measure as "on balance positive" because it will discourage "people desperate to leave" from risking their lives at sea, but he also expressed doubt about the Cuba's willingness to abide by the it.
"I am worried that there is no independent system to supervise the implementation of this agreement, and would like to see representatives of the United Nations or the International Red Cross involved," he said.
Mr. Remirez, however, said Cuba had a history of "rigorously abiding by all international agreements it has signed" with Washington and others. He pointed to the agreement that led to the end of the conflict in Angola and Namibia.
Another dissident leader, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said the accord would prove to be a valuable recruiting tool, a notion that has also been advanced by some diplomats here. The new situation is likely to encourage disgruntled Cubans to "channel their efforts into a greater willingness to work in Cuba, rather than just getting out of the island," said one.
But other diplomats said the agreement created a situation more complicated than either the United States or Cuba was willing to admit. "Yes, both sides have rid themselves of an unwanted and unwelcome problem," said one. "But there are also risks, especially for Cuba."
Cuba has said it will soon begin laying off hundreds of thousands of workers because of the economic crisis that began with the collapse of the Soviet bloc. With shortages of electricity, food and fuel looming again, there is concern that without the "safety valve" of immigration to the United States, outbreaks of discontent such as those that sparked last summer's crisis could recur.
"I hope that all of this encourages the Cuban Government to accelerate the pace of economic reforms," one European diplomat said. "They seem to think that the worst of the economic crisis is over, but they could be wrong, and if they are, the prospects for this country are too grim to contemplate."

13 Refugees Returned
 MIAMI, May 6 (AP) -- The Coast Guard ferried 13 refugees back toward Cuba today as angry exiles planned civil disobedience to protest President Clinton's reversal of 35 years of refugee policy.
A Coast Guard cutter transferred the refugees from a Caribbean cruise ship just before midnight on Friday, but the Guard disclosed few details about they were being taken.
"We really, truly don't know," said Lieut. Comdr. Pat Philbin, chief of Coast Guard media in Washington. "We don't know which port we're going to. The details are being worked out as we speak."
The refugees would be the first to be repatriated under the policy that has angered Cuba's exile community, whose leaders met today to map a response that some said could include civil disobedience.
The Coast Guard picked up the 13 men from the Majesty of the Seas cruise ship, whose crew found them adrift in two boats south of Little Cayman Island late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: VIOLENCE;
Anger of the 60's Takes Root in the Violent Right

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
On the surface, few eras would seem to have less in common than the tie-dyed turmoil of the 1960's and the edgy, armed-to-the-teeth anger of the 1990's.
But many historians who track the nation's mood swings say they detect an odd and striking inversion in which the anger, discontent and distrust of authority that erupted on the left in the 60's have become the signatures of the right 30 years later. 
 The notion is not that the rumblings of the old left have been transformed into today's right-wing agenda or that the sporadic and largely inept violence of the 60's is mirrored in the horror of Oklahoma City. Instead, there is a sense that Vietnam War-era turmoil tore a hole in the post-World War II social fabric, and that although it was the left that opened the rift, it is the right that has driven a truck through it.
Indeed, many experts say that to understand today's right-wing anger it is necessary first to make sense of the tumult three decades ago.
"What happened in the 1960's was that the Government was successfully 'delegitimated,' " said Gerald Marwell, a sociologist at the University of Wisconsin who studies American political movements. "We had a period from World War II through the 1950's where the Government was seen as having rescued the nation from the Depression and successfully prosecuted the war, and then we were told in the 1960's that the emperor has no clothes and people shouldn't accept what they're told."
Historians acknowledge the limitations of comparing different eras. Many say any understanding of the passions and paranoias of the 90's must begin with the recognition that the nation's history is rife with bitter rifts and conspiratorial vapors.Indeed many historians find the relative, though hardly universal, degree of national consensus that marked the 1940's and 1950's to be the exception in American life rather than the norm.
"This is the most anti-state country in the Western world, probably on earth," said Michael Kazin, a historian at the American University in Washington and the author of "The Populist Persuasion: An American History" (Basic Books, 1994). "Throughout American history groups on the right and the left have seen the Federal Government as an alien force inimical to their interests, so you see this sort of thing over and over again."
What happened in the 60's, he wrote, is that the left "only discredited the old order without laying the political foundation for a new one."
Many scholars of American history have long acknowledged what the historian Richard Hofstadter called "the paranoid style in American politics," a tendency to view the world in terms of dense conspiracies that in various eras have centered on groups as diverse as Masons, Catholics, Jews, international bankers, Mormons, foreign gold traders, and the Bavarian Illuminati.
To cite a more recent example, Senator Joseph McCarthy, during his campaign against Communist infiltration in 1951, described "a great conspiracy, a conspiracy on a scale so immense as to dwarf any previous such venture in the history of man," to undermine the United States Government from within.
The Soviet threat is gone, but conspiracy theories spring up with numbing frequency, exemplified most recently by the claim that the attack on the Federal Building in Oklahoma City was a Government plot to discredit the paramilitary groups that call themselves militias.
Even the details of the supposed conspiracies faxed and E-mailed among right-wing groups from Montana to Michigan are eerily similar to those alleged by the John Birch Society and other right-wing groups of the late 50's and early 60's.
Today there are claims that United Nations troops have taken over Yellowstone National Park and that sinister military vehicles identified with an inverted V are prowling rural Michigan. Three decades ago allegations included reports that 35,000 Chinese Communist troops were poised on the Mexico border ready to invade California, that the Army had been turned over to a Russian colonel in the United Nations and that an Army guerrilla warfare exercise in Georgia called Water Moccasin III was actually a United Nations operation prepared to take over the United States.
Still, the suspicions of today are hardly limited to the right.
Not far from Professor Marwell's office, Karlton Armstrong runs an outdoor juice stand on the University of Wisconsin Library Mall. Twenty-five years ago, Mr. Armstrong, then an antiwar activist, was one of the campus radicals who planted a fertilizer and fuel oil bomb at Sterling Hall, home of the university's Physics Department and of the oil bomb's target, the Army Math Research Center. The explosion killed a graduate student, in one of the most infamous episodes of the era.
Mr. Armstrong, who served 7 years of his 14-year sentence for murder and arson in the bombing, is now 48 and has no sympathy for today's far-right fringe groups. He now views the Sterling Hall bombing as a betrayal of his own beliefs, even though the bomb was detonated with the intention that the building would be unoccupied.
But when asked about the sense of frustration and alienation abroad in the land, he said: "These people are rapidly becoming dispossessed, like they are losing what little power they had. I totally empathize with that sense of alienation."
And just as it was alienated hippies who preceded ring-wing groups in retreating to the woods to create communes free from the corrupting influences of the Government and urban life, the sensibilities of the 60's have left many with the same kind of distrust of Government now so endemic on the right.
"I don't consider myself a paranoid by any means, but I've been given plenty of reasons to fear my Government," said Susan Spangenberg of Madison, who is active in the Wisconsin Alliance for the Medicalization of Cannabis, which seeks to make marijuana more readily available for medical uses. "The militias have the same civil rights as I do, as we all do, and if the Government can intrude on civil rights on the right, it could just as easily do it for someone who gets labeled a left-wing liberal."
To many on the left, there is something utterly perverse in any effort to link their philosophy with the armed extremist right of the 1990's. Many say the incessant anti-Government rhetoric of the right says more about the present than the turmoil of the 60's.
"Don't insult me," said Paul Soglin, the former anti-war activist who is now Mayor of Madison. "That's the thinking of very stupid people who need an elementary education in civics and political science."
He and others said the left of the 1960's was rooted in nonviolence and sought to prod the Government toward what it saw as appropriate action in ending the war in Vietnam and enforcing civil rights laws, while the extremist right is steeped in weapons and violence and opposed to almost all Government activism. Those on the right say a more telling difference is that the 1960's were also steeped in a contempt for traditional values.
But many experts see important points of convergence. Professor Marwell of Wisconsin and Professor Kazin of the American University see a libertarian strain from the 1960's that, intentionally or not, became more of a legacy than leftist politics. To the 60's left it might have meant the right to smoke pot, while to the 90's right it might mean the right to own guns, but the instinct is similar.
"My favorite button from the anti-draft S.D.S. was, 'Not With My Life You Don't,' " Mr. Kazin, a former anti-war activist himself, said, referring to the radical group Students for a Democratic Society. "It could be the slogan of the right wing today, a don't-tread-on-me, get-off-my-back kind of statement."
Others say that rather than the politics of the student movement of the 1960's and early 70's, it was the various upheavals and shocks of the era -- from the Kennedy assassination to the Vietnam War to Watergate to unresolved issues of racial and sexual equality -- that produced fault lines in American life that have never been bridged.
"There's a culture war, particularly the part of it that has to do with gender, that's still playing out today, whether it's overtly talked about or not," said Emily Rosenberg, a history professor at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn.
Professors Kazin and Rosenberg both said a more compelling historical parallel than the 1960's may be the 1890's, when structural changes in the economy, anger at immigrants and the widespread sense that communities and individuals were losing economic control produced an angry populist movement and widespread social turmoil. Ms. Rosenberg noted that the last decade of a century has almost invariably produced a sense of momentous change, whether manifested as dread or as anticipation. She said she suspected the discord of the 90's could have further to run.
But the ripples of the 1890's are merely historical. The reverberations of the 1960's are still very real. Professor Marwell said one to watch would be whether the violence of Oklahoma City would discredit the right in the 1990's in the way that the Sterling Hall bombing short-circuited the left in the 1960's. He said he thought it would.
"The bombing here in Madison almost ended the anti-war movement all by itself," he said. "The whole right may not be at fault for Oklahoma City, but I think they're underestimating the price they're going to pay."

HEADLINE: CLINTON ADVISERS CALL FOR TARIFFS ON JAPAN IMPORTS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
President Clinton's top economic advisers recommended yesterday that he impose record-breaking sanctions against Japanese imports, chiefly automobile parts, in retaliation for Tokyo's refusal to open the Japanese automotive market to America.
The recommendation came at a two-hour meeting of the National Economic Council in Washington, after last-minute negotiations broke down Friday night between the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, and Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Ryutaro Hashimoto. 
 The centerpiece of the retaliation is expected to be tariffs ranging up to 100 percent on billions of dollars in Japanese automobile-related imports. Japanese automotive goods accounted for more than 55 percent of America's $66 billion trade deficit with Japan last year.
American officials would not specify the total value of the products subject to sanctions, but it has been reported that the initial range could be from $5 billion to $10 billion. But that figure is expected to decline during a review process.
In Tokyo, Japanese Government officials and car manufacturers said the United States was to blame for the impasse and called on the Administration to back down from its sanctions threats. [Page 10.]
Mr. Kantor would not describe the specific recommendations made, but said that a range of actions was "unanimously agreed to after a thorough review, but very little debate." Administration officials said they expected Mr. Clinton to approve the sanctions before he leaves for Moscow on Monday.
But the formal announcement may be delayed for days, while officials refine the list of Japanese goods affected. They may also consider imposing broader, nontariff sanctions against Japanese industry like prohibiting the opening of new Japanese automobile dealerships in the United States or restricting Japanese investment.
In Auburn Hills, Mich., the Chrysler Corporation issued a statement in which its chairman, Robert J. Eaton, praised the Administration's efforts to open Japan's market and pledged support for any further action Washington takes.
"The key to opening Japan's closed market has always been in Japan's hands," Mr. Eaton said.
Under American trade law, the tariffs cannot go into effect for 30 days, giving American firms a chance to review the list and seek the removal of items that cannot be obtained from non-Japanese suppliers.
But the sanctions are unlikely to go into effect anyway until late June. The delay is intended to increase the pressure on Japan to resolve the dispute when President Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama meet at the annual summit talks of the Group of Seven leading industrial countries on June 15 in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Trade disputes are often settled on the brink, and American officials hope a deal can be struck in Halifax, if not before. But they insisted that they are not bluffing. The recent trade dispute with China was settled just before sanctions were imposed.
"The President is very determined in this matter," Mr. Kantor said yesterday. "This has gone on for too long, and the President will act decisively."
If effected, the tariffs would raise costs for Japanese auto manufacturers, though it is unclear whether they would pass those costs on to consumers -- a move that would inevitably hurt their business. That would be welcomed by the American industry, which is increasingly concerned that the overall automobile market is falling off dramatically, a cyclical event that generally focuses attention on Japanese competition.
The tariffs could also harm America's Big Three automakers, however, because some major components are only manufactured in Japan. That is why Commerce Department officials have been working for weeks on a proposed tariff list that would primarily cover products for which a substitute American product is available.
Administration officials have insisted that the dispute with Japan can be contained and that it will not spill over into Japan's political relationship with the United States. But there is growing doubt about that point among younger Japanese leaders, who say that the increasingly angry confrontations, combined with the ravaging effects of the high yen on Japanese competitiveness, are eating away at the underpinnings of the relationship.
For the Administration, the confrontation with Japan is also an implicit acknowledgment that one of its major foreign policy goals -- to break the cycle of pressure, threats and counterthreats that have marred Japan's relations with the U.S. -- has so far failed.
Only two years ago, President Clinton signed a broad "framework accord" with former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa that was supposed to lay out a schedule and method for resolving trade disputes. At the time Mr. Clinton talked of a new era of cooperation between the world's two largest economies.
Since then, however, Japan has changed prime ministers three times, its effort to overhaul its political system and deregulate its economy has largely stalled, and officials on both sides of the Pacific acknowledge that trade relations between the countries have plunged back into their old patterns.
"It is enormously frustrating," one of Mr. Clinton's closest economic advisers said late last month. "What we thought was a new beginning turned out to be more of the same, a bureaucratic blockade."
Some trade and political specialists argue that the Administration also bears some of the blame, chiefly for its failure to convince the Japanese public that more deregulation is in its interest. The Administration is also blamed for its inability to convince American industry to invest more heavily in the Japanese market, rather than bypassing it to move into China and Southeast Asia.
"It was not inevitable that we would find ourselves in this situation," said Mike Mochizuki, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "Because of the way we pursed out policies, we forced the Japanese into a defensive position," he said. "And after all these talks, it is remarkable how little communication there really is between the two governments."
Sanctions are nothing new in the rocky economic relationship between the two countries; the Reagan Administration imposed tariffs on Japanese electronics products in the 1980's to force an opening of its semiconductor market. But the sanctions were relatively small, and partly hurt American manufacturers who depended on Japanese suppliers.
Mr. Hashimoto, one of Japan's most experienced politicians and a man viewed as a candidate for prime minister in the near future, charged again on Friday that the United States was insisting on managed trade with Japan by pressing Japanese automakers to agree to "voluntary" plans to purchase a vastly increased amount of American-made auto parts.
"It is regrettable," Mr. Hashimoto said. "The U.S. insistence on voluntary plans has remained as an insurmountable stumbling block to a negotiated agreement."
He has threatened to take the United States to the newest court of international trade, the World Trade Organization in Geneva. Mr. Kantor says he would welcome such a challenge, because "it would give us an opportunity to make clear to the world the full range of Japan's discriminatory practices" in the auto market.
As in any trade argument with Japan, there are numbers to support the contention that the market is essentially closed, and numbers to support Japanese arguments that things are changing.
American officials say that by their measurements, Japan imports only 2.4 percent of its auto parts, while the United States imports 32.5 percent and the United Kingdom imports 60 percent. Exports of automobiles and parts from the United States to Japan totaled $3.5 billion last year -- a 54 percent jump -- but the flow from Japan to American shores was more than 10 times higher, $40.3 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Trade talks between the United States and Japan broke down Friday night during meetings in Vancouver, British Columbia. Chart: "Issues in Dispute"
 The three main points of contention in United States-Japanese auto trade.
 
ACCESS TO DEALERSHIPS
 Washington argues that American companies have been systematically prevented from access to "high quality" car dealers in Japan, those who already own showrooms for Toyota, Nissan and Honda. The Japanese say that Americans have failed to invest in dealerships.
 
REPLACEMENT PARTS
 The Japanese government regulates car repairs heavily, requiring "inspections" every two years or so that include the replacement of parts worth thousands of dollars. The repairs are done by shops closely tied to Japanese auto makers, and the result is that competitive, less expensive American parts are seldom used.

ORIGINAL EQUIPMENT
 American companies say that if Japanese makers can use American parts in cars they in the United States, they can use the same parts in Japan. But in Japan, parts are usually made by companies with deep ties to to the auto makers. (pg. 10)

LENGTH: 1221 words

HEADLINE: Japan Cites U.S. Demands In Collapse of Auto Talks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 6

 BODY:
Japan's Government and car manufacturers closed ranks today, placing the blame for a breakdown of automobile trade talks with the United States squarely on what they called Washington's unreasonable demands for Japan to set numerical targets for purchases of American auto parts.
The show of solidarity indicated that Japan, for the moment at least, will not budge, even as the Clinton Administration moves to impose sanctions on billions of dollars of Japanese products exported to the United States. 
 "The Japanese Government did all it could to settle the issue in line with international rules," Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, who was traveling in China, was quoted as saying by the Kyodo News Service.
Yoshifumi Tsuji, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said, "It is truly regrettable that the auto trade talks have broken down due to continued insistence by the United States that the voluntary purchase plans be increased and revised." In a statement, he called on the Clinton Administration to "react sensibly" and not impose sanctions.
Japanese officials today reiterated their intention to fight American moves toward sanctions by taking the dispute to the World Trade Organization, the successor to the world group that administered the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Japan could still make concessions before any sanctions take effect, perhaps in late June. But the fact that Tokyo has not caved in so far to American demands is remarkable, and somewhat puzzling to American negotiators. In the past, such as in last year's negotiations on Japanese Government construction projects and cellular phones, the threat of sanctions prodded Tokyo to reach agreements.
Last February, when talks on autos and other issues also broke down, bureaucrats and businessmen here were elated at first that Japan had actually said "no" to the United States' demand for numerical targets.
But within days the yen started to climb against the dollar and panicky business leaders began calling for Japan to resolve the trade issues. Less than two months later, Japan's five leading auto makers issued new voluntary plans to increase their purchases of foreign parts. The United States, however, did not think those plans went far enough.
Japanese officials said today that they wanted to draw a line in the sand against numerical targets, so that they are not requested in future trade negotiations. "It's a vicious cycle," said one Japanese trade official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
This official said governments should not meddle in the purchasing decisions of private companies. Even if the purchase goals are supposedly voluntary, he said, Washington has demonstrated in the past that it will threaten retaliation if the targets are not met.
But ideological support for free trade cannot be the only reason for Japan's opposition. For one thing, Japanese auto makers could have issued the plans on their own, freeing the Japanese Government from being involved in private-sector matters. Indeed, the companies indicated a willingness last year to issue such plans. The question is whether as businessmen it would have been better for them to revise last year's plans upward rather than risk huge tariffs imposed on the Acuras and Lexuses sold in the United States.
Auto executives say their bleak and unpredictable business outlook leaves them little room to make any commitments, especially of the size required to satisfy Washington. "The business environment surrounding us has been very fragile," Toshiaki Taguchi, a director of Toyota Motor Corporation, said in an interview today.
Japan's car exports and production have been shrinking for years, and are likely drop further because of the yen's recent surge. Japanese companies are struggling to cut expenditures on parts by up to 30 percent in the next two or three years. That makes it very hard to increase parts purchases from new foreign suppliers, especially as domestic parts companies are suffering.
The auto makers were also involved in stringent cost-cutting efforts last year, but still came out with voluntary plans. And the strong yen, which makes imports cheaper, is a good reason for increasing purchases of foreign parts.
Another factor behind Japan's resistance appears to be a belief that the United States will not go through with sanctions. "We're counting on the sound judgment of American Government executives," Mr. Taguchi of Toyota said.
Japanese trade officials say they know there is ideological opposition in the United States to such tactics. Moreover, any American consumers or companies hurt by higher-priced imports will raise a fuss.
If sanctions are imposed, they may end up being relatively light in comparison with Japan's total trade with the United States. In Washington today, the National Economic Council recommended the imposition of tariffs ranging up to 100 percent on billions of dollars Japanese automobile-related imports. Japan's exports of automobiles and parts to the United States totaled $36 billion in 1993.
Japan also hopes to have the sanctions removed in as little as half a year by the new World Trade Organization, which came into existence in January. Under the older GATT rules, resolution of a trade dispute could take two or three years, a Japanese official said.
Japanese officials said referring the matter to a referee like the World Trade Organization might ease tensions, not escalate them. "We'd like to de-politicize the matter and have the talks move out of Washington and Tokyo to Geneva," one Japanese bureaucrat said.
Japanese officials say they think Japan has a good chance at the World Trade Organization against any unilateral sanctions applied by the United States. A highly favorable ruling for Japan might also make it harder in general for Washington to apply Section 301 of American trade law, which empowers the United States Government to take retaliatory measures against nations it deems unfair traders.
But Takeshi Kondo, general manager of the office of political and economic research at Itochu, a large Japanese trading company, said it was possible for Washington to fashion sanctions that are consistent with World Trade Organization rules. Also, he said, if Japan wins its case, there might be a rebellion against the World Trade Organization in Congress that would fatally weaken the new international trading body.
Some analysts here, as well as some Clinton Administration officials, think the Japanese auto companies would be willing to increase voluntary plans but are being held back by Japan's Government. One reason could be that Mr. Hashimoto, a likely future candidate for Prime Minister, wants to look strong in negotiations.
But once the sanctions are actually proposed or the yen starts to rise, Japanese auto makers will be able to argue to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and their domestic parts suppliers that such plans are unavoidable. Already, there are some mumblings from Japanese auto executives about "management plans" to cope with the rise of the yen, in part by buying more foreign parts.
"It's safer for them to wait until the last moment," Mr. Kondo of Itochu said about the Japanese auto companies. "And they consider that the last moment hasn't come yet."

HEADLINE: Christopher To Cut Jobs At State Dept.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher plans to eliminate about 500 State Department jobs as part of a streamlining effort intended in part to head off a more sweeping overhaul proposed by Republicans.
Mr. Christopher's aides say his plan aims to save tens of millions of dollars a year, to make his department more flexible in responding to crises and to derail Republican efforts to revamp the Government's foreign policy agencies. 
 Democrats in Congress have been pressing Mr. Christopher for weeks to present a plan, which will be announced Monday, to give them an alternative to Republican reorganization efforts.
But Republican lawmakers insist that what they have heard so far about Mr. Christopher's new plan is far too modest to dissuade them from their efforts, which call for the most sweeping overhaul of the foreign policy apparatus since World War II.
Sometime this month, Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is expected to introduce a bill that would eliminate 30 senior positions in the State Department, reshuffle its responsibilities and reduce budgets by at least 15 percent by cutting more than $3 billion a year from the $21 billion foreign affairs budget.
The Helms bill would eliminate the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Helms has proposed closing the development agency's overseas missions, cutting about half of its 9,000 jobs and using a semi-independent foundation, rather than the Government, to distribute aid grants through private organizations.
"Our foreign policy institutions are a complete mess," Mr. Helms said. "Over the past four decades, key foreign policy functions have been spun off into a constellation of money-absorbing, incoherent satellites, each with its own entrenched, growing bureaucracies."
Mr. Christopher's plan would cut the managerial staff in State Department headquarters by 10 percent, close about 20 overseas posts and emphasize the use of teams to make the department more nimble in handling crises. Those moves are intended to save at least $50 million a year, his aides estimate, although most of that money would be plowed back into modernizing the department's obsolete computer system.
"This plan is an efficiency-enhancing plan, not a cut-and-slash plan," said a senior State Department official. "The Secretary doesn't think the foreign affairs budget should be cut. He thinks it should be enhanced, and he's going to try to make that case."
Another Republican plan, proposed in a bill by Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York representative who heads the House International Relations Committee, is far less radical than the Helms proposal. Mr. Gilman's bill would merge the aid, information and arms control agencies with the 26,000-employee State Department, but unlike the Helms plan, it would preserve much of their organizations.
Republican and Democratic aides say Mr. Gilman believes that a more extreme proposal would push moderate Republicans to join Democrats in defeating any overhaul plan.
Although the Clinton Administration favors the Gilman plan over the Helms proposal, it has stepped up its efforts to defeat both.
"I don't think abolishing agencies insures that we are conducting foreign policy in the best interests of the American people," one senior State Department official said.
But Several Congressional Democrats are sympathetic with the aims of the Helms bill.
At a recent Senate hearing, for example, Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat, told Administration officials: "I'm not persuaded by your arguments that maintaining independent fiefdoms is in the best interest of American foreign policy. I am persuaded that the present structure is outmoded."
