HEADLINE: In Philippines, Wary Hopes For a Shift From Stagnation

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: MANILA, May 6

 BODY:
It became the nightmarish symbol of a desperate nation -- thousands of Filipinos swarming over a mountain of garbage as tall as a 10-story building, scavenging through this Everest of rotting trash with their bare hands.
A generation of rag-pickers settled in shanties atop Smokey Mountain, named for the noxious haze pumped out by methane fires smoldering beneath the refuse. 
 Across town, Manila's rich had their own evidence of the collapse of a nation that was once the most prosperous in Southeast Asia: they could not even keep the lights turned on. In the early 1990's, the capital's business districts were blacked out for as much as half the day when the antiquated power grid failed.
William S. Tiffany, president of Caltex Philippines, an American-owned oil company, saw the blackouts as evidence of a nation "with no direction for the future, with no commitment for sorting out its problems." He added, "It was a terrible time." Many large American investors talked openly of giving up on this former American colony.
But could the terrible times finally be over? Almost three years after the inauguration of Fidel V. Ramos as President, the symbols of stagnation have begun to disappear, replaced by the hope that this nation of 67 million might finally be shaking its decades-old reputation as "the sick man of Asia."
The optimism is not universal. The modern history of the Philippines is one of lost opportunity, and Mr. Ramos's leadership has been tested this spring by the uproar over the execution in Singapore of a Filipino maid, Flor Contemplacion, whose name has become a rallying cry for the nation's poor.
Many Filipinos do not believe the 42-year-old maid was guilty of the two murders that sent her to the gallows, and they blame Mr. Ramos for not having done enough to save her. The furor could cost Mr. Ramos's supporters at least a few seats in the Philippine Congress in elections on Monday.
But the controversy has not dampened the enthusiasm of many economists and foreign investors who say that under Mr. Ramos, the Philippines appears to have come to the end of an era of decay that began during the rapacious dictatorship of Ferdinand E. Marcos and continued through the chaos of the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino.
The economy grew 5.1 percent in 1994 -- modest by the standards of Southeast Asia but dazzling for the Philippines -- and is projected to grow by at least 6 percent this year. Exports rose in 1994 by nearly 20 percent, while commitments for foreign investment quadrupled, reaching $2.5 billion.
Michael Taylor, an economist with Morgan Stanley, described the accomplishments as "a truly unexpected Asian economic miracle."
Smokey Mountain is being bulldozed and its 10,000 residents are being moved to a new housing development that will offer them running water, most for the first time in their lives.
"It will be good for my kids to have a clean house and a toilet," said Anna Mae Paronda, a 33-year-old rag-picker with four children. Across town, the lights are back on, the result of a crash program to build electricity plants.
"The vision of President Ramos is changing the Philippines," said Mr. Tiffany, whose company plans to spend an additional $600 million on new oil refineries here.
Still, the question for Mr. Ramos is whether the problems of the Philippines are too entrenched to allow this country ever to achieve real prosperity. While the official unemployment rate is about 9 percent, as much as one-third of the work force is considered chronically underemployed. And there is little hope that before he leaves office in 1988 -- under the Constitution, he is permitted only one six-year term -- Mr. Ramos will have made any real improvement in the lives of tens of millions of the poor.
'Sick Man of Asia' Takes Up Jogging
 Malacanang Palace has changed little since the days of Mr. Marcos, whose 20-year rule left the country in tatters by the time he was forced into exile in the United States in 1986.
The former First Lady, Imelda R. Marcos, converted the presidential palace into a gaudy showplace, a monument to excess with French antiques perched on gilded tables set in front of wall-sized murals of carefree Philippine peasants tilling their fields. Her famous shoe collection is on display downstairs.
The ostentatious decor is at odds with the informality of the palace's newest tenant, President Ramos, a cigar-chomping, West Point-educated general whose decision to turn on Mr. Marcos in 1986 made him a hero of the "people power" revolt led by Mrs. Aquino.
Mr. Ramos, 67, allowed ash from his cigars to drift to the thick palace carpet, laughing when asked if the Philippines could still be described as the "sick man of Asia."
"Oh, no," he said. "The sick man has been out of the hospital for a long time. And he's up and jogging."
Mr. Ramos has done much to reassure foreign investors who fled from the Philippines during the presidency of Mrs. Aquino. Her Government faced almost daily coup threats from disgruntled soldiers.
An investment in the Philippines is still a gamble, of course. Investors on the southern island of Mindanao have been alarmed by a new wave of violence by Muslim militants there who may have allied themselves with suspected Middle Eastern terrorists, including Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, accused of masterminding the bombing of the World Trade Center in New York in 1993.
The Contemplacion case has frightened away investors from Singapore, the authoritarian city-state that had been a large source of investment in the Philippines. But even as Singaporeans pull out, other, much larger foreign investors have announced that they are here to stay.
"I have the impression that the Philippines is back on track for good," Shoichiro Toyoda, chairman of Toyota Motors, said during a recent visit. He said the dispute with Singapore would have no effect on plans by the carmaker to build a second assembly plant here.
Breaking the Hold Of the Oligarchies
 Not everyone is convinced that the economic revival of the Philippines will last, and there was alarm here last winter over the collapse of the Mexican economy, which had been seen as a model for the Philippines and other developing countries.
"Is this bubble going to burst?" asked Solita Collas-Monsod, an economist at the University of the Philippines. She said that too little foreign money was being spent to build job-creating factories, and that too much of it was being poured into the stocks and bonds of Philippine companies. "Mexico had an enormous amount of portfolio investments and look what happened there," she said.
But other economists say the Philippines has done a far better job than Mexico in managing its economy and its currency, the Philippine peso.
The reputation of the Philippines as the economic laggard of Southeast Asia has begun to fade.
Finance Secretary Roberto F. de Ocampo remembered attending the World Bank conference in Washington in 1993 and finding himself sitting alone. "Nobody wanted to talk with us about anything," he said.
But when he arrived at the World Bank summit meeting in Spain last fall, he found himself a celebrity. "My schedule was full every day because suddenly everybody -- everybody -- wanted to talk about the Philippines," he said. "People think there has been a sea change here."
Once among the most protectionist nations in Asia, the Philippines under Mr. Ramos has freed up currency controls, cut import duties and moved to court foreign investors, offering them 100 percent ownership of companies in key industries.
Mr. Ramos's most lasting contribution to the economy may be his assault on the handful of oligarchic families who control most of the nation's wealth, including the Cojuangco family, the clan that controls the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company.
For millions of Filipinos, the phone company symbolized not just what was wrong with the economy but also what was wrong with the country. Effectively a monopoly, it provided some of the worst phone service in Asia at some of its highest prices. In 1993 there was a backlog of hundreds of thousands of people seeking phone lines, with many told not to expect installation until well into the next century.
But the monopoly-like grip of the Cojuangcos, relatives of former President Aquino, ended last year, when the Government opened the telephone industry to competition. New phone companies have been formed. In just a year, telephone service has improved markedly.
The Church, the Poor And Birth Control
 Mr. Ramos's most notable challenge may be the one issued from behind the white stucco walls of a Manila hacienda that is the home of the second most powerful man in the country, Jaime Cardinal Sin.
As the head of the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines, Cardinal Sin is the spiritual leader of 85 percent of the population, and he insists that Filipinos reject a centerpiece of Mr. Ramos's development program for the country: birth control.
The Philippines has one of the highest birth rates in Asia: 2.3 percent growth a year. If it holds, the population will double by 2035, which economists say would condemn the Philippines to eternal poverty as farmland is devoured by slums.
In an office decorated with an autographed portrait of Pope John Paul II, Cardinal Sin insisted that he was a friend of Mr. Ramos.
"He is a good person, a good manager," the Cardinal said of the President, who is a Protestant. "I want him to succeed."
But the Cardinal says he will not compromise over Government programs that encourage the use of condoms and other "artificial" methods of contraception. The Government, he said, is encouraging promiscuity and masturbation -- "and this is a sin, naturally."
Besides, the Cardinal said, the despair among large, impoverished families is overstated. "They are very happy when they have so many children," he said.
But if they are content, it is despite living conditions that are among the most desperate in Asia. Malnutrition is as common in the Philippines as it is in parts of sub-Saharan Africa.
A survey of more than one million children entering the first grade last year found that four out of five were malnourished, and that the vast majority were severely underweight.
Malnutrition is evident in the sickly, stick-thin bodies of the children of the village of Waling-Waling on the island of Mindanao. The village offers a typically bleak portrait of Philippine rural life.
Guialuson Maulana, a tenant farmer, hands over a fifth of his earnings from his tiny rice farm to the landlord. That leaves Mr. Maulana with about $80 a year.
Mr. Maulana's face is drawn, his shoulders slumped, and his four children look no healthier than their 32-year-old father. None of the children have ever seen a doctor or a dentist.
Mr. Maulana says his family survives on three meals a day of seasoned rice -- and most days, only rice, because there is no money for meat or fish.
"Sometimes I can find a few vegetables," he said with a shrug of resignation. "I am thankful for the rice. At least our stomachs feel full."

HEADLINE: Different Drummers;
One Man's Parade, Another's Parking Lot

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
This weekend, like every other spring weekend, the streets are filled with people exercising a privilege cherished by every group of citizens in New York: the right to inconvenience every other group of citizens in New York.
Yesterday, Times Square and Columbus Circle were occupied by throngs protesting the Contract With America. This morning, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and streets in all five boroughs are to be closed for 20,000 touring bicyclists. This afternoon, as Knicks fans drive in for the playoff game, they will find the Avenue of the Americas closed for a parade of Cubans, Fifth Avenue closed for a parade of African-American veterans, and stretches of Broadway and First Avenue closed for street fairs. 
 You could call it a fine day for New York's gorgeous mosaic, but people trying to go crosstown probably will see it differently. So do some economists, budget analysts and traffic engineers, who wonder if it is sensible to give away so many streets to private groups. They estimate that these events cost the public tens of millions of dollars a year -- partly in the pay of police and street cleaners, but mainly in the time wasted by people sitting in traffic jams.
In recent years, city streets have been closed for more than 100 parades annually, and since 1989 the annual number of large street fairs has doubled, reaching 400. There are thousands of other street closings for smaller fairs, political demonstrations and film production. Organizers of some of the largest street fairs pay a fee to the city and hire their own cleanup crews, but many of the city's costs are not reimbursed.
These events sometimes require extra police officers and sanitation workers on overtime pay at about $35 an hour, and the annual overtime bill for parades alone has amounted to $5 million for police, half a million for sanitation in recent years. Although police officials have cut some of these overtime costs -- they expect this year's tab to be less than $3.5 million -- they are still concerned about the number of officers on their regular shifts who must be reassigned to parades.
"We're tring to reduce the number and the size of parades by looking at the applications a little more carefully and encouraging some groups to combine their parades," said the police Chief of Department, Louis R. Anemone. "Parades not only cost us money for overtime, they force us to divert cops from normal duties."
It is hard to measure the inconvenience that parades cause, but engineers like to try. They estimate congestion costs by calculating how much time is wasted by people sitting in idling cars. For instance, according to a study by Brian Ketcham, a transportation consultant in Brooklyn, the daily parade of cars into the Lincoln and Holland tunnels produces $50 million in congestion costs for the motorists who are not using the tunnels but are stuck in the traffic jams near the entrances.
Mr. Ketcham said that no one has estimated the total toll taken by the city's parades, but he provided one small measure by calculating the disruption to be produced by today's parade celebrating Cuba's independence. He estimated that the parade, by closing down the Avenue of the Americas from 44th to 58th Streets for three hours, will delay 180,000 people an average of 15 minutes apiece as they drive through midtown. Valuing their lost leisure time at $5 an hour -- a relatively conservative estimate -- Mr. Ketcham calculated that the parade will produce $225,000 in congestion costs for motorists, as well as 10,000 extra pounds of carbon monoxide from their idling cars.
Like others, the Cuban parade does not pay fees, and its organizers do not see why it should. People who complain about inconvenience miss the point, said Jorge Mascaro, the president of the parade.
"Maybe those people are not tied into any roots," he said. "Maybe those people don't understand the multicultural status of New York City. The parade keeps our culture and our roots alive, and it brings all ethnic groups together. Parades make us understand each other."
His view is shared by plenty of others, who believe that it is churlish to do a cost-benefit analysis of events that produce so much intangible public good.
"Parades serve a big social function by validating a lot of marginal groups," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center. "They are for the middle classes what charity events and debutante balls are for the elite: a chance to show off your latest hairdo and to reflect in the halo of other people. This is one of the last cities where people still thrive on the streets and sidewalks, and I think we ought to encourage parades."
Nevertheless, a few people -- most of whom are not running for office anytime soon -- suggest that there might be fairer ways to pay for parades and other street events.
"When times are tough and services to New Yorkers are being cut, everyone should be asked to do their share," said Dean Mead, a senior research associate for the Citizens Budget Commission, the business-supported nonprofit group. "We should cut down the number of fairs and parades, and we should have the organizers contribute to the city's costs of running them."
Robert H. Frank has a more radical proposal. Dr. Frank, an economist at Cornell University, suggests that the city charge fees for parades according to all the costs they produce, from police to street cleaning to wasted time in traffic jams.
"The city could offer a menu of fees by location," Dr. Frank said. "A parade would cost you big bucks on Fifth Avenue, a lot less on Coney Island. Fees would encourage groups to minimize disruption and to look for creative alternatives for demonstrating that they've come of age. It's probably possible to find a way of proclaiming your presence that doesn't involve calling out the police and tying up traffic."
In some ways, Dr. Frank's proposal might be fairer to new groups, since they could at least bid for a parade on Fifth Avenue. Responding to complaints from merchants and residents along the most coveted parade route, the city has decided not to allow any new annual parades on Fifth Avenue, effectively discriminating in favor of established groups like the Irish against newcomers like the West Indians, whose parade in Brooklyn is now the city's largest.
City officials are setting up a central office to keep track of the various events -- parades, street fairs, movie shoots -- that are approved separately by different agencies. Until now, a lack of coordination, they said, has produced schedules like the one for May 21 -- a Sunday featuring the AIDS Walk, the Israeli Day Parade and the Ninth Avenue Food Festival -- and today's.
"This is exactly the kind of weekend we want to avoid in the future," Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter said. "Some commitments were made by people without knowing what else was going on. Street activity does help the city, but over the years more and more people have wanted to use the streets, and it's causing problems."
Ms. Reiter said that the city requires street fairs and some parades -- those that left behind exceptional messes in the past -- to post a bond covering cleanup costs. "We have never charged for police services," she said, "and I can't imagine that we ever will, except possibly for a profit-making event."
Not many other politicians can imagine trying to extract money from a parade organizer. They would offend not only the parade marchers themselves -- a voting bloc -- but also the affection that many other New Yorkers feel for parades, even noisy, inconvenient ones held by other ethnic groups.
"Every St. Patrick's Day the noise and the crowds and the litter are annoying," said Menachem Weinglas, a diamond dealer on West 47th Street. "The guys are out in front practicing on their drums and tubas, scaring away potential customers. But it's a small price to pay. The disruption does not outweigh the joy that it brings the people in these parades. I know how good I feel when I walk in a parade or watch one."
Tom Cusick, the president of the Fifth Avenue Association, agrees with that sentiment -- up to a point. "We know that people love parades, and we understand that everyone wants to be on Fifth Avenue," he said. "We certainly don't want to abolish parades here, but we want to remind people of other options. For instance, we think Park Avenue would be a wonderful place for a parade."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Moscow Visit: A Climate of Mutual Doubt

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, May 6

 BODY:
Not since the grim old days of the cold war have relations between the United States and Russia been quite as problematic as they are this weekend, on the eve of President Clinton's visit for celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe in World War II.
The man on whom Mr. Clinton has counted so heavily, President Boris N. Yeltsin, has been severely weakened at home and abroad by his army's devastating suppression of dissent in Chechnya. No longer Bill and Boris, buddy-buddies, the two leaders have squabbled over NATO expansion, Moscow's plans to sell a nuclear reactor to Iran and the fighting in Bosnia. 
 It is by no means certain that they will be able to patch things up when they meet on Wednesday after Tuesday's anniversary bash.
Indeed, American policy makers are not nearly as sure as they were only a year ago that Russia will evolve into a democracy, and they doubt that the United States can count on forming a solid strategic alliance with Moscow anytime soon.
Michael Mandelbaum of the Council on Foreign Relations, like other students of East-West affairs, speaks of "containing a smaller, no longer Communist, but still aggressive Russia" goaded into hard-line policies by resurgent nationalism.
But the Clinton Administration remains determined to make the best of the cooling relationship with Mr. Yeltsin. Describing Chechnya as a tragic setback, Richard C. Holbrooke, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, wrote in the spring issue of Foreign Affairs magazine, "If the forces of reform are embattled, the United States must reinforce, not retreat from, its support for them."
During the long debate over whether Mr. Clinton should make the trip, Secretary of State Warren Christopher argued for using the occasion to try to pry some concessions from the Russians on dicey issues. The President was able to win few if any guarantees during a long phone conversation with Mr. Yeltsin last week. American leverage now seems limited, with the Administration unwilling to cut American aid any further, despite growing disillusionment in Congress.
As a sign of disapproval of the overwhelming use of force in Chechnya, Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister John Major of Britain will shun a military parade in Moscow on Tuesday. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France will boycott not only that one but also a parade of World War II veterans in Red Square that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Major will attend.
Even so, it will be an uncomfortable moment for some in the Western delegations. Heroic as the Soviet Army and the Russians on the home front were, the record of Soviet soldiers in the war was "extremely mixed, to put the best possible face on it," the senior American diplomat said.
In addition to winning celebrated victories at Stalingrad and elsewhere, they forcibly occupied the Baltic republics and killed thousands of Poles in the massacre in Katyn Forest.
Here and in Moscow, the streets are decked with banners and posters and bunting, many bearing the hammer-and-sickle emblem of the old Communist regime whose troops fought the Nazis. On one of the first sparkling days of spring, young women in cotton dresses, young men in army uniforms and old-timers dressed in shabbier clothes carried flowers today to St. Petersburg's imposing war memorials.
Nearly 27 million Russians died between 1941 and 1945, more by far than died in all the other combatant nations combined. More than a million perished in the gruesome 900-day siege of Leningrad, as St. Petersburg was then known, many starving or freezing to death in temperatures that neared 30 below zero.
It was that immense Soviet sacrifice half a century ago that prompted Mr. Clinton's decision -- "a supremely personal decision, against the advice of some of us," one White House aide called it -- to celebrate V-E day not in Paris, London or Washington, as he well might have, but in Moscow.
Officials involved in planning the trip said Mr. Clinton planned to devote more time to meeting other Russian officials, including Mr. Yeltsin's rivals, than he did on his stay here in January 1994. Mr. Christopher sounded the theme in a briefing in Washington on Friday: "In the long run we will only have a good relationship with the Russian Government when we have a good relationship with the Russian people."
As he did last time, Mr. Clinton is expected to speak directly to them on television next week.
Though beleaguered by crime and government corruption, the Russians are beginning to feel the first slight benefits of economic reform. Yet bitterness over the loss of empire and their place in the front ranks of nations has proven a fertile forcing ground for nationalist extremists and hard-liners in the Russian military.
Mr. Yeltsin and other leaders are therefore determined to recover some of their influence in adjacent countries, not to lose more through the admission of Central European nations to the NATO alliance.
At a meeting in Budapest in December, Mr. Yeltsin denounced NATO expansion as anti-Russian. American officials hoped that was just a phase and that Russia would accede to plans for countries like Poland and the Czech Republic to join the alliance, so long as the pace was not too quick. The Americans are talking about admitting the new members within the next five years.
They consider it absolutely essential to stabilize Central Europe, the cockpit of conflict during the cold war and the point of origin of both of this century's world wars.
But Andrei V. Kozyrev, the Russian Foreign Minister, warned last month in Copenhagen that NATO enlargement would lead "to a nightmare of renewed confrontation." He also lamented that "the nationalists are using the enlargement of NATO to demonstrate the failure of our Government, including myself."
In an interview last week with Time magazine, Mr. Yeltsin sounded equally uncompromising. "Expanding NATO to the east" would "leave not only a dividing line on the map of Europe, it would also carve a deep scar in people's minds," he declared.
Some Administration officials think that a form of words can be worked out that would save face for Mr. Yeltsin; some do not. But all insisted that Moscow will not be given a veto over the fact or the timing of the expansion program. When the Czech Prime Minister, Vaclav Klaus, met with Mr. Clinton at the White House on Thursday, an American official reported, he asked a direct question.
"I want to know only one thing," he was said to have asked the President. "Are you going to Moscow and allowing Yeltsin to slow up this procedure?"
Mr. Clinton answered, "No."
On Chechnya and Bosnia, little progress appears possible, although Mr. Clinton may press for the extension of the cease-fire that the Russians have declared in Chechnya for the May 9 holiday.
Mr. Kozyrev has hinted at various times that Moscow might cancel or modify its $1 billion sale of nuclear equipment to Teheran. But Mr. Yeltsin has been adamant on this issue, too, and it is possible that Mr. Clinton will go home empty-handed.

HEADLINE: Poor Illinois Tenants Face Eviction After Public Complaint

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALORTON, Ill., May 6

 BODY:
There is a hole in the floor of the mobile home in which Pamela Taylor lives with her two young children. Cracks in the kitchen linoleum are big enough to trap her 1-year-old daughter.
Ms. Taylor, who is 24, single and unemployed, pointed to gaps under the kitchen sink. "I keep salt right there to keep the snails out because my baby tries to eat them," she said. 
 She said she was being evicted by her landlord, Callie Mobley, for speaking with a reporter last month about the poor housing conditions. Ms. Taylor said that she had sought help from half a dozen state and local agencies, but that they had said they had little or no say in the matter.
The problem is, she said, Ms. Mobley is also the Mayor of Alorton, a poor town in southwestern Illinois, just outside East St. Louis.
With Ms. Mobley as Mayor, it is virtually impossible to appeal an eviction, Ms. Taylor said. She did not even ask the six-member village board for help because she says it is nothing but a rubber stamp for the Mayor.
Another of Ms. Mobley's tenants, Vernard Harris, also spoke to the reporter, from the Belleville News-Democrat, and is also being evicted.
He agrees that it is hard to fight a landlord who is also the Mayor. "She's the boss out here," he said.
The two were told last month that they would be evicted, days after they had talked to the newspaper.
Ms. Mobley said they were being evicted because they were habitually late paying their rent. Although Ms. Taylor and Mr. Harris admit that they had fallen behind, they have offered to pay Ms. Mobley in full. The tenants are planning to go to court to challenge the evictions as retaliatory.
Mayor Mobley, in response, pointed out that she had not tried to evict two other tenants who had spoken to the newspaper. They pay their rent regularly, she said.
One of them is Ms. Taylor's neighbor, Monica Young, who told the newspaper that her heat had been broken since December.
The problem was fixed, but Ms. Young said her landlord "just doesn't really do her job like she's supposed to."
"You have to really beg or something, and I don't like that, especially when I'm paying my money every month," Ms. Young said.
Mayor Mobley rejects the accusation that she fails to maintain the property, which she and her husband own. She said that she had never been told about the problems and that the residents had caused most of the damage.
"Alorton is a poor community, but my property is no worse than anybody else's," said Ms. Mobley, who has been Mayor since 1981. She was re-elected in 1993.
Many residents of Alorton live on lots overrun by weeds, in ramshackle houses and more than 200 rusty mobile homes, where the smell of burning garbage fills the air.
The city requires that houses be inspected before people move in, but no inspection records are available. The Mayor said they might be among the village records seized in October by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for an investigation the agency would not discuss.
Mr. Harris, his wife and their three children lived in a two-bedroom house owned by Ms. Mobley for about two years; the rent is $300 a month.
The Harrises' house is across the street from the Mobleys' house, where a camper and a Cadillac are parked.
Mr. Harris said his 10-year-old daughter had fallen through a hole in the bathroom floor. It has been repaired, he said, but the heat does not work and standing water under the house attracts bugs and rats.

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: The Measure of a Summit

 BODY:
There was a sense of history in the making eight years ago, as Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev unexpectedly extended their Iceland summit talks into the night. With their planes poised for departure, the two men groped their way along the unexplored boundaries of nuclear arms control, only to turn back when the leap ahead seemed too great. The instant Mr. Reagan grimaced as he stiffly bade farewell to Mr. Gorbachev, a waiting world knew the meeting had ended in disappointment.
 The stuff of such high drama will be largely absent this week when President Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin meet in Moscow at a time of strained relations. Except for discussion of missile defense systems and Russian doubts about the still unratified 1992 arms reduction agreement, the likely agenda lacks the gravitas that invested cold-war summit meetings with singular importance. 
 Yet the nuclear stalemate, while far more threatening, was in some ways more ordered and manageable than relations today. The tidy universe of arms negotiators seeking the precise number of warheads acceptable to both sides has given way to disorderly wrangling over Russia's nuclear energy deals with Iran. The familiar issues of military demarcation in Europe between NATO and the Warsaw Pact have been replaced by a recondite debate over NATO expansion. Instead of concrete talks about the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan there are now inconclusive exchanges about ending the Russian offensive in Chechnya.
 As the relationship has changed, the American calculus used to evaluate summit meetings has not. It is still based predominantly on agreements reached and differences narrowed or more clearly defined. Those remain important considerations, but a broader definition is needed now that American interests revolve less around keeping the peace with Russia than building democracy in Russia.
 In an interview with Mr. Yeltsin published last week, Time magazine portentously asked him about "relations between the superpowers." That flattering formulation mistakenly perpetuates an image of Russian parity that makes this week's talks seem yet another summit meeting of contending and equal powers. Russia is a European and Asian power today primarily because of history and geography. Its struggling economy, hollow military and volatile political environment have long since rendered it considerably less than a global superpower.
 That precipitous fall has reinforced the defensive streak in Russian foreign policy and the nationalist streak in Russian politics. These may be the invisible forces that shape the Moscow meeting, and make it difficult to judge. No one in Washington can predict how Mr. Yeltsin will balance the need to build ties to the West with the domestic pressure to make Russia look strong and independent. With the rapid devolution of power in Russia, no one really knows for whom Mr. Yeltsin speaks.
 While one measure of summit success may be whether Moscow gives up its nuclear deal with Iran or drops its posturing about the 1992 arms agreement, evaluation should also rest on the quality of Mr. Clinton's conversation with the Russian people. For many Russians, the American President is the respected symbol of a stable, prosperous democracy, and they will listen intently when he speaks. As their own experiment in democracy proceeds unevenly, there is much Mr. Clinton can tell them about managing and maintaining liberty, and the benefits they will realize if they do.
 That may be the single most important thing he can do in Moscow. Mr. Reagan would no doubt have gladly exchanged the drama of his unplanned evening with Mr. Gorbachev for the opportunity to encourage a free Russia to remain that way.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
In My Next Life

BYLINE: By Thomas L. Friedman 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In my next life I want to be a European statesman.
 I want to be able to turn up my nose at the United States when it puts principle before profit and naively imposes an embargo on Iran to prevent this medieval theocracy from acquiring nuclear arms. I want to be able to tell the Americans with great arrogance that the right way to deal with Iran is through what European statesmen call "a critical dialogue." Which I assume means the Europeans criticize America and carry on a dialogue with the Iranians, while pocketing their cash. 
 If I can't be a European statesman, then in my next life I want to be a Japanese trade negotiator. I want to erect trade barriers around my country and then accuse whoever tries to break down those barriers of engaging in "managed trade." I want to be able to grossly underpay my country's workers, while I plow all my profits into building new markets abroad. And then when my currency soars in value against the dollar -- because I don't import anything from anyone -- I want to say with a straight face that the whole problem could be solved if the U.S. would just choke off its growth and raise its interest rates.
 If I can't be a Japanese trade negotiator, then in my next life I want to be a North Korean diplomat. I want to be able to defy the world, build nuclear weapons and then get the U.S. to bribe me with a safe nuclear reactor to halt my program -- without having to give up any of my bombs. And then, when the deal is done, I want to tell the Americans that I changed my mind, that I won't accept the reactor they are giving me free because it's made by my archenemy, South Korea, but that I still want Coca-Cola to open a bottling factory in my country.
 If I can't be a North Korean diplomat, then in my next life I want to be the head of the Russian Atomic Energy Commission. I want to sell nuclear technology to Iran, so that its cynical, hate-filled ayatollahs living near Russia's southern border will one day have a nuclear weapon with which to threaten Moscow. I want to do this because I can make lots of money and be a real power player in the Kremlin -- until the Iranians blow it up.
 If I can't be a Russian energy czar, then in my next life I want to be President of Serbia (or Croatia). I want to slick back my hair and wear tailored suits, while I stand before the world and deny perpetrating ghastly atrocities in order to cleanse my homeland of strangers. I want to give lots of interviews on CNN and declare that if only the world remembered the Battle of Kosovo, in 1389, it would understand why my people were the true victims and justified in slaughtering their neighbors.
 If I can't be President of Serbia, then in my next life I want to be a Republican Presidential candidate. I want to be able to repeal the ban on assault weapons so that paranoid private militias trying to subvert the Constitution will be much better armed to resist the police, F.B.I. and A.T.F. the next time they try to blow up a Federal building.
 If I can't be a Republican Presidential candidate, then in my next life I want to be Speaker of the House. I want to be able to have my mother call the First Lady a "bitch" on national TV. I want to denounce editorial writers and certain bureaucrats as "socialists." And I want to delegitimize the Federal Government. Then I want to be able to say it's "obscene" to suggest that my obscene language might have contributed to an atmosphere in which right-wing anti-government extremists feel so alienated from their fellow Americans that they would blow up a Federal building with a day-care center inside.
 If I can't be Speaker of the House, then in my next life I want to be one of O. J. Simpson's lawyers. Yes, I want to be a Harvard-trained hired gun who -- just like gun fanatics -- tries to undermine public faith in our legal system by inventing government conspiracies behind every drop of spilt blood.
 But if I can't be any of these, then in my next life I think I just want to be an American citizen.
 I want to be a member of the freest society in the world. I want to have a government that, with all its flaws, is occasionally ready to stand up and act on principle, not just profit. And I want to understand that preserving such a society is not automatic. It is something that has to be worked at every day. And it has to be worked at by nurturing a society where people appreciate that the government-is-us, that hate speech leads to hate acts, and that the civic courage to be a tolerant, law-abiding, tax-paying citizen is the greatest courage of all.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Jobless Rate Heads Upward . . .
So is it over? Did the Federal Reserve manage, all too well, to yank the economy to a crawl? It may seem so on the news that April unemployment jumped 0.3 points, to 5.8 percent, and payrolls fell for the first time in more than two years. But no, analysts said, the expansion is still alive -- but humbled. "This is not a recession," said the head of the National Association of Manufacturers. And Labor Secretary Reich saw "no evidence that the economy's going into reverse." The bond market like it just fine, as long-term interest rates headed down close to 7 percentCHECKKKKKKK, the lowest level in a year.
 
. . . but Layoffs Slow Down
But look at it another way. The truly wrenching part of the job picture in recent years has been the mass layoffs, which, properly placed, can devastate whole neighborhoods or towns. But according to the latest employment report from the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas, fewer layoffs were announced in April than in any month since May 1993. In fact, for 1995's first four months, the report said, layoffs were down by nearly half from last year. So even though unemployment is up, "wholesale cuts are slowing," said John Challenger, the firm's executive vice president. And "layoff figures are more indicative of how companies are looking at workforce reduction."
 
LIABILITY
 
Bankruptcy Over Implants?
The breast-implant mess keeps taking a toll -- and not just on the true victims, the women involved. Last week Dow Corning, facing 20,000 lawsuits, said it might have to file for bankruptcy protection, which would put a halt to all the litigation. Not that it would be broke. The company is owned by Dow Chemical and Corning, and also last week came news that Marion Merrell Dow -- 71 percent owned by Dow Chemical -- would be bought by Hoechst of Germany. What that means in the industry is yet another huge merger, this one creating the world's No. 2 drug maker, right after Glaxo Wellcome. And what it means for Dow Chemical is $5.1 billion (out of a total purchase price of $7.1 billion) to help it with implant settlements.
 
TELEVISION
 
Danger! Ad Rates on the Loose!
Wait a second. Hasn't everyone in the universe already seen "Jurassic Park" 11 times? Well, NBC clearly hopes they'll make it an even dozen, for it paid $50 million for the rights to broadcast it, the first showing being tonight. And advertisers are paying $650,000 for 30-second spots -- an otherworldly figure that puts the event (that's the way NBC wants you to think of it, as an "event," not a mere "movie") up there with such pivotal moments in world history as this year's Academy Awards or the "Cheers" finale in 1993. (Of course, it's still well behind recent Super Bowl ad rates, which are too absurd to mention.) Among the advertisers, of course, is the Ford Explorer -- which, you'll recall, got rather unkind treatment from Mr. Rex.
 
AUTOS
 
It's Drizzling in Detroit
Well, Chrysler has been saying -- to fend off pesky takeover offers -- that it needed its $7.5 billion nest egg in case rainy days returned, and it may be right. Last week auto makers said sales were slipping badly -- off 6.1 percent in April, the fourth straight monthly drop. (One exception: Ford keeps selling light trucks; they rose 16 percent.) What's up? For one thing, even as interest rates ease, car-loan rates stay stubbornly high -- not to mention car prices. Maybe it's just part of a slowing economy. And maybe, with so many good used cars around -- thanks in part to leasing -- buyers don't care so much about shiny and new. But whatever the reason, watch for more rebates and good deals.
 
BLAME GAME
 
A Team Effort at Barings
Nicholas Leeson is still in a Frankfurt jail, taking most of the heat for the collapse of Barings two months ago. But the new owner of what's left of Barings -- the Dutch company ING -- decided last week that it was unlikely that Mr. Leeson was the lone gunman, the supervillain of the piece. Without ladling out fixed doses of guilt, ING ousted 21 top Barings executives, saying they had "functional responsibility" for the mess at the Singapore outpost. The clear message: Even if those executives didn't know the disastrously risky road Mr. Leeson was taking, they should have known.
 
BANKING
 
Tellers With a Difference
Yes, First Chicago had any number of sound, sober reasons for that $3 teller fee. And who knows -- maybe it is the best way to keep banking costs low for the low of balance. But let's face it: walking freely up to a teller (after waiting in line, of course) is right up there with sunshine and tulips -- it seems almost a constitutional right. Tinker with tulips and you make yourself an awfully easy target for all manner of reactions, from indignant to teasing. And sure enough, some Chicago-area banks had a field day, as Lake Forest Bank gave $3 to customers after their transactions were finished, and a Harris branch handed out dollar bills to customers who asked whether it charged fees. What did Richard Thomas, First Chicago's chairman, think of all this? "A little silly," he said.
 
NEWSPAPERS
 
NEWS TO 42D ST.: SO LONG
In 1930, The Daily News built an Art Deco temple for itself on -- where else? -- 42d Street, the center of the known universe. The building so resonated with nostalgic newspaperdom that it was used as a set in the "Superman" movies. But like the world, The News has changed. In 1947, its daily circulation was 2.4 million; today, the paper's bruises still healing from labor battles, it's scarcely a third of that. The payroll has plunged from 9,000 to a little over 1,000. The presses left the 42d Street building more than a decade ago. And last week The News made its biggest symbolic break with its past, leaving that home behind and moving to a single floor across town -- one with the high-tech bells and whistles deemed necessary for a modern paper.
 
PUBLISHING
 
Today's News (Net Wt., 12 Oz.)
And here's another sign of changing journalistic times: when Times Mirror named a new chief executive last week, it wasn't someone from the ranks but Mark Willes, a General Mills vice chairman with no media experience. His message: "Start from the consumer," strive to be "the low-cost producer," "refresh" products just as food companies tinker with cereals and cake mixes. Yes, many newspapers are hurting -- Times Mirror's two big papers, The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, reported big circulation drops last week. But what's coming? Banner headlines saying "Light and Fluffy" or "Only 17 Calories"?
 
BROADCASTING
 
The Murdoch Exemption
Some matters, it seems, transcend the laws of the land -- matters like Rupert Murdoch's ownership of American TV stations. Yes, the F.C.C. said last week, Mr. Murdoch and his News Corp. had violated foreign-ownership laws -- but the agency said it had no intention of doing anything about it. No fines, no drastic cutbacks in his ownership stake. Why? As one commissioner, James Quello, put it, the "compelling public interest" lay in the creation of a fourth network to promote competition. As for Mr. Murdoch, he rejoiced that the "meritless, wild and malicious charges of some of our competitors" had been rejected. But of course the ownership issue was clearly not meritless -- just rejected.

HEADLINE: Isolating Nuclear Iran Endangers World Health

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "The Iran Embargo" (editorial, May 2) ignores the most serious side effect of further isolating Iran through pressure on Russia to cancel its planned sale to Iran of nuclear reactors. Technologically isolating Iran would result in a vicious cycle of more radicalization and isolation. 
 Iran, determined to develop its nuclear energy option, will acquire components for reactor systems from many sources, which could be scattered in different countries. This could result in a piecemeal assemblage of incompatible parts of questionable reliability in an untested reactor with no operational track record and obsolete safety systems.
 The radioactive fallout from the 1986 Chernobyl accident in Ukraine spread death and disease across the world, including the United States. Chernobyl taught the harsh lesson that a nuclear accident anywhere is an accident everywhere. An Iranian reactor that is hastily or secretly designed and untested will pose much higher risk to the health of Americans and to the environment than a well-designed, tested and safely operated one.
 The best control is through the integration of one country's technology with that of other countries, such that no one component can operate independently of the whole system. Interdependency and correlation among technologies provide more oversight, control and assurance than restrictions and isolation.
 The United States deal with North Korea for developing and installing light-water reactors is a step in the right direction and an example of a new paradigm in foreign policy that should be duplicated elsewhere.
 
NAJMEDIN MESHKATI
Los Angeles, May 4, 1995
The writer, an associate professor at the University of Southern California, conducts research on nuclear power plant safety.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
The Mayor of Kentucky Avenue

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
HE IS an example of what Atlantic City politics have never, ever been. In a city of blustering movers and shakers both inside and outside the casino industry, Sidney Trusty is so soft-spoken that if he weren't six feet tall, you wouldn't know he was there.
Yet when he lumbers past a low-income housing project, settles in to a plate of ribs and greens at Shotgun's Westside Restaurant on Hummock Avenue or sits down to watch a council meeting in City Hall, so many people wave at him, call him "mayor" or buttonhole him with the latest gossip that you know you're with an authentic power broker. 
 When Mayor James Whelan, who is white, was asked if he'd needed the support of Mr. Trusty, who is black, when he won his second term, he replied: "Unquestionably. Sid's a bridge builder. He can go into any neighborhood, deal with anybody from the highest to the lowest, and he will be received, well respected and liked. In a racially divided city, he's been able to help heal the racial divisions."
In a city where local politics has wide-ranging effects on the way casinos operate and the manner in which state revenue is spent, Mr. Trusty likes to operate as an almost, but not quite, invisible man. He attends every public meeting and takes careful notes on who votes and why. He rarely makes public comments. He doesn't give speeches. His most visible job, and the one he's proudest of, has to do with history, not politics: he is historian of the city's small black history museum, the Kentucky Avenue Museum.
He got into politics almost as an afterthought. The adopted son of an Atlantic City butler and a maid, he performed as a drummer in local nightclubs. He was a policeman and a waiter in the hotels, ran a Boardwalk bowling alley, was a vice president and business agent of Local 708 of the musicians' union and edited a national bowling newspaper. He drove a cab for 34 years, retiring at the age of 70. At that point, he said, "I had the time to follow up on things."
"I never got involved directly in politics," he went on, "but I kept my eyes on what was going on. In the beginning, when somebody wanted to know why it was that all the money from the casinos that was supposed to help the city was going out of the city, I could tell them that it was the greedy politicians, and I could tell them who these politicians were.
"I was like a drummer, you know, in the back, keeping the time. You show off, you try to get attention on yourself, you're going to miss the beat. Your power comes from staying on the beat."
Because he doesn't gamble, Mr. Trusty doesn't have much use for the casinos. But unlike many residents, he doesn't blame the casinos for the city's problems.
"The casinos have done their share, as far as I'm concerned," he said. "They're here. They're open for business. You stick your nose into what a business has to do just to stay open in this town, and you'll have a lot of respect for them."
Respect, but not necessarily admiration. The benefits of legalized casino gambling have eluded many grandchildren and great-grandchildren of the black and Hispanic working people who were once the backbone of the city's economy -- hotel workers, restaurant cooks, fishermen. They have claimed few significant positions in casinos' upper management. They have seen entire neighborhoods destroyed before casino-financed low- and middle-income housing projects could take hold in the North and South Inlet. Many are still resentful of a state corruption investigation that ended the political career of James L. Usry, the city's first black Mayor.
As cruel as the city's racial polarization has been, Mr. Trusty says, it could have been much worse. "I am fundamentally a historian," he said. "Sure, there was racism in this city, but not as bad as other cities. There was a life here, a vitality that attracted people, white and black, from New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, Washington, D.C., to Kentucky Avenue, where the greatest entertainers worked the greatest nightclubs you ever saw. On Kentucky Avenue, there was no racism -- just people having a good time.
"That's my city. That's the city I remember. We're going to bring that back again. Just you wait."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Past and present: Sid Trusty in the Kentucky Avenue Museum, which houses an exhibition of Atlantic City black history. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Downsizing Impedes Rebound

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE road to recovery is full of potholes, commercial real estate professionals say. The county's office market got off to a slow start in the first quarter of the year, with corporate downsizing leaving vacancy rates higher and resulting in a surplus of office space.
While much of the action in the market is a result of steady leasing activity of small to mid-size companies -- the industry's "bread and butter" -- the continued downsizing by Westchester's largest corporate employers remains a hindrance to sustained recovery of the office market, said William V. Cuddy Jr., senior vice president of the Rostenberg-Doern Company, an independently owned real estate concern in the Westchester-Fairfield region specializing in corporate real estate brokerage and consulting. 
 "Most of the vacant space in the county, over 75 percent of it, has been generated by just two corporate downsizings, I.B.M. and Nynex," Mr. Cuddy said, adding that consolidations by Advantis, an I.B.M.-Sears joint venture, and Nynex returned almost 370,000 square feet of leased office space to the marketplace during the first quarter.
A recent survey of the Westchester office market made by Rostenberg-Doern showed a negative absorption of 489,596 square feet of Class A and B office space for the quarter. The countywide vacancy for the quarter was 24.9 percent, up from 22.3 percent at the end of last year.
"The good news is that there are positive signs that the market will begin to rebound," Mr. Cuddy said. "Steady leasing activity looks good for the rest of the year. I think it's safe to anticipate that the pace we will see will be similar to that we had during the early to mid-80's with the same brisk market."
There have already been encouraging signs of change, he said, "Companies in Manhattan are looking at space in downtown White Plains partly because of the good train service but primarily because of the rent differential, which is significant. There is a spread of $10 to $15 a foot for Class A office space."
Despite the unfortunate contractions of I.B.M. and Nynex, John Halpern, president of Halpern Enterprises in Tarrytown, says the resurgence of office leasing activity proves that tenants believe real estate in Westchester is a good product. "They are further attracted by the quality of life here, which is a big draw," Mr. Halpern said.
At Halpern Enterprises Tarrytown Corporate Center, a multi-use office park of 1.2 million square feet in Tarrytown, 98 percent of the space in the park has been re-leased in the last 12 months, Mr. Halpern said.
"I think of our center as a microcosm of the larger market," he said, "There are so many similarities. Even at the depths of the recession, when I.B.M. pulled out and left us with 450,000 square feet of vacant space, which was 35 percent of the Tarrytown Corporate Center, at the end of the day, the bread and butter companies kept on leasing. Big users, those who take large blocks of space -- 100,000 square feet or more -- like Ciba and Mastercard, will change the market, but it's the small and mid-sized users who are the guts of the industry."
Ciba's decision to relocate its corporate headquarters and additives division from Ardsley into two existing buildings at the Tarrytown Corporate Center was completed at a closing in March. Now under renovation are 540 White Plains Road, a 120,000-square-foot, six-floor office building purchased by Ciba, and 520 White Plains Road, a 170,000-square-foot, six-floor office building leased by Ciba. In addition, a 160,000-square-foot, $40 million laboratory is under construction at the Tarrytown Corporate Center.
"Ciba's renewed commitment to Westchester means that 1,000 jobs will remain in Westchester and tens of millions of dollars will be invested in the county," Mr. Halpern said. "Ciba and deals like it are a sign the recession is behind us."
Among the companies signing significant leases in the first quarter were Dansk International Design. Dansk's lease for 25,873 square feet at 108 Corporate Park Drive in White Plains was the largest new lease in the county for the first quarter.
Frank Tomasulo, first vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate Group in White Plains, which is representing Dansk, views the company's move from Mount Kisco to White Plains "as a positive indicator of Westchester's vitality and continuing ability to attract and retain national and international corporations who want to enjoy prime facilities and comfortable life style."
"There is good leasing activity going on in the county," he continued. "We have leased in excess of 426,000 square feet this quarter, primarily to small and mid-sized tenants."
At the end of last month, Mr. Tomasulo said, his company completed a major deal, the sale for more than $18 million of the 213,000-square-foot Christiania Building at 120 White Plains Road in Tarrytown to J. P. Morgan Investments in Manhattan.
"The Christiania Building is 90 percent leased," Mr. Tomasulo said. "The J. P. Morgan Company bought it as an investment property. What is significant is that it shows that Westchester is viewed as being desirable and one of the most highly regarded locations in the country."
When Eastridge Properties took over 18 buildings that formerly belonged to the Shulman Group on Westchester Avenue in White Plains, the vacancy rate was 25 percent.
"That was a little over three years ago," said Michael J. Ziatyk, Eastridge's managing director. "Now 90 percent of the space, two million square feet total, is rented to small and middle-size users. Most of them in the range of 2,000 to 25,000 square foot space requirements."
Rents, he said, have risen only slightly but concession packages -- free rent and tenant improvements -- have become less generous.
"Much of the activity we're seeing has been from intra-county upgrades," he said, "mainly coming from law and accounting firms, architectural practices, entrepreneurial companies, whose principals are seeking a good location close to home in order to shorten commutes with only a handful -- 10 percent -- of our tenants relocating to Westchester from Manhattan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Tarrytown Corporate Center, tenants have been found for 98 percent of the space. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FOR AMERICA, IT TRULY WAS A GREAT WAR

BYLINE: By ALAN BRINKLEY; Alan Brinkley, professor of American history at Columbia University, is the author of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War," recently published by Knopf.

 BODY:
AMERICA WAS BOOMING. America was at war. Men and women were working again. Men and women were dying. There were dreams of a new world order. There were fears of a new Depression. For Americans, more than for any other combatants, World War II was a paradoxical experience -- simultaneously horrifying and exhilarating. For all the fervor with which Americans committed themselves to a great national cause, they were terrified at the possibility of losing the struggle -- a possibility that seemed particularly real in that first difficult year after Pearl Harbor -- and of having to live in a world dominated by tyranny. Even as the war neared its end and victory seemed assured, optimism mingled with doubt; and several very different ideas about the nation, the world and the future seized the American imagination. Fifty years later, many of those ideas seem relics of a more innocent time. But perhaps for that very reason, they resonate still in the stories World War II veterans tell about themselves, and in the imaginations of their children and grandchildren.
FEW AMERICANS WHO GAVE SERIOUS THOUGHT TO WHAT THE WAR had been about could avoid feeling profound anxiety in 1945, as they contemplated the beginning of the postwar era. World War II had revealed a human capacity for evil and destruction that exceeded even the darkest assumptions of previous eras. It had been a war against militarized tyrannies, a war to stop nearly a decade of brutal, naked expansionism. It was a war to avenge what Franklin Roosevelt called the "dastardly" Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941. And gradually, as news of the Holocaust had filtered out of Europe to an incredulous world, it became for some Americans a war against genocide, against a madness so terrible that many people, even when faced with incontrovertible evidence of its existence, found the knowledge of it unassimilable. 
 How could anyone absorb such horror and not fear for the future of mankind? A world that could create so terrible a war, a world that could produce Auschwitz and Dachau, the Katyn Forest, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, a world capable of such profound evil and such inconceivable destruction: it was necessary, some men and women now began to argue, to regard such a world suspiciously, even fearfully.
For some Americans, those fears led to an increased skepticism of the power of government -- a skepticism driven by the kind of state power that in Germany, Italy and Japan had produced tyranny, war and genocide. Many liberals continued to argue that an active government need not lead a nation down so dark a path. But others were less certain. In 1944, the Austrian-emigre economist Friedrich Hayek published "The Road to Serfdom," a stark warning against any increase in the powers of government (including, he made clear, the New Deal reforms of the 1930's). For any such increase, he argued, represented a step toward fascism. "It is necessary now," he wrote in his impassioned introduction, "to state the unpalatable truth that it is Germany whose fate we are in some danger of repeating." "The Road to Serfdom" was a major best seller. Not unlike Allan Bloom's "Closing of the American Mind" decades later, it captured some of the popular anxieties of its moment.
Less conservative figures rejected the starkness of Hayek's warnings. But they, too, were suddenly racked with doubts. Among them was the great liberal theologian Reinhold Niebuhr. "The rise of totalitarianism," he noted somberly late in the war, "has prompted the democratic world to view all collectivist answers to our social problems with increased apprehension." Hence "a wise community will walk warily and test the effect of each new adventure before further adventures."
For some, the lessons of the war included a deeper challenge to one of the nation's oldest faiths. Americans, they argued, must resist the temptation to think of themselves in their hour of triumph as a chosen people. No nation could afford to revel too much in its own virtue because in doing so it might ignore the darkness near the center of its (and every society's) soul. Niebuhr spoke for many liberals when he wrote of the dangers of "a deep layer of Messianic consciousness in the mind of America" and warned of liberal culture's "inability to comprehend the depth of evil to which individuals and communities may sink, particularly when they try to play the role of God in history." Americans, he said, would do well to remember that "no nation is sacred and unique. . . . Providence has not set Americans apart from lesser breeds. We too are part of history's seamless web."
But Niebuhr's statement was obviously meant to refute a competing assumption. As it suggests, there were also very different cultural forces at work in America during World War II. The war, after all, had been that rare thing in American life: a universally shared experience, a truly collaborative, collective effort (perhaps the nation's last) that had engaged the energies of almost everyone and had propelled the nation to victory and prosperity. As terrible as they knew the war itself to be, the men and women who remained in the United States -- thousands of miles from the fighting and the death -- drew considerable satisfaction, even joy, from their experiences in the war years.
They did so in large part because the war had brought an end at last to the Great Depression and had ushered in a great economic boom that would last, with only a few interruptions, for 30 years. The vast productive power of the United States supplied its own armed forces and those of its allies with airplanes, ships, tanks and ammunition. It fed, clothed and housed the American people. And it helped feed, clothe and house much of the rest of the world as well. Alone among the major nations, the United States faced the future in 1945 with an intact and thriving industrial economy.
Abundance created a striking buoyancy in American life during the early 1940's. Suddenly, people had money to spend again and -- despite the many shortages of consumer goods -- at least some things to spend it on. The theater and movie industries did record business. Resort hotels, casinos and race tracks were jammed. Advertisers, and at times even the Government, exhorted Americans to support the war effort on the grounds that victory would insure a future of material comfort and consumer choice for themselves and their children. "Your people are giving their lives in useless sacrifice," The Saturday Evening Post wrote in a mock letter to the leaders of wartime Japan. "Ours are fighting for a glorious future of mass employment, mass production and mass distribution and ownership." Even troops at the front seemed at times to justify their efforts with reference to the comforts of home more than to the character of the enemy or the ideals America claimed to be defending. "They are fighting for home," the writer John Hersey once wrote from Guadalcanal (with at least a trace of dismay), because "home is where the good things are -- the generosity, the good pay, the comforts, the democracy, the pie."
And yet, as Hersey's assessment suggests, abundance was not necessarily the enemy of idealism. Democracy, he argued, was part of the mix. In the 1930's, the fear was often voiced that democracy had exhausted itself because it had failed to produce the economic success on which a good society depended. By 1945, democracy had become America's central "fighting faith," triumphantly vindicated by prosperity and prepared to take on new challenges, both at home and abroad.
NOWHERE WAS THE CONFLUENCE OF ABUNDANCE AND democracy clearer than in the experiences of African-Americans during the war. Prosperity transformed the economic circumstances of many black men and women; the war -- and its democratic rationale -- transformed their expectations.
Nearly two million African-Americans left the rural South in the 1940's, most of them in search of the industrial jobs in the North that the war had helped produce. Among the results of this massive migration were new demands for racial justice. A. Philip Randolph's threat to stage a great march on Washington in 1941 spurred Franklin Roosevelt to create the Fair Employment Practices Committee, which sought to guarantee blacks access to jobs in war industries. But protests continued throughout the war. In Washington, Detroit and other cities, there were demonstrations against discrimination -- picketing, sit-ins, at times violence -- that anticipated the civil rights movement of the 60's.
Early in 1944, the publication of a remarkable book -- Gunnar Myrdal's "American Dilemma" -- helped galvanize the urgency of their cause. Myrdal, an eminent Swedish sociologist whom the Carnegie Foundation had commissioned in 1938 to supervise a major examination of America's "race problem," described the "American dilemma" in part as an economic problem -- the failure of American society to extend its riches to its black citizens. But it was also a moral dilemma -- a problem in the hearts and minds of white Americans, a problem born of the impossible attempt to reconcile a commitment to freedom and democracy with the willingness to deny one group of citizens a set of basic rights guaranteed to everyone else. In the shadow of Nazi tyranny, such a contradiction seemed to Myrdal -- and to many readers of his book -- especially glaring. "An American Dilemma" helped define a moment in history, and its reputation grew so rapidly that to many Americans, white and black, its findings soon came to seem almost unassailable. The war didn't provoke a stern resolve to address what most Americans still called "the Negro problem," but it altered the country's racial geography. A system of segregation and oppression that had been dismally stable for more than half a century would never be stable again.
IN MUCH THE SAME AMBIGUOUS WAY, THE WAR ENCOURAGED many women to question their place in American life. More than 4.5 million women joined the paid work force during World War II (raising the total number of working women by almost a third). Many of them took traditionally male jobs that were suddenly vacant as young men left the factories to join the military -- hence the famous image of Rosie the Riveter. And a lot of them found the experience transforming. In the absence of fathers, brothers, husbands and boyfriends, many women lived, worked and traveled alone for the first time in their lives. Some joined unions. Others wore uniforms. For some, it was an experience of unprecedented freedom; as a female aircraft worker later recalled, "It really opened up another viewpoint on life."
The popular folklore of the time depicted Rosie the Riveter as a woman pitching in to win the war but eager to get home to her family. In fact, most working women came to the end of the war determined not to resume a purely domestic life. Some lost their jobs when peace arrived and the men came home, but most of those who did looked for work somewhere else. The number of females in the paid work force never declined to its prewar levels, and it continued to grow throughout the 1950's and beyond.
The war created very different expectations among many men, especially those at the front -- expectations that they would return to a world where things were more or less the way they had been before. Fighter pilots gave their planes female names and painted bathing beauties on their fuselages. Sailors pasted pinups inside their lockers; infantrymen carried them (along with pictures of wives, mothers and girlfriends) in their knapsacks. Such images were not just a reflection of desire. They were a reflection of how many soldiers and sailors wanted to remember home.
The most popular wartime female icon was Betty Grable -- five million pictures of her found their way into the hands of fighting men by 1945. She was a mildly erotic figure to be sure. But as the historian Robert Westbrook has noted, she was not really a sex goddess. In her films, she generally played wholesome, innocent young women, the kind any guy would want to marry. And she became a model at the front for the supportive, nurturing girlfriend or wife many servicemen dreamed of finding on their return. After she married the bandleader Harry James and had a child in 1943, the men at the front seemed to find her even more appealing. When John Hersey compiled his list of the comfortable images that motivated many G.I.'s to fight ("the generosity, the good pay, the comforts, the democracy, the pie"), he might well have added another: the image of a world of traditional heterosexual romance.
THE WAR INSPIRED A GREAT DEAL MORE THAN DREAMS OF NEW freedoms and comforts at home. Among some men and women, it inspired a vision of a world made over in the American image. Despite the warnings of Niebuhr and others of the dangers of self-righteousness, World War II greatly reinforced the vision of America as a special moral force in the world; America as a country insulated from the sins and failures and travails that affected other nations, standing somehow outside of history, protected by its own strength and virtue. "America stands at this moment at the summit of the world," Winston Churchill told the House of Commons as the war neared its end. Walter Lippmann wrote at about the same time: "What Rome was to the ancient world, what Great Britain has been to the modern world, America is to be to the world of tomorrow."
World War II did not create those beliefs. They are as old as the nation itself. But the American experience in the conflict, and the radically enhanced international stature and responsibility of the United States in the aftermath of the war, gave them new strength. Bringing American values and institutions to the world became, for some, a crusade -- as vital to the future as the war itself.
It was not just the contrast between America's democratic potential and the autocracies of Germany and Japan that shaped these expansive visions. There was also a strengthened sense that the United States -- triumphantly prosperous, anointed by victory -- had something worth sharing with all nations, a unique commitment to freedom and justice that could serve as a model for the rest of the world. Certainly that was the message of Henry R. Luce, the crusading founder and publisher of Time and Life magazines. In 1941, Luce published a small book titled "The American Century." In it, he sketched a picture of the nation's destiny that only slightly exaggerated what would come to be, by the late 1940's, a widely shared and increasingly powerful view -- a vision in which American abundance and American idealism seamlessly merged. The American century, Luce wrote, "must be a sharing with all peoples of our Bill of Rights, our Declaration of Independence, our Constitution, our magnificent industrial products, our technical skills." For "we are the inheritors of all the great principles of Western civilization -- above all Justice, the love of Truth, the ideal of Charity."
Luce's language may have been bombastic, but the ideas he expressed -- the belief that America had a postwar mission and special virtues worth sharing with other peoples -- penetrated deep and helped reconcile many Americans to the crusading international role that victory had thrust upon the nation.
In the glow of that victory, in the sense of old orders shattered and a new world being born, came an era of exuberant innovation, an era in which, for a time, nothing seemed more appealing than the Modern, the New. The allure of the new was manifest in the confident vision of architectural modernists, whose controversial legacy is so much a part of the postwar American landscape. It was manifest in the explosive growth of the innovative and iconoclastic American art world, which made New York in the 1940's and 1950's what Paris had been in the 19th century: the capital of international art. It was manifest in the increased stature and boldness of the American scientific community, and in the almost religious faith with which Americans welcomed technological progress.
And it was manifest in the way it excited, and then frustrated, a generation of American liberals imagining new forms of progress and social justice. For out of the war they brought, and sustained for 20 years, a commitment to a new political order. Wartime abundance, they believed, had vindicated Keynesian economics -- the alluring conviction that governments could sustain prosperity and economic growth indefinitely through enlightened use of their fiscal powers (spending and taxation) rather than by intervening directly in the affairs of capitalist institutions. Liberals also envisioned an abundant nation expanding and perfecting a generous welfare state to redeem the blighted lives of those cast aside by capitalism's imperfections. Such visions found only limited popular sympathy in the turbulent and divisive years immediately following the war. But they survived to become the basis of some of the great, and now controversial, liberal crusades of the 1960s.
In 1943, the poet and war administrator Archibald MacLeish gave a speech at Berkeley in which he expressed something of the extravagant hopes embraced by so many men and women of his time. He described the "Unimagined America," the new society the war was encouraging Americans to create:
"We have, and we know we have, the abundant means to bring our boldest dreams to pass -- to create for ourselves whatever world we have the courage to desire. We have the metal and the men to take this country down, if we please to take it down, and to build it again as we please to build it . . . to brighten the air, to clean the wind, to live as men in this Republic, free men, should be living. . . . We stand at the moment of the building of great lives, for the war's end and our victory in the war will throw that moment and the means before us."
In retrospect, of course, it is easy to see the many flaws in these expansive visions of a new postwar world: the dangerous arrogance they at times helped create, the reckless and at times disastrous experiments they helped launch, the intractable problems they helped bring to the surface and then proved unable to solve. But it is also difficult to look at today's world -- a world of diminished expectations and profound cynicism -- without finding something appealing about the brief and admittedly deceptive moment when large numbers of Americans, at the close of the most catastrophic war in human history, found it possible to believe that a brave new world was at hand.
