HEADLINE: Hitting the Road

BYLINE: By Jonathan Franzen; Jonathan Franzen is the author of the novels "Strong Motion" and "The Twenty-seventh City."

 BODY:

RULE OF THE BONE
By Russell Banks.
390 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $22. 
ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S famous mot regarding "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" -- that all modern American literature comes from one book by Mark Twain -- is no less apt for being an overstatement. In its pioneering of the vernacular first person, its search for authentic American experience among the dispossessed and traditionally voiceless and its use of comedy to bring home grim realities in ways that gravity cannot, "Huckleberry Finn" is a bantamweight story with a heavyweight's impact. Of the many writers working in the great tradition today, one of the best is Russell Banks. In novels like "Affliction" and "Continental Drift" Mr. Banks has deepened Hemingway's investigation of American maleness, lending a voice to working-class fathers who want to be "good" men but are reduced, by economic brutalities and some essential rage riding on the Y chromosome, to bad ones. Now, in "Rule of the Bone," his 12th book, Mr. Banks has returned to the source of sources and reinvented "Huckleberry Finn."
The narrator of "Rule of the Bone" is not a river rat but a mall rat, a boy named Chappie from Au Sable Forks, N.Y., who sports a nose ring and a Mohawk and tells his story in underpunctuated deadpan sentences: "Anyhow my life got interesting you might say the summer I turned 14 and was heavy into weed but I didn't have any money to buy it with so I started looking around the house all the time for things I could sell but there wasn't much." In his parents' closet, Chappie finds a cache of old coins that he can pawn in small batches. It's a teen-age weed fiend's dream, but, as he sadly admits, he's a clumsy thief. His mother and stepfather throw him out of the house, and he embarks on a lowlife tour of upstate New York, dealing dope at the local mall and hiding out with a brutish motorcycle gang called Adirondack Iron. Mr. Banks has the milieu down cold. "I can hear Megadeth thumping through the walls," Chappie says, "and I can smell dope smoke and pizza and can hear the refrigerator being opened and closed and the top-popping of beer cans. Adirondack Iron is having its breakfast."
Chappie shares with his precursor Huck Finn an abusive (step)father, against whom his only defense is to harden himself into a criminal. He shoplifts and trespasses, indulges in some random vandalism and (in a pinch) helps steal a truck; he is also, like Huck, presumed dead for a while. Skipping town, he has himself tattooed with a crossbones and rechristens himself Bone. This is potentially a Beavis and Butt-head moment, but Mr. Banks is so sure of Bone's voice that he can instill silly posturing with the poignancy of an adolescent groping for an identity.
Rewarding his loyal readers, Mr. Banks weaves into "Rule of the Bone" the fishing boat from "Continental Drift" and the school bus that crashed in "The Sweet Hereafter," a bus now inhabited by a pair of crackheads who claim to be the brothers of the girl who was crippled in the accident. Returning to this bus after various adventures, Bone encounters the novel's Jim character, a runaway migrant farm worker from Jamaica who calls himself I-Man. Bone and I-Man make a home in the bus, with a kitchen garden and a cash crop of cannabis, and it's here, as Mr. Banks trades the aimless fun of the picaresque for the moral responsibilities of the Bildungsroman, that the story flags a little. The genre dictates that Bone learn lessons from I-Man, and although Mr. Banks is too good a novelist to dehumanize I-Man with saintliness, the reader may squirm at the alacrity with which Bone embraces the manners, the philosophy, even the cooking, of the old Jamaican. In these middle chapters, Bone verges on the naive sanctimony of white Rastafarians who have found a Better Way.
Fortunately, I-Man's homesickness propels the story southward to Jamaica, where drug dealing, sex and violence re-energize it. Along the way, Bone sneers at American vacationers who are "too scared of black people to buy ganja from them," and you wonder if the author, whose knowledge of backwoods Jamaica is obviously firsthand, isn't sneering a little himself. More bravely than almost any other contemporary writer, however, Mr. Banks is wrestling with what it means to be a white man in a multicultural world. A central insight of his oeuvre is the kinship of frustrated Snow Belt whites with desperate black Caribbeans, and in "Rule of the Bone," by reinterpreting Twain, he extends that insight to the whole tangle of race relations in America: the evil isn't whiteness but the white political economy, and the abuse of any child, black or white, is tantamount to slavery. This may sound somewhat heavy, but for the most part the book itself is not. Mr. Banks is a mythmaker who understands that before a myth can matter it has to entertain.
"Rule of the Bone" invites comparison not only with "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" but also, somewhat unflatteringly, with "The Catcher in the Rye." Bone is more generic and less funny than Holden Caulfield, and unlike Holden, he displays an odd immunity to pop culture. It's as if J. D. Salinger registered 40 years in advance a commercialized teen-age reality that Mr. Banks himself shies away from. Mr. Banks also falls short of Mr. Salinger's artistry in filtering acute psychological observation through vernacular distortion. But the comparison is not entirely fair. In his social and economic privilege, Holden Caulfield is so familiar to educated readers that Mr. Salinger can afford the luxury of subtlety. Bone, on the other hand, has had as little exposure to "sivilization" as Huck Finn did, and in order to rescue him from muteness Mr. Banks is compelled, a la Twain, to place him in fantastic situations. If the resulting story seems unrealistically bleak and its hero incompletely lovable -- if you balk at the unrelenting depiction of white adults as selfish, cruel and criminal -- it's worth remembering that for kids like Bone the state of innocence to which Holden longs to return has never been an option; they would be happy to meet adults whose worst sin is phoniness. Intoxicating and unsparing, "Rule of the Bone" is a romance for a world fast running out of room for childhood.
 
 
 
Just Another Dropout
 My stepfather probably thanks to my mom decided not to let the cops put me away for my Christmas shoplifting so long as I didn't try to move back in with them again, which was funny since the cops'd signed me over to my parents in the first place only on condition that I move back with them and take eighth grade over. The new rule was basically don't bother your parents and don't bother the cops or one of them will sic the other on you. All I had to do was stay out of the way of both and not flag either by going back to school who didn't want me anyhow. Which wasn't hard because they both tended to look in the other direction when they saw me, my parents on account of my bad attitude and drug use . . . and the cops because as a criminal I was more trouble than I was worth, just another homeless stoned dropout dealing small-load boom to the locals.
But even the cops know that a little weed can't hurt anybody. Most of them when they bust you are only trying to score for themselves anyhow and once they take your stash if you lick their boots and promise never to smoke reefer again so long as you live and thank them for saving you from a life of drug addiction and criminality they keep your drugs and let you go. Unless they're after you for something else you're not worth the paper work. I've learned that's generally true of life, if you're not worth the paper work adults won't hassle you. Except for the truly dumb and the nut cases of course, people who act on principle. They'll hassle you. From "Rule of the Bone."

LENGTH: 1055 words

HEADLINE: Rent Control Process Sets New Emphasis on Landlords' Needs

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In past years, the annual ritual of setting rents for New York City's rent-stabilized apartments has gone something like this: A rancorous crowd of tenants and landlords loudly plead their cases before the nine-member Rent Guidelines Board, which then adopts rent increases loosely based on the last year's changes in landlords' operating costs.
But last week, the board deviated from the usual script, proposing to increase the rents of tenants in the cheapest apartments by a higher percentage than those of tenants in more expensive apartments. 
 The board member who proposed the increases, Barbara Gordon-Espejo, said she was prompted by the agency's research, which suggested that many landlords of low-rent buildings were under the greatest financial strain. With poor tenants and little rental income, she argued, higher rent increases were needed to insure that the landlords did not abandon their buildings, causing a housing crisis.
The board will meet two more times before voting on Ms. Gordon-Espejo's proposal. But the fact that the plan is even being suggested reflects the increasing difficulty of keeping rents affordable while giving landlords sufficient rental income to keep buildings in good repair.
Beyond that, her proposal is yet another sign of the board's wavering support of the present system of rent control.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, remains firmly committed to rent regulation. "The Mayor has supported rent control in the past and that support continues," said Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor. "'He believes rent control serves as protection for fixed-income people who would be hurt by its elimination."
Rent protection has always been sacrosanct in a city in which nearly 70 percent of the residents are tenants. But in the last two years, the State Legislature and the City Council have reduced those protections for apartments that rent for more than $2,000 a month and whose tenants make $250,000 or more a year.
And on less expensive apartments, even some advocates for the poor acknowledge that rent rules intended to keep low-income tenants in their homes are worthless if their landlords cannot make enough to operate their buildings.
"This is an economic fact," said Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit community preservation, research and advocacy organization. "There is no point in putting regulations on landlords that they cannot meet. You will ultimately lose housing."
In the past, Mr. Braconi said, challenging rent regulation by elected officials has been tantamount to political suicide. But recently, more and more people have argued that rent regulations keep rents artificially low, leading strapped building owners to neglect or even abandon their properties.
"The difference between then and now," he said, "is that the ravaged neighborhoods and disasters of the 60's and 70's are clear evidence of the consequences of ignoring this economic fact."
Mr. Braconi said that between 1963 and 1978, an estimated 400,000 apartments were either lost to fire or abandoned. Mr. Braconi said that he supports changes in the rent regulation system, but that he believes some form of rent protection is needed.
The proposal given initial approval by the guidelines board last week calls for rent increases of 4 percent on one-year lease renewals and 8.5 percent on two-year leases in apartments renting for less than $400 a month. Landlords of these apartments would also be entitled to a $15-a-month surcharge for each apartment.
Apartments renting for more than that would be allowed increases of 1 percent on one-year leases and 2 percent on two-year leases.
The increases would cover nearly a million leases signed between Oct. 1 and Sept. 30, 1996. Last year, the board voted to allow increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases for rent-stabilized apartments, the smallest increase in 25 years.
The board's proposal comes as there are mounting indications of a housing crisis on the horizon. The most telling sign, housing experts say, has been the sharp rise in the number of apartment buildings defaulting on their property taxes in recent years. Tax delinquency, they say, is often the first signal that a building is vulnerable to abandonment.
But a more graphic reminder of the fragile state of some buildings was the collapse in March of a decrepit Harlem apartment building. The collapse, which killed three people, was blamed on a crack in one exterior wall. The building had been all but abandoned by its owners, and had deteriorated to the point where it was barely habitable.
Edward Hochman, chairman of the Rent Guidelines Board, said the board needed to address the problems distressed landlords are having.
"We can no more discount the difficulty of operating housing with very low rents than we can discount the difficulty some tenants will have paying increases," said Mr. Hochman, who was appointed to the board last year by Mayor Giuliani.
Ms. Gordon-Espejo, an appointee of Mayor David N. Dinkins, based her recommendation for the two-tiered rent schedule on a study that showed that on average, it costs landlords of rent-stabilized apartments $396 a month to operate one apartment. According to the United States Census Bureau's 1993 Housing and Vacancy Report, about 212,000 apartments in New York City rent for less than $400 a month.
But it is far from certain that the two-tiered system will go into effect. Some board members have signaled their opposition to the proposal in their initial vote, in which the measure passed by 5 to 2, with two abstentions. The board will not take its final vote on the matter until June 26.
Tenants and their advocates are certain to challenge the board's proposal fiercely at hearings June 19 and 22. William Rowan, of the Metropolitan Council on Housing, a tenant advocacy group, said he will present evidence showing that many tenants paying less than $400 a month are already paying more than 30 percent of their income in rent -- a figure economists say should be the maximum.
Mr. Rowan faulted the two-tiered proposal. He said the guidelines board's own study found costs for operating and maintaining buildings increased last year by one-tenth of one percent.

HEADLINE: Republicans Warn Russia That Deal With Iran Threatens Aid

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
As President Clinton prepared for summit talks with President Boris N. Yeltsin, Republican leaders warned today of "catastrophic consequences" for United States aid to Russia if Moscow goes ahead with plans to sell nuclear technology to Iran.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich said Russia's insistence on selling Iran light-water nuclear reactors and equipment useful in making bomb-grade material threatened to jeopardize relations between Moscow and Washington. 
 "Unless the Russians are prepared to accept very, very severe safeguards to insure that it's only a reactor for power purposes, that none of the raw material can be used to make a bomb, that there's very careful records kept and very careful inspections, I think that this is a very serious problem," Mr. Gingrich said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
"I'm not prepared to say today what we would do, but I think it would have catastrophic consequences in the Congress."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, left no doubt that the Senate would swiftly re-examine American aid to Moscow if President Clinton failed to win assurances from Mr. Yeltsin that the deal would be canceled or modified.
"It would be almost immediate," Mr. Dole said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
"Congress is a little leery of aid right now in any event, and with Chechnya and other problems that Russia's had," Mr. Dole added.
Without Moscow's acquiescence, Mr. Dole said, "it's going to really cool relations with Yeltsin, with the Russian Republic."
The comments from the two senior Republicans came on the eve of Mr. Clinton's departure for Moscow, where he is to join more than 50 other world leaders on Tuesday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Allies' victory over Nazi Germany. He is to meet with Mr. Yeltsin on Wednesday to discuss the Iranian deal and Chechnya, as well as Russia's concerns over plans to expand NATO.
In recent days the Administration has expressed serious concerns over Russia's nuclear deal with Teheran, and made it a top priority in this week's talks. "If this sale does go forward, Russian national security can only be weakened in the long term," Mr. Clinton said tonight in remarks to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
Russian officials say there is no reason to object to the agreement because Iran has signed the treaty to prevent the spread of atomic weapons and permits international inspectors to examine its nuclear installations.
In his remarks, Mr. Clinton said disputes over Iran's nuclear program and Russia's fighting in the breakaway region of Chechnya were disagreements that must be handled "openly, constructively and resolutely."
"I believe Russia has a powerful interest in preventing a neighbor -- especially one with Iran's track record -- from possessing these weapons," Mr. Clinton said.
But the Administration has shied away from threatening to cut off foreign aid. Indeed, in his remarks, President Clinton pledged to nurture ties with Moscow despite the agreement with Iran. "Crises come and go," he said. "But interests endure."
"We must not hold our relationship hostage to any one issue," he said.
On Saturday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher suggested that Russian aid was imperative, regardless of what Moscow does on the Iran-nuclear issue. "Every bit of aid we give them is in our interest," Mr. Christopher told CNN.

HEADLINE: Rethinking Welfare: Interstate Migration -- A special report.;
Larger Benefits Lure Chicagoans to Wisconsin

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
In its heyday of counterculture chic a generation ago, the streets of this Wisconsin capital pulsed with protesters demanding a fair share for America's poor people and its racial minorities.
Yet the profile of the city itself was not exactly proletarian: overwhelmingly white, highly educated and relatively affluent. Madisonians might have been champions of the downtrodden, but they were rarely their neighbors. 
 In recent years, however, issues of race and poverty have become a bit less abstract here, as a small but growing number of poor Chicagoans are fleeing gang-torn neighborhoods and moving the 150 miles to Madison for better schools, safer streets and, some of the newcomers acknowledge, more generous welfare benefits.
"It's not the only reason I came," said Austina Moore, 26, who moved here from Chicago last fall with her four young children, and later persuaded her mother, Hester Moore, who is also on welfare, to follow them. "But it sure helps to get $200 more a month."
She now receives $708 a month, and the cost of living is generally lower in Madison than Chicago.
The influx of poor people from Chicago is testing this city's historical liberalism. About one-quarter of the 3,300 Madison families receiving welfare are former Illinois residents.
Even Mayor Paul Soglin, who earned his liberal stripes in the anti-establishment politics of the 1960's as a leader of Vietnam War protests, now talks of "finite limits of resources" for the poor. He warns against "the duplication of old ghetto neighborhoods" with the same problems that families came to Madison to escape.
"We're like a lifeboat that holds 12 people comfortably," Mr. Soglin said. "We've got about 16 in it now, and there's a dozen more waiting in the water. Since we're already in danger of going under, what can our community be expected to do?"
Despite benefit levels that have been frozen for nearly a decade and eligibility rules that have been tightened under Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, assistance checks for the poor in Wisconsin are still about 40 percent higher than in Illinois. A family of four living in poverty in Wisconsin is entitled to $617 a month while the same family would receive $414 in Illinois.
Some experts on poverty say migration of welfare recipients would increase sharply under the Republican plan in Congress to replace the main Federal program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, with a system controlled by the states.
Under the current A.F.D.C. program, the Federal Government pays about half the benefits, at levels set by the states. Already the payments vary; for example, in Mississippi the amount is $120 while New York pays $703.
In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani drew criticism last month when, in defending welfare cuts, he suggested that lower payments might persuade some welfare recipients to leave the city.
Under a block-grant system approved by the House of Representatives, the Government would give the states lump sums for welfare, to be spent as they saw fit. Many experts say this system could widen the differences in benefits because states would have more freedom to set eligibility criteria and benefit levels.
"States that are concerned about welfare migration now, just wait," said Thomas Corbett, associate director of the Institute for Research on Poverty at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. "They'll really be concerned under the block-grant system."
Governors are already trying to throw up fences to reduce their states' appeal to welfare migrants. In Connecticut, for example, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, has proposed slashing benefits and adopting the toughest eligibility requirements in the country to discourage poor people from moving there.
Newcomers to four Wisconsin counties, not including Madison's, are only eligible for aid at the level paid by their former state for six months. After that, they receive the same rate as other Wisconsin residents.
A vibrant economy in Wisconsin surely accounts for much of the migration among poor people, most of them looking for jobs. The state's unemployment rate has dipped below 4 percent while that in Illinois is 4.4 percent.
In Madison, it is less than 2 percent, the lowest of any large city in the United States. That has put pressure on the city's employers to raise wages. Even fast-food restaurants are advertising jobs at $6 and $7 an hour, plus benefits.
But Mr. Thompson insists that many poor people are coming to the state principally for welfare. "If you don't think so, just look at the statistics," he said.
Since Mr. Thompson took office in January 1987 and began efforts to trim the welfare rolls, the number of recipients has dropped nearly 25 percent, to about 75,000. In one program, now being tested in two counties, welfare benefits end after two years.
Mark Rom, the author of "Welfare Magnets: A New Case for a National Welfare Standard" (Brookings Institution, 1990), said most studies have found that such migration "is real, but is quite modest." Decisions to move are "as complicated for poor people as they are for rich people," he said, and rarely boil down to a single factor.
"But while there is some disagreement among social scientists about whether this kind of migration exists," Mr. Rom said, "there is no doubt among state legislators that it is real. Under the block-grant program, states will trim benefits to make sure they're not any more generous than their neighbors, worried that they'll be seen as welfare magnets."
One terminus for newcomers here, the Broadway-Simpson neighborhood, is one of the city's poorest, but its rows of tidy brick apartment buildings would never be mistaken for a rough section in Chicago. Nonetheless, some gang members and drug dealers have settled among the families that came here to flee such problems.
"This was our neighborhood before the gangs and drugs took it over," declared the hand-printed sign in a neighborhood center here, written by 9-year-old Keisha Robinson. "And we want it back." Next to the message, someone has written in large letters: "Now!"
While the migration of poor Chicagoans has brought some problems, it has also brought redemption for many families that had once virtually given up on life.
Cindy Wells, 37, recalled hearing gunshots every day in her South Side neighborhood in Chicago, where her three young children were not allowed to play outside, and where she said she watched a police officer take a bribe from a drug dealer in broad daylight.
Ms. Wells, who had been on welfare when she arrived in Madison eight years ago, said a network of charitable organizations and social service agencies helped her get squared away. She was given temporary housing in the Y.W.C.A., furniture, clothes, food and transportation vouchers for the children to get to school.
"People in Madison smiled at me, shook my hand, answered my questions," she said. "For once, I could walk the streets without wondering, 'Who is going to jump me? Who is going to beat me up?' "
Within a couple of months, she got a job working with poor children. And today, her family is thriving. Her eldest son, Irwin, 16, an honor student at James Madison High School, was recently awarded a college academic scholarship.
"I blossomed here," said Ms. Wells, an ebullient woman in dreadlocks and a "Beverly Hills 90210" sweatshirt. "I became a whole person."
But Ms. Wells said she planned to move out of her apartment complex and into a nearby town house because drug dealers in her building had created an unsavory atmosphere. She said her children had complained of headaches from the stench of marijuana and crack.
She said that when she told a man smoking crack in the hallway to have the decency to go inside his own apartment, "he spit in my face."
Groups of former Chicagoans, intent on preserving the good life in Madison, have established support groups like the Moms of Simpson Street. The Simpson Street group holds festive dinners to honor men in the community, like police officers, teachers and ordinary fathers, who are good role models.
One of the best things about life in a place like Madison, many of the newcomers say, is that ill-mannered behavior is not tolerated. "It's strict up here," said Ruthie Debrow, a former Chicagoan who moved here on welfare and now works for a social service agency, "and the young people learn that in a hurry." She added, "If a kid gets into trouble, you can be sure the social workers are going to be coming to the home, asking, 'Now what's going on here?' "
The police say keeping a lid on trouble is easier in a smaller city like Madison, with a population of about 190,000, which is not overwhelmed by crime. Selling drugs on street corners might be considered old hat in Chicago, officers say, but it is not tolerated in Madison.
Dorothy Doheny, a police officer here, said one young drug dealer had asked incredulously, "For just one rock of cocaine, you're going to throw me in jail?" The officer replied, "Yep."
Ms. Wells, among other newcomers, said she would never consider returning to live in her old home town: "I only go back to Chicago for funerals."
 
RETHINKING WELFARE
Block Grants
 
THE GOAL -- Block Grants, or lump sum Federal payments made directly to the states, would gove more states control over Federal aid to low-income people without the bureaucratic strings attached in Washington. House Republicans say a block-grant system would control costs and rein in the growth of entitlements.
 
THE PROPOSALS
 
HOUSE PLAN
Under a welfare bill passed by the House, Federal entitlement program including family assistance and school lunch subsidies would by replaced by block grants that states could use as they wished to aid the poor. The money would be earmarked for specific purposes, but states would be able to set benefits and eligibility criteria.
 
GOVERNORS PLAN
Republican governors say the House bill would still impose too many restrictions on them. It would, for example, set a five year limit on Federal welfare payments to a family and would bar the use of Federal money to provide cash assistance to unmarried teen-age mothers. The governors have devised an alternative proposal that would give them more say over eligibility rules. They would also replace the food stamp program, which the House bill would keep at the Federal level, with block grants.
 
EFFECT ON STATES -- Some governors fear that under the House proposal many poor people would be out of luck if demand for services outran a state's grant or if state officials were unable to administer such complicated programs. Some critics also fear that the money would not be evenly distributed among the states.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

German Central Bank Chief Urges U.S. to Act on Dollar
 The dollar is not going to rise against the Japanese yen or German mark, according to Hans Tietmeyer, the head of the Bundesbank, until the currency markets see President Clinton and Congress taking steps to reverse the United States' declining savings rate and to reduce the budget deficit. 
 Mr. Tietmeyer also said that the current American economic performance did not justify the roughly 12 percent fall of the dollar against the mark this year. "It is not only the presence of the current deficit that seems to concern the markets, but also the prospect for the future," he said. D2.
 
Gingrich Discloses Medicare Plan
 The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, said the budget being proposed by his Republicans would cut projected Medicare spending by hundreds of billions of dollars over seven years without significantly affecting anyone now enrolled in the program. A1.
 
What of Chad? And the Ratings?
 Soap operas once ruled the daytime, but televised trials, talk shows and specialized cable channels now vie for the same audience. The biggest single cause of the soaps' recent ratings slippage has been the addiction to the O. J. Simpson trial. In the first three months of 1995, at least a million fewer households tuned in to 'All My Children,' 'As the World Turns' and 'The Young and the Restless' than in the similar period a year ago. D8.
 
Coast Air Shuttles a World Apart
 On the West Coast, $69 fares are being offered for flights between Los Angeles and Oakland, a distance of more than 300 miles. But to go the roughly 250 miles between New York and Washington, a traveler pays $147, despite the competition from Amtrak. And it does not seem to bother the airlines running Northeastern shuttles that ridership has dropped by roughly a quarter since 1987. D3.

New Names, New Prospects
 Investors may have trouble identifying three health care companies that took new names to distance themselves from sleazy episodes. Under new colors, Tenet Healthcare, Circa Pharmaceuticals and Pharmaceutical Resources appear to be thriving. Market Place. D4.
 
The Coming Battle in Video Games
 For video game aficionados, the gore of "Mortal Kombat" is a diversion. For the five companies competing for the next generation of video game players, there is nothing diverting about the coming confrontation. D7.
 
After the Murdoch Ruling
 When the F.C.C. began its investigation into the ownership of the Fox television network more than a year ago, most industry executives were skeptical. And indeed, Rupert Murdoch has come through untouched. But the ruling on Thursday may lead to changes in broadcast regulations that please even some of Mr. Murdoch's toughest rivals. Bill Carter: Television. D8.
 
Of Patriotism and Ads
 Marketers and the news media are celebrating the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe with advertising and promotions laced with patriotism, nostalgia and even humor. Many programs start today, marking V-E day, the Allied victory over the Nazis in 1945. Buick, for instance, is sponsoring a campaign that includes a reprint of the V-E Day issue of Time magazine. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D9.
 
A Vision, Reduced
 For more than half a century, New York City's politicians have built the city's government into the nation's most sheltering, one that protected its citizens from some of the harshness of the free market. Now change is coming -- and far faster than many people wanted or expected. A1.

HEADLINE: On Philippine Ballot Today, Well-Worn Names

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: MANILA, May 7

 BODY:
When Filipinos vote on Monday, they will face a ballot that resembles both a social register and a rogues' gallery, a reminder of how name recognition can mean much more than anything else in this country's messy democracy.
For Senate, the candidates include Ferdinand (Bong Bong) Marcos Jr., son of the late dictator; Gregorio (Gringo) Honasan, a former army colonel who was implicated in several coup attempts, and Rosemarie (Baby) Arenas, a socialite who does not hide her close friendship with President Fidel V. Ramos and who is often called the Second Lady. 
 Certainly the best-known candidate seeking election to the lower house of Congress is Imelda R. Marcos, the widow of Ferdinand E. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos is almost certain to win the race in Leyte, her native province, despite the widespread assumption among Filipinos that she helped her husband loot the Philippine treasury of billions of dollars. She is now appealing a conviction here on graft charges.
Although more than 17,000 races are being contested across the country, the most important are those in the Senate, where the outcome could determine the fate of Mr. Ramos's three-year-old economic-reform program. In the Senate races, voters are asked to select 12 names from a national list of candidates.
While the economic reforms have brought billions of dollars in foreign investment to the Philippines, opposition candidates assert that the investment has meant little for the tens of millions of Filipinos who live in dire poverty.
Recent opinion polls suggest that the President's supporters should add to the 17 seats they now hold in the 24-member Senate, a gain that would be a relief to Mr. Ramos because his personal popularity has plummeted in the furor over Singapore's hanging of a Filipino maid in March.
The maid, Flor Contemplacion, is described here as a martyr to the cause of more than two million Filipinos who are forced by poverty to work abroad. Many Filipinos blame the President for not having done enough to save her from the gallows in Singapore, where she confessed to two murders.
Opposition candidates have tried to capitalize on the hanging at the expense of Mr. Ramos.
But if polls are right, the issue will not result in many new Senate seats, if any, for the opposition. Mr. Marcos and Mr. Honasan no longer seem assured of victory in their races. That Mrs. Marcos, her son and Mr. Honasan could get this far would seem to support the idea that in Philippine politics, memories are remarkably short and that ideology and political parties count for little.
Mrs. Marcos and her son spent most of the last decade in exile in the United States, while Mr. Honasan, 47, spent several years on the run for his part in the coup attempts against Mr. Ramos's predecessor, Corazon C. Aquino.
Political scientists say the willingness of voters to forgive these once-vilified figures can be explained by the relative youth of the electorate: the voting age is 18, with millions of voters living on remote islands in an archipelago nation.
Mrs. Aquino, who led the popular revolt in 1986 that overthrew President Marcos, has become a chief sponsor of a movement called Never Again, formed to stop Mr. Marcos and Mr. Honasan. She argues that they have already proved to be a threat to democracy here.
As for Mrs. Marcos, it is not clear that she would be allowed to take her seat in the next Congress because the national elections commission ruled last month that she had failed to satisfy a residency requirement.
The election is seen as the last formal referendum on the presidency of Mr. Ramos, who is barred by the Constitution from seeking a second six-year term.
Before the furor over Mrs. Contemplacion's hanging, Mr. Ramos was hugely popular among Filipinos and had predicted that his candidates would win all 12 of the Senate seats available in the Monday election. But he is now saying his supporters will take at least 5 seats, the number needed to secure passage of his economic program.

HEADLINE: Shuttles in Northeast Keep Fares Up and Thrive

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
America's two coasts have always seemed like worlds apart. Their air shuttles make it more so.
On the West Coast, the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation and Southwest Airlines are fighting it out with $69 fares for so-called walk-up passengers who want to fly between Los Angeles and Oakland, a distance of more than 300 miles. Even after a $10 increase last month, the price of a one-way shuttle ticket from Los Angeles to San Francisco is $99. 
 But to go the roughly 250 miles between New York and Washington, or New York and Boston, you pay not less, but more -- $147 to be exact -- despite the competition from Amtrak. And it does not seem to bother the airlines operating the Northeast shuttles that ridership has dropped to slightly more than 3 million last year from a peak of 4.2 million a year in 1987. Indeed, on average the East Coast shuttles are less than half full each flight.
Normally, keeping the fare high -- it is twice what it was in 1987 -- is not the way to win back disaffected passengers. R. E. G. Davies, for one, curator of air transport at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington and the author of 12 books on world transport, should be a natural shuttle passenger. But he takes the train when he travels to New York.
"It's easier to write or read proofs on the train," he said, "and you don't lose productive time in traffic jams, checking in, and not having enough elbow room once you're aboard. Besides, it's cheaper."
Teleconferencing and other stops along the electronic highway could further erode the shuttle business, but both Delta Air Lines and USAir -- the current competitors on the Northeast shuttle -- are not budging.
Why?
One reason is that more than 80 percent of their passengers are business travelers, whose employers or clients often pick up the tab. Another is that the limited number of takeoff and landing slots at LaGuardia Airport in New York and National Airport in Washington insulates the two airlines from additional competition.
"Because of the limit on slots, the shuttle's effectively a duopoly," said Lee Howard, president of Airline Economics Inc., a consulting company in Washington. "So why should they get in a cat fight when they're both doing well? It isn't like the West Coast shuttle, where anybody can go into that market." (The West Coast shuttles operate among many more airports.)
In the Northeast, Delta and USAir can count on passengers like Hartmut W. Stauss. A divisional vice president for Hyatt Hotels and Resorts, Mr. Stauss takes the shuttle from New York three or four times a month to check on Hyatt hotels in Washington and Boston. He has been doing this for more than five years.
"It's not as comfortable as the train," he said, "and there always seems to be a traffic jam or some other delay. But the shuttle frees you from schedules and timetables, because you don't have to be at the gate by a certain time." After all, Delta flies on the half-hour and USAir on the hour.
Not engaging in price wars means that while Delta lost $159 million last year, its shuttle operation may have earned as much as $20 million, Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley, said. USAir lost a whopping $685 million in 1994, but its net shuttle income was $4.4 million for the first nine months of the year, according to estimates by Avitas, an aviation consulting firm in Reston, Va. According to the Air Transport Association, the airline industry has lost $13 billion since 1990, much of it from heavily discounted fares.
In addition to their 64 scheduled daily flights, both the Delta and USAir shuttles continue to keep standby crews available for the many unscheduled planes they roll out during rush hours for passengers who could not get seats on crowded scheduled flights. In Delta's case, that has been as many as 22 added flights in a single day.
Each shuttle also regularly adds "enhancements" -- amenities and services to set it apart from its rival.
In September, for example, Delta added Starbucks coffee both inflight and at the terminals. Passengers may use Delta cellular phones for the day, paying only for their phone calls. Delta is installing new self-ticketing machines at its three shuttle terminals, machines that will issue tickets in 30 seconds instead of two minutes. Later this month, it plans to issue to 5,000 shuttle customers a credit-card-size Smart Card with an imbedded computer chip that enables the user to make reservations, bill his or her credit card, get a receipt and earn frequent-flier miles.
In November, USAir began offering a special coffee blend of its own. In January, it introduced ticketless travel. It is also experimenting with an in-flight system that will allow passengers to shop, make hotel reservations and play video games.
Neither shuttle thinks it can raise fares as high or as fast as it wants, despite increased costs. "Our $147 fare has been stable since September 1993," said Terry Hallcom, president and chief executive of the USAir Shuttle. "We've been lucky that fuel costs have been relatively stable, but we've had increases in rent and permits and landing fees."
Both shuttles operate at airports where parking space is inadequate and fees are sky high, and they contend with total costs that are almost three times the industry average. Moreover, the shuttles' load factor -- the total number of seats occupied by paying passengers -- averages only about 46 percent, almost 20 points below the industry's overall break-even threshold.
But in some respects, Delta and USAir have an easier time of it than their near counterparts on the West Coast. (On the West Coast they do not roll out extra planes when the scheduled flights are full.) The West Coast shuttle route stretches from Phoenix to Seattle. For flights between Los Angeles and the San Francisco Bay area, there are six airlines from which to choose.
With the West Coast's dearth of business travelers, said Ed Scerbo, an industry analyst in Arlington, Va., "business travelers get the benefit of lower fares, but Southwest really positioned its low-cost fares on the West Coast as an alternative to driving." The Northeast, on the other hand, offers many transportation alternatives, including Amtrak's 36 daily roundtrips between New York and Washington that include 17 Metroliner express trains that reach Penn Station in New York from Union Station in Washington in less than 3 hours.
USAir is so optimistic about its shuttle service that it hopes to exercise its option next year and buy the shuttle from the group of banks that owns it. The bank group had financed Donald J. Trump's $350 million purchase of the former Eastern shuttle in 1989, then acquired the Trump Shuttle two years later when the cash-short Mr. Trump stopped paying interest on the debt. In April 1992, USAir paid $16.2 million to manage and operate the shuttle for five years, with an option to buy at the end of four and a half years.
"The shuttle has met all our expectations to date," said Seth E. Schofield, chairman and chief executive of USAir. "The opportunity to acquire it is a high priority for USAir."

HEADLINE: U.S. Policy a 'Betrayal,' Cuban Exiles Protest

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 7

 BODY:
The anger is unmistakable. In news conferences, on picket lines and in caravans, groups of Cuban exiles have been lashing out at the United States for negotiating with Cuba and then deciding to send back all future illegal refugees leaving the island.
At a demonstration on Thursday, one sign read: "Bay of Pigs, Part II." 
 "The betrayal continues," said Jose Miro Torra, a veteran of the Bay of Pigs, the 1961 failed invasion of Cuba. Mr. Torra said that exile groups were planning a strike that he said would "paralyze" Miami and a march in Washington to "recover the dignity of the Cuban people, which has been trampled on."
But if the loudest voices heard in reaction to the American policy reversal were familiar, coming from conservatives for whom any deals with Fidel Castro amount to treason and the repatriation of Cubans to murder, there is also a softer but steady rumble from Cuban Americans who agree to talk to Cuba, who hope negotiations go beyond immigration issues to normalization of relations, who call the hard line against Castro a failure.
They include people like Nati Morales, 28, a mixed-media artist born in Philadelphia of Cuban parents who went to the island for the first time last summer to bring pain killers to an older relative who had fallen and broken her hip. On her visit, she says, hardly anyone talked about the political situation or even mentioned Fidel Castro. They were just hungry, she said.
"If this is the means to an end and if the end is to end Castro's dictatorship, then it's great," Ms. Morales, who lives in Miami, said of the Clinton Administration's new policy on Cuban refugees. "If that's the dead end, then that's pathetic and in line with previous policies in that it doesn't do anything."
Cubans in the United States speak with one voice on certain points, like opposition to Mr. Castro and Communist rule and support for human rights groups on the island, opinion surveys show. But the spectrum of views widen significantly on what to do to quicken the pace of bringing democracy to Cuba.
A Florida International University poll last month of 1,500 Cubans in Florida's Dade County and in Union City, N.J., found that a strong majority -- 63 percent of respondents in Dade County and 79 percent in Union City -- favored negotiations to facilitate peaceful democratic change in Cuba. But the same poll found that more than half also favored military action by the exile community and even an American invasion of Cuba.
Researchers said that although seemingly contradictory, the answers reflect an openness to consider a variety of options, preferably a stick-and-carrot approach. They said that age, time in exile and even location had been factors in the responses. Those most likely to support negotiated solutions were younger, had arrived since the 1970's and lived in New Jersey, where more Democrats were found, despite a Republican majority among respondents. There is a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent for the Dade County sample and plus or minus 4 percent for the Union City sample..
The differences in opinion were in evidence last week when Attorney General Janet Reno announced that while most of the 21,000 Cuban refugees held in camps at the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay would be allowed into the country, those leaving the island illegally from now on would be intercepted and returned to Cuba.
The decisions came after meetings with Cuban Government officials in order to control a migration characterized by periodic massive waves of Cubans -- more than 30,000 last summer alone -- leaving for Florida in rafts and boats. The United States would still grant 20,000 visas to Cubans each year.
While news of the release of the Guantanamo refugees was widely welcomed, the policy of intercepting rafters sparked a furious reaction in some quarters. The Cuban American National Foundation, the leading conservative exile organization, immediately withdrew 15,000 sponsors it had recruited to take over resettlement expenses for the Guantanamo refugees, saying the Federal Government should pay for a decision it made without consulting exiles.
A few hundred people protested at the Port of Miami today, sporadically disrupting traffic. City Manager Cesar Odio defended the acts of civil disobedience, comparing Fidel Castro with Hitler.
Brothers to the Rescue, a volunteer pilot group that spots rafters for the Coast Guard, says it will no longer report sightings unless the refugees themselves consent.
"If the Coast Guard picks you up it is possible that you would be returned to Cuban authorities," reads a flier to be dropped to the refugees, or rafters. "If you want us to alert the Coast Guard, wave your arms. If not, stay motionless when we fly by again."
Some experts said the new policy cuts through the heart of an exile community that identifies the evils of the Castro Government with a sense of urgency in leaving the island. Many would never buy into the idea that worsening economic conditions is what has driven many of the rafters to the seas, they say.
"It's really a difficult situation for the hard line in the exile community," said Max Castro, a sociologist with the University of Miami's North-South Center who came here from Cuba as a child. "They only had one ally in the world and that was the United States."
But almost as quickly, a national coalition of Cuban groups called the Cuban-American National Alliance said it would take over efforts to find sponsors and refugee assistance. And in interviews since the Administration chipped away at the special status Cubans have enjoyed for three decades as political refugees, many Cuban Americans say they see the policy changes as positive.
Alfredo G. Duran, a Miami lawyer, former chairman of the state Democratic Party, is a member of the board of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, a coalition of "moderate and progressive" business executives, academicians and other professionals who favor talks with Cuba.
"If they give the 20,000 visas, which has never happened, the policy establishes an orderly immigration process that prevents more deaths near Florida," Mr. Duran said. In the long run, he said, "it internalizes the opposition in Cuba."
"Now the regime's opponents will have to solve the nation's problems internally," he said.
Many Cuban-Americans said the Administration should next rescind restrictions imposed last year on travel and cash remittances to Cuba, then move toward easing the trade embargo, to allow exports of food and medicine and commercial and cultural exchanges that they say would force Cuba to change quicker than punitive measures would.
A widespread concern is whether the Cuban Government can be trusted not to take reprisals against the repatriated, and whether those with valid cases of persecution would be given political asylum. Ms. Reno said that persons with "a genuine need for protection" would be "examined before return."
The first 13 Cubans to test the policy were picked up at sea late Wednesday by a cruise ship and were turned over to the Coast Guard late Friday night. After more than 30 years of unconditional welcome in the United States, most Cubans here find repatriations hard to stomach.

HEADLINE: U.S. Savings and Deficit Key to Dollar, German Says

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 7

 BODY:
The head of Germany's central bank, in his most pointed remarks to date on the prospects for the beleaguered dollar, said it would not rise against the Japanese yen or German mark until the markets were convinced that President Clinton and Congress were taking steps to reverse the United States' declining savings rate and reduce the budget deficit.
"The problems for me are clear," said Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the reserve bank, widely known as the Bundesbank. "Low savings ratio, relatively high budget deficit, no absolute assurance it will come down in the long run, and a high net debtor position" on the part of the United States. "These are the points that have to be addressed." 
 Mr. Tietmeyer said the current American economic performance -- low inflation, moderating growth and a soaring stock market -- did not justify the roughly 12 percent fall of the dollar against the mark this year. But, he added, currency speculators were no longer basing their buy or sell decisions just on current economic factors.
"It is not only the presence of the current deficit that seems to concern the markets, but also the prospect for the future," Mr. Tietmeyer said. "The markets seem to think that there is not enough correction on the way, as far as these fundamentals are concerned. The markets of today are more and more looking to the future, more than just the present."
When they look there, he said, they seem to be seeing no change but an increase in American indebtedness.
Mr. Tietmeyer spoke extensively about his views on the dollar and the recent gyrations in world currency markets in an interview in his office late last week. He said he would not comment on specific American legislation. But he was not shy in criticizing the United States for making little progress in finding a long-term way of bringing down future deficits.
His remarks followed by a little more than a week a tension-filled meeting in Washington of the finance ministers and central bank chiefs of the Group of Seven industrial nations. The falling dollar has driven the cost of German and Japanese exports up, causing outcries by industries in those countries. Others in Europe blame the weak dollar for dragging down currencies like the French franc, Italian lira and Spanish peseta. Thus, almost all of Washington's major trading partners are calling for corrective action that would bolster market confidence.
Criticism of American policy has been particularly sharp from Germany, where Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Mr. Tietmeyer have repeatedly pointed at American policy and said it was coming up short.
Mr. Tietmeyer said there was no coordinated plan on the part of the German Government to criticize Washington, but he conceded that he did not remember such outspoken criticism from Germany of American policy since the early 1980's, when the deficit ballooned under dual Reagan Administration policies of tax cuts and a military buildup.
"I am not interested in interfering in the policy of the United States," he said. "I am only saying that it is important to understand what are the problems behind the dollar's low value, and that the markets are not only looking at the present problems but they are looking always at what will happen in the future."
President Clinton took a somewhat different tack last month in responding to questions on the dollar's troubles at a televised news conference. "In the present climate," he said, "the ability of governments to affect the strength of their currencies may be limited."
"The United States does want a strong dollar," he continued. "We believe in the importance of fundamentals in our economy. We believe in getting the deficit down, getting jobs up and pursuing a responsible course. We do have an interest over the long run in strong currency. But we have to look at it, for Government actions need to be directed toward long-term fundamentals, sound economic policies, sound growth policies, sound investment policies."
Mr. Tietmeyer and his Bundesbank colleagues are amply familiar with criticism of their own monetary policy. Frequently in 1992 and 1993, the central bank, the most powerful in Europe, came under bitter charges that it was keeping interest rates so high that this hindered economic recovery in Europe. The bank developed a reputation as a cold, heartless organization, unmoved by complaints from weaker European economies that its policy promoting a powerful mark was creating unemployment outside Germany.
Yet it is such discipline that has earned the bank, and the German mark, such credibility among international investors that in times of uncertainty, many of them buy the mark as a safe-haven currency.
Mr. Tietmeyer, though characterized as stiff and heartless, gave the opposite impression, as he rested his large frame on a sofa in his office in the bank's headquarters here -- one leg propped up, clearly relaxing. He laughed as he reminded an interviewer that he was not about to comment on what he thought the real value of the dollar should be against the mark.
And he repeated several times that "every country has to take care of its own currency," and that a strong dollar was in the interest of the United States as well as the rest of the world, since most nations stored their excess cash in dollars.
But time and again, he emphasized that currency markets were looking more at prospects two to three years from now. And he pointed to two events in recent months when the markets seemed to believe that there was little hope of the United States' moving to end growing deficits.
One was Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in February. Mr. Greenspan indicated that the Fed might not have to raise interest rates and that with signs of a weak economy, might indeed be moved to cut rates. The other came on March 2, when the Senate failed to approve a balanced-budget amendment.
Mr. Tietmeyer said that vital to reducing the United States debt would be promoting higher savings by Americans. Private households save only 4 percent of the gross national product, compared with 12 percent in Germany and 17 percent in Japan. Because of the low savings rate, the United States is much more dependent on foreigners' buying its debt paper, and is thus more subject to swings in market sentiment.
While he would not predict when or if the markets would shift more in favor of the dollar, he said he believed that the Clinton Administration had finally accepted that the dollar needed to be strengthened.
"I believe that the United States Administration now has a clear policy of saying that it is interested not in a weak dollar but a strong dollar," Mr. Tietmeyer said. "I think the Administration knows that it is in the interest of the United States to have a strong dollar. This is important to say, but convincing the markets cannot be done only by statements. The markets are looking at what are the policy decisions behind those words."

HEADLINE: Rich Life Style and Looted Church;
Ex-National Episcopal Treasurer Plans to Make Restitution

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
Before the scandal, Ellen F. Cooke, former treasurer of the national Episcopal Church, and her husband, the Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d, an Episcopal priest, paid nearly $1 million for an 18th-century house with a wraparound porch and five fireplaces in Montclair, N.J., and a 23-acre vacation farm in a peach orchard in the Virginia countryside. Thousands more went into a new kitchen for the Montclair home and for tennis courts and a new 140-foot dock on a river flowing by the honeysuckle patch at the edge of the Virginia farm.
"Everybody said they must have had an awfully big congregation -- they had so much money," said M. S. Harcum, a neighbor in the sleepy hamlet of Ottoman, Va., about 90 miles east of Richmond. "I couldn't get any masonry or woodwork done, they kept everyone so busy." 
 But the money the Cookes spread among the craftsmen of Virginia, among other places, came from $2.2 million that church officials say Mrs. Cooke, 50, looted from the church treasury from February 1990 to last January.
The church's Presiding Bishop, Edmond L. Browning, said last week that outside auditors had found that Mrs. Cooke "systematically diverted" the $2.2 million, much of it from the Bishop's discretionary accounts.
Bishop Browing said he had not decided whether to press charges against Mrs. Cooke but would "cooperate with the appropriate authorities in any investigation that may ensue."
In a letter released by her lawyer, Mrs. Cooke said she planned to make restitution and was receiving psychiatric help. "In the psychiatrist's opinion, I experienced a breakdown precipitated by many factors external to me and related to the workplace." Mrs. Cooke's husband, who has not been accused of wrongdoing, told his congregation at St. John's Church in McLean, Va., at services yesterday that he would resign at the end of the month.
Church officials and parishioners expressed shock and anger at what they called Mrs. Cooke's betrayal. They said it was particularly galling that she led such a grand life style while helping to arrange staff reductions and other cuts in the national budget in recent years. Since 1991, the Episcopal Church has had to cut its national budget by several million dollars and its national staff by a third, to 200 people.
"While we're cutting staff and budget, she's putting in a tennis court at the Virginia farm and adding a guest house," said James Solheim, a church spokesman.
Over the five years cited, Mrs. Cooke, who is listed with her husband in the Social Register, often indulged in limousines and bought lavish gifts for her staff at Episcopal headquarters in Manhattan, including cut-glass bowls and glass apples, church officials said. Church funds, they said, paid these bills.
Church money also is said to have gone to private school tuition for her two teen-aged sons by her first husband, also an Episcopal priest, and for airline tickets for friends visiting Virginia from the New York area. And church officials said there were purchases of clothing and jewelry, including a $16,000 Tiffany necklace.
Friends in Montclair, acquaintances in Virginia and Mrs. Cooke's brother all said they had thought the opulent life style was rooted in old family money, shrewd investments or comfortable Episopalian salaries. (Mrs. Cooke was paid $125,000 a year as church treasurer before her forced resignation early this year, and her husband about $70,000 as rector at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair before he transferred to the McLean church.)
Apparently, few eyebrows were raised at Manhattan headquarters about the Virginia spread and the Cookes' move a year ago to the fancy Montclair home. The Virginia farm cost the Cookes $500,000 in July 1991, and the Montclair home, just up Union Street from St. Luke's, cost $465,5000 in March 1994, records showed. A building permit on file in Montclair's Town Hall put the price of the Montclair kitchen renovation at nearly $38,000.
Bishop Browning, once one of Mrs. Cooke's most ardent supporters in the power politics at church headquarters, now says his trust was betrayed. The Rev. John S. Spong, Bishop of the Diocese of Newark, who is a family friend and frequent dinner guest at the Cookes' Montclair home, said the same thing in a meeting last week with about 150 parishioners at St. Luke's. He asserted that Mrs. Cooke was a skillful and deliberate embezzler.
"The church has lost a lot of intregrity, the church has lost trust," Bishop Spong said. "People are disillusioned and we'll pay for that in a thousand ways."
Father Cooke's former parishioners at St. Luke's were stunned and angry and some called for criminal charges against Mrs. Cooke. One woman said criminal prosecution "helps get you on the road to redemption."
"I don't disagree," Bishop Spong said.
Mrs. Cooke's parents, Evelyn and John, were "floored" by the accusations, said her 42-year-old brother, Kevin Gerrity, associate editor of The Kansas City Business Journal.
"They're extremely proud of her," Mr. Gerrity said. "They could always point to Ellen. They could say, 'Look at what she's accomplished for the Episcopalian Church.'
"If it's true she took all that money, it's a mind-blower," Mr. Gerrity added. "I don't understand why."
In a statement issued through her lawyer, Plato Cacheris of Washington, Mrs. Cooke said she would make full restitution. She contended, however, that some of what the church called $325,000 in improper charges on her corporate credit card were justified business expenses.
Her statement said an Episcopal priest now counseling her stressed "the truth of my inappropriate and wrong response to the situation in which I found myself." Mrs. Cooke said the priest, who is a woman, "has also helped me acknowledge the pain, abuse and powerlessness I have felt during the years I have worked as a laywoman on a senior level at the church headquarters."
Colleagues at the Manhattan headquarters and ranking church officials elsewhere disputed Mrs. Cooke's comment about powerlessness. In fact, they said, she had considerable power, as both treasurer of the national church and chief administrator of day-to-day operations at the headquarters, and exercised her authority vigorously.
"She was tyrannical," said a top-ranking female official who asked to remain unidentified.
Others who spoke on the condition of anonymity said Mrs. Cooke enjoyed the confidence of Bishop Browning, who hired her as national treasurer in 1986, and also named her administrator, a position customarily filled by a bishop.
Amid deepening staff unrest last fall, Bishop Browning decided to seek Mrs. Cooke's resignation, officials said. When she agreed to step down in late January, the church said she was leaving because of her husband's transfer from Montclair to St. John's Church in McLean.
The real reason for the departure, the Bishop disclosed, was that "her working style did not serve our common mission."
The $2.2 million in diversions was uncovered, the church said, only after Mrs. Cooke improperly took $86,000 in back pay and unused vacation on her departure. An accounting firm, Coopers & Lybrand, found she had switched $1.5 million that was to have been deposited in church accounts in a bank and brokerage house into personal accounts she kept at the institutions, the church said. In addition, it said, she wrote $225,000 in church checks to third parties for nonchurch purposes and piled up $325,000 on church credit cards.
The diversions went undetected for years, Bishop Browning's statement said, because Mrs. Cooke had "absolute control" over auditing at the headquarters and prevented others from checking the books.
Church officials said they expect to recoup the lost money with a $1 million insurance policy and the sale of the two homes. The Cookes have surrendered titles to both. The Montclair home is on the market for $695,000 and the farm for $850,000.
As the church tries to recover, some at headquarters say they are wondering how well they really knew Mrs. Cooke. Her resume says she graduated from Georgetown University in 1969 with a degree in economics. But Georgetown officials say they have no record of her attending the university.
Officials at George Washington University say she was enrolled in its business school in the summer of 1962 and during the 1962-63 academic year but left without graduating.
The oldest of six children, Ellen Fahey Gerrity was raised in Vienna, Va. In 1967, she began two years of part-time work in the business office at the Washington Cathedral, the main church of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington. In 1969, she became business manager of the church's school, the National Cathedral School.
She left that job in 1971 and married an Episcopal priest, William C. Koch. In 1973, Father Koch became rector of All Saints Church in Brookline, Mass. In 1977, his wife began working for the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts and eventually became its assistant treasurer from 1980 to 1986. While she was there, her two sons, Michael and Jamie, were born.
In the mid-1980's, the couple divorced. Mrs. Cooke apparently met her current husband when she was working for the Massachusetts Diocese and Mr. Cooke, a Richmond native and a lawyer, was a seminarian at the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge.
After his ordination, Father Cooke was assigned in 1983 to a parish in Alexandria, Va. In early 1986, she left the Massachusetts Diocese to become assistant treasurer briefly of the Diocese of Virginia.
That fall, Presiding Bishop Browning named her the church's national treasurer and she transferred to Manhattan. Two years later, in 1988, Father Cooke was transferred from Alexandria to Montclair.
Two years after that, the suspected diversions started.
Father Cooke has not been officially implicated, but church officials say they want to question him about sloppy bookkeeping of about $64,000 Mrs. Cooke is believed to have transferred to a St. Luke's fund that her husband maintained without any independent oversight. One person was paid $17,000 of that money, and Bishop Spong said he wanted to know why.
During their summer and holiday visits to the Virginia farm, the Cookes were casual and chatty and they fit in comfortably with local residents.
"Everybody worked and got paid, and that's all that was said," said Sammy R. Berry, 42, a painter who lives next to the farm. "Some people you work for, they're fussing all the time -- you can't suit them to save your life. The Cookes were the nicest people you ever want to meet."
The couple became so impressed with a local cabinet maker, John Bielo, 55, that they rented him a car to drive to Montclair so he could do carpentry work in St. Luke's rectory, he said.
Sometimes, Mr. Bielo recalled, Mrs. Cooke came home from Manhattan stressed out from work. "She'd make dinner for everybody," he said, "or we'd go out to eat, and then she'd be in her office working when I'd go to bed at 10."

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: Dorothy Whipple, 94, Doctor Who Advanced Women's Rights

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Dr. Dorothy V. Whipple, who helped to secure the rights of women in the medical profession and advanced the cause of children through her widely influential work in pediatrics, died Friday at her home in Washington. She was 94.
Dr. Whipple was the first married woman admitted to Johns Hopkins Medical School ("They objected on those grounds but finally took me in," she recalled in an interview decades later) and an early advocate of rearing children by using liberal amounts of cuddling and common sense. She graduated in 1929. 
 "Be natural and easy with your baby," Dr. Whipple wrote in her 1944 book "Our American Babies." In an era when many doctors advocated strict feeding schedules and letting babies cry to exhaustion, Dr. Whipple dared to argue that feeding a baby when it was hungry might be a good idea, and she insisted that love and understanding were what counted: "Nothing we can do or provide for a baby is more important."
As for letting a baby cry on and on, she said, "I found it made a lot of difference to me whose baby was crying."
She was speaking as a mother as well as a professional, a dual role that she played long before it became common. In a 1968 interview, she said it required a sympathetic husband (in her case, the economist Ewan Clague), domestic help and "the constitution of an ox."
Happy to be called "Mrs. Clague" by some friends and neighbors, Dr. Whipple, who grew up in New York City, did not change her name when she married Mr. Clague in 1923, after her graduation from the University of Wisconsin, where she had been a speed skater. She also received a master's degree from Wisconsin before attending Johns Hopkins.
In the New Deal era, Mr. Clague helped organize the Social Security Administration and later served as Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the early 1940's, Dr. Whipple was hired by the Federal Government to revise its popular "Infant Care" pamphlet.
In her revised pamphlet, as in her book and in a syndicated weekly newspaper column on child care, she promoted a nurturing, down-to-earth way with children even as she showed her awareness of common family problems. A grandmother, she wrote, could be a blessing, or "a terrible pain in the neck."
In 1939, Dr. Whipple began a private practice in Arlington, Va., one she continued for 40 years. She was a frequent contributor to professional and popular journals and wrote two other books: "Euthenic Pediatrics" and "Q: Is the Grass Greener? Answers to Questions About Drugs."
The book on drugs was published in 1971 and advocated a more lenient approach to prosecution of marijuana-related crimes because, she argued, criminal sanctions had not stemmed the spread of drug use.
Dr. Whipple's husband died in 1987. She is survived by two sons, Llewellyn Clague of Hastings, N.Y., and Christopher Clague of College Park, Md.; a daughter, Anne Farber of Manhattan; seven grandchildren, and a great-granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Taxes a Hard Sell in Orange County

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 4

 BODY:
Before he goes to bed at night, Bill Mello sets up his personal computer, and while he sleeps, it sends out fax after fax urging voters to reject a sales-tax increase on a special ballot in Orange County next month.
As the head of the Committees of Correspondence, a local anti-tax coalition that takes its inspiration and its name from the organizers of the Boston Tea Party, Mr. Mello is part of a broad-based movement propelled by a mix of fiscal conservatism and outrage as Orange County struggles to overcome bankruptcy. 
 After chipping away at a $1.7 billion deficit with plans for layoffs, asset sales and privatization of some county services, a proposed increase in trash-dumping rates and several other measures, the five county supervisors last month took what had seemed a politically unthinkable step and put on the ballot for June 27 a measure to increase the county's sales tax by a half cent, to 8.25 percent.
The move initiated a political campaign that goes to the soul of this wealthy and conservative county where low taxes are an article of faith and politicians who advocate tax increases rarely last long.
"When did you ever hear of taxes going up and prosperity following?" asked Anita M. Mangels, a political consultant who is not a participant in the tax campaign but who expressed serious doubts about the measure. "They have got to convince people that it's a good idea to give more money to the same people that lost it the last time, and that's a hard sell."
One leading proponent of the tax is Sheriff Brad Gates, who has stepped into a leadership vacuum and spends much of his time arguing for the tax increase at various forums around the county.
"Basically, we are all angry," he said at a recent luncheon of business leaders here. "Everybody is angry, including Brad Gates. It's O.K. to feel angry. But we do have a $1.7 billion hole we have to fill. We have to pay off our debts. That's the reality."
The sometimes complacent affluence of the county was shattered last Dec. 6 when Orange County declared bankruptcy, becoming the biggest public body ever to seek protection from its creditors. Together with some 200 other local government entities including cities, school districts and public utilities, the county had placed some $7.6 billion in the county investment pool.
Last Thursday the former county treasurer, Robert L. Citron, pleaded guilty to six felony counts of defrauding investors after employing a high-risk strategy with the pool that included heavy borrowing to buy rate-sensitive derivative securities. When his bets on stable or lower interest rates crashed, the county lost $1.7 billion in investments.
At the luncheon at a hotel here, near the John Wayne Airport, which the county is now struggling to find a way to sell, opponents of the tax argued that it was a quick fix that ignored deeper problems with county management.
"They are rushing to the altar of new taxes to get things behind us as fast as they can," argued Bruce W. Whitaker, a consultant who is active with the Committees of Correspondence. "This offends the sensibilities of taxpayers: there apparently is no Plan B."
On this, Sheriff Gates agreed. "I'm telling you there's only one plan, and that's the one we have on the table. There's nothing else we've got on the table to solve the problem."
One question neither side seemed to be able to answer clearly was what would happen if the sales tax failed. The county faces a deadline this summer to pay $1.1 billion on its bond debt and to find a way to prevent broad layoffs among teachers.
Sheriff Gates warned that if the county did not pay its debts promptly it would find it prohibitively expensive to borrow in the future, schools would face painful cutbacks and vital services including public safety and health care would suffer.
Mr. Whitaker argued that the county was underestimating the amount it could recover in a suit against Merrill Lynch, which advised Mr. Citron in his investments, was backing away from deeper cuts in government operations and was failing to push privatization of services and sales of assets.
Independent analysts agree that the sales-tax measure faces an uphill battle. "It is a huge challenge for the proponents of a tax increase, within a very short period of time, to convince voters that they ought to go against their basic instincts," said Mark Baldassare, a professor at the University of California at Irvine. In a county that is 55 percent Republican, he said, voters are hearing a "counterintuitive" message from their party leaders, many of whom are advocating the tax increase at a time when Republicans in Sacramento and Washington are pressing an anti-tax, small-government message.
In a poll he conducted a month ago, soon after the ballot measure was announced, Mr. Baldassare found that 57 percent of potential voters opposed the sales tax increase, with just 36 percent in favor and 7 percent undecided. The margin of error of the poll was plus or minus 4.5 percent.
Tellingly, older voters, who are the ones more likely to vote in a small-turnout special election, were even more strongly opposed to the tax, Mr. Baldassare said.
With the campaign just getting under way, the momentum still seems to be with the anti-tax forces.
Hugh Hewitt, a radio and television commentator who strongly opposes the tax, said a major problem for the pro-tax campaigners was that despite the immensity of the county's bankruptcy, people here still live well.
"It's been six months, and people are still not seeing doom and gloom," he said. "They are not feeling the pain. So why tax themselves?"
