HEADLINE: Lack of Job Growth Creates 'Sobering' Economic Outlook

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a report on what he called a "disappointing setback," State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday that New York City's economy, which had already been lagging behind the rest of the nation's, took a turn for the worse over the nine months ending March 31. In that period, 9,000 jobs were lost.
The report appeared to support arguments, offered by several economists in recent weeks, that aggressive cuts in government spending are undermining the city's economy. It found that the heaviest job losses were in government agencies, where 29,700 jobs were cut, compared with a gain of 20,700 in the private sector. 
 But Mr. McCall, who said deep cuts in government employment had been expected, maintained that the biggest disappointment was a sharp slowdown in the growth of employment on Wall Street and in banking, advertising, manufacturing and other private industries.
For now, the report found, the city's slow climb out of its deepest recession in decades has come to a halt. In that recession, from the begining of 1989 through 1992, 342,000 jobs were lost. Only 70,900, or about 21 percent, of those jobs have been recovered.
Not only are private businesses failing to compensate for government cuts, but their prospects over the next year are grim because of the slowdown that has begun across the nation after a sharp increase in interest rates.
As things get worse for the nation, Mr. McCall said, they are bound to get worse for the city.
"Given the prospect of weaker national growth and rising unemployment, the near-term outlook for New York City's economy is sobering, at best," Mr. McCall said.
Despite its largely bleak conclusions, the report found some pockets of strength in the city. One is in personal income, which has continued to rise even while employment has declined.
"Increasingly, the city's economy is characterized by profit and income growth in the absence of meaningful job growth," the report said. It found that average wages for workers in New York City rose by 3.5 percent in 1994.
Among the strongest sectors of the city economy is tourism, which has surged since late 1993, raising hotel tax revenues by 31 percent in 1994, the report said. Retail sales have also been buoyant, rising 6.2 percent in the 12 months that ended in February, it said.
But Mr. McCall said those areas of expansion were far from enough to compensate for a mix of slow growth in private businesses and continued government cuts that will continue to take their toll over at least the next year.
Job cuts in health care, resulting from Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to reduce Medicaid reimbursement, could be significant, the report said, although it did not forecast how many jobs would be lost.
It said the city was also vulnerable if national policies miss the mark in controlling inflation and creating an environment of slow, steady growth, as has been the intention of the Federal Reserve in raising interest rates seven times over the last year.
A national recession would have a particularly harsh impact on the city, the report said. It also said the city would suffer if the dollar continued to sink against other currencies, which would prompt the Federal Reserve to raise rates even higher.
In either case, the report said, many of the city's industries would be hurt, particularly its banks and Wall Street investment firms.

HEADLINE: Round 1 on Republican Budget Begins in Senate Committee

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The Senate Budget Committee took the first tentative step today in the long march toward enacting the first Republican budget in history, with one senator after another staking out a political position for the days of debate that lie ahead.
In a morning devoted to opening speeches, Republicans held that the country's economic future rested on their plan to balance the Federal budget over the next seven years, the details of which have yet to be announced. 
 Democrats countered with the argument that the Republicans were not interested so much in fiscal discipline as they were in protecting the privileged at the expense of the poor and the aged.
On Tuesday, the committee's chairman, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, will reveal the details of his budget proposal. The plan was developed in consultation with other Republicans. It is likely to be adopted intact by the committee later this week, over the solid opposition of Democrats.
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, chairman of the House Budget Committee, also plans to release his balanced-budget plan on Tuesday.
These proposals, called budget resolutions, are broad outlines that set spending levels for large categories of Government spending. The specific program reductions needed to meet those levels will not be determined until later.
The Senate and House plans are expected to be similar, with large cuts in projected spending for Medicare and many other areas of the Government, the abolition of several Government departments and agencies and a freeze more or less in military spending.
The cuts in Mr. Kasich's proposal will be deeper than those in Mr. Domenici's because the spending reductions in the House measure offset about $350 billion in tax cuts over seven years that the House approved last month. Mr. Domenici has said that the budget he proposes will not include a tax cut.
One reason for the high political stakes is that this is the first time Republicans have been in control of Congress since it began adopting comprehensive budgets in the 1970's. Before that, spending and tax bills were approved piecemeal with little consideration of their overall effect.
In his opening speech this morning, Senator Domenici declared, "Our Government must be reined in."
"Over the next few days," he said, "we will have the debate so many of us have said we want -- a debate to balance the Federal budget. America's future, for young and old alike, will be shaped by the outcome."
He promised to slow the rate of growth in Medicare spending to 7.1 percent from 10 percent and said his proposal would order the creation of a "bipartisan Congressional commission" to recommend the changes needed in the Medicare system to reduce spending that much and prevent the system, which covers health care for 37 million elderly and disabled Americans, from running out of money by 2002. He also said he would recommend that lawmakers' salaries be frozen for the next seven years.
As for taxes, Mr. Domenici said, "It's not that I'm opposed to cutting taxes; it's just that I believe our first responsibility is to get to balance."
Democrats seized on the Medicare proposals to underscore their argument that the Republicans were out to do harm to the most needy Americans. Jim Exon of Nebraska, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee, said: "They will take a hatchet to Medicare -- but not to save the system. Oh, no! No one here is fooled by their Medicare crocodile tears. They will hack away at Medicare to pay for the House-passed Republican tax cut."
An influential Republican Congressman said today that, as one way of holding down spending, the age of eligibility for Medicare, now 65, should be gradually increased to 67.
The Congressman, Representative Bill Thomas of California, is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. He has been working with Speaker Newt Gingrich on proposals to restructure Medicare.

WOMEN WITH AIDS FIGHT TO HAVE CHILDREN
The likelihood of an H.I.V.-infected mother passing the virus to her child is 15 to 30 percent, experts say. And new studies suggest that taking the drug AZT during pregnancy can reduce the risk to 8 percent. For some women who have had to face their own mortality or lives freighted with obstacles, those are odds they can accept. They say that if they have a baby who is ill they will love it anyway. A1.

HEADLINE: Air Force Plans to Mothball Plane Used in Icy-Flying Tests

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Air Force is planning next month to mothball a special plane used in icy-flying tests, a cost-cutting move that aviation safety experts say will handicap efforts to test the performance of commercial and military planes.
The tanker plane, the only one of its kind, is used to spray water onto other airplanes in flight to test how icy conditions affect them. It was used extensively to test turboprops made by Avions de Transport Regional, the type that crashed last October in Indiana, killing all 68 people aboard. 
 The plane was also used to test an expanded de-icing system intended to better protect those ATR aircraft in conditions far more hazardous than the ones for which it and other planes were originally certified.
In a typical test, the modified KC-135 tanker aircraft, which can carry 2,000 gallons of water, uses a nozzle to spray small water droplets over a trailing plane at rates as high as 55 gallons a minute.
Through such tests after the Indiana crash, the Federal Aviation Administration and ATR found that a small but potentially dangerous ice shape could build up on the wings of the ATR aircraft in certain conditions. This prompted ATR to modify the ice protection system on the wing.
The aviation administration has asked manufacturers of similar planes to test how their aircraft perform in such extreme conditions. Its goal is to identify and correct any problems before the start of the next icy weather season in November. The F.A.A. has asked manufacturers of about 20 models of planes to test their aircraft.
The tanker, based at Edwards Air Force Base in California, is widely considered one of the most effective ways to re-create such weather conditions, and has been used to test military planes as well as commercial jetliners like the Boeing 737 and 757. Tests on commercial aircraft are paid for by the manufacturer.
"It's the best tool available at this time," said John P. Dow, a safety engineer and an icing expert for the F.A.A. An additional benefit of the tanker plane tests, Mr. Dow said, is that they can point out other visual cues for pilots that develop on the plane as early warning signs of dangerous conditions.
Other testing methods include high-speed runway taxi tests, computer simulations and wind-tunnel studies, each of which has limitations. Anthony J. Broderick, the F.A.A.'s associate administrator for regulation and certification, said that if such tests showed that a problem might exist, the F.A.A. would probably suggest that manufacturers then test their planes in actual flight tests in known icing conditions, meaning either in naturally occurring weather or behind the tanker. However, natural icing conditions can be time consuming to find.
Although the Air Force has operated icing tankers since the late 1950's, their importance has grown in recent years with the introduction of advanced wing shapes that are more sensitive to icing, said Russ Ashenden, a former manager of the tanker program and currently a research associate at the University of Wyoming's department of atmospheric science.
But Air Force officials said their decision to stop using the plane -- which they said was likely but not final -- was based on economics. The aircraft, which requires a staff of more than 20 to support it, was scheduled for a comprehensive maintenance check in October that would have cost about $2.3 million. The Air Force also saw few sure outside customers in the near future for its icing tanker program.
Mr. Dow said the F.A.A. hoped that the program might be extended for several months, allowing the F.A.A. and manufacturers to complete any required testing before the icing season begins.
Air Force officials said a final decision on the program would probably be made around June.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Are Down in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were down yesterday, fluctuating slightly in thin trading, as traders awaited a new supply of bills and notes and new data on inflation.
The market, which staged a powerful rally on Friday, began the week on a more cautious note. The Treasury begins its quarterly refinancing today with an auction of three-year notes. It will auction 10-year notes tomorrow. And the Government will report on producer prices in April on Thursday and on consumer prices on Friday. Some traders wondered yesterday whether last week's rally was overdone. 
 There is much uncertainty with the market still wanting to track higher but lacking the strong conviction regarding economic fundamentals, traders say. They see it as a euphoric mood that may only be feeding on itself.
"Fully aware that the market has moved so fast, traders are afraid to be in and afraid to be out all at the same time," said Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed- income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
Amid the uncertainties prompted by the coming inflation data and the new supply of Treasury securities, there is also a flood of money waiting to be invested, Mr. Roden noted. "The traders are scared of long end of the market, and also scared of being out of it, for fear of missing the boat," he said.
Trading, however, was quiet yesterday, with little activity coming from overseas. Financial markets were closed in London and Paris, and markets in Tokyo reopened after a five-day holiday weekend.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32 , to 10714/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 7.03 percent, from 7.02 percent on Friday. Long-term interest rates remain at their lowest in nearly a year.
Bond prices surged on Friday after a Labor Department employment report showed unexpected weakness. The report provided compelling evidence that the economy was sharply decelerating, with no threat of inflation. Ahead of the inflation data this week, traders will receive more clues about the pace of economic growth. The Federal Reserve will release its so-called beige book survey of regional economic conditions tomorrow and the Government will report on April retail sales on Thursday.
Mr. Roden of Josephthal, Lyon said he expected the market, after rising so quickly, would decline if the data this week do not support the view of an economic slowdown.
Still, he noted that the market had come a long way. "What a difference in the market in just a few months," he said, "from talk of 'When will the Fed raise rates again?' to whispers of 'When will the Fed ease?' "
Rates on shorter-maturity bills were also a bit higher yesterday, with a three-month bill up a basis point, to 5.58 percent, and a six-month bill up 4 basis points, to 5.64 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Treasury began financing $72.6 billion this week with yesterday's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.
At the auction, rates were moderately lower, with the three-month bill averaging 5.63 percent, down from last week and the lowest since April 17, when it was 5.56 percent. The six-month bill rate averaged 5.65 percent -- the lowest since Oct. 31, 1994, when it was 5.51 percent.
In the corporate debt market, the first group of issuers looking for cheap financing amid the lowest government bond yields in a while, Motorola sold $400 million of 30-year debentures with a 7.50 percent coupon at a price to yield 7.559 percent, or about 48 basis points more than a 7.50 percent Treasury due 2024.
Noncallable, the debentures are rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Quarterly Earnings at Goldman, Sachs Fall 47%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs Group L.P.'s fiscal first-quarter pretax profit fell 47 percent as earnings from trading bonds and currencies evaporated amid rising interest rates.
Profits at the nation's biggest investment banking partnership fell to $160 million in the three months ended Feb. 28 from $301 million a year earlier, according to a report by Canadian Bond Rating Service. Goldman's pretax profits do not include partners' income taxes. 
 While earnings plunged from the comparable quarter a year earlier, Goldman's results improved from its fourth quarter, when the firm lost $42 million before taxes, the rating company said.
"They are doing better," said Mark E. Bachmann, managing director at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. "The trading markets are better and the volumes are up. I think other people are having the same experience."
A Goldman spokesman declined to comment. The privately held securities firm does not release its results to the public.
Goldman expects higher profits for the current year than for the last one, when its pretax earnings fell 81 percent, to $508 million, Canadian Bond Rating Service said in the report, in which it affirmed Goldman's bond ratings.
"In 1994, Goldman, Sachs's trading results suffered from difficult conditions in the currency and fixed-income markets, reversing what has been an impeccable earnings record," the rating company said.
The 126-year-old firm, the parent of Goldman, Sachs & Company, was in the black in the first quarter, partly because it cut about 1,000 jobs and trimmed employee perks last year.
The year-to-year decline in earnings reflects the difficulty Wall Street faces in recovering from last year's bond rout. Earnings on Wall Street fell about 80 percent from 1993's record profits and last year was the worst for the United States securities industry since 1990. Trading profits disappeared and underwriting slowed to a trickle.
Goldman benefited from the rally by participating in some of the first-quarter's biggest stock sales. The firm was the lead underwriter for Nabisco Holdings' $1.1 billion initial stock sale in January. It also led securities firms in AT&T's $1.8 billion stock sale this year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Widespread Decline; U.S.-Japan Trade Friction Cited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen and other leading currencies after the United States and Japan failed to reach an accord in talks aimed at opening Japan's market to more American cars and car parts.
The last-minute negotiations in Vancouver, British Columbia, broke down Friday night. The Clinton Administration is expected to announce this week a list of sanctions on billions of dollars of Japanese goods imported into the United States 
 "The reaction of the market to the breakdown in the auto talks has been to sell dollars for yen," said Karl Halligan, vice president of strategic trading at CIC Bank New York.
The trade friction also indirectly hurt the dollar against the German mark and the Swiss franc. In times of dollar instability, the mark and the Swiss franc typically gain because of their reputations as safe-haven currencies.
"With the U.S.-Japan trade problem, the mark and Swiss franc become obvious offsets to that as security," said Steve Flanagan, foreign exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "Any escalation in U.S.-Japan problems will benefit the mark."
The dollar fell as low as 82.72 yen in Asian trading yesterday, its lowest level since April 26. In New York trading, the dollar settled at 83.27 yen, down from 83.96 yen on Friday.
The dollar fell to 1.3677 German marks from 1.3730 marks and to 1.1281 Swiss francs from 1.1346 francs.
But trading was lighter than usual yesterday because of holidays in London and Paris. In addition, dealers in Tokyo returned to their desks after a five-day holiday weekend.
While few currency dealers had expected an agreement to emerge from last week's trade talks between Japan and the United States, the possibility of an accord, however remote, had helped to underpin the dollar against the yen, dealers said. With that prop gone, the way may be clear for further dollar declines.
"The exporters still need to sell dollars," said Joe Francomano, foreign exchange trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York.
In other currency trading, the French franc gained against both the mark and the dollar after Jacques Chirac, the conservative Mayor of Paris, won the French presidential election on Sunday. Many currency dealers and analysts view Mr. Chirac as more likely to pursue prudent fiscal policies than his rival, Lionel Jospin, the Socialist Party candidate.
Doubts persist, though, about the commitment of Mr. Chirac to a strong franc, especially given his pledge to reduce unemployment.
In New York, the dollar fell to 4.8427 French francs, from 4.9055 francs on Friday.

HEADLINE: President Chirac

 BODY:
Unyielding determination and a populist campaign have at last won for Jacques Chirac the presidency of France, the prize he has sought for 14 years. Like the man he will replace, Francois Mitterrand, it took Mr. Chirac three tries to achieve his goal.
Mr. Chirac fought his way to a close victory, commendably resisting deals with the racist far right. He now restores the presidency to center-right control after 14 years of Socialist incumbency under Mr. Mitterrand. Conservatives have held a share of power since triumphing in parliamentary elections two years ago. But the Fifth Republic Constitution, designed for Charles de Gaulle, gives supreme power to the president, who names the Cabinet and directs foreign policy. 
 Like his mentor, General de Gaulle, Mr. Chirac is more of a socially minded nationalist than orthodox conservative. His main campaign theme was attacking France's 12 percent unemployment rate, for which he prescribed tax incentives and other government subsidies.
Americans will be interested in his positions on Bosnia, Europe and agriculture. He has hinted at a possible withdrawal of French peacekeepers from the former Yugoslavia, argued for more democratic checks on Brussels bureaucrats and made protection of French farmers a lifelong cause. But all of these positions involve other countries too, and Mr. Chirac will learn, as Mr. Mitterrand did, that even the powers of a French president are limited by the need to coordinate with allies and partners, especially other members of the European Union.
Lionel Jospin, the Socialist candidate defeated by Mr. Chirac in Sunday's runoff, did far better than anyone imagined at the start of his campaign. All the same, his party is now virtually shut out of national political power, with only the tiny parliamentary minority it retained in the 1993 conservative landslide.
If Mr. Chirac can now reunite the right, he will enjoy a concentration of power unrivaled in other Western democracies and unseen in France since the heady beginnings of the Mitterrand presidency in the early 1980's. May he use it well, for France and for Europe.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Facing the Next Recession Without Fear;
Newly Lean Corporations Expect to Do Fine When the Tough Times Come

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
As a longtime executive at Caterpillar, the nation's leading maker of heavy construction equipment, James W. Owens has been through the wringer.
A decade ago, battered by three straight years of losses totaling $953 million, Caterpillar Inc. was a deeply wounded company that seemed to represent everything that had gone wrong in America's industrial heartland. And even after the company made its first efforts to slash bloated payrolls and overhaul outmoded factories to stave off tough foreign competition, it still lost $404 million in 1991, during the last recession. 
 Talk to Mr. Owens today, though, and he almost sounds as if he is looking forward to the next downturn. "We'd be profitable, in my opinion," if a slump like that of the early 1990's were to hit, he said. With another wrenching upheaval under his belt, said Mr. Owens, one of two group presidents at Caterpillar, "We are prepared to weather a recessionary environment now."
Even as businesses set new profit standards today, analysts say, it is inevitable that the economy, already slowing, must eventually fall into another recession. But the experience at Caterpillar, which has chalked up record earnings as it continues to operate through a bitter strike by the United Automobile Workers, is just one of a host of examples convincing many experts that Corporate America is better prepared than ever to ride out a future downturn without the horrendous financial losses of the past.
"Clearly companies have lowered their break-even points," said Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. "They can do better in a low-volume situation, which is what we are likely to run into at some point."
While the overall economic rebound of the last few years has been moderate, Mr. Chimerine said, "it has been superb in terms of cash flow and debt reduction and profits; companies have accumulated a lot of cash."
How American business set itself up to generate big profits today while positioning itself to better absorb the shock of the next recession is a story that stirs mixed emotions. The millions of white-collar and blue-collar workers who suffered through wave after wave of layoffs in the last decade are still paying the price for Corporate America's hard-won financial rigor. They represent the human side of today's obsession with profits and efficiency.
Caterpillar, for instance, has continued to operate with replacement workers despite the yearlong U.A.W. walkout. The company insists it is just trying to create a more flexible and productive workplace. The union contends that the company, based in Peoria, Ill., has engaged in unfair labor practices. While an extreme case, Caterpillar's toughminded attititude toward labor unrest is now a central element of America's new corporate ethos.
The Big Three auto makers, which were struggling badly during much of the 1980's, have also sharply reduced costs and shortened the time it takes to get vehicles from the drawing board to the showroom floor.
In 1991, during the last recession, General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler lost a combined $7.5 billion. "If it happened today, they'd come in slightly above break even, I believe," said David Healy, an independent analyst. "I don't think any of the companies would fall into real financial difficulty."
Many other companies have managed similar turnarounds. Harley-Davidson's heavy debt burden and lumbering culture made it look like a dinosaur a decade ago, when it came within days of bankruptcy. Now, after a remarkable revival aided by temporary tariffs against foreign competitors, it is enjoying soaring profits and strong demand for its motorcycles.
Harley-Davidson's share of the American market has grown from 3 percent in 1980 to 20 percent today. Based on suggestions from its customers -- who range from the Hell's Angels to clean-cut college students -- the company has done everything from lowering its seats to improving its engines.
"They've come back from the dead, and they're probably on the threshold of another big growth spurt," said Jill S. Krutick, an analyst at Smith Barney. "They could double their capacity and still not meet demand."
Most telling, even dynamic companies that have never lost a dime are taking drastic steps to streamline operations in response to heightened competition and the desire to sustain growth through tough times.
Consider Sun Microsystems Inc., the leading manufacturer of powerful work station computers. It dominated its industry even before starting a zealous efficiency campaign several years ago. Since then, Sun Microsystems has slashed the production time for one of its systems from three months after an order arrives to just 10 days.
Factory space was cut by two-thirds even as output jumped five-fold. Revenue per employee is up to $403,000 a year from $90,000 in 1989.
The company's executives believe they are in much better shape than their rivals. Consequently, when the next recession comes, says John Shoemaker, Sun Microsystems' vice president for worldwide operations, "we'll do better in that kind of environment than in good times."
A decade ago, companies argued that they were forced to cut shop-floor workers and layers of management primarily to meet the demands of a global marketplace. The strong dollar added to pressure by making imported goods less expensive. But now, the dollar is weak and many companies are sprinting to stay ahead because of their own profit goals and fear of domestic rivals.
To be sure, some experts warn against excessive optimism. The economy, while slowing, is still in the midst of a long expansion. That cyclical improvement may be covering over many remaining problems.
"Corporations are generally in a better position," said Michael Boskin, an economist at Stanford University who was President George Bush's chief economic adviser. "However, nobody should believe the American economy is immune to serious problems in a downtrend."
Meanwhile, corporate profits are expected to climb again this year, but by 10 percent or less, not the big jumps of 30 percent or more posted last year.
And some sectors, like retailing and apparel, are already in trouble and could suffer a great deal in the next economic downturn. The aerospace industry, now a victim of dwindling military budgets, is never expected to regain its former glory and profitability.
Moreover, some experts say the job of refitting corporations to be faster on their feet is far from finished. "Yes, American multinationals have gone a long way toward becoming more competitive," said James Champy, a consultant and a co-author of "Re-engineering the Corporation," one of the biggest business best sellers of recent years. "But this is a permanent revolution that we're going to be going through for the next 10 to 25 years or so."
Still, there are several reasons so many executives and experts are not as frightened as they once were at the prospect of a recession.
For one, profits have soared. First-quarter earnings, according to estimates by Standard & Poor's, rose more than 40 percent from a year earlier. That has helped fill corporate coffers with cash.
Chrysler's $7.5 billion stockpile of cash is the focus of the company's battle with its largest shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian. Mr. Kerkorian contends that the company is now so efficient it does not need such a big cushion, while Chrysler says it needs the money to sustain crucial investments in the next recession.
Second, even some of the most vibrant American industries are going to extraordinary lengths to improve efficiency. Manufacturers of computers and electronic hardware, for example, have cut overall employment even as they continue to grow by leaps and bounds.
Bill Lewis, a senior partner at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, said, "We're going to see layoffs in the traditional parts of the economy on a continuing basis; we're always going to be shedding those jobs."
But that has been understood for years. What is surprising is that "even in computers it is going to continue," he said, adding, "It just shows how fast an industry like this matures these days."
Third, with inflation low and most people relieved just to have a steady job, wage demands are modest and pay increases have been held down for years. Companies are now moving to the next step by squeezing the costs of employee benefits. They are hacking away at everything from the costs of medical benefits to the generosity of retirement plans. Such costs were up a minuscule two-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier.
Overall employment costs rose just 2.9 percent for the year that ended on March 31, the smallest increase since the Government began collecting the figures in 1982. Indeed, adjusted for inflation, wages for production workers are down by 12 percent since 1978.
Finally, manufacturing companies are continuing to upgrade their factories, improve just-in-time delivery systems to hold down excess inventories, and increase productivity, leading to an explosion in business investment.
Caterpillar has slashed its employment from nearly 90,000 in 1979 to 54,000 today. It closed nine manufacturing plants and spent $1.8 billion to modernize its remaining factories while reorganizing to give its 13 operating divisions more autonomy. Now, some components that once took 25 days to produce are stamped out in 6.
"We've almost doubled our productivity since the mid-1980's," Mr. Owens said.
This trend has affected nearly every industry. Despite the recession, which cut sharply into output, manufacturing productivity rose by 3.2 percent a year in the United States from 1990 through 1993. That is more than double Germany's 1.5 percent pace and Japan's 1.2 percent rate.
But the successes have come at a high price in terms of careers shattered and communities disrupted. And for all the traumas of the recent past, the experts concede that there is still more pain to come.
"I hate to use the term quick deaths," said George Shaheen, worldwide managing partner of Andersen Consulting, "but we'll see winners and losers very quickly in the next recession. The market is not very forgiving."

HEADLINE: Let That Be a Lesson;
Rutgers Ousts a Well-Liked but Little-Published Professor

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 5

 BODY:
As a teacher at Rutgers University, Richard L. Barr was called "outstanding," "exceptionally talented," "one of the best." But the stack of scholarly publications he submitted was described, in the precise grammar one would expect from an English Department tenure committee, as "not so thick as the usual packet for tenure."
So as of July, Dr. Barr, an assistant professor of English, will be just Richard Barr, lecturer, forbidden even to sign university letters of recommendations for his students and required to be gone entirely from Rutgers by the summer of 1996. In the hard world of publish or perish, Dr. Barr has crashed and burned. 
 At age 38, Dr. Barr has discovered that even at Rutgers, which promotes the idea of undergraduate-friendly teaching, the only guarantee of lifetime employment at a major research institution is to have a list of scholarly credits somewhat longer than two articles, two theater reviews and an unpublished book.
"Professor Barr has not achieved a level of scholarly accomplishment to justify promotion to the rank of associate professor with tenure," wrote Joseph J. Seneca, university vice president and chairman of the promotion review committee, in March.
The decision has distressed many of the devoted students to whom Dr. Barr has fed pizza and puns during his six years at Rutgers. After all, they point out, he has won three teaching awards, including the school's own Award for Distinguished Contributions to Undergraduate Teaching. To them, the denial of tenure is a repudiation of the promise Francis L. Lawrence made when he became president in 1990: to re-emphasize undergraduate education.
"I have to say that I'm terribly demoralized to be going out into the job market after seeing what the university has done to Rick," said Abby Attias, a doctoral candidate under Dr. Barr's supervision.
Dr. Barr is a cheerful man for all his worries, and one who speaks in the metaphor of the theater, his chosen field, and of the things the audience knows and does not know, which is his specialty.
"In the foreground there is a commitment to undergraduate excellence," he said. "The problem we have is that my case was widely perceived as the best test case of the rhetoric, and Rutgers flunked. This is a victory for the idea of excellence very narrowly displayed for a scholarly audience whose international membership is smaller than the undergraduate enrollment at Rutgers."
But to hear senior Rutgers faculty members tell it, the decision to give lifetime employment is rarely clear cut, and it has become still more complicated these days. For one thing, they say, New Jersey's eight state colleges have in recent years polished their national reputations as centers of undergraduate teaching, offering employment for great teachers who are less driven to do pure scholarship.
"Almost every Ph.D. student knows the situation nationwide that there are two kinds of institutions," said Richard Foley, dean of the School of Arts and Sciences. It was Dean Foley who informed Dr. Barr of his demotion, and who responded for the university to a request for comment on tenure issues at Rutgers.
(When Dr. Foley won tenure at the University of Notre Dame at age 33, he had published 20 scholarly articles and had won one teaching award. Like Dr. Barr, he had not yet published his first book. He has had two books published.)
While state colleges would welcome a teacher with Dr. Barr's record, reduced levels of state aid have made Rutgers hungrier for faculty members with reputations that attract grants and contracts that help pay the cost of running the vast network of campuses, said an economist at Rutgers's business school in Newark.
"It's a hard thing to say, but you don't get that way by being popular with the kids," the professor said, on condition of anonymity, citing a university rule against commenting on the specifics of a tenure matter.
Indeed, popularity with undergraduates can be a kind of warning flag, said another senior faculty member.
"We have seen patterns where some young faculty members are close to their students in age, they get along well with them, they play up to them, and maybe 25 years ago they would get tenure on that basis," the professor said. "But as time goes by, their teaching does not become rejuvenated because it was based on having values similar to the students, and as they get older they have no research to fall back on."
Sometimes a great teacher remains a great teacher, the professor conceded, "but in 90 percent of the time that doesn't happen," adding, "They hit 50 or 60 and they're no use to the university."
Ms. Attias, the graduate student, rejected this argument. "To suggest that Rick is some kind of social Pied Piper to the undergraduates is tremendously patronizing to Rick and to undergraduates," she said.
Defending the university, Dr. Foley said that the tenure process at Rutgers now took far longer than before precisely because the university was trying so hard to give recognition to gifted teachers, whose talents are harder to measure than those of prolific writers.
"There's a national recognition that there was some imbalance in the promotion process whereby teaching didn't always count enough," he said. "We do look for something in a candidate that is truly outstanding and I'm afraid what is often not understood is that, when it is a lifetime employment decision, the benefit of the doubt cannot go to the candidate for tenure."
During office hours in Dr. Barr's cramped, windowless and nearly chairless office in the basement of Murray Hall, Seema Lal, a junior who had a problem with an end-of-term paper, came in and sat comfortably on the floor next to Chris Haskell, a senior.
"I was an accounting major," Ms. Lal said. "I took Rick's introductory course on theater just to see what it was. He made me an English major."
Some of Dr. Barr's friends have urged him to file a grievance, which is allowed under the tenure review rules if an oversight can be proved. Dr. Barr said the committee had failed to notice several articles he had in the works.
But he did not seem to have much interest in going another round with the university, and in the next breath he spoke of walking away from campus life altogether.
"In three years I could become accredited as a psychotherapist," he said.

The university has denied him tenure, saying that despite his reputation as an excellent teacher, his scholarly credits are too slim. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Find Suggests Weaving Preceded Settled Life

BYLINE: By BRENDA FOWLER 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
SOME 27,000 years ago, an innovative group of hunters and gatherers were in the habit of setting up their summer base camps near a river along the Pavlov Hills in what is now the southeastern Czech Republic. They mixed the fine soil with water and molded it into human and animal figurines and fired them, creating the oldest known fired ceramics. They took the two-and-a-half-million-year-old technology of flaking stone tools a step further by grinding them into smoothly polished pendants and rings, the earliest known examples of ground stone technology in Europe.
And now, at a meeting here last week of the Society for American Archeology, scientists announced that this same group, contemporaries of the earliest cave painters of France and northern Spain, has left the oldest evidence of weaving in the world. The site has yielded clay fragments bearing impressions of textiles or basketry, which according to Dr. James M. Adovasio of Mercyhurst College in Erie, Pa., and Dr. Olga Soffer of the University of Illinois at Urbana, push back the known origin of these technologies at least 7,000 years, to 27,000 years ago. 
 It also validates a suggestion long offered by some archeologists that the origin of textile technology by far predates the Neolithic period of plant and animal domestication to which it had traditionally been assigned. Archeologists tended to believe that people did not weave until they abandoned the migratory hunting and gathering way of life and settled into permanent agricultural villages with domesticated plants and animals, a process that was getting under way in many parts of the world by around 8000 B.C. and is known as the Neolithic. Once they were sedentary, the story went, they could develop such technologies as ceramics and weaving.
"I think this will really blow the socks off the Neolithic people because they always think they've got the first of everything," Dr. Soffer said in an interview. "We have this association of fabric and ceramics and ground stone technology with the Neolithic although we've known about ceramics from these people at Pavlov for a while, but it was written in Czech or German and it didn't make an impact."
Some scholars of the Upper Paleolithic, which in that part of the world stretches from about 40,000 to 12,000 years ago, had predicted that textiles might have been around at that time. "It's not very unexpected but it's very important," said Dr. Anthony Marks, an archeologist at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.
Textile specialists, especially, were encouraged by the discovery.
"It indicates how important textile structures are," said Dr. John Peter Wild, an archeologist at the University of Manchester in England. "You're way ahead of metals. The only technologies you have to compare it with in sheer brilliance of execution are stone implements. This is the organic technology that matches it."
Previously, the earliest known basketry dated to no earlier than around 13,000 years ago and the oldest piece of woven cloth was a 9,000-year-old specimen from Cayonu in southern Turkey. The oldest known twisted fibers, which could have been woven into basketry or textiles, were found in Israel and date to about 19,300 years ago.
Because baskets and textiles are made of organic materials, they perish rapidly once deposited, Dr. Adovasio said in an interview. Not surprisingly, the absence of hard evidence for textiles in the Paleolithic molded the theories on the origins and development of weaving technology.
The evidence presented last week consists of four small fragments of fired clay bearing negative impressions of a textile or finely twined basket, Dr. Soffer said. Along with hundreds of thousands of other artifacts at the rich site, they were excavated in 1954 by Dr. Bohuslav Klima, a Moravian archeologist. In the summer of 1990, Dr. Soffer, sorting through about 3,000 clay fragments in an effort to categorize them stylistically, noticed four pieces, about the size of a quarter, with markings on their concave sides.
She photographed them, with the notation "plant fibers?" and the next year showed them to her colleague, Dr. Adovasio, who, she said, went "absolutely ballistic."
Three radiocarbon dates of ashes at the site ranged from 24,870 to 26,980 years ago, and Dr. Soffer said the fragments could date from anytime between. She said she was entirely confident of the dating because there was no evidence at the site of any human occupation at all after 24,870 years ago, so the pieces could not have come from any other layers deposited later.
Analyzing magnified, high resolution photographs of the fragments, Dr. Adovasio determined that two fragments bore two different weaves and two bore indistinct parallel impressions that might be from warps, the vertical threads of a weave. He could see the alignment of the plant fibrils in the photographs so he knew the fibers were made of plant material, or bast, and not sinew, which can also be woven. Among the plants that could have provided bast were the yew and alder trees or the milkweed and nettle, the researchers said.
The archeologists did not know whether the impressions were made intentionally or accidentally. Many of the fragments were found in ash deposits. Analysis of all four showed that they had been fired at 600 to 800 degrees Fahrenheit, which is consistent with a simple kiln or a bonfire, or even a dwelling burning down, Dr. Soffer said. One possibility is that the woven item was unintentionally pressed into wet clay near a hearth -- perhaps by walking on it -- and subsequently fired.
Because the fragments are so small and no selvage, or defined edge, is apparent on them, Dr. Adovasio could not determine what they came from. He said the mesh would have been similar to that in a potato sack and might have come from a bag, mat, clothing or a basket. While it would have been possible to make the pieces without some sort of loom, it would have been far easier using one, he said, even if that meant only tying one end of the warp around a tree and the other around one's waist.
"This demonstrates an amazing investment of energy," he said.
Dr. Elizabeth J. W. Barber, a prehistoric textile scholar at Occidental College in Los Angeles, noted that plain, or true weave, involved passing a weft, or horizontal, thread over one warp thread, under the next warp thread, over the next and so one. If a nonflexible stick is woven through the warp like this, then the process can be mechanized halfway. Raising the stick lifts up every other thread of the warp (or whichever warp threads are required for the desired weave) and the weft thread can be speedily pulled through. For the following pass, the position of the separated warp threads must be reversed and that is where a heddle, which individually holds the warp threads of the second group and attaches them to a bar, comes in.
The type of weave in the Pavlov clay fragments is "twining"; though it too can produce a cloth, it cannot be mechanized because the parallel weft threads cross each other. Dr. Barber said twining produced a more stable weave because the weft threads twisted around each other and prevented sliding.
"When you see them switching from twining over to the true weave or plain weave by around 7000 B.C., then they've figured out mechanization," she said. "They've given up stability of weave for speed of production."
Dr. Adovasio noted that twining itself was already a relatively advanced form of weaving technology. He suggested twining might even be as much as 40,000 years old.
"If they're making this, then they're making cordage," said David Hyland, an archeologist at Gannon University in Erie, Pa. Cordage, essentially plant fibers twisted together, includes string and rope.
"And if they can make this, they can make anything in the way of a net, trap or snare," said Dr. Adovasio, who believes that because of the scarcity of evidence, prehistorians had underestimated the importance of woven materials in early peoples' lives. Conversely, he said, because of their relative abundance, stone tools have been overemphasized in archeologists' interpretations of prehistoric economies.
"I don't buy a lot of the gender studies stuff," began Dr. Adovasio. "But mostly men have done the analysis of Paleolithic sites and they have in their minds the macho hunter of extinct megafauna. Guys who hunt woolly mammoths are not supposed to be making these."
The model of the Paleolithic men going off with spears to hunt while the women stayed home and gathered plants around the camp may be too simple, he said.
"Maybe they killed one mammoth every 10 years and never stopped talking about it," Dr. Soffer said.
At the Pavlov and nearby Dolni Vestonice sites, for example, Dr. Klima unearthed far more bones of smaller animals than of mammoths. While the former may have been hunted with spears, it is more likely that nets were used to capture small animals like rabbits, the archeologists said.
"This tool," noted Dr. Hyland, of cloth, "represents a much greater level of success where used for hunting than lithic tools."
Dr. Adovasio, who has been working with textiles for more than 25 years, said he hoped the discovery would inspire archeologists to learn more about how textiles and basketry decayed and to pay more attention to the possibility that textiles or their impressions are preserved on sites.
One mystery is what became of the apparently advanced technologies of these Central European hunters and gatherers after 22,000 years ago, when, as the weather gradually turned colder, the archeological record of their presence in the Pavlov Hills suddenly ceased.
"You've got the huge Scandinavian ice sheet coming down from the north and glaciers coming from the Alps and you get this no-man's land and people get out of there," Dr. Soffer said.
She suspects that some went east and some southeast. But except for a few random fired ceramics and bits of net or cord in eastern Europe, the technologies themselves remain silent for the next 7,000 to 10,000 years. When they resurface, the skills the Pavlov people employed so fancifully have been converted to practical purpose. The technique of stone grinding, instead of being used in decorative items alone, is now applied to making hoes and axes. Fired clay turns up not in figurines but in cooking and storage vessels.
"It had never dawned on these people that they could make a pot," Dr. Soffer noted.
Textiles and basketry, too, anchor themselves firmly into the technological landscape.
"It's like who invented the first flying machine? Leonardo da Vinci," Dr. Soffer said. "But Boeing didn't start making them until this century. There has to be a social and economic context for new technology. If you don't have the context, then it won't really go anywhere."

HEADLINE: Lead-Based Battery Used in Electric Car May Pose Hazards

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
For years, electric cars and vans powered by lead-based batteries have been promoted as a way to reduce health-damaging urban smog. But now the potential risk from production of the batteries, long quietly acknowledged, is drawing more careful scrutiny from scientists, and their findings are alarming.
In a forthcoming study, three researchers at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh suggest that emissions from mining, smelting and recycling the lead needed for a large fleet of electrical vehicles would pose serious threats to public health. 
 Thus, while Government regulations requiring the sale of electric cars are intended to improve public health by limiting smog, they may have the indirect effect of exposing thousands of people living or working near industrial sites to toxic doses of lead.
"We're talking about very real health hazards," said Robert Hahn, an environmental economist at the American Enterprise Institute. "This could be the kiss of death for electric vehicles."
The potential risk from lead batteries illustrates a fundamental conundrum for policy makers. Aggressive efforts to clean up the air, water and land often drive rapid changes in technology, which in themselves may prove hazardous. Even seemingly more benign battery technologies based on other materials could have unintended consequences.
"Loading the environment with any primary metal is going to lead to problems," said Dr. Ellen Silbergeld, a toxicologist at the University of Maryland Medical School.
Exposure to low levels of lead can harm the brains of young children, reducing intelligence and impairing neurobehavioral development, studies have found. Very severe exposure can cause coma, convulsions and death.
The electric car question has its origins in the Clean Air Act, which set tough health standards for ozone exposure. To meet them, California, New York and Massachusetts are demanding the introduction of "zero emissions vehicles" by 1998, with 10 percent of all new cars meeting the zero-emissions test by the year 2003.
The only zero-emissions vehicles close to mass production are powered by electricity that is stored by conventional means. "First-generation electric cars will have lead-acid batteries," said Bob Hayden, executive director of the Electric Vehicle Association of the Americas.
Electric cars have already run a gantlet of controversy. Auto makers maintain that vehicles using current technology, which have a very limited range, could not be sold at cost -- even in the modest numbers mandated by state rules. Thus, they say, they will be forced to "cross-subsidize" buyers, raising the prices of conventional internal combustion cars to cover the difference.
Many economists who share the policy makers' sense of urgency in containing urban smog are nonetheless critical of the zero-emissions requirement because it does not give auto makers the flexibility to meet the targeted emissions level for automobiles with less radical technology. And even some environmentalists acknowledge problems underlying the electric car remedy. They note that the extra electricity generated to charge car batteries will come from power plants that also generate pollution.
"Of course there are trade-offs," said David Driesen of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
In an article to appear this month in the journal Science, Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie Mellon, along with Chris Hendrickson and Francis McMichael, his colleagues in engineering, estimate a life-cycle scenario for emissions associated with lead-acid batteries. Their scenario, "available technology," is based on the specifications of the General Motors Impact vehicle, now being tested around the country. The study was supported largely by the National Science Foundation, with other funds from I.B.M. and A.T.& T.
To create a best-case scenario, the researchers imagine a "goal technology" car with batteries that use one-third as much lead to generate the same amount of power, yet last twice as long. They use data from the Bureau of Mines, an agency of the Interior Department, and the Environmental Protection Agency to estimate the amount of lead that would be lost in the environment during the life-cycle of the battery from both scenarios.
According to their calculations, an "available technology" car would indirectly generate 1,350 milligrams of lead emissions for each kilometer (about five-eighths of a mile) traveled. The "goal technology" car does much better, at 120 milligrams of lead per kilometer. But a car using even this relatively clean technology would push six times as much lead into the environment as a tiny Geo Metro burning gasoline with the lead additives that were gradually eliminated in the 1980's.
The form of the pollutant matters, of course. Lead from leaded gasoline went out the vehicle's tailpipe; the Carnegie Mellon scientists concede that five-sixths of the emissions from smelting and recycling would be more manageable solids and liquids.
As important, emissions from leaded gasoline were concentrated in urban areas, while emissions from the battery life-cycle would be focused near smelters and recyclers. "Location isn't everything," says Rob Stavins, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, "but it's almost everything."
Dr. Silbergeld, the toxicologist, is not mollified. "Lead particles can move long distances," she said. "This is potentially a global problem."
She also worries that in their zeal to encourage the recycling of lead batteries, regulators have underestimated the risks from recycling plants, many of which operate near urban areas.
Thus, while it may be technically possible to clean up lead smelting and reprocessing, there is little indication that the Government has the will or skill to do the job. Nor is there hard evidence about how much cleaner lead technologies would add to the already high cost of electric vehicles.
The magnitude of the health problem depends, of course, on the number of vehicles powered by lead batteries. But even the relatively modest penetration implied by the state mandates could generate large-scale emissions.
If just 5 percent of the 200 million vehicles in the United States were powered by batteries made entirely of lead processed by responsible recyclers, Mr. Lave estimates that an extra 21,000 tons of lead would be released each year into the environment. That would nearly double the amount now lost in smelting and manufacturing.
Environmentalists who want to keep the pressure on Detroit to build electric vehicles expect that technology and economics will eventually favor materials more benign than lead. But that is only a hope.
Batteries based on nickel, nickel-cadmium, sulfur-sodium and lithium all show some promise, as do hybrid systems combining smaller batteries with flywheels or capacitors to meet peak power demands. But they are likely to remain more expensive than lead-acid systems, which in turn cost far more to build and operate than the cleanest-running internal combustion engines.
"We haven't closed the door on other technologies," said Chris Preuss, a spokesman for Chrysler, "but it's not looking good."
David Hawkins, a senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council and an architect of the Clean Air Act, thinks the risks implied by forcing electric cars into the nation's vehicular fleet are worth taking. The alternative, he said, is dependence on super-clean gasoline engines that require careful, and politically unpopular, inspection and maintenance.
"We think it makes more sense to try to pick winners than to settle for losers," Mr. Hawkins said.
But others are critical of using environmental policy to force industry to invent new technologies in general, and the zero-emissions mandate in particular. "Regulation leads to innovation," says George Eads, a consultant in Washington and a former chief economist at General Motors, "but it is often the wrong innovation."
Mr. Eads also maintains that the strict timetable for zero-emissions vehicles, meant as a wake-up call for Detroit, has already had a perverse effect. Since auto makers are under immense pressure to put electric cars on the road that will not haunt them with repair or safety problems, "the mandate puts a premium on using the most conservative technological option," he said -- in this case, lead-acid batteries.
"Getting rid of lead in gasoline was one of the great public health triumphs of our generation," Mr. Lave said. "It would be a tragedy if we reversed the benefits in the name of environmentalism."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Science Times on Tuesday about lead pollution arising from the making of lead batteries for electric vehicles misstated an estimate of the average amount of indirect lead emissions generated by an electric car using available technology. It is 1.350 grams per kilometer, not 1,350.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
The Roots of Terrorism In the Power of Speech

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
In a typically acidulous mood, H. L. Mencken wrote in 1929: "The danger of free speech does not lie in the menace of ideas, but in the menace of emotions. If words were merely logical devices, no one would fear them. But when they impinge upon a moron they set off his hormones, and so they are justifiably feared. Complete free speech, under democracy, is possible only in a foreign language."
Mencken, as usual, was referring to the Puritanical spirit, mob mentality and generally dim intellectual powers of the booboisie, particularly when joined in prayer, boostership or vigilantism. How he would deal with the issues of liberty and democracy stirred by the Oklahoma City bombing, we can only surmise. But with much concern being voiced these days over the power of words, his own words retain considerable force. 
 Though always willing to assume the worst about politicians as a class, Mencken could not have resisted doing a job on the politician-hating militia members who have recently been discovered by television. Their comical camouflage, sappy strutting and he-man pretentions, their free-floating charges, rote slogans and bellicose incoherence, all lately displayed on screen, would have been rich grist for a writer who found joy in reviewing the latest vaudeville acts of his countrymen.
The militianiks are a very small bunch, but television interviews in their neighborhoods and the comments of callers to various television and radio programs indicate their ravings are considered worth something by many outside their circle. The ground has been prepared by the ranters of the airwaves. To judge by the popularity and apparent influence of radio and television yakkers, millions of Americans are intellectually deprived or emotionally disadvantaged.
Although President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich may safely inveigh against those whose words may have somehow inspired a terrorist bomber or a mother who killed her children, no politician is likely to suggest in public that the main argument against free speech is the susceptibility of the audience. When an office holder or a campaigner utters the phrase "the American People" (by all odds the most-uttered phrase on the Sunday interview programs) it is in tones of respect shading into reverence. Politicians can teach a thing or two to television producers about pandering to the customer.
Sure there is too much rant, too much hate and of course too much violence on most channels, many radio stations and elsewhere along the ever expanding, mercilessly accessible information highway. The sewage in the flow cannot be good for the national ecology. The legal problem is making the connection between a G. Gordon Liddy instructing his fans on where to shoot a Federal agent and an actual act of terrorism.
But you can't blame television or radio for violence in America; it's as old as the nation. In the past, Americans have by and large resisted the worst rabble-rousers and probably, with outrages like Oklahoma City fresh in mind, will continue to do so. But the times they could be a-changing.
What is new is the reach, impact and audacity of all sorts of what is loosely termed communication, combined today with nervous-making economic difficulties and social strains in big cities and small towns, with the political fragmentation and religious zealotry of the New World Order and with easier ways of making more destructive explosives. The Justice Department would be remiss if it did not take into account the fact that your common run of monomaniac or wishful martyr can build a bomb and be induced to use it.
The stock in trade of the yakkers -- that powerful forces in and out of Government are kicking around just plain folks -- can only agitate receptive hormones. The enduring problem that Mencken so frequently and entertainingly described is the vulnerability of democracy to demagogy, a condition that has been much heightened by the noise explosion. So Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich had better begin worrying more about the audience than about the performers. Whether the fertilizer comes from Oliver North or Oliver Stone or a white separatist or a black nationalist, it seems to find a volatile following.
The current pressure on the yakkers to tone down their agitprop is deserved, but they will assuredly be at it again as long as their shows get the ratings. By comparison, the soap operas they have nudged aside are harmless diversions; the soaps may not do much for the mind, but they do not poison the political air.
It is not for a democratic government to tell people what to listen to or watch. What a reviewer can suggest (how Mencken would have scorned this milk-and-water prescription) is that the welcome being given to the merchants of rant should draw the most urgent attention to the schools that continue not to educate and the conditions that continue to unhinge, with all respect, the American People.

HEADLINE: U.S. Blacks Pledge Aid For Africa

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The American minister who organized a conference in Senegal that brought together 1,000 black Americans and 4,000 African government officials and business executives said today that the meeting was the first step toward building a movement for American blacks to help Africa.
The Rev. Leon Sullivan, the civil rights leader from Philadelphia who organized the conference, said the Americans who attended pledged to promote trade with Africa, defend foreign aid to that continent and set up education and health projects to help dozens of countries. 
 "A new movement is being born among African-Americans," Mr. Sullivan said in an interview. "We're going to build bridges to Africa. We're going to put our skills and training to work to help Africa."
Twenty African Presidents and Prime Ministers attended the Dakar conference, which ended last Friday. Mr. Sullivan said the 1,000 black Americans there represented "the largest number of blacks to return to Africa since the end of slavery."
Among those attending were Commerce Secretary Ronald Brown, Mayor Marion Barry of Washington, Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
Participants said the conference emphasized trade and investment more than it did foreign assistance.
"Trade, not aid, and the power of Africans and African-owned enterprises in the international marketplace will bring hope and progress to this continent," Mr. Brown said.
He said American business has a crucial role to play to create jobs and teach skills in Africa. "America will no longer concede the African marketplace to Europeans," he said.
African leaders urged the industrial world to forgive much of the continent's $300 billion foreign debt, while American officials and executives said African countries needed to do more to reduce inflation and budget deficits and improve education.
During the official sessions, there was little effort to urge African nations like Nigeria to embrace democracy. Mr. Sullivan said the purpose of the meeting was to promote economic development and education.
He vowed to build a movement in which one million American blacks were committed to help Africa. He said he wanted these blacks to help Africa as much as Polish-Americans help Poland and American Jews help Israel.
In his keynote address, Mr. Sullivan urged American blacks to obtain dual citizenship with an African country as a means of strengthening their ties with that continent.
He said his movement will press Congress not to cut aid to Africa, saying that it is hard for African countries to move toward democracy when tens of millions of people on the continent are hungry.
"What Congress is trying to do to aid to Africa is denigrating to black people in the United States," he said. "American aid is a lifeline to a lot of people in Africa."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Still Pricier Fountain Pens Gain Cachet and Profit

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: HAMBURG, Germany

 BODY:
To the generation accustomed to the Web and cyberspatial schmoozing, the fountain pen is about as useful as a quill. But to increasing numbers of people, it is an item of such allure that they think nothing of paying a sum that could get a computer aficionado a down payment on a respectable laptop.
In the $5 billion worldwide market in writing instruments -- everything from plastic ballpoints to gold-nibbed fountain pens -- the fastest-growing segment is in premium pens, those costing more than $50. 
 Spurring this boom is a clientele receptive to the idea that expensive fountain pens are antidotes to the ubiquity and instant obsolescence of many high-tech products. Not since the heyday of fountain pens in the 1910's and 20's has there been a greater variety of pens offered in department and stationery stores.
The potential market for pens is much wider now than it was in the 80's, when fountain pens came back into vogue after a hiatus of a few decades. The traditional markets for fountain pens are the United States and Europe. But, says Christopher Rhodes, marketing director of the Gillette stationery products division in Britain, demand is particularly strong now in the vibrant economies of Asia and among emerging elites in Eastern Europe and Russia.
Elysee, a German-owned company, set up American headquarters in 1991 in the Chatsworth area of Los Angeles, offering pens ranging in price from $65 to $450. Each year since, it has seen a 50 percent increase in sales. Gillette -- the razor, personal-care products and writing-instrument conglomerate based in Boston, and owner of the Paper Mate, Parker and Waterman companies -- had a nearly 10 percent rise last year in premium-pen sales in the United States.
The Geneva-based Vendome Group, parent company of Montblanc, Dunhill and Cartier, all prestige pens, reported 1993-94 sales of writing instruments totaling about $290 million, an 11 percent increase over the previous year.
These days, the customers being sought ever more aggressively by premium-pen companies are not board-room types or collectors who seek the limited editions of pen sets costing thousands of dollars. Increasingly, the targets are those who have not thought of using anything other than the ballpoint or roller ball or people who have just discovered the fountain pen and are willing to venture up into the premium price range.
In their marketing campaigns, pen companies are seeking to persuade the unconverted that when you've made it -- or when you want people to think you've made it -- you should say it in writing. The campaigns tout fountain pens as ego-boosting devices that will transform even indifferent penmanship into what a Montblanc ad campaign calls "the art of writing." The latest Parker ads suggest that a fancy pen will bring out the poet in the purchaser.
Pen marketers don't have to explain why their products are getting more expensive as computers become cheaper. In this fast-changing cyber-age, they can make much of the notion that their products have investment value, and an esthetic far superior to that of the latest wunderchip.
"For the customer today, the idea that a product will be more expensive in five years' time than when they bought it is not worrying," said Norbert A. Platt, Montblanc's chief executive, "because everything you buy today is devalued when you buy it and that's true of all high-tech products." A pen, Mr. Platt noted in an interview here, "might last not only for a lifetime but also for the lifetime of a son or daughter."
This, he added, "is a very reassuring thought."
Over the last seven or eight years, Montblanc's prices have doubled -- far exceeding production costs. The company's limited-edition Writer series -- with pens named after Ernest Hemingway, Agatha Christie, Oscar Wilde and Voltaire -- costs more than $1,500 for a set of fountain pen, ball pen and retractable pencil. In what Montblanc calls its De la Culture series, production is restricted to 4,810 fountain pens, each costing $1,700.
The limited-edition market continues to grow, said Nancy Olson, editor of Pen World in Dallas. The reason seems obvious. Aurora's limited-edition Carlo Goldoni fountain pen, which sold for about $900 when its 1,492 units went on the market in 1993, now sells for three times that.
Montblanc executives say collectors have been known to pay as much as five times the original price for some of their limited-edition pens within a few years of their manufacture.
For the rich collector, Montblanc will build a special-order, diamond-studded, solid gold version of its classic black Meisterstuck fountain pen for around $120,000, probably the most expensive fountain pen in the world. The solid gold Aurora Optima pen sells for about $1,900; the new Waterman model, the Edson, for about $700.
Jostling for an edge over their competitors, premium-pen companies are constantly trying to come up with that extra special product. "There has been a shift to pens that are unusual, that have character, that are much more a statement of personality," Mr. Rhodes of Gillette said.
A. T. Cross, long known for its thin gold pens, came out in 1993 with fatter pens in various lacquer colors. Its newest has a lapis blue coating, using powdered lapis lazuli, that is flecked with gold and costs $350.
To sell itself as purveyor to the carriage trade, Montblanc in the mid-80's discontinued a range of cheaper writing instruments. "We believed we could build a business by focusing entirely on the upper type of manufacturing," Mr. Platt said. He declined to offer details of his company's operations, but said production was kept lower than capacity to maintain scarcity.
Montblanc tries to maintain a certain mystique, as well: the black resin for its pens is made from a mixture as closely guarded a secret as the formula for Coca-Cola. In addition, the number 4,810 -- the height in meters of the highest peak in the French Alps, Mont Blanc -- recurs on nibs, limited editions and in the number of diamonds set in the $120,000 Meisterstuck Solitaire Royal.
Elysee, which was bought by Staedtler Mars, a German drawing-instruments company, in 1991, emphasizes the way its pens are made. According to its promotional brochures, its pen makers in Pforzheim, Germany, use processes particular to jewelry making -- such as layering platinum plating over gold plating or filling sculptured paneling with lacquer or applying yellow gold plate to a layer of black gold.
Manufacturers are coming up with other ways of increasing their sales. In 1992, Montblanc took over Seeger, a high-quality German leather- and travel-goods company, so it could offer leather writing accessories like organizers and pen wallets. It also sells its own high-price writing paper.
With nostalgia a big selling point nowadays -- and capitalizing on a thriving market for old pens -- many high-end pen companies are tapping into that market.
In the United States, Capella just came out with a sterling silver Victorian-look ballpoint that sells for $125. Later this year, Parker will offer a limited-edition fountain pen named Mandarin Yellow that is a throwback to Duofold orange pens of the 1920's.
The price tag: $750.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pens at the end of a Montblanc production line. The brand, hailed in its ads as essential to "the art of writing," is one of the premium lines enjoying a boom -- a reaction formation in a cyber-age, perhaps.
