HEADLINE: Plan to Abolish Commerce Dept. Risky for G.O.P.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The most prominent Government department chosen for elimination in the Republican budget announced today is also the one that the Clinton Administration has declared to be the Government's most potent weapon in an age of international economic conflict: the Commerce Department.
Under the budget proposal, presented by Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, the parts of the Commerce Department that have promoted American exports abroad and paid for research in new technology would be ended outright. Other functions of the department, which has a budget of $4.2 billion this year, would be spread among other Government entities. 
 It is an odd political calculus, because American business executives -- including some traditional supporters of the Republican Party -- have been big enthusiasts of the Commerce Department in recent years. They argue that after years of mismanagement, the department has finally learned how to compete with Japan and Germany in securing contracts for American business abroad. But to Mr. Domenici and many other Republicans, the Commerce Department represents everything that the new Republican majority in Congress is out to abolish, a symbol of Government interference in the market economy.
"The budget that we put before you presents hard choices, and I make no apologies for that," Mr. Domenici said. "The American people by overwhelming majorities, 80 percent of them, want a balanced budget."
The Administration was quick to denounce the Republican plan, which predicts savings of a billion dollars a year after the department is dismantled. "I would characterize the proposals as ludicrous," Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said in a telephone interview today. "They are best described as unilateral disarmament in the battle for global competitiveness."
It is a theme that the Administration is likely to strike again on Wednesday, when the White House is expected to announce that President Clinton has decided to proceed with trade sanctions against Japan for its unwillingness to agree to purchase more American automobiles and parts. Commerce Department officials have played a central role in the negotiations and in designing what they call advocacy programs to press the cause of American businesses abroad.
Mr. Brown said today that the department's International Trade Administration, which runs the "war room" that tracks American business efforts abroad and uses everyone from President Clinton on down to advance their cause, has helped businesses win $25 billion in contracts, on a budget of $250 million a year.
Many business leaders have come to the defense of the Commerce Department in recent months. C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of Hughes Electronics, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said today: "It's easy to forget that many of the big deals and large transactions these days are not business to business; they are between American business and some Government entity -- an Indonesian energy project, or a Chinese satellite, or a Norwegian missile. I'm not saying that we can't reduce the size of the bureaucracy, or consolidate the number of Government agencies that deal in exports. But to get rid of these functions, that would be madness."
There are competing theories about why the Commerce Department is seen as such a ripe target. One is Mr. Brown's own political vulnerability: He is under investigation for a variety of private dealings, and many Republicans have said in recent months that he is not in a strong position to defend his own department. He replied today, "If they are expecting me to roll over, they are mistaken."
A second theory is that the constituency of the Commerce Department is limited. Its programs do not have the reach of Medicare or even the Education Department.
And a third is that the Republican leadership is betting that big business, in the end, will not come to the aid of the department. Business leaders, according to this theory, are interested first in lower taxes and second in the dismantlement of Government regulation. Winning business abroad, this argument goes, comes in a distant third.
The Democrats are betting that the strategy will backfire, especially at a time of renewed trade tension with Japan. The business advocacy effort and the department's Advanced Technology Program, which provides seed money for technological ventures, were responses to the kinds of Government initiatives that Japan and other major industrialized nations have promoted for years. "It's a rare chance that you can make the case that Republicans are anti-business and anti-exports," one of Mr. Clinton's advisers said late today. "And this is that chance."
In fact, breaking up the Commerce Department may have more symbolic effect than budget impact. More than a third of its budget, or about $1.78 billion, goes to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which includes the Government's primary weather-prediction operations and would in large part be preserved under the proposal. The contribution of the Commerce Department to research and development -- one of the main targets of the Republicans -- is about 1 percent of all Government R.& D. spending.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Offers Budget That Balances

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
After months of making many promises but offering few specifics, Republican senators today proposed a historic plan that showed in actual dollars and cents how they hope to balance the Federal budget with cuts in projected Government spending of nearly $1 trillion over the next seven years.
Money would be saved in virtually every area of Government except Social Security, which would be untouched, and law enforcement, where spending would be allowed to rise by about 20 percent over the period. Military spending would basically be frozen, with no increase allowed for inflation. 
 The plan, called a budget resolution, is the first step in what is expected to be an arduous journey that will take most of the rest of the year and almost certainly dominate political discourse. Republicans in the House of Representatives will present their budget plan on Wednesday.
In many respects, the Senate plan is short on details. Democrats maintained that the Republicans still had no notion of what some of the biggest spending reductions would entail. They were especially critical of the lack of specifics about how to save money in Medicare. The Republicans would turn over decisions about Medicare to a bipartisan commission rather than bear the political heat of making those decisions directly.
The most prominent Government department that would be eliminated under the plan is also one that the Clinton Administration has declared to be the Government's most potent weapon in global economic battles: the Commerce Department. [Business Day, page D1.]
In terms of dollars saved, the biggest bite would come in the Government's health programs -- Medicare, which covers the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid, which covers the poor. Under the plan, Medicare spending would be $255.6 billion, or 15 percent, below what it would be without changes in the law governing the program. Medicaid spending would be $175 billion less, or 18 percent. But few details were offered about what policies would be changed to achieve those savings.
Spending for the programs would continue to rise, but the rate of growth would be slowed, to 7.1 percent from 10 percent for Medicare and to 5 percent from 10 percent for Medicaid. Republicans said the Medicare savings were needed in part to keep the trust fund that finances hospital care from going bankrupt in 2002.
As an indication of the political wars ahead, dozens of retirees spread across Capitol Hill today to protest the Medicare figures. Many wore buttons asserting that retired people would have to pay $900 a year more for their health care under the Republicans' plans.
Some smaller Government programs would be cut even more deeply in percentage terms than the health programs. Energy programs, for example, would be cut by 39 percent, and spending for community and regional development programs would be 32 percent lower.
The resolution, the first ever offered envisioning a balanced budget, was presented to the Senate Budget Committee by Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman.
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the head of the Budget Committee, plans to offer a parallel measure on Wednesday. Tonight, he issued a sketchy statement indicating that the cuts he would make in projected spending would be even deeper than Senator Domenici's.
That is because over the seven-year period the House measure must offset about $350 billion in tax cuts that were approved by the House last month. The Senate has not acted on the tax bill, and Senator Domenici's proposal makes no allowance for such a loss of revenue.
The purpose of a budget resolution is to set dollar limits for broad categories of Government programs like transportation, agriculture, education and the military. The resolution makes suggestions for how the targets can be met, but they are only for guidance, and the actual policy decisions are left for later.
In many instances, though, Senator Domenici's proposed budget resolution offers precise suggestions for how the savings could be achieved.
It recommends, for example, eliminating Federal operating subsidies for mass transit and Amtrak. In suggesting that the Commerce Department be abolished, it proposes transferring the department's most essential agencies to other departments. It would terminate President Clinton's volunteer service program and cut financing for the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities in half.
But in places where the political choices are tougher to make, especially Medicare and Medicaid, the Domenici proposal was shy of specifics. In the case of Medicare, for instance, the chairman proposed only that the bipartisan commission develop the policies necessary to reduce spending by 15 percent.
The administration of Medicaid would be turned over to the states, and poor people might no longer be entitled to benefits merely because they meet the eligibility requirements. Beyond that, no details were offered about how the spending target could be hit.
For Senator Domenici, scarred from many budget battles of the past, the submission of his proposal today was the fulfillment of a dream. "I'm thrilled today to present the first balanced budget in about 25 years," he told his committee. "I'm very proud."
For years, he has argued for a balanced budget. Democrats have always responded, "Put up or shut up."
Today, whatever the drawbacks in his offering, he answered that challenge.
Under criticism from Democrats that he was protecting the privileged while cutting programs for the poor and elderly, Senator Domenici declared, "It's going to turn out to be fair."
But Democrats were skeptical. Referring to the plan to have a commission figure out what cuts to make in Medicare, Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina said, "You and I have been in Government long enough to know that's a cop-out."
If Senator Domenici's resolution prevails, no large tax cuts would be at hand, but he held out the possibility that some might come later.
Economists believe that if Congress adopts a credible balanced budget plan, the nation would enjoy a stronger economy because interest rates would fall. The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that this economic dividend, small at first, might save $170 billion over the next seven years in interest payments on Government bonds.
Senator Domenici proposed that this dividend go for tax cuts. But the amount would be tiny in the first few years and reach a meaningful level only after the turn of the century.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who is running for the Republican Presidential nomination, has promised to offer a tax-cut amendment when the budget resolution reaches the Senate floor, probably next week. But by most accounts, the Gramm amendment will be voted down.
In fact, the Republicans' party discipline is such that the budget resolutions are likely to sail through the Senate and House unscathed. But the solid front may crack when the time comes later in the year to tally up who would lose the most from the budget cuts.
Already, Senator Domenici has made some concessions to politics. Cognizant of a furor that developed in March after the House voted to reduce the Federal school lunch program, Mr. Domenici left that popular program alone.
Based on the material presented tonight, the House budget resolution would one-up Mr. Domenici in several respects. Where the Senator would abolish one Cabinet department, for example, Mr. Kasich would shut down three: Commerce, Education and Energy.
"We're doomed without this," Mr. Kasich said tonight after he had outlined his proposal for fellow Republican representatives. "It's now or never."

HEADLINE: BOARD IS GIVING IN OVER SCHOOL CUTS

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Board of Education officials conceded yesterday that they are likely to find a way to cut the school bureaucracy by hundreds of millions of dollars next year without affecting classrooms very much, just as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said they could.
Their conciliatory tone is a dramatic shift. Since last June, each time the Mayor issued orders to slash, arguing that the city could ill afford to support a bloated school system, Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines and other school officials responded that they could cut some, but warned of bigger classes and teaching layoffs. Since then, though, the school system has cut $540 million from the board headquarters bureaucracy by eliminating 2,000 jobs, cutting back on school supplies and ending extras like some sports programs. 
 Now, the same officials are saying that they are close to meeting the Mayor's target of reducing the total budget by an additional $400 million, from $8.5 billion, to $8.1 billion, and the classrooms will largely be insulated from the cuts.
"The billion-dollar problem is going to be solved in one year," Leonard Hellenbrand, the budget director for the Board of Education, said at a budget briefing for reporters yesterday. "It's a daunting challenge, but we have to do it."
There is no doubt that students and parents will feel some of the pain of the budget ax: bigger special-education classes, fewer after-school programs and almost no money for arts and music, officials said. But no teacher layoffs are planned, and class sizes should not grow significantly next year even though school enrollment is expected to rise by about 20,000 students.
The air of resignation at the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn signals what may be a new spirit of cooperation between school officials and City Hall. Where once there was public feuding between Mr. Cortines and the Mayor over how much the school budget could stand to be reduced, now both sides are working together to find a way to accomplish the streamlining of the giant school system.
"There is a much more positive approach on both sides right now, and it's very, very positive for both the city and the school system," the Mayor said in an interview. "At times in the past, there was a feeling that the city was hiding money on the board, and the board was hiding money on the city, and it took a while for the board to understand that we were not hiding money and we were not playing games with them."
Dr. Robert Berne, dean of New York University's Wagner School of Public Service, said both the Mayor and the Chancellor, in spite of their earlier bickering, both essentially want the same thing: a better public education for New York City children. The two, he said, have probably finally concluded that their feuding was counterproductive.
"Now, the decibel level has lowered significantly," he said.
Yesterday, Mr. Hellenbrand and Barry F. Sullivan, who as chief operations officer for the Board of Education is effectively the system's No. 2 official, said they were still trying to find the last $149 million in savings. This is all spending that they are obligated to do by law or labor agreements.
For example, they said, the labor contract with teachers requires the board to spend $584,043 for teacher sabbaticals, while the city budgeted nothing for that category.
School officials said they needed $2 million for psychologists required in the special education area. The city budget gave them nothing for that category.
Also, school officials estimated that they would need $468,166 to cover postal rate increases because of inflation. The city budgeted no money for such an expenditure.
Mr. Sullivan said school lobbyists in Albany were working to relieve the school system of some of the costly requirements for special education that critics have said are not necessary. That may bring relief in much of the $150 million shortfall.
Mr. Hellenbrand and Mr. Sullivan say the final tally is almost $1 billion from what the system needs. In this total, they are including such things as loss of one-time funds for certain programs and other revenue they counted on for next year's budget.
The board's projection for its budget shortfall constantly changes throughout the year as spending exceeds projections and anticipated revenues do not come in exactly as expected. During this school year, the school system was told to make cuts several times as the Mayor discovered new shortfalls in the city budget, which supplies nearly half of the school budget.
School officials said they did not want to minimize the pain the school system will undergo with a budget that must be tightened even as schools accommodate a larger and larger student population, now exceeding one million. More than 40,000 additional children enrolled this year, and next year 20,000 more are expected.
Next year, they added, there will be a variety of service cuts just on the periphery of the classroom. For example, to reduce spending on transportation, the school system may provide bus service to fewer students. Schools will be asked to look to private industry to provide computer equipment if they want to make it a part of their curriculum. New schools planned to ease overcrowding will not be built.
In the past, the Mayor and the Chancellor have clashed publicly over the amount of cuts they each believed the school system could weather. In April 1994, the Chancellor resigned briefly over a budget dispute with the Mayor -- which included Mr. Giuliani's demand that he dismiss Mr. Hellenbrand. Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly accused the Chancellor of crying wolf over what budget reductions would mean to the school system.
When Mr. Cortines faced midyear budget cuts a few months ago, he told City Council members that teacher layoffs were a possibility, a threat that did not come to pass.
Yesterday's remarks by Mr. Hellenbrand and Mr. Sullivan seemed to be more in line with the Mayor's contentions as he has tackled the city's overwhelming budget problems: that an ax could be taken to the budget without causing New Yorkers any real pain.
"Threadbare is the word I would use to describe the school system under the new budget," Mr. Sullivan said.
Dr. Berne said that what has probably created a more cooperative atmosphere between City Hall and the Board of Education is the involvement of Mr. Sullivan and Marc V. Shaw, the Mayor's budget director, in the talks. Mr. Sullivan, a former banker who was Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economics under Mayor David N. Dinkins, knows his way around City Hall better than some other board administrators. He was named to his post in September, while Mr. Shaw, who was appointed just four months ago, has children in the public schools.
Dr. Berne also said the Mayor and the Chancellor appeared to have toned down their oratory against each other. The Chancellor and the board, not the Mayor, control how school funds are spent, but that was not very evident months ago when Mr. Giuliani was piling criticism on the Chancellor when he resisted some of the budget cuts.
"While the Mayor can make suggestions, now he seems to be acknowledging that it's the Chancellor's call as to how to do that," Dr. Berne said. "They've reduced the public feuding to make good on a bad situation. In the end, the children benefit from that."

HEADLINE: McCall Says He May Run For Mayor

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday that he was so unhappy with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's leadership that he would consider running against the Mayor in the 1997 election.
Mr. McCall's comments, in a television interview on New York 1, came a day after Mr. Giuliani said that he had asked state officials for permission to stop paying for the section of the Comptroller's office that monitors the finances of New York City. 
 Mr. McCall complained that the Mayor's announcement amounted to bullying, saying that Mr. Giuliani is seeking to remove a fiscal monitor, the deputy state comptroller for New York City, who examines the city's budget and the health of its economy. The office often issues reports critical of the city administration.
Yesterday, Mr. McCall said: "Now, I don't have any plans to run against the Mayor. But if the Mayor continues to demonstrate his inability to deal with all the factions of the city to provide effective leadership to get us out of this fiscal crisis, maybe we would have to change our mind and do what I did with the bully who used to bother me in my neighborhood. One day I walked up to him and popped him in the nose."
There is no indication that Mr. McCall has taken any steps toward organizing a campaign and it is difficult to assess whether he is seriously considering it. But Mr. McCall's name has often been mentioned in political circles as a potential candidate. He is the highest-ranking Democratic elected official in the state and has long been politically active in New York City.
Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, and Mr. McCall have been trading political shots since the Mayor was inaugurated last year. Mr. Giuliani has been harshly critical of Mr. McCall's stewardship, saying that the Comptroller's criticism of the Mayor's performance was politically motivated.
In a news conference yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said, "There is no question that this particular Comptroller has never ever demonstrated even-handedness about looking at the city's budget."
Karen Crowe, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, said, "No one should be surprised that Carl McCall is resorting to political rhetoric." She added that since Mr. McCall became Comptroller, "he has made it clear that he was turning his office into a partisan political operation by firing the professionals in his office. This shouldn't shock anyone."
Mr. McCall said his difficulties with Mr. Giuliani are a result of the Mayor's inability to accept criticism easily.
"I would hope the Mayor could focus on those big issues," he said, "rather than the petty issues of always being confrontational and always assuming that, if people criticize him, they're being political."
In asking the state for permission to stop payments for the Comptroller's office, Mr. Giuliani has maintained that although the Comptroller has a legitimate interest in monitoring the city's finances, the city should not be obligated to subsidize that process. For the current fiscal year, the city is paying $3.2 million of the $5.3 million budget for the section that monitors the city's finances. And the Mayor has insisted that the office's audits are redundant, since several other agencies and offices review New York City's finances.
Terminating payments to the office by the city would require the approval of the State Legislature and the governor.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Against the Mark And Other European Money

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark and other European currencies yesterday after two officials of Germany's central bank hinted that the bank might cut interest rates.
The dollar was little changed against the yen as currency dealers waited for the Clinton Administration to impose trade sanctions on Japan with the breakdown of talks last weekend on automotive trade. 
 Many dealers bought marks last week out of concern over the French franc in advance of Sunday's runoff round of French presidential elections. The mark is increasingly considered a safe currency in times of political uncertainty. But the victory of Jacques Chirac, the conservative Mayor of Paris, seemed to comfort the currency dealers, and the mark has since fallen back.
The drop in the mark's value yesterday was spurred by comments of a German central bank official, Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, who said he saw a chance of further cuts in short-term interest rates. Reimut Jochimsen, another official of the bank, widely called the Bundesbank, said further rate cuts could not be ruled out. Lower interest rates often hurt a currency by making investments in it less attractive.
The German officials' comments aided the mark's drop against the dollar, said Stephen Jury, chief currency dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.
The Bundesbank's policy makers are to next meet on May 18. The bank surprised currency markets on March 31 with a key-rate reduction.
Yesterday, the dollar rose against a basket of 10 major currencies tracked by Finex, a financial-futures exchange. The Finex dollar index last stood at 81.32, up from 80.80 late Monday in New York.
In trading late in the day, the dollar increased to 1.3805 marks from 1.3677 marks on Monday. It edged up to 83.35 yen from 83.27 yen. It also rose to 4.8521 French francs, from 4.8425 on Monday, and to 1.1406 Swiss francs from 1.1278 francs.
The British pound fell against the mark and the dollar. Some dealers said the selloff had come after The Guardian reported that the Bank of England's inflation report, scheduled for release today, would say that a decision by Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke not to raise rates had put the British Government inflation target in jeopardy. London has fixed a target range of 1 percent to 4 percent and wants the inflation rate in the lower half of that band by May 1997 at the latest.
The pound fell yesterday to a record low of 2.1750 marks, before recovering to 2.1907 marks in late New York trading, down from 2.1945 marks on Monday. It fell to $1.5869 from $1.6044.
The dollar drew only limited support from a rally in Treasury bond prices. Bonds jumped and their yields declined, to 6.94 percent on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, amid speculation that American inflation would remain under control.

HEADLINE: Class Notes

BYLINE: By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
On some campuses the question of whether gay groups are entitled to official recognition is a matter of social policy. On others it seems to amount to a struggle for the university's soul.
Two major universities with vital links to the religious establishments from which they sprang -- Yeshiva and Notre Dame -- have wrestled with the issue this semester and come to different conclusions. 
 The University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Ind., has denied recognition to a group called the Gays and Lesbians at Notre Dame and St. Mary's College. The university said the organization's purpose was inconsistent with the mission of Notre Dame and the moral teachings of the Roman Catholic Church. The group is barred from using campus buildings, receiving university money or sponsoring activities.
Insisting that they, too, are committed to religious principles, officials of Yeshiva University have provided a small office, a telephone and an indirect subsidy to the Cardozo Lesbian and Gay Student Alliance at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in Manhattan.
The president of Yeshiva, Dr. Norman Lamm, said: "As a rabbi, I cannot and do not condone homosexual behavior, which is expressly prohibited by Jewish law. But as president of a nondenominational institution that must accommodate people who reflect a wide range of backgrounds and beliefs, it is my duty to assure that the procedures of Yeshiva University conform to the applicable provisions of secular law."
Although Yeshiva is seen as a pillar of Orthodox Judaism, it has declared itself a nonreligious institution since 1967, to take advantage of tax-exempt bonds and other state aid. Therefore, lawyers for Yeshiva contend, the university does not qualify for exemption from a New York City law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
Critics on campus and off have denounced the university for repudiating the basic credo embodied in the words inscribed on its seal, "Torah Umadda," the joining of secular learning (madda) to Jewish law and religious teaching (Torah).
"Torah comes first," said Jeff Stier, a second-year student who is co-editor in chief of The Cardozo Law Forum newspaper. "The second you allow gay clubs at Yeshiva University you are degrading the Torah Umadda symbol.
"It seems like the politically correct environment is having an effect on the university. What should be having an effect is Torah. That's what they stand for. That's what's on the door. That's how they raise money."
Howard L. Hurwitz, chairman of the conservative Family Defense Council in Jamaica, Queens, said it was a legal fiction to describe Yeshiva as a nonreligious institution.
But the university administration has assured the lesbian and gay alliance that it was in no danger of losing recognition or financing. Among the schools at Yeshiva, gay groups have also been organized at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the Wurzweiler School of Social Work and the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology.
Michael John Kay, a 1994 Cardozo graduate who practices law in Manhattan, said the presence of the group had attracted him to the school. In his years there, Mr. Kay said, he was not treated disrespectfully by classmates, many of whom knew of his longstanding relationship with another man, Michael Joseph McGrail Jr.
"At orientation I saw persons of color, persons of Asian descent," he recalled. "The school didn't require you to be Jewish. Therefore it didn't occur to me that I would have to subscribe to their principles. It never made me think for a minute that I would be bound by Torah Umadda.
"It's intellectually dishonest to push any part of the community under the rug. If you take the funding away you don't make them go away. You make them invisible."
The Notre Dame group formed in 1984. The university rejected its request for recognition in 1986 but allowed homosexual students to use a room in the University Counseling Center. The administration canceled that arrangement in January, on the ground that the group had advertised its meetings there.
A month later, the Campus Life Council -- a group of residence-hall rectors, faculty members, administrators and students -- called on the university to recognize the gay group. The resolution passed, 13 to 2.
Notre Dame again denied the request. The vice president for student affairs, Prof. Patricia A. O'Hara, said the university calls for chastity from all unmarried students, whatever their sexual orientation, believing that "a genuine and complete expression of love through sexual union requires a commitment to a total living and sharing together of a man and woman in marriage."
While Notre Dame had a "genuine desire to acknowledge and affirm the presence of the gay and lesbian students in our midst," Professor O'Hara wrote in an open letter, the gay organization had shown a "consistent pattern of philosophical dissent from Church teaching."
A day after her letter was published, the Faculty Senate called on the university to recognize the gay group by a vote of 30 to 3.
Dr. John G. Borkowski, a Senate member and professor of psychology, said the controversy "won't go away until the university stops fearing sexuality and until the university accepts people as individuals where they are in life."
"We just have to love one another," he said, "as the university should love them, as Christ loves us."
John Blandford, a graduate student in economics who is co-chairman of the gay organization, said the fight for recognition, now supported by "every major representative body on campus," would continue.
For its last event of the semester, the group invited Cliff Anchor to the campus. Mr. Anchor has identified himself as the companion of Dr. Thomas A. Dooley 3d, a revered alumnus. Dr. Dooley cared for hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese refugees in the 1950's as a naval officer. He returned to Southeast Asia as a medical missionary and built hospitals in Laos. He and Mr. Anchor met in New York in 1959. The doctor died of cancer in 1961, at the age of 34. A statue in his honor stands on the Notre Dame campus.
Until the publication two years ago of "Conduct Unbecoming: Lesbians and Gays in the U.S. Military" by Randy Shilts, it was little known that Dr. Dooley had been discharged from the Navy because of his homosexuality.
"We thought it was important that we give another face to what lesbians and gay men represent at the university," Mr. Blandford said. "We've always been a central part of this place. Dooley is used all the time as an ideal of what Notre Dame students are about. We wanted to be sure people had a complete picture."
Mr. Anchor, who is 58 and lives in Monte Rio, Calif., talked with 45 students while he was in Indiana last week and then met privately with the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president emeritus of Notre Dame. "I told Father Hesburgh that we both loved the same man, but in different ways," Mr. Anchor said. "I felt that he understood that Dooley was the greater hero for having withstood all this bigotry and turning out as he did."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cliff Anchor, companion of Dr. Thomas A. Dooley 3d, a revered Notre Dame alumnus, at a campus statue honoring the missionary. (Ed Ballotts/The South Bend Tribune)

HEADLINE: Restaurant Owners Plan Fight Against Smoking Restrictions

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York restaurant and tavern owners yesterday began what they called a counteroffensive against New York City's sweeping, four-week-old restrictions on smoking in public places, lining up members to testify at a city hearing and releasing a survey of owners who said their businesses were hurt by the rules.
About 250 restaurant and tavern owners met yesterday at a midtown hotel in hopes of forging a strategy for the law's repeal. The meeting, called by the Manhattan Tavern and Restaurant Owners Association, attracted people from all five boroughs, all of whom appeared to agree with the organizers' contention that the smoking ban is an unfair invasion of business owners' rights, and is costing them business. 
 "The issue here is not whether smoking is good or bad for people," said Joan Borkowski, the owner of Billy's Tavern in Manhattan, who was the chief organizer of the meeting. "This is a matter of economic survival. We are a service industry, and it is our job to serve customers. It is not our job to be policemen."
Mrs. Borkowski said the next step for restaurant and tavern owners who oppose the ban will be to attend a meeting next Tuesday before the New York City Health Commission, to be held in the commission's offices on Worth Street. At her urging, dozens of people at the hotel gathering filled out forms necessary to testify against the law.
Since it took effect on April 11, the law has banned smoking everywhere in New York City restaurants with more than 35 seats except at their bars. It replaced a law, accepted with little protest by the restaurant industry, that required separate smoking and nonsmoking sections for diners.
The smoking ban was approved by a large majority of the City Council, and has been vigorously supported by medical and antismoking groups as a way to cut down on exposure to secondhand smoke. Advocates of the law have argued that the goal of creating a healthier environment outweighs the possibility of a negative impact on some business owners.
One group, the Coalition for a Smoke Free City, did acknowledge before the City Council that some smokers who had patronized large restaurants might shift their loyalties to those with fewer than 35 seats to avoid the ban. For that reason, the group contended that the ban should be applied to all restaurants.
To provide evidence of what they called the harsh impact of the new regulations, the organizers of yesterday's meeting released the results of a poll of 1,000 restaurant owners and managers from all five boroughs, showing that most said their businesses had been disrupted.
The poll, conducted from May 3 to May 6 -- when the law had been in effect only three weeks -- by a firm from Alexandria, Va., was designed to elicit opinions about the impact of the law instead of provide a precise gauge of its long-term impact on business.
The poll showed that most of those who participated were troubled by the ban. About 56 percent of those surveyed said that they had experienced a decrease in sales, compared with 38 percent who said sales had not been affected by the ban.
The poll also found that a large majority of participants -- 81 percent -- agreed with the assertion that the new smoking ban is "government over-regulation of small business."

HEADLINE: Monrovia Journal;
Old Elite From America Loses All in Liberia

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
Like most Liberians, Clarence L. Simpson does not have to look far for signs of his country's collapse into chaos and barbarism.
What sets Mr. Simpson apart is the distance he has fallen since the 1980 coup that brought a young, semiliterate master sergeant named Samuel K. Doe to power, an event that ultimately set Liberia on the path toward seemingly endless civil war. 
 Mr. Simpson, 62, the son of a former Vice President, was a leading member of the country's quasi-colonial settler class, the Americo-Liberians.
Over the span of his public career, starting as a Supreme Court justice at 31, and including jobs as Attorney General, secretary general of the long-ruling True Whig Party and scion of the Masonic Order, the country's most secretive and influential institution, Mr. Simpson was intimately familiar with virtually all of the power and prestige that his country's elite had to offer.
Now, however, he is reduced to the status of a lawyer in a society where law has hardly any meaning. This holds not just for the illiterate indigenous people who were always treated as distinctly second-class citizens by the recently freed black Americans who began settling this country in 1821, but for anyone without a gun.
Although he maintains appearances, working in his neat downtown law offices, surrounded by the shattered remains of a city that once liked to think of itself as the Manhattan of West Africa, Mr. Simpson, who returned from exile in the United States in 1991, literally cannot go home.
Nowadays, no writ can win for him repossession of the large house he once lived in, filled as it is by members of the Armed Forces of Liberia, just one of the country's dozen or so tribal militias. Worse, he says, were the killings of his peers and the brain drain that followed, with the educated survivors and their children lost to exile, mostly in the United States.
"I woke up one morning and most of the people I associated with were dead," said Mr. Simpson, who was lucky to be abroad when Sergeant Doe took power, executing 13 Government ministers by firing squad as one his first acts. "I wondered to myself, should I ever go back to Liberia?"
Having chosen to return to contribute to the building of a peaceful new society, nowadays Mr. Simpson says Liberia needs "someone who can lead without regard to tribal affiliation," preferably, he adds, someone who is not an Americo-Liberian. The old elite, he says, had already come to this conclusion when it was overthrown.
If Mr. Simpson betrays little irony in delivering his prescription, most of his fellow Americo-Liberians here now acknowledge that their behavior was the very study of tribalism -- though, given their origins, a most peculiar form of it.
Most agree that the settlers' mission, put forth in a Declaration of Independence inspired by America's, "to regenerate and enlighten this benighted Continent," somehow never made it beyond the noble word.
"They might have borne the idea of building a new society for all Liberians on their lips, but that was not what they bore in their minds," said G. Henry Andrews, a former newspaper editor. "What they had in mind was transplanting the feudal system they knew in the States to Liberia, with themselves this time in the master's role."
Driven by a resentment that accumulated over generations from deprivation of everything from roads, schools, hospitals, to voting rights and other benefits of citizenship, the first instinct of Sergeant Doe and his young comrades was to kill their perceived oppressors.
The second instinct, however, was to emulate them. Mr. Doe eventually became a Mason, and made the transition from crude speaker to giver of grandiloquent addresses. Finally, he packed the only institution he fully understood, the army, with his fellow tribesmen, the Krahn, and sought to set up his own ethnic hierarchy.
By the time civil war broke out, in 1989, with an invasion by another ethnically based Liberian force from the Ivory Coast that had been victimized by Mr. Doe's Krahn, each of Liberia's major tribes seemingly had a grievance against another. So far, the violence, carried out in village burnings and urban guerrilla assaults, has taken at least 150,000 lives. Mr. Doe was himself captured and killed by members of a militia in September 1990.
"It was no longer an affair of Americo-Liberians," Archbishop Michael K. Francis, said, mentioning the country's other tribes. "If you were Krahn you were killed, if you were Gio you were killed, if you were Mano you were killed. It was just senseless killing, and before we knew it, our streets were just filled with skeletons and the stench of death."
Still, clinging tightly to the world he once knew, of hat shows and gloved church ceremonies for women in yellow dresses and Masonic rites for men in pinstripes, Mr. Simpson refuses to indict his own.
"History shows that people who try to liberalize after sustained repression are generally swept away," he said. "The pity is that so many thought that the only thing that had to be done to get justice was to get rid of the Americo-Liberian."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clarence L. Simpson was once a leading member of Liberia's quasi-colonial settler class, the Americo-Liberians, whose privileges were swept away in a 1980 coup. Now he practices law in a lawless land. Children played in the yard of his house, which he cannot use because it is occupied by militia soldiers. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Crisis Hits Mexico's States, With Some Nearly Broke

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 9

 BODY:
The severe economic crisis that has thrown hundreds of thousands of Mexicans out of work and devastated the balance sheets of many Mexican companies is also taking its toll on the country's 31 states, which have asked the federal Government to help them avoid bankruptcy.
Soaring interest rates, which have hit 100 percent, have made it impossible for states and local communities to repay billions of dollars in loans that were used to finance public works projects. 
 President Ernesto Zedillo announced a $2.9 billion rescue program last Thursday that would allow the states to restructure their loans, lowering interest rates and spreading out the time for repayment to as long as eight years.
In return, states that take part agreed to prepay part of their loans. They also accepted conditions imposed by the federal Government to overhaul their fiscal operations, possibly including the privatization of state-owned enterprises.
The 31 Governors have generally accepted the need for such a program but the four who belong to the opposition accused the federal Government of assuming the same intrusive role that they said the United States did when it offered Mexico $20 billion in loans last March to deal with the economic crisis.
Mexico then was forced to change its fiscal policies radically, and will have to report to the United States and international financial organizations on the progress of its restructuring before it can receive full use of the rescue money.
Carlos Medina Plasciencia, opposition Governor of the central state of Guanajuato, said the program is simply "an aspirin," and another indication of the dependency of the states on the central Government.
President Zedillo said the debt restructuring is part of his ongoing attempt to transform the relationship between the federal Government and the states, which he said has been marked by excessive reliance on the center.
"Centralism is a drag on development that inhibits the deployment of social, economic and political energies of the states," Mr. Zedillo said in announcing the program.
The opposition has so far been skeptical of Mr. Zedillo's efforts. Last month, the opposition Mayor of Ciudad Juarez set up his own toll booths on the international bridge connecting with El Paso to protest what he called the federal Government's unfair distribution of funds.
Mexican states rely on the federal Government for about 80 percent of their funds, which have been cut by an average of 14 percent this year.
The total debt of the 31 states is estimated by officials to be around 23 billion pesos, or almost $4 billion at current exchange rates. Most of the debt was incurred by states and local communities that took out commercial bank loans at variable interest rates -- Mexican states and municipalities do not float government bonds -- to pay their share of public works projects financed primarily by the federal Government.
All 31 states have been hurt by the rising interest rates but some, including Nuevo Leon in northern Mexico and Jalisco in the center, have been pushed to the edge of bankruptcy.
States that take part in the loan restructuring agree to prepay 10, 20 or 30 percent of their commercial loans. They will be allowed to use recent increases in sales taxes to make those payments.
Interest rates will range from 7.5 percent to 9.5 percent, depending on the size of the prepayment. The loans will be restructured in such a way as to protect them from the effects of inflation, which is expected to exceed 50 percent this year.

HEADLINE: Scientists Reject Criteria for Wetlands Bill

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
One day before the House begins debate on a bill that would greatly reduce Federal protection for wetlands, the National Academy of Sciences today published an authoritative report to Congress that repudiates the basic approach taken by the bill.
The bill would require that any protected wetland must match a strict set of defining criteria involving water saturation, soil chemistry, vegetation and similar measurements. But the new report rejects these criteria, which critics say would remove Federal limits on development from most of the nation's remaining wetlands. 
 Though the report does not comment directly on the legislation, a revision of the Clean Water Act, its conclusions are sure to be the most powerful argument raised against the bill. The 268-page report, by a panel of 17 prominent wetlands experts, calls for fundamentally different criteria and makes clear that the approach outlined in the bill has no basis in science.
Wetlands serve important functions like absorbing flood waters, filtering pollutants, and giving fish and waterfowl a place to breed. But protecting such areas is bitterly debated, in part because of the giant economic stakes involved in their development.
Two years ago, Congress asked the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's most eminent scientific organization, to settle the debate. But the legislation before the House was approved in a bipartisan committee vote last month, while the academy's work was undergoing final review. Opponents of the wetlands provision have tried unsuccessfully to have the debate delayed while the report was being finished.
The release of the science academy's report today confronts House members with a complex scientific document only a few days before they are scheduled to vote on a large, complicated bill that makes fundamental changes to one of the nation's most important environmental laws.
The Administration strongly opposes the bill before the House, and the Senate has not begun work on a measure to revise the Clean Water Act, which supposed to be revised and extended every five years.
The House bill would exempt many kinds of wetlands from Federal regulation altogether and would require the Government to compensate property owners when it refuses to allow them to develop their wetlands.
The bill would also attempt to rank wetlands in order of ecological value, protecting only the ones that provide the most important functions like wildlife habitat, flood control and filtering pollution. The scientific report said that scientists do not know enough about wetlands ecology to make such a ranking reliable.
The chairman of the science academy's committee, William M. Lewis Jr., called the bill's requirements "arbitrary" and said in an interview that he personally opposed the legislation because it would lead to a continuing loss of wetlands.
"I would personally be opposed to the reduction of the total acreage of wetlands in the United States by 50 percent or more, which would be the implication of this bill over the next generation," said Dr. Lewis, a water scientist who heads the Department of Environmental Biology at the University of Colorado.
Representative Wayne T. Gilchrest, a Republican from Maryland's Chesapeake Bay area who originally sought the science report, called the bill's language "somewhat ludicrous" in light of the report.
But one of the bill's authors scoffed at the report.
"Anybody in academia who wishes to defend the litany of nonsense that has occurred under the Clean Water Act is either unfamiliar with that nonsense or should have his academic credentials questioned," said Representative Jimmy Hayes, Democrat of Louisiana.
The report says there is wide consensus among scientists about what constitutes a wetland, but the criteria it cites bear no resemblance to the definition in the bill.
For example, in requiring that a protected wetland be saturated by water at the surface for 21 consecutive days in the growing season, the legislation deviates from what the scientists considered an accurate definition: one that would look at periodic saturation for shorter periods, in the root zone of plants rather than at the surface, and not necessarily in the months between the spring thaw and the autumn frost.
And the academy's report said that as a scientific matter, it was generally not necessary to independently confirm that a site has typical wetlands soils and plants as well as actual standing water, the requirement imposed by the bill.
A group of moderate lawmakers led by two Republicans, Sherwood Boehlert of upstate New York and H. James Saxton of coastal New Jersey, said today that they would offer a substitute bill that includes relatively modest changes to wetlands provisions that are favored by the National Governors Association.
They said that they had 20 or 30 Republican supporters and that they were also seeking Democratic support for their substitute, which would also make a number of other major changes to the pending bill, which was drafted by a House committee with substantial bipartisan support and the strong backing of industrial and agricultural lobbyists.
Mr. Boehlert, in a sign of the moderate's frustration, said, "We are Davids up against the more powerful, better organized Philistines."
But Representative Hayes said today that he thought the academy was meddling in politics by issuing the report on the eve of the debate.
"This is not science, it is political science," he said.
In any case, Mr. Hayes said in an interview, the question of whether to protect wetlands was at its heart a political decision to be made by Congress, not one that could be dictated by science. And, even though state wetlands regulators have officially opposed his bill, he said the states were better able to regulate wetlands than the Federal Government.
Judy Meyer, president of the Ecological Society of America, a professional scientific organization, said in a letter to members of Congress that she was concerned that the report would not receive adequate consideration before the votes this week.
"Clearly, science cannot provide all the answers in developing policy," she wrote. "But science can and must play a part in considerations of a bill that will affect the future of one of our nation's most vital resources, one that affects every American citizen."
The report said that even though wetlands regulations have been repeatedly changed during a prolonged political tug-of-war since the 1980's, "the Federal regulatory system for protection of wetlands is scientifically sound and effective in most respects."
Carol M. Browner, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said, "I think the report points out that wetlands protection, and the definition of wetlands, has to be based on sound science, not on political expediency as it is in the bill."

HEADLINE: Ford Sees 1995 Auto Sales Falling Below Level of Last Year

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 9

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that after lowering its forecasts for the second time in about a month, it expected 1995 auto sales to fall below the levels of last year.
The company said it cut it projections again because of surprisingly weak sales in April. But it said it expected its own sales to continue to outperform those of the industry over all. 
 Ford now estimates that sales of all cars and light and heavy trucks will total 15.1 million this year, down from 15.4 million last year. Its previous projection was for sales to total 15.5 million. Typically, heavy trucks account for about 300,000 sales.
The Chrysler Corporation is also weighing a cut in its forecast, which is now 15.5 million, including heavy trucks. The Chrysler economists are considering reducing that estimate to a range of 15.2 million to 15.5 million. As recently as January Chrysler was projecting sales of 16.2 million this year.
The auto makers have said that higher interest rates have restrained buyers. But because rising rebates and other incentives to customers have failed to jump start sales this spring, some Wall Street analysts have concluded that higher prices for new cars have convinced potential customers to postpone purchases or buy used cars.
Joel Pitcoff, market analysis manager for Ford, said Ford now expected sales in the second quarter to fall below those in the first quarter, but for the market to improve from then on. Ford still expects 1996 to be stronger than 1995, he said.
"There's nothing fundamentally that's eroding," Mr. Pitcoff said. However, sales in April were so weak that the industry could not hope to meet the old forecast of Ford. "Even if it's an anomaly, you need too steep a climb over the rest of the year to reach 15.5," he said, referring to millions of sales.
The General Motors Corporation projects sales of 15.6 million this year. G.M. has not said if it will change its forecast.
Mr. Pitcoff said the Ford production estimates for April were based on the lower forecasts, and as a result would not be reduced. "This does not augur any further production cuts," he said.
Ford still expects record truck sales of 6.6 million this year. The cut in its sales projection came entirely from anticipated car sales.
Ford announced its reduced projections for auto sales after the stock market closed today. Earlier, shares of Ford closed at $27.125, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of G.M. rose 25 cents, to $43.75, while shares of Chrysler fell 50 cents, to $41.875.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises Only 6.91, Indicating the Market May Stall

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed and little changed yesterday, a circumstance that would normally go unremarked in the fifth month of a substantial rally in stocks.
But with the Dow Jones industrial average up a steep 15 percent for the year, these are not normal times, stock traders say. Market professionals are, if not worried about, then extremely attentive to the possibility of the market stalling. 
 That is because the market ought to have risen sharply yesterday. The dollar's value rose overseas, bond yields fell below 7 percent and the price of gold fell -- all factors that in the past would have sent stock prices soaring.
But the Dow rose only 6.91 points, to 4,390.78, still the 26th closing high this year, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.40 point, to 523.56. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.12 point, to 848.17.
Volume on the New York Exchange was unusually heavy, with 365.4 million shares changing hands, up from this year's daily average of 333 million shares.
"Every one is looking for that tea leaf that says the stock market is going to correct," said Todd Clark, managing director for equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw. "It's a little early to say that somehow today is an indication of equities beginning to stall."
But yesterday's trading pattern, with its sharp rise in the morning and feeble performance in the afternoon, if it persists for the rest of the week, could be worrisome for stocks, Mr. Clark said.
For one thing, the Dow Jones industrial average surged past 4,400 twice before 11 A.M., but then fell back from 4,403.58. Last Thursday, the Dow sprinted past 4,400 as well, only to fall back from 4,410.15.
Technical stock analysts call these price thresholds "resistance levels," Wall Street argot meaning the market may not get there from here.
Resistance can become worrisome when so many other signs seem to be positive. Long-term interest rates in the bond market continued to fall. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.94 percent from 7.03 percent, the lowest level since March 1994.
And one of the most widely watched measures of market anxiety -- the price of gold -- fell once again. The contract for June delivery of gold fell $6.30, to $384.60 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange of New York.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.06 point, to 281.74, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,334 to 994. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.70 point, to 483.64.
Among advancing stocks was United Insurance Companies, which rose 7, to 52, on the strength of a 26 percent rise in quarterly earnings reported on Monday as well as a planned 4-for-1 stock split. But in after-hours trading, its stock price fell.
The Picturetel Corporation, a telecommunications equipment maker, rose 3, to 47 1/8, after it announced that it would work with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, one of the world's largest phone carriers, to develop video-conferencing systems for Japan.
Among declining stocks was Unilever, the British-Dutch conglomerate, which fell 7 7/8, to 126 1/2, after it announced that first-quarter profits fell 7 percent. Whirlpool, the big appliance manufacturer, fell 4, to 50, after reports that Goldman, Sachs sold a large block of Whirlpool shares. Following the close of trading, Whirlpool said its second-quarter profit may not match its earnings of a year earlier.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 rose, led by United Technologies, which rose 1 7/8, to 74 7/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S,& P. 500, 216 fell, led by Exxon, which fell 1/2, to 69 7/8.
The most active stock, at 8.6 million shares, was Intel, which fell 3/8, to 111 1/4.
